reviews.review: incredible collection!. I wandered awestruck @ this collection, found it most fascinating & interesting, mindblowing the age of so many pieces - we live in such a young country here in Australia!

Eclectic Wonderful Collection. This fine Museum has a great collection of Mid- east textiles and ceramics. China and Japan are represented too. There is both a very nice European section and Allows glass.
Be aware that tourist books are WRONG. The museum is open Mondays and closed Tuesday.

One of the most important art collection in the world. Clouste Gulbenkian museum is one of the best in POrtugal and in the world. With a collection of art and antiques gatered over decades by Mr Gulbenkian, is exposed in Lisbon and is a "must visit" place of Lisbon.. and of course walk on the garden is sublime....

Loved the old stuff, but not a fan of the modern art. As a fan of traditional art, I really loved the tastes of Gulbenkian's collections. The modern material (not part of Gulbenkian's collection) was typical modern art with no real feeling behind it. I realize that this is subjective and my viewpoint, but that's my opinion. I recommend that anyone visit this unique collection, but the kids might get a bit bored early on as our daughter and friends did.

Small, but worth a visit. Rick Steves guidebook sent us to this little museum. The outside is utilitarian. It had an interesting assortment of treasures, but I feel there is something for everyone in it. I particularly liked some Japanese boxes. The cafe was a little odd, but we were able to find something to eat for lunch despite being rather late. It's not large or fancy, but I was grateful it was there.

Beautiful park setting for stunning collections.. We very much enjoyed our afternoon at the Gulbenkian, there are two separate museum buildings set in the most wonderfully tranquil and beautifully designed gardens.The collections have something for all tastes; from ancient art right up to the present day, the modern art building was showing three very interesting temporary exhibitions. The quality of the founder's collection is of the highest order, the painting collections and Islamic and Oriental decorative art such as carpets and ceramics were fantastic. A wonderful collection with some real masterpieces.

Outstanding museum. We visited on Sunday afternoon when there is free entry. The building is beautifully designed for the exhibits. The ceramics and fabrics/wall hangings are stunning. The paintings are a good selection of classic art and there are some good sculptures too. The park around the museum is also very pleasant.

Stunning. The Gulbenkian is set in beautiful gardens and is remarkably well set out, it's airy and cool. Contemporary art leaves me a little cool but the historical collection is superb without swamping the senses. The examples are exquisite and very well displayed in a truly beautiful building.
Fantastic art museum. Oil money, great taste, generosity. Great private art collection ranging from 5000 years ago to today, donated to Lisbon. Gorgeously displayed. Art lovers rejoice!

Annoying. After checking carefully on the website we were annoyed to find its NOT free on a Sunday as advertised. The charge is E12.50. There were other angry visitirs there so I guess they will change the info on the website ?

Holiday in Portugal. We came across this place by accident whilst out walking.
Great gardens, full of lots of water fowl on the ponds, & easy walking around.
The museum was good.

Liked it, but have been to more impressive museums.. Being a local, I heard quite a lot of Gulbenkian and therefore wanted to visit it. In the end I liked it but I must say that it did not deeply impress me. Maybe I knew too little about arts and the painters though. What I liked most actually, was the wonderful garden surrounding the museum.

Ancient artefacts stupendous. A couple of Rembrandts and a superb Turner were memorable, but Mr G went for Guardi rather than Canaletto in his Venice views but little else struck me among the paintings. The most stunning things were from the pre-Egyptian period, a couple of small portrait busts that might have been made yesterday by one of the best portrait sculptors ever. Also lots of excellent ceramics, inc a pristine Greek Krater, nearly 3ft high. Breathtaking.
Hard to navigate round. Staff not helpful and surly. Building not welcoming for those with a walking disability. The whole place seemed jaded, worn and dark. Huge queue for refreshments.

Calouste Gulbenkian Museum - a must for visitors. Calouste Gulbenkian Museum - a must for visitors! This person, actually, has done so much for Portugal - it's hard to even imagine. The Museum contains items from different cultures and countries. Come and see!

Beautiful garden lanscaping & an escape to the world of art in the city. Love this place, whether it's to see a live music performance, read a book on the green grass or see the latest art exhibition; all my trips to Lisbon imply a visit at least once to FCG!

Small but beautiful collection. This museum is a beutiful collection of pieces over 5000 years of human history. Some great Persian and Ottoman Empire art, rugs, ceramics. Not the Prada or the Louvre but well worth the visit

Don't go in the wrong way!. We were shocked when we walked into the entrance via the modern art section. It's not really our thing and were about to give up! Persist and head over the gardens to find a vast array of fantastic 15,16,17th century works of art, and some great examples of ancient artefacts from Ancient Rome and Chinese empires.

A small collection, but worthwhile. This museum is an impressive personal collection and is in a lovely setting also. Give yourself time to walk around the park, and don't miss the excellent collection of rugs and textiles.

Excellent museum. Don't miss this place.. The best museum I have visited in Lisboa . Beautiful exhibits and all very well organised and preserved . Beautiful garden. Highly recommend a day visit . One of the must see in Lisbon.

Leisurely viewing. All the exhibits have adequate space and can be viewed in an unhurried calm atmosphere. We loved the extensive Lalique collection, the beautiful Rodin Sculptures, the paintings, the massive French silver table pieces, the furniture, etc etc. Only slight criticism is that unlike the Frick and Wallace collections which to some extent still have a "domestic" setting, the display here is definitely in a gallery.It was helpful therefore to see the displays of personal items in the display cases in the entrance hall which should not be missed.

Top destination in Lisbon for art lovers. The Gulbenkian Museum is a unique sort of art collection that began as the private collection of a wealthy Armenian who was raised in Great Britain, then moved to Portugal in his later years. It is very eclectic, including many painting, antiquities, and decorative art item. But the beauty of the collection for visitors is that there is not too much - something for every taste, but not overwhelming to sample. The collection includes what are indisputably great masterpieces by painters such as Rubens and Rembrandt that are rarely reproduced and a much greater variety of artistic treasures than could ever be described briefly. For lovers of modern art, there are special building devoted to Portuguese art that were not a part of the original collection. The grounds are absolutely enchanting to visit, full of beautiful foliage arranged within quaint walkways and ponds. There are animals all over. In short, there's something for everyone, and it induces quite a feeling of peace and contentment to visit. Unless you're utterly indifferent to the restorative effects of art and nature, this is a must-see attraction in Lisbon.

See the modern and the historical all in one place. This collection is amazing, so many works in one lovely setting. It offers every type of art lover something special. Fab grounds to walk and wander in too.
Suprising collection. There is a lot to see, and it was quite surprising to find such an extensive art collection which holds pieces from all over the world and ages.

recent visit. This is one of the top attractions in Lisbon and definitely worth a visit. You nead to spend at least a couple of hours here. It is different to other museums as it is the collection of one man and therefore the exibits are a reflection of his tastes and tend to be from the Middle East.

Not modern art at all. Just check out the free gardens instead!!. This 'modern art' museum was such a waste of time and money. 20 euros to see an exhibition of how Portugal has developed it's cultural heritage (with no useful narrative to accompany the pieces) and a rag-tag collection of old and newer pieces assembled to suggest links across time and art-form. This exhibition was so tenuously curated as to be laughable and instead felt like you had wandered into a second hand shop or someone's private collection. When we discussed our displeasure with the desk clerk, he explained that as we had seen the exhibits, we could not then receive a refund...he also said to us "why did you even come here if you don't like it?" honestly, the mind boggles! Please take note of the likes of the great Astrup Fearnley museum in Oslo for how modern art museums should be.The only saving grace was the beautifully landscaped gardens that the museum building sat in. The park is free to explore, lush and interesting...it was the only part i would recommend.

A truly awe-inspiring collection of art. My husband and I have travelled extensively. This is one of the most amazing private (and eclectic) collections of art we have ever seen. The art of many different types, including paintings, sculpture, ancient artifacts, jewelry, Oriental rugs, and more was beautiful to observe and informative about many different cultures and time periods. Don't miss this museum if you are visiting Lisbon, even for just 1 or 2 days.
Beautiful museum. A must ! We lost our way , because we had a different entrance but finally we arrived on the terrace and so we come in! Beautiful european art and the Lalique room was Wunderfull

Beautiful museum in lovely surroudings. This museum is wonderful, with stunning exhibits, all set out tastefully and spaciously. It is one of the nicest museums we have visited, and there is an excellent cafe and lovely grounds to wander round.

A wonderful collection. The Museum is in Two parts, the private collection and the Modern Collection and an exhibition (which I assume changes). Some wonderful objects,painting, carpets and tapestries. The Gardens are beautiful. €10, museums - garden free

A Very Good Little Bit of Everything. This museum is relatively small, but the pieces inside are well worth a visit. It's like a condensed version of the Louvre, which makes it very approachable. You can get up close to enjoy a few wonderful examples from each epoch of art instead of being overwhelmed by the vast halls and crowds of a bigger museum.

You can skip this one if you have a tight schedule.. We entered when it was free of charge on Sunday but turned out it was free after 1 pm so we waited. Good thing we did not pay for it because this is a rather subjective taste of arts. A very rich man called Gulbenkian collected these art pieces, totally based on his own taste, a very random collection of this and that. We could not get the fuss about it. It has a nice garden, and we listened to a nice orchestra and saw some ducklings and they were all better than what we saw in the collection. So unimpressive and totally not the must-see in Lisbon, unlike how it is reflected here in TA.

Mixed bag. There are some really great, thorough art works collected here but as an art lover I got a little overwhelmed by the "variety". Sometimes I thought Gulbenkian collected everything and anything. His Middle East and medieval collections are outstanding; his classical paintings are not bad but nothing outstanding but his modern room had a feeling of too much eclectic work. Some will love this; I did not.Still, what is here is worth seeing but doesn't rank with the big museums.

Remarkable, eclectic art collection. The Museum is set in very attractive grounds, with winding paths and water features. The collection is very extensive and ranges from Egyptian, Middle Eastern, Greek and Roman artefacts to European Masters and an interesting collection of Lalique jewelery.

What a great collection of artifact over the centuries . Easy to get to museum by metro and you get a bonus modern art museum too. The structure is half the benefit of this museum, and the artifacts will blow you away.. From 500 BC to modern day sculptures, money, paintings. Regular price 10 euros, seniors 5 euros. You can easily spend 3 hours here and be satisfied .

Stunning collection. In this well designed museum and associated garden an amazing personal collection of art from all over the world astounds in its quality. The Islamic section is breathtaking and a great Rembrandt were the highlights. One section of temporary displays is free. A combined ticket will give you access to the equally good modern art museum.

Wonderful Collection when we found it!. We had some difficulty finding the museum as there are very few signposts to museums or other tourist attractions in Lisbon and if you are an independent traveller this can be very frustrating. However the collection itself was stunning. Free for seniors it is beautifully displayed and each room takes one.s breathe away. We particularly loved the ceramic collection and the Chinese room. The museum is quite manageable for an hour and a half's visit.
Wonderful. We only had two hours and it took all of it to go around. The exhibits are varied from antique furniture, paintings and porcelain.The rooms are well air conditioned and spacious..

Amazing place. Do not miss this museum 15min by bus from centre of town. Most beautiful displays, only 10 euros entrance (5 to OAP) gardens are free well worth seeing a beautiful experience all round not to be missed also excellent food in 3 cafes inexpensive too
a wet day treat. Admission a little steep except on sundays.Excellent free annexe,good cafe.not vital to see but worth the trip.

An amazing collection, a real gem. It is not a huge museum, but it houses a huge range of eclectic acquisitions, beautifully exhibited. It is mostly chronological, but also geographical, and really inconceivable how these items can be accumulated by one man... I have a real soft spot for the Turners, but the Lalique at the end is the big fat cherry on that beautiful cake.
Brilliant . Brilliant museum & gallery. Very spacious, bright and airy. If you don't fancy the museum, it's set in beautiful gardens.
Don't miss this museum. we were told by friends of this surprising collection..not disappointed! Easily accessible by taxi and Metro.

He may have been a voracious collector but.... A generous act by Mr 5% but I'm not convinced about his eye for art. However the Lalique is worth the entry price and the gardens and cafe are excellent.
It probably rates as a must visit but try to time for poor weather!

GREAT MUSEUM. Best museum in Lisbon....something for everyone! Collection was assembled over several years by Mr. Gulbenkian and his wife and includes nice examples from Egyptian to Contemporary art. Very well done!

A WONDERFUL DIVERSE MUSEUM. Our mail reason for going was to see the Lalique collection. It is outstanding. I only wish there was more. The art, the furniture and the sculpture were first rate. The collection is well lit. Loved the garden. The surprise - the building was so contemporary. A great s top in Lisbon. I would say, "Don't miss it!"
5*. Amazing museum and galley. Try the cafe and the garden outside, you will love it! The art collection is amazing, from Ancient Egypt to modern art

Stunning range of ceramics, carpets, and art. We visited the Founder's Collection which is housed in its own building. All the exhibits were collected by Gulbenkian himself for his own pleasure. He describes considering his works art (feminine in the Portuguese language) as his 'daughters'.The collection starts with Egyptian ceramics, funerary masks and statuettes,Roman and Greek glassware and bronzes dating back several centuries BC. It then moves on to Persian tapestries and carpets, woven with silk thread on velvet, predominantly from the 12th century AD. Turkish ceramics and panels of tiles in a variety of designs and colour leave you marvelling at Gulbenkian's taste and wealth. Eighteenth-century Chinese ornamental jars, plates and figurines - many in rose pink, as well as the more well-known blues and greens - complete this part of the exhibition.Gulbenkian's collection of art forms the second part of the collection - the 16th and 17th century Dutch schools. We left the eighteenth-century works - both paintings and a collection of clocks for our next visit.

A MUST. It is not exactly a museum. It is a private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian which give away free in the government. There are exhibits from different countries and centuries.There are paintings, carpets, articles from China and so on. There is also some mondern paintings..

Gulbenkian Surpise. This museum was on our own and yet great value. A short walk from our Corinthian Hotel (always use the crosswalks and follow the green person light for walking). The admission tickets are purchased at the main museum, yet, upon approach, it is easy to enter the modern art component. Your ticket gets you access to both, but you must enter via the main museum.
Great. A fantastic collection of a bit of everything from Japanese laquerware to super Lalique to gorgeous Iznik tiles

A treasurer trove of art and design. This wonderful museum set in a delightful park houses Calouste Gulbunkian's fabulous personal art collection with pictures, including Rembrandt's, Constables,ceramics, furniture, both antique and more modern. There is a modern section which is more focused on particular artists. We spent a whole day there with a delightful and reasonable cafeteria for lunch in the middle.

More than worthwhile!. The Gulbenkian experience is something every art lover owes him or herself. The quality of the holdings, their presentation in the museums, the history of the founder's collection are all worth a morning or afternoon of one's time. Schedule at least two hours - and then stay for lunch in the garden cafe. I was so impressed, I went back a second time!

Very worthwhile three hours spent here. We are not museum regulars but this was something special. A beautiful collection of treasures from yesteryear. Oh to have the resources and time to put this together. The silver and the Persian carpets were the highlight for me and my wife was enthralled by the landscapes. Very worthwhile.

Very interesting museum. This museum is well worth the visit. It is the private collection of the very wealthy Calouste Gulbenkian. On his death he gave it to the govt of Portugal. There is everything from ancient Egyptian to 1600's Europe. Housed in a beautiful building, it takes about 1.5 hours to tour. Well worth the visit.

a must when in Lisbon. A Visit to the Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is a must when in Lisbon. The range of artworks in display is absolutely world class and extends from antiquites to french impressionists to art deco. Gubenkian died in 1955 and each item in the purpose built museum up to his death was personally sought out by him. The garden restaurant provides excellent meals and its worth having a break there.

A beautiful and assorted art collection.. Before i visit the museum (Founder´s collection) i read some reviews here and they were quite harsh and unfair. Some of them are not about this collection but from the "Centro de Arte Moderna Azeredo Perdigão" located in the far end of the garden. This part of the Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian has temporary modern art exhibitions, some of them of dubious taste, others very good (its a matter of luck on the time you visit).About the Founder´s Collection, the visitor must keep in mind that it reflects the personal taste of Mr. Calouste Gulbenkian (1869-1955).The collection spans from ancient egyptian artifacts to roman and greek coins and pottery, from chinese porcelain and japanese jade sculptures to persian tiles and rugs, decorative arts from silver wear to furniture, and painting from classics (some Rembrandt and Rubens) to early and late 1800´s (William Turner, Monet, Manet, Degas, Renoir and many others).The last room of the exhibition houses the worlds largest collection of René Lalique jewels and drawings. This one´s definitely worth a visit.Take some time to walk in the wonderful gardens.An issue the management should take in consideration is the staff training, they are quite unfriendly and unhelpful.
Wonderful museum. Very nice collection of art from various eras, east and west. Beautiful relaxing gardens. Don't miss the resturant, good quality food with outdoors sitting area.

Two buildings, much history, abundance of art through the ages. What a find even though it was hiding in plain sight. It's one of the better known art museums in Lisbon but has a sensibility all its own. One building houses old masters, ancient Egyptian, Greek and Roman artifacts all well lit and presented, much of the pieces are in stunningly pristine condition. The second building houses exhibits and modern artwork and is equally respectfully presented. But the real shock was the garden that lies between the two buildings. It's quiet, has a stream, many varieties of birds and fauna and is an oasis in the midst of a museum. Make sure you get there because it's a Lisbon must-see.

What a gem!. Do not miss this museum if you go to Lisbon! Impressive art and furniture collection. If you go on the hop on/ off bus, ask the driver where to get off, as they changed that stop and did not change the bus route map. You have to get off a few blocks before.

Wonderful eclectic collection. If you visit Lisbon and like culture this is a must. The collection is well organised and presented and you need a couple of hours to appreciate it all. The €10 entry fee is well worth it.

True Art. Take time to appreciate the Calouste Gulbenkian personal art collection and the Foundation Garden.
I just do not give the maximum grade because they push us to visit a modern art exhibition that has nothing to do with Calouste Gulbenkian aesthetic ideal.

Breathtaking and Varied Collection. The 'Founders Collection' at the Gulbenkian is a gift to the people of Lisbon but it is a gift on an international scale. From ancient Roman and Greek coins and art to Monet, John Singer Sergant and Marie Cassatt to a vast furniture and rug collections, this is a must-see for anyone into many art periods. My favorite was the stunning Lalique jewelry from the Belle Epoque. There are pieces housed there that rival the museums of Paris! Check the website b/c some days are free before a certain hour of the day. There is separate admission for the ancient collection and the modern collection. You may also stroll the grounds and gardens gratis. A very nice space and relaxing atmosphere.
Well worth a visit. Beautiful gardens and interesting buildings. The permanent collections are fabulous and diverse. The interior spaces and lighting very good.

A great find. It is worth seeking out this museum. There are no signs from the nearest metro station and a map does not help very much. We (and some others also searching for it) found the entrance by accident. The tiles and glassware are amazing. Rembandts, Monets, Manets among other great art works..Worth giving this some time. here are also lovely gardens; unfortunately we did not have time to explore as it took so long to find the museum.
Insightful and interesting !. The Museum is based around a private collection and is an interesting mix of old and new art and artefacts.
Very well presented exhibits. This museum is well worth making the effort and needs a couple of hours to do justice. Very well arranged in chronological order and some excellent paintings.
Simply wonderful. It is an wonderful colection of one man with great taste in arts. The verity is great but all is a joy to the eyes. Do not miss and take the full tour.
To visit but not if you are in a short stay. Was not impressed by the collection... The Museum and the size of the Museum is interesting, the park as well
Good museum. Good sized museum plus sister modern art museum included in ticket. Free Sunday after 2pm. The gardens surrounding the museums were the best part

Impressive collection of art from all around the world. The art collection is amazing from all around the world. From China to Europe. Impressive how this person collected all these, succeeded to by all there and bring them to Portugal. A must see !!!!!

must see. the Gulbenkian has a year round gallery and a visiting /changing modern one.there was a female poetry /art exhibitian when i was visiting and as typical all over Lisbon although you are a captive audience the prices in their restaurant are very competitive.

The best art collection in Portugal. It´s really worth the visit. Not only it features the great names like Renoir, Monet, Manet, etc, it also has a really beautiful garden where you can sit and relax, have a pic-nic or simply walk around.

One word - WOW!. We would have skip this place but our tour guide advised us to come.What a collection. What a story behind it. You should definitely visit this place.Besides the interior, park around the building is amazing. A lot of people sitting on the grass, on the benches. Wonderful trees and gardens.So peaceful, so wonderful. One of my favorite places.Entrance is free on Sundays after 2 pm.
A cultural visit of a world reknown art collection. Art collection; permanent and temporary exhibitions;music programs, including alive transmission of Operas; workshops, etc.

A Wonderful Place to Spend the Day. The Gulbenkian is a fantastic museum. The buildings are modern and not that attractive but once you are inside and you see how they used the advantages of modern materials to enhance the view of the collection they really shine. It is easily one of the best laid our collections that I have even seen and the space and the pieces work together seamlessly. The museum is also set in a park that is very nice to walk around in. All in a very good place to spend half a day.
Inside and outside worth a visit. Take your time for a visit inside and a walk around in the garden. Don't miss the modern art. enjoy coffee in the small bar in the parc. Perfect day

Incredible Museum. The Gulbenkian covers art from 5000BC to today. It provides a history of art tour and is trule a museum and art gallery combined. All features are beautifully presented and the gardens are a delight to walk through for tranquility and rest. It is a total environment and is most sensate.
Callisto Gulbenkian. Wonderful museum that is very "doable". Both ancient art and contemporary art in two smallish museums

If he'd had a smaller space to fill the collection might have been better. The building is gorgeous. It's 1960's architecture at it's best: Clean modern lines, low and wide, dramatic proportions; textures of concrete and wood contrasting with lush planted gardens. The collection however says more about the wealth of its creator than his taste. There's loads of everything, covering a huge range of eras, from ancient Egypt to Modern Portugal. The sheer quantity of opulent gilded furniture and carpets makes some sections look like an upmarket furniture store. Yes there are Rembrandts, Renoirs, Monets, Manets and others, just not very good ones. I did enjoy the cool of the gardens and the subtle artworks there. And tucked in a corner of the Modern Gallery was a genuinely moving photographic piece featuring prisoners in Lisbon Jail in 1915, who were forced to wear hoods whenever in communal spaces. Less might have been more.

A not to miss museum. Gulbenkian museums are in the best ones in Lisbon, Located in the center of the city. You can get there by metro, easily. But for me the more beautiful is the whole thing, the buildings, the gardens and also the cafeterias.

Fabulous collections, but don't miss the gardens. Fabulous collections, but don't miss the gardens. We entered by a gate which wasn't the main entrance and we strolled through the labyrinth of gardens, which we would have missed if we had entered through the main entrance. Collections are spectacular and we could have spent days wandering around, but unfortunately only had one afternoon.

Top museum with amazing back story. Essentially a private collection of one person and accordingly different to other elite collections. Nice surroundings and focussed on Asia Minor and France with a fantastic grew gold coin collection.
Unbelievable collection. Extensive collection from 2600 BC to present day. Surrounded by gardens and extensive landscaping. Carpets, tiles, ceramics furniture paintings statues etc.

Amazing. This is an incredible collection. I would have given it a 5 but the signage getting from the Modern Collection to the Founders Collection were abysmal and in the heat, even worse. Overall the Modern Collection was a disappointment because over half the museum was being staged and thus nothing to see. The Founders Collection is interestingly staged and all of the buildings are works of art themselves. A bit out of your way but well worth the effort.

It's worth the visit. Quite interesting! It kinda reminds London's Victoria and Albert Museum. There are items from various historical periods and Countries. Most interesting Rubens, Monet and other famous painters' works along with an exquisite exhibition of modern portuguese artists.
Wonderful Private Collection!!!. Went there and I was so pleasantly surprised to see this place. A collection that belongs to an Portuguese-Armenian, a must go place!!!

Not to be missed, if you are an art lover.. This collection is absolutely stunning. Put together over a life time by one collector, it would put many national collections to shame. Gulbenkian said that only the best would do, and that is what you see - from Egyptian, Greek and Roman treasures through exquisite oriental carpets, tiles, fabrics and ancient books; then amazing medieval and Renaissance art from various parts of Europe, furniture from Marie Antoinette's chambers, a brilliant Rembrandt, Gainsborough, Reynolds, Turner and so on .....The collection is beautifully displayed and when you need a rest there is a great cafeteria (indoor and outdoor tables) and a gelato bar. There is a full canteen style restaurant in the building next door, housing a modern collection, and a lovely garden to stroll in while reflecting on all the wonders you have seen!

Staggering variety and quality of fine and decorative art from ancient times to the 20th century and from East and West.. This museum houses the former private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian, an extremely wealthy British businessman, oil magnate and philanthropist of Armenian heritage, who collected over 6,000 works of art during the course of his life and journeys across the globe. There are said to be approximately 1,000 items on permanent display with the collection comprising Greek, Egyptian, Roman, Islamic, Asian and European art works and relics that include paintings, sculptures, mummy masks, Greek coins and medallions, Roman glass and ceramics, Persian carpets, ornate tiles, mosque lamps, Qing porcelain, beautifully illustrated bibles and manuscipts, furniture, including exquisite desks, chairs and lounges plus magnificent clocks, silver work and jewellery.There are paintings or sculptures from the likes of Ghirlandaio, Rubens (Flight into Egypt), Rembrandt (Portrait of an Old Man), Rodin (Eternal Spring), Renoir, Van Dyck, Degas, Manet, Monet, Gainsborough and Turner plus many more. Rather than many paintings or sculptures from one artist there appears to be one from some of the best. It is reported that Gulbenkian purchased many artworks from the Hermitage during a period when they had a sale.We spent a pleasurable 3 hours exploring this museum on a Sunday afternoon being wowed at just about every turn. The artwork is extremely well laid out.There is a cafe in the museum but unfortunately the meals that we had were pretty ordinary.
A great day out!. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is located in a beautiful garden, with amazing natural settings. The museum architecture is beautiful, and the exhibitions are worth going.
Eclectic collection. There is something for everyone from antiquities to modern, fine art, textiles, rugs, glass, ceramics. Easy to visit in a half day without rushing.
Excellent collection, a must see!. Allow at least 2 hours - there's so much to see and enjoy, including the gardens and the restaurant.

Interesting collection. Very interesting collection, I wish there were interactive stuff for children. I loved the art, but the kiddos were bored. It would be great, if they offered some activities for all ages.

Underwhelming. This museum just doesn't rate highly with me because of lack of services. They once had an audio guide, no longer and no maps. No self storage lockers, so all your valuables go with someone to somewhere behind a big wall. Poor signage, too small requiring visitors to get too close to the art work. They did offer in a few rooms some informative cards. The day I was there, photos of any kind were not allowed.The collection is more of interest to those who want to see a little of everything. I did enjoy the Lalique room, but overall I was pretty underwhelmed. And the lovely garden outside is lovely, but be very careful there are so many uneven pieces of sidewalk, its a landmine if you aren't watching each step, let alone for wheelchairs and people with mobility problems,

Very interesting concept. A collector's choice resulting in a very special museum. Because the exhibits were "hand picked" by the collector (and also payed for) they are in their best shape (not like in a public museum). It the first time I've seen a Lalique collection of jewels. Highly recommend.

A world level quality museum. Gulbenkian Foundation's Museum can be compared with the bests of the world. Take some minutes to search on the Internet what you can see there and you will feel forced to visit such impressive museum. The building and its gardens deserves also a visit. This visit is not for tourists looking for the most popular sights but for art oriented people.

Fabulous museum. The Gulbenkian museum is set in a lovely garden with an amphitheatre, allow time for looking around. There is a charge to enter the main museum. There are lockers and a cloakroom (free) for your valuables and you are allow to take photographs without flash in the main museum but not in the special/temporary exhibition room. There are plenty of exhibits ranging from statues, Egyptian artefacts, tapestries, paintings, carvings and period furniture. There is a café, but it was being used for a private event when we were there and we had to use the coffee machine near the toilets (once we were shown how to use it, as we did not want sugar!)Allow around two hours or longer for a visit.

Interesting collection. I would recommend visiting this museum. It is very well organised, well looked after. The collection is interesting to watch. I especially liked various items from Iznik in Turkey. The museum is surrounded by a nice park and also has an art library in it. There are also various exhibitions taking place there.
Extensive art collection.. Art, furniture, rugs, coins, Lalique, Monet, Rembrandt, ancient Egyptian, ancient Greece, and on and on. Great rainy day activity. Check for free days.

Enjoyed the Asian Exhibit the most!. Since we went on a sunday, it was free! They have services to store your backpack. The museum is huge itself with tons to keep you occupied. The asian exhibit was my favourite as I learned about the different colour families.

nice and cool on a hot day. On a hot day in August, the 10 euro entry (2 adults 2 students) was justified by the cool aircon alone. Some good artworks, some pretentious video productions, and a nice little park outside (free access) with turtles swimming in the pond. An okay venue, with clean toilets!

Beautiful pieces, peaceful park, delicious cafeteria. Near the Cortes de ingles. Euro 10 covers both the founders collection and the modern section. The pieces are not necessarily artistically or historically significant (per the museums own inform cards) but the items are striking. Not being an art buff, I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the museum and walking through the garden. If you get a chance visit the cafeteria - line of locals queuing for the healthy and well priced meals (4 items for 6.50, beer for 1.25). Deserts were amazing. Also read up about Calouste G., what a fascinating life!

What a collection!!!. This was a real treasure. I love colour and pattern and the Iznik collection here is stunning. Really interesting pieces in display, ranging from Chinese vases to impressionist paintings and Lalique jewellery. The exhibition space is great, the building was designed to house the collection and it really works. Don't forget to wander round the magical gardens too!!

The Perfect Museum to Visit. Gulbenkian's eye for beauty and understanding of art and artists are displayed in a highly enjoyable and digestible way. The explanatory sheets available in each gallery give you an understanding of why he chose each piece and their relationship to each other and himself. Particularly Lalique's jewelry, right at the end, should not be missed. Sit in the outdoor cafe space for a mid point rest and conversation. The range covered is immense, from glass to sculpture to paintings to tapestries etc. And not too much!

a "big" boutique museum. not only a great collection , the core based on the personal (good) taste of the founder but also beautiful garden and nice bar restaurant for a quick lunch/snack. in teh auditorium program is always worth the ticket

An inspiring collection. It's been a while since I visit the collection, but it is impressive, since the late Calouste Gulbenkian, Mr. 5% (I understand he got rich by lending his lands (full of oil) at a 5% rate) had an exquisite taste for ancient art, from old civilizations and Empires. Those who love art should visit it.

Nice museum!. The museum lies inside a huge garden and it has a large collection of art with an explanation of how the museum came about. It has a contemporary and older collection of art and it is well worth a visit. It is a 5 minutes walk from the Praca de Espanha subway station.

Terrific tour by museum educator. Monday mornings the museum offers a tour in English lead by the museum's educator (sorry I don't have his name). He was very knowledgeable and so interesting he made the history, artifacts and art come alive! Very reasonably priced --they offer a senior rate--a terrific value. Don't miss Marie Antoinette 's chair!

Lisbon August 2016. You have to get up early to avoid the queues for the elevator we didnt manage it but it looks great and there is a nice bar behind the convent at the top of the hill so you can see the people who were prepared to wait and have a go.. modern art museum, gulbenkian,st jeronimos monastery, Belem tower, trams and the castle. great food, especially at Sacrimento restaurant. shops and bars. Lots to do in this buzzy city

Fascinating collection. Fascinating collection and story of how the museum came about. Astonishing pieces, particularly if you are a Lalique fan. We only visited the older collection, not the contemporary section). Well worth a visit. We took the metro to the Praca de Espanha and walked 5 minutes.

Impressive garden. Huge garden, more like a park, with amphitheatre and carefully chosen trees & plants. Poor signage may either be charming or confusing. It hides two modernist buildings with art exhibitions, neither of which were of interest to us.

More Here Than You Might Expect. There is the traditional Gulbenkian, with his collection. The standout is the turkish rugs and handcrafts, which is worth the visit. The collection of paintings surely contains some excellent pieces and is enjoyable, but it is not the Prado or Kuntsmuseum.The museum is part of a campus that has park-like water features, an outdoor performance space, and a contemporary art museum, as well as a very nice outdoor cafe (gelato) structure. In total we spent about 5 hours exploring the grounds and the museums. Also, I am not a big fan of Lalique glassware, but the museum has a room that houses the good stuff--one of a kind jewelry and glassware. Don't skip it.The outdoor space was about to start a summer jazz series, unfortunately we were a week to early, but Marc Ribot and Tim Berne were performing, so the facility programs top notch music.
NICE PIECES FROM DIFFERENT COUNTRIES, CENTURIES. Nice pieces from different countries belong to different centuries. We visited with our 7.5 years old son. Also, he liked the museum.

Must to be seen!. The museum collection turned out to be a pleasant surprise. We lived in a hotel some 200 m from the museum and left the visit for our last day in Lisbon. It was Sunday, and after 2 pm the entrance was free (regular fee is 10 Euros). The vast collection (once private!) is displayed in a spacious halls. The museum's site presents the masterpieces, so one can learn beforehand about them and the founder, Calouste Gulbenkian. The park around the museum is a masterpiece by itself: large, shadowy, with many benches, ducks, open-air cafe.

A lovely museum in a lovely park. Whenever you are in Lisbon, check out what is going on at the Gulbenkian. Great exhibitions, but also concerts!Also, a charming little cafe. And not to forget: a quite lovely park with artificial streams and fantastic plant arrangements. A green oasis on hot summer days.

Museum was a highlight. Hard to find our way around.. The founders, modern, and temporary exhibits were all excellent. The grounds/gardens are beautiful. The maps and guides provided at front desk were poor.

Fantastic collections. We absolutely adored this museum, which offers probably the best collection of artwork and sculpture in Lisbon.The museum was easily accessible, with a few nearby Metro stations, and can be accessed by wheelchair users with ease.The grounds are lush and picturesque, and the museum itself is cool with air conditioning.We loved the collections - with a vast array of portraits and brilliant art work.

Awesome. It's great collection; free Sunday after 2 pm. It is impressive small but unique; and LOVE the Lalique exhibition ❣ Very very gorgeous ~ the park outside was lovely too with many paths and. seating area. Really enjoyed the visit.

Yet another "must see" if you enjoy art collections. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museum houses one of the most breathtaking and diverse art collections, not only in Portugal, but anywhere in the world! Paintings by the masters, Ming China, Jewelry and statues are among the exhibits. Every time I am in Lisbon, I go back to see it, although I have seen it many times before.

Superb collections. It was an old dream of mine to visit the collections of the famed Armenian businessman and aesthete, and the place did not disappoint (the portrait of an old man by Rembrandt alone would warrant a visit). But the peaceful and lush gardens, as well as the elegant modern buildings housing the many tasteful objects Gulbenkian collected during his remarkable life, were an added bonus. Not to be missed.

Stunning. This is THE must see museum in Lisbon even for those who do not normally like art museums. It has a fabulous collection of objects from all over the world and also an extensive collection of both classical and contemporary art. Absolutely worth a visit. Take your time, a couple of hours will just fly and is not enough.

Beautiful collection and park. This museum is a must-see in Lisbon, either for the collection which is wonderful, especially the Iran objects and paintings and Lalique, and for the parc that is a heaven break, particularly n summer and you can enjoy concerts.
Large collection. this armenian man lived in Lisboa in the late part of his life. He collected lots of things and all on display here in the museum. Very large museum, so lots to see.

incredible collection. The best of the best pieces of art of the 20th century... When a man became rich through work thanks to oil and talent he decided to collect and share with others his love for arts...

Good but overpriced. The museum offers a variety of exhibits, from Egyptian Pharaoh findings to modern art. But 10€ was too much I think. Good thing was the free wifi and several spots to sit and rest!
absolutely fantastic place. an amazing collection of artefacts from many eras as well as paintings and sculptures by many artists

Very eclectic, beautiful pieces, very surprising mix. This collection is the most unusual. A mix of different periods, artists, media, genres. Beautifully displayed. Very interesting story (Calouste Gulbenkian), amazing art collector.

Stunning collections, lovely gardens, nice cafe. I stayed quite near the Gulbenkian, so I came several times. First, the Oriental and European fine and decorative arts collections are stunning. I hardly know where to start. There's a whole room of Guardi's views of Venice, for heaven's sake. The hall full of Chinese ceramics is jaw-dropping. After you've toured the collections, do take the time to stroll the grounds, which are beyond lovely, and great for people-watching, too, because the locals hang out in them. The garden cafe is a great favourite of mine for coffee and a pastel de nada. The queijoada is good, too. Highly recommended!

This collection is not to be missed. None of the books mentioned this absolutely extraordinary collection of artifacts and art that is housed in an architecturally beautiful building with a lovely, serene botanical garden inside the grounds. It was a wonderful afternoon.

one of the best museum collections, lovely craft,building of great architecture and a beautiful garden. dont miss this fantastic museum if you love porcellan and tapestry. There also is a beautiful romantic garden near it with a lake, a perfect place for a picknick in the grass in the hot summer, lots of shades. You can buy bread, cheese and tapas at the spanish department store "il corte inglese" which is nearby. There also is a small amphitheater in the gardens and sometimes there are concerts. Every 1.sunday each month the entry to the museum is free.

A great disappointment. What a phenomenal collection, the building and grounds were exceptional.
But what a dull and uninspiring layout. I can't imagine that the people responsible for the layout gave any more than cursory attention. Cabinets were dusty, labelling was always difficult to read, often couldn't be related to the exhibits and only gave the barest description - "A plate" etc.

Surprisingly good collection, great location and grounds. Come for the art, stay for the setting. The Founder's Collection is an impressive collection of art from ancient Egypt to the mid-20th century. Certain areas are represented in more depth than others. But overall an impressive collection of art. Art includes stone carvings, rugs/tapestries, tiles, books, and vessels. Later periods have many pieces of furniture and paintings. The French furniture is over-the-top.But you can also enjoy the beautiful park setting of the museum in the center of a world capitol city. It's a nice collection in a nice setting. There are certain days of free entry
incredibly collection. Amazing collection, it is unbelievable that is the collection of one man. The building is located in a beautiful park. Do not miss snack in their cafe.

Knockout exhibition. Great to see such a wonderful range of works all in one place. It's a tribute to Gulbenkian (the Roman Abramovich of his day) that he collected the items and left them to his adopted nation. We only had time to visit the classical exhibition which starts with a range of Egyptian and Islamic artefacts; Turkish carpets and tiles follow, and then the paintings; many from notable geniuses such as Rembrandt, Rubens, Renoir, Monet, Degas, Turner and Gainsborough. There is a lovely collection of Italian scenes by Guardi. A range of Louis XV and XVI furniture and dining artefacts come next and lastly an amazing collection of jewellery by Rene Lalique. Even if you don't like Museums or Art galleries this is worth a visit if only to get a real feel of how the mega rich of the early C20 lived and what they spent their money on before football teams, super yachts and Jets!

Not to be confused with Guggenheim.. About 2 miles north of the city and about a 7 Euro taxi ride but very much worth it. Calouste Gulbenkian, an Armenian oil tycoon gave Portual his art collection in gratitude for granting him asylum during WW11.On display are a few select pieces from the last 5 thousand years. The museum has a flowing design that's easy to follow seeing the entire collection. Easily the best museum in Lisbon.

Enlightening. The museum is much larger than we anticipated, offering you the chance to spend a couple of hours in there browsing without intending or realising.Indeed, we had only planned to spend a quick hour or so there, but found ourselves encapsulated by the artwork, sculptures and portraits on offer.A really good museum, offering artefacts from everything from the Ottoman Empire to 20th century Portugal.The highlight, for us, was the array of portraits from famous 20th century painters.The animal sculptures, too, were brilliant.The carpet exhibition downstairs was a little disappointing, merely because of a lack of length and a lack of immersiveness.Regardless, this is definitely a great way to spend a few hours in Lisbon.

Gulbenkian Museum. We chose to get there by taxi, just for sheer convenience. The museum is very well set out, and had an interesting and wide selection of artefacts. It took us 4 hours to wander around at a slow pace with a break in the middle in the cafe which had a good selection of food and snacks.The gardens are worth a visit in their own right. A very enjoyable experience.

Outstanding art collection. This art museum is much better than many art museums I visited! We can see masterpieces by Renoir, Rembrandt, Manet, Rodin and more. It has an impressive coin collection from Ancient Rome and Greece, Lalique jewelry and accessories and super Moorish tiles, just to name a few examples of the diversity and quality of the art presented there. Highly recommend to art lovers!

Rich collection but poor documentation. We visited this gallery in order to see the European paintings section. The building itself was vast and somewhat difficult to navigate as well as being very discreetly lit, so discreetly that many areas were quite dark. The collection includes j Islamic and oriental art as well as jewellry and a lot of exquisite furniture, much being French. The highlight was the European Paintings section with many paintings by well known artists such as Van Dyck, Gainsborough, Monet as well as other beautiful paintings by less known artists. These paintings, because privately owned, are not so well known and therefore even more beautiful and worthy of attention. The 18th century gallery was sadly closed for rehanging and those of us who are English or frenchspeaking would have appreciated an audio guide .

Almost a secret. Not to be missed by art loversUnique collection which covers various periods and areas: Egyptian, Islamic and Oriental art and European painting and decorative arts.Enjoy the very quiet and pleasant garden.

Impressive museum. I enjoyed this museum and its grounds were lovely too. It's an easy walk from Parque Eduoardo. I took advantage of the free entrance after 2pm on Sunday. However, if my schedule didn't allow for the free visit, the entrance fee (10 euros) would have been worth it. There were many things to see, and I particularly enjoyed the beautiful and unique Lalique collection. There was also a special exhibit of the first editions of Molière's plays when I was there.
Never ending great value. What a great collection, lots of variety can see why it's rated number 1 museum its great it has modern art and his own private collection

World's finest private art collection. Large art collection donated to the city by Calouste Gulbenkian, one of the founders of Royal Dutch Shell.Important display of Modern Art, the founder's collection which collection covers various periods and areas: Egyptian, Islamic and Oriental art, old coins and European painting and decorative arts. High quality museum surrounded by a beautiful garden.

One of my favourite museums. A small number of exhibits by comparison with the major museums yet it covers a number of areas well. The exhibits are high quality and well chosen examples. Lovely grounds and nice coffee shop / restaurant too.

Unusal. This museum is a small oasis surrounded by a lovely garden in which you can enjoy a cool drink or an interesting meal.The museum is in part one persons particular passions be it the most beautiful and rare rugs to a wonderful collection of Lalique jewellery and glass to a great collection of watches and clocks.How Mr Gulbenkian an Armenia by birth came to own such a collection is explained as you walk through this museum also the advise he took to guide him on his selections yet ultimately he had a great eye for the rare and beautiful.Well worth a visit
To visit our heritage. Excellent and spacious building but a modest collection of exhibits. Good to see art students working in the museum cafeteria.

Eclectic collection which is stunning. The Museum was recommended by the hotel staff and it did not disappoint. It is an amazingly varied collection, a real jackdaw's treasure trove and set out really well with space to see everything clearly without feeling hemmed in by crowds. The gardens it is set in are worth exploring too with lots of shady benches to sit on and people watch. Excellent room of Lalique pieces worth visiting for that alone.Great café and gift shop toO. A must see place
Must Go ! Art, music, garden. This is The place where art lives In Lisbon ! Classic concerts, well knowned painters and sculptors exibition. The gardens surrounding the building are espectacular!

Amazing museum - A must in Lisbon. The Gulbenkian collection must be one of the most amazing art collections in the world and the museum that was built for the collection in one of the most elegant areas of Lisbon is not going to make you disappointed. Free entrance on sundays after 14h.

Gulbenkian Foundation - a place to visit again and again. The gardens, the architecture, the collections and temporary exhibitions, the auditorium and program, the events, the library, coffee shop, all is worth visiting and worth enjoying for its quality and pleasure of just being there. It's a place where you feel "at home" and want to visit again and again, for a concert, an exhibition or a simple stroll in the park.
Best museum in Lisbon. Amazing collection of paintings. Free every Sunday and is right by this amazing gardens in the heart of the city.
Amazing museum. It isn't the biggest museum ever, but the sheer quality of each section is amazing... noteworthy are the Iranian art and lalique crystals

Marvellous. An fantastic collection:Egyptian funeral masks, beautiful rugs, amazing pottery, delightful items including table silver, clocks, Lalique pieces and so on. Then almost as an afterthought there are some world-class paintings by Manet, Rembrandt, Rubens, Turner etc etc. . The modern art museum was a good exhibition space and I suppose if I understood the work better I might have got more out of it. The museums and exhibitions were very reasonably priced. The gardens surrounding the buildings (free) are very beautiful,

Feel the art and the beauty. Situated at the Spanish Plaza in Lisbon with easy access including underground.In 1942 Calouste Gulbenkian came to live in Lisbon. He was one of the most wealthy men in the world, with oil business in Iraq. He fell in love with Lisbon and here left his magnificent Foundation,Classic music and dancing, operas, paintings, jewelery, libraries, lovely gardens, restaurantes, etc. Calouste Gulbenkian was an art lover, and in his collections you have woks from Vittore Carpaccio, Peter Paul Rubens, Antoon van Dyck, Rembrandt, Thomas Gainsborough, George Romney, Thomas Lawrence, Jean-Honoré Fragonard, Jean-Baptiste Corot, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, François Boucher, Édouard Manet, Edgar Degas, Claude Monet and many others.It´s a MUST to feel this beauty.

One of the best places in Lisbon. Lisbon is blesses with the Gulbekian Foundation and museum. It is not the largest and most impressive museum one could see - what always intrigued me here is the collective passion of a man to keep the history alive and to promote culture on all levels. There is a little of everything in Gulbekian collection and the temporary exhibitions are always good as well. Check if there is some cultural event on the museum premises on the agenda.The canteen is ok for a coffee and is perfect for a short pause but the food is mediocre and overpriced.Better enjoy a picnic in the adjacent park grounds.
High expectations.. A Rembrandt in Lisbon? That definitely put this museum top of my list. I really enjoyed the varied collection and loved the building itself with the surrounding park too.
Wonderful Experience. An eclectic collection so something for everyone. The park-like setting is delightful.The café is very good. The cost is 10 euros. Seniors 5 euros. Sundays after 2 p.m.are free.

Amazing collection and beautiful gardens. Mr Gulbenkian clearly decided to buy only the best of everything and there is a stunning collection on view in the main museum - Egyptian funeral masks, beautiful rugs, amazing pottery, a whole host of other delightful items including table silver, clocks, Lalique pieces and so on. Then almost as an afterthought there are some world-class paintings by Manet, Rembrandt, Rubens, Turner etc etc. The building was spacious and cool and there were surprisingly few people when we visited so we were allowed slow and calm consideration of all the amazing items.The modern art museum was not particularly to my taste but was a good exhibition space and I suppose if I understood the work better I might have got more out of it. The museums and exhibitions were very reasonably priced.The gardens surrounding the buildings (free) are very beautiful, merging lovely planting and water features with quite severe concrete structures - somehow it all works and makes for a very soothing space in which to walk, read, picnic and so on.
interesting museum in a nice garden. Interesting collection, what I liked the most were the glass pieces in the middle east part of the museum

Exquisite Lalique exhibit. Went to see the Lalique room....amazing! I skipped the rest of the classic museum due to lack of time. Overall it appears to be a very large collection of art and antiquities collected by Gulbenkian of all sorts. Gardens surrounding are also very beautiful.

A must if you are interested in oriental art. A nice place to spend pleasant 2 hours.
Very interesting Turkish/Persian/Syrian art.
A must for people interested in Iznik tiles.

Sunday late pm (re)treat. We went to visit the beautiful park and the museum on Sunday afternoon when it's free and would have happily paid the 10 EUR entrance, as the museum and the exhibited items are very impressive. Our highlight was a Rembrandt painting "the old man".

Interesting museum, a bit overpriced. We enjoyed our visit to this museum, spent about 2 hours exploring the collection. It's worth the time, but at 10 euros per person, it's not a good fit for everyone (a bit expensive for a larger family, perhaps).

Beautiful museum with a beautiful and varied collection.. This museum will give you a beautiful tour of the history of art. The collector, Mr. Gulbenkian, selected only the finest examples of the art of the centuries and placed them in a beautiful setting.This is not a large museum, so I hope you will fit it into your Lisbon touring. We had an excellent lunch in the museum cafe.

A spectacular museum surrounded by a beautiful garden. This was a revelation to us, after visiting so many other museums in Lisbon. This museum is stocked with treasures including paintings by Rubens, Turner, Corot, Renoir, Manet and many other masters of the craft. But it is much more than this, including as it does, beautiful ceramics, statuary, glassware, carpets and artifacts from many corners of the world. With its basis in a private collection, this is definitely worth a visit. It is surrounded by beautifully landscaped gardens which create a delightful ambience.

Most Interesting !. A terrific find in a beautiful setting ! I agree with other people's comments on the artwork . The overall atmosphere was very conducive to taking one's time and enjoying the assorted collections. I truly enjoyed the Lalique art deco pieces. This museum was a highlight of my last day in the amazing city of Lisbon.

A must to visit on your trip to Lisbon. A really fascinating museum to visit, with many interesting exhibits from Ancient Egypt, Greece and Rome to Impressionist Paintings.The museum walks you through history. The items are beautifully displayed, the works of art are stunning including Persion Artefacts and rug, Chinese Porcelain and French furniture. It's a spacious air conditioned museum, which makes it a pleasure to visit.The grounds are also worth a stroll through, quite lovely and the cafeteria is a good place to enjoy a delicious lunch.
Gulbenkian Museum. Amazing collection. Worth a trip there and the surrounding garden is like a secret garden in the middle of the city.
Gulbenkian Museum Review. Eclectic collection of art and artifacts from all over the world: Chinese pottery, Japanese screens, illuminated medieval prayer books both Christian and Muslim, etc.

Impressive . Having their modern display of Portuguese art and very impressive array of Egyptian to Lalique art, with few Rembrandt and also some Monet's collection, like typical museums with cafe that good for a cup of coffee and you're choice of some sweet, if you are really starving try food outside.

Amazing oasis. The Gulbenkian is a must see for anyone visiting Lisbon. Its incredible collection of ancient and modern art and artefacts, all within acres of wonderful gardens makes for a delightful day visit. The Lalique exhibit alone is worth the affordable entry fee. It also has a super high quality catering set up with surprisingly low prices.
Lovely place. We went to the museum and walked through the garden. Everything was beautiful. We went Sunday after 2PM and the museum is free and we were able to see everything very calmly.
A beutifuul museum. The museum has a very nice collection of modern portuguese art. They also have two beautiful Rembrand and several Monet. The park is exquisite.

Beautiful collection and impressive presentation!. This museum is the only one open on Mondays (closed Tues) and has a very eclectic collection from early Egyptian to modern Impressionists. Highlight is the grounds and museum itself.

Good museum to spend a half day!. Highly recommend visiting this museum as it has an exquisite collection of Lalique art deco jewellery. If you stay for lunch in the museum cafeteria, be forewarned that the food is not that good and looks better than it tastes. However, it is fine to sit there to enjoy a coffee and something sweet.

One of the best museums in Lisbon!. Together with the Museum of Old Art (Museu de Arte Antiga or Museu das Janelas Verdes), I would rate this museum as one of the two art museums not to miss in Lisbon if you like art!The collection is fantastic and the museum display is beautiful done, and set in a marvelous building. Although it is relatively small, it should be ranked with the best you can get.As an added bonus the gardens around the museum are outstanding and some of the temporary exhibitions in the main building very worth the visit.I live in Lisbon but I visit it regularly to see some of "my" paintings and sculptures! What a privilege to have something like hoo close at hand!

Very interesting museum . There are a lot of famous painters like Rembrandt, Renoir, Manet and much more, a rich collection of Rene Lalique, Oriental and Egyptian art, decorative arts like furnitures.During our visit were not a lot of people so we could admire everything in silence and calm.

Worth taking a look. We showed up a bit late to this museum so we didn't get to see everything. What we did see was great. The garden around this area is a beautiful place to hang out. We went back a couple of times.

Beautiful museum, interesting for its collections, architecture and Landscape. Free on sunday, a wide variety of collection : Calouste Gulbenkian impressive private collection but also moderm or contemporary art.The gardens and building are beautiful and deserve an architectural visit too...A nice place to go with children .

Must visit museum and garden. One of the most eclectic and exciting collections in Europe in its custom built modernist building. Just the right size to enjoy without being overwhelming and don't miss the excellent shop and cafe in the basement. We loved our visit

I fell in love with a dream. Imagine that powerful men are in love only with culture and art, definitely not with war or personal ambition. And imagine that they build great museums, special places just to admire the human creativity. Fundacao Calouste Gulbenkian's Museum is something like this - a very rich businessman spent his life collecting art and gave all to us. That was his dream. It allows us to study the greatness of his soul. And it is a great pleasure verify the way his sensibility dialogued with the treasures of human civilization. From Pre-Historic, Antiquity, Medieval and Modern Ages till the time he lived, a wonderful choice of sculptures, paintings, art craft, bijoux, porcelain, furnitures, well, numerous precious objects, are there. But there is also a continuous regard to art production, many events in open air irresistible garden, formative projects... what can I say? Like in the old song, what one can do is just fell in love with his dream.
Beautiful museum!. Varied and exquisite private collection in a lovely setting. Nice gift shop. A bit out of the way, so best way to arrive is by cab. About $10 from Rossio.

Do not miss to pay a visit here while in Lisbon.. It was a heaven in a hot and humid weather in July. You can find merely EVERYTHING necessary for a human. Good music performance by the Armenian String Quartet in the garden, and free entrance to the museum after 14:00 P.m. on sundays. There is much more than a private collection...
One man's ...... Amazing what one man can collect and you can see this man's various collections here on the little campus set up to display them. Don't miss the separate modern arts pavillion.
Must see!!. An absolutely must see attraction when in Lisbon. Took my breathe away at the extent of 1 man's appreciation of art and his generosity in sharing it.Truly amazing.

Interesting Museum and Gardens. I was drawn to this museum and gallery purely on the recommendations I had received. Depending on how you arrive, I got the Metro to Sao Sebastiao as I wanted to explore the gardens first. These are also recommended and a beautiful way to start your day before moving onto the museum itself. A mixture of architecture of features there are numerous small ponds and streams to explore and navigate around and a genuinely beautiful area in the middle of this district of Lisbon. Without a map or direction I did get a little lost trying to find the museum entrance itself if you decide to wander down a path using intuition however they would led to a different area of the gardens to see or explore and the building itself was usually within sight. You can of course get off the metro closer or take a bus however in my opinion a visit to the museum requires a visit to these free gardens as well.The museum or gallery itself great value for money, it is an assortment of art, tile work and rugs and tapestries from a personal collection. At first I was concerned there would be little content however once inside you follow a set path around and see a lot of rooms and collective pieces. There are temporary paid for exhibits on top of the entry price you pay which did feel a bit off putting however this is In no way different from other galleries and museums around the world. I enjoyed seeing the main permanent exhibits on display, there were some beautiful pieces on show and you can spend an hour or two just walking and admiring the art on display before you reach the end.Facilities wise there is a small restaurant on the lower ground floor which opens out into the garden. Food is what you usually find in a museum café however it was nice to sit with a drink overlooking the gardens and pond that it faces out onto. Toilets are located on the lower ground level but again clearly sign posted. My only real critique was a sign saying the entrance to the modern art facility was free close by which seemed to be a connected museum. On arrival this was not the case and required purchase of separate ticket to gain entry. Overall I was happy with the original permanent collection itself, its surrounding gardens were a nice experience in itself and the museum was home to some beautiful pieces. It was relatively cheap and good value for money.

Second Visit - Three Years Later. This museum is incredible on so many levels, the first and foremost being the man himself, businessman and philanthropist Calouste Gulbenkian, who collected good art...lots of it. Instead of hording his art and sharing it only with those closest to him, he decided to share it with the world. Thank goodness for people like this. The collection is so extensive it is almost incomprehensible. I believe his earliest piece dates back to 1860BCE - an Egyptian antiquity and his most recent acquisition dates from the 1940's/50's. Aside from the vast collection of furnishings and furniture there is an entire wing dedicated to the European masters. Several of the artists represented here include Rembrandt, Rubens, La Tour, Boucher, Pigale, Rousseau, Corot, Boudin, Manet, Monet, Degas, Renoir, etc. Not only is this museum eye candy for those who appreciate good art/collectibles, but it also serves as a history lesson.This time I visited, there was a special exhibit on carpets and tapestries. The numerous carpets from Iran, India, Turkey and India were absolutely magnificient. A separate and equally fascinating exhibit focused on Hagop Kapoudjian, one of the most famous master carpet weavers who also worked for Gulbenkian repairing many of his priceless carpets.Prepare to spend several hours and that doesn't even include a visit to the sprawling gardens that surround the museum. Note, the museum is free on Sunday AFTER 2PM.

Exciting for a single person collection. Gulbenkian started as an oil exporter from Baku when it was cosmopolitan and free (end of 19century). He continued from London and then moved to Lisbon. Quite and exciting collection. And it is a still functioning foundation attracting interest and good temporary exhibitions. A must if you are in Lisbon.

Intriguing range of historic display items.. Half a day spent here would be an enjoyable experience for anyone with an interest in eastern fabrics, tiles, pottery, glassware as well as (relatively more recent) art and furniture.

A gem in Lisbon. Well done for everyone involved in granting Calouste Gulbenkian all the necessary authorizations to place this spectacular urban gem in Lisbon.Great architecture, fantastic garden, unique (ancient and modern) art collection makes this wonderful Museum a place to visit recurrently.
Great way to spend an afternoon. There is something for everyone who loves art, beautiful grounds, with the added bonus of a lovely cafeteria with remarkably delicious ice cream.

Impressive and Uncluttered. This is a wonderful and delightful collection with some very important art. I especially enjoyed the fact that it was u cluttered like so many museums can be. You could really concentrate on the individual pieces. This should not be missed.

An impressive collection. An impressive collection of art displayed in two buildings amidst a park in central Lisbon. Impressive collection of china, carpets, furniture, paintings and Lalique glass and jewlery.

Great paintings. Go to this museum if you want to see the classical painters and sculptures. Very little people. You can actually touch a Rhodin or Rembrandt, but please don't:)
The egyptian art section is magical!

The best museum I have ever visited worldwide of a private collector.. The breadth of this collection was amazing. Ancient right through to modern art,silver,gold, jewellery, ceramics,silk Persian rugs,an amazing Lalique collection,first books and writing, a collection of Moliere's original books....the collection goes on all give to the nation by Gilbelkian.

Modern art collected by Mr Five Per Cent. Make the effort to visit this museum. It will be worth it. Mr Gulbenkian, was known as Mr Five Per Cent for reasons that will become clear when you go there. It goes to explain how he could afford to amass so many collections. He knew Rene Lalique and the collection has over a hundred pieces of Lalique glass and jewelry. But that is just one of many themes. Don't miss it.

Spectacular. There are marvelous museums inside to visit including contemporary art, a big concert Hall with a varied program and concerts.The gardens are a must to enjoy specially when the weather is fine.

If there is One place to see here in Lisbonne this is it !. It is one of these places where you sense that the person who collected the items really cared for them and their beauty. There are about a 1000 pieces out of his collection that accounts for about 6000 . They are well kept and exposed for all of us too see.
Perfect for a rainy day. This is one of my favorite museums. The collection is so varied and interesting. Perfect way to spend a few hours regardless of the weather. You won't be disappointed.

Outanding collection. This museum is a MUST see in Lisbon.Wide ranging collection of the highest quality pieces covering areas from ancient coins, marvellous works of art and exquisite furniture. May need two visits to absorb it properly.

Good variety. Visited the gardens on my first day in Lisbon (a cool, peaceful oasis) and the museum on my last day - a Monday when most attractions in Lisbon are closed. I was so tired by then that I didn`t do it justice, but this has an excellent collection of various items and is a good exposure to some culture for those who don`t wish to spend a lot of their time visiting museums.

A treasure trove. You really must visit this place when you are in Lisbon. The number of treasures it has from various civilisations is staggering. It is very roomy so you always have plenty of time to linger at objects of interest. What a superb gift this man left to humanity!

Stunning Collection. We had planned a couple of hours here, but ended up spending twice that and enjoying an excellent lunch in the pleasant café. The main museum takes your breath away, but the adjacent museum of modern art is a matter of personal taste!

Very good manageable museum. This is a very good museum, it is relatively small, thus manageable. Lots of pieces from the Middle East (Mr. Gulbenkian was Armenian). You should plan for about two hours, a bit more if you want to wander around the beautiful gardens.
Gardens, two just perfect musea. Take time to walk through the gardens and certainly don't miss the foundation museum: every single piece represent a summum.

A collectors' experience. Persian rugs, furniture, sculpture, ceramics, painting etc, things to interest from different periods and cultures. Two good Rembrandt's and a nice series by Guardi of Venice and a Turner, as I like their work, but others as well.

Excellent Diverse Collection. While not a large museum, this has a lovely and diverse collection and is an enjoyable way to spend a few hours looking at art. We particularly enjoyed the presentation of the textiles and tiles. Sundays the museum is free to the public; we ate a tasty lunch at the museum cafe and there were healthy options.

Two (seemingly unrelated) collections in one small museum. This museum is divided into two areas, one with ancient art (Greek, Roman, Egyptian, etc.) and one with European art and artifacts. We saw this museum late in the day after seeing others, so perhaps we were too tired to appreciate it, but we are not knowledgeable about ancient art and we found that there was not a great deal of high-quality European art, especially in comparison to the top museums of the world. Probably it has the best European art collection in Lisbon, but I would rank it low on places to see. For us, its top feature is its gardens.

always good choices. You have to check first what's the premium exhibition, of course the museum in general in worthwhile. But enjoy the gardens around the buildings, particularly when you have your girlfriend with you. Again note that my notes are based in several visits, none was less than good.

Amazing. What an amazing and manageable museum. The range of exhibits is quite mind blowing but the quality of everything is consistently high. From coins and fine art (Monet, Rodin, Rembrandt) through to amazing Lalique (changed my understanding of what he did) and Louis XIV furniture to carpets and wall tiles. Just an astounding collection and whilst vast it was not overpowering and really enjoyable. It was accessible also - Whilst we were there a bus load of really well behaved school kids arrived and it was a pleasure seeing them get so much out of their visit. A must see
Great collection. This is an example of someone who really wanted to give something worth to society can do. The museum, the cultural center, the exhibitions, the garden... I loved it all.

A Treasurehouse!. When they learned that I was visiting Lisbon several people quite independently urged me to visit this museum, and I now see why. It is quite simply a splendid collection of the highest quality, very well displayed in a purpose built building surrounded by beautiful parkland. Easily accessible by Metro, though the signposting could be improved, it is a most rewarding way to spend a few hours away from the bustle of the city and crowded tourist attractions. Highly recommended!

Not to be missed. This museum offers an impressive collection of all sorts of artworks throughtout history, Paintings, porcelain, jewellery carpets. This is my favourite Lisbon museum and I always go there whenever I visit Lisbon. Not open on Tuesday.

Interesting even for non-art lovers. The many objects collected by Calouste Gulbenkian span about 5,000 years and are arranged in a very interesting and informative chronological and country of origin manner. The objects are not crowded in their display cases. The museum building is very modern and easy to walk around in. There is an inexpensive cafeteria on site. The museum offers English tours 10:30 - 12:00 on Mondays. We visited the museum with our local Rick Steves tour guide.
