The museum is not to far from the San Sebastian metro station which is north of the center of Lisbon.Admission to the museum is 5 euro; but is free on Sundays. It is not open on Tuesdays but Wednesday - Monday it opens at 10:00 and closes at 18:00.

Good selection of decorative art. We went here on our 4th day in Lisbon so I wouldn't include it in the top 10 list. You also have to use the metro to get here, it is a bit on its ownHowever the museum is very easy to walk round, well laid out and a great selection of decorative art
Well worth a visit!. A decent collection of art and furniture from across the globe and the centuries. Given the EUR 5 entry fee and the lovely cafe and gardens this is well worth a visit!

Don´t Miss it. Last time I went there decided to invite my grandchildren. Thought they wouldnt appreciate the beauty of the place and the great pieces of art you can find. I was completely mistaken, they understood the collection, asked a lot of questions, and from than on, is one of the places they like to go back and enjoy. The gardens are superb, the collections are superb. Don't miss it if you are in Lisbon. And if you like music, book in advance a ticket to assist one of the super classic concerts.

Mini Smithsonian!. This museum is first rate, and covers art from ancient to modern. Especially amazing were the coins, although I wish they had been displayed with mirrors so you could see the reverse side. Learning about the collector, Calouste Gulbenkian, was also inspiring. He "tithed" for art, spending one tenth of his fortune each year to support the arts. One caveat, that if your time is limited and you want to learn specifically about Portuguese art and history, this may not be the place for you.

Beautiful building but spoilt by noisy tourists. We arrived by tourist bus to Belem. The overall appearance of the building is stunning. Inside the ambiance and spiritual feeling was destroyed by noisy inconsiderate people despite numerous notices requesting silence

Large eclectic collection makes it a unique experience. The large range of exhibits are well displayed in different buildings in a small park setting. A lot of the stuff was not really to my taste, but I still enjoyed my visit. It'd be fair to say there's bound to be something for everyone to enjoy. It's not particularly cheap, even with a concession, so only fair value. Nontheless, I'd recommend a visit, but ideally on a dry day, so you can wander round the park in comfort. The staff were helpful.

Nice museum, eclectic.. This museum is nice and worth a visit. However, for my tastes, the exhibits were too "scattered." That is, there did not appear to be a coherent theme. A "little bit of everything" seemed to be the mantra. Still, if one wants to see what excessive money can buy this is a good place to start.

Well worth a visit. This museum is very nicely organised and signed and has much in it. There is a lot of porcelain, furniture and carpets - unfortunately they are not my things but are very good of their type. What made the visit good for me is the fine and mixed collection of paintings by such as e.g.van der Weyden, Rembrandt, Turner Gaudi etc. I also very much admired the Art Deco jewelry rooms. It was relatively unfilled with visitors and it was a pleasure to stroll around. I am very glad to have seen it.
Well worth the walk. We really enjoyed this museum with its amazing collection. Its a little walk out of the centre, but well worth it.

Magnificent Lalique. This is an unusual museum in that the exhibit areas appear to be more random than normal, but this is a good thing because there is a surprise around every corner. This display of Lalique jewellery is fabulous.
Amazing Collection!. By far the best museum I've visited. The collection is amazing and it's free entry on Sunday. Easy to get by using public transport - metro.
A great tourist attraction. We really enjoyed our Saturday visit. There is so many different things to see. The attraction met all our expectations and was as promised in our tourist guides. No cost!

World-class museum in an outstanding landscape. This compact museum has an exceptional range of paintings, statutes, miniature carvings, glassware, furniture, antique carpets...something for everyone. We just visited the main Museum (saving the Modern Art Museum for another day). What is astounding is that only about one-sixth of the whole collection is actually exhibited. Particularly notable are the 16th-century or so Persian, Turkish, Indian, and Chinese tiles, rugs, ceramics, and glass--a real eye-opener for me.

A lovely place. Plan to spend leisurely hours here. A very well designed museum with an extensive collection. We especially were impressed with the 14th century glass lamps from mosques in Syria. Amazing thin glass artwork.
Compreensive colection. Art collection that starts with Egipt, goes thru Greeks, Chinese, European and much more. The indian carpets are a must see. The Garden outside is wonderful.

Treasure of art. First thing - there are 2 museums on this site - one is the Museum of Modern art,the second is this one. The Modem Art on is sparse - not worth a specific visit, but worth the 5 E if you are there.The Calouste Gulbenkian is a hidden jewel. Degas and Manet, Monet and Turner. Sculpture, and Egyptian artifacts and some jaw dropping 18 C gilded furniture. The gift shop is nifty, but skip the cafe - meh food and over priced.

Outstanding collection of items from around the world. We have been in museums around the world, but the variety and quality of this collection stands out. Pieces from ancient Greece that are in mint condition. From art work, to coins to furniture, it was well worth the visit

Beautiful private collection of Art. Firstly double check the opening days, the AA cityguide stated it was open Tuesday to Sunday, closed Monday...this is incorrect it is open Wednesday to Monday and closed on Tuesday...we went on the Tuesday and there were several people outside with different guide books all of which said it should have been open. The collection is exquisite housed in an ideal 60's building. In particular the Rembrandts, Turners and a Burne-Jones and a Singer Sargent, but the highlight is undoubtedly the collection of exquisite glassware by Rene Lalique.

Not your usual museum. The collections of a very wealthy man many times are skewed toward his interests. The Gulbenkian breaks that form by trying to have a few outstanding pieces from each general historic period 500 BCE to the present. Housed in a low slung modernist building deep in a park like block with few signs, it can be a bit hard to locate on foot but when you do it is well worth the few missed turns. We particularly enjoyed the paintings and sculptures from the Impressionist Period. Mr. Gulbenkian used his wealth well.
Gem of a musuem. If you like to see excellent collects of many items this is a musuem for you, it is beautifully edited giving us the best Furniture, coins, paintings, books etc.

Amazing. I know, amazing is a word overused these days but this museum deserves it. Set is a very pleasant park which was well used the day we were there, the museum is just one of the buildings on site. Go on Sunday and it is free. That's we did. It wasn't overly busy and we were able to enjoy all the artefacts on display in comfort. Mr Gulbenkian believed in buying the best and it shows. The people of Portugal were so lucky to have been given this amazing (that word again) gift. He had his preferences. Lots of carpets and textiles, Egyptian finds, ceramics from the Middle East and China, French furniture  (this not to my taste but the workmanship was top-drawer.) and more and more. Every room led to an other filled with exquisite offerings. To be honest, there is too much to take in at one visit. We were happy to retire to the café for a reviving drink and a custard tart.There is a small shop where I would have expected something bigger.There is an art gallery on the same site. The café here had a very long queue but the gallery itself was pretty much empty. The art on view had not been picked for its popular appeal.You could spend all day at this museum. Remember...free on Sundays.

Exquisite. This is the most incredible private collection I have ever seen. You are transported back through time, seeing the best examples of art and artefacts of every empire and culture.To know that each piece was collected by one man is extraordinary. We all have a personal preferences and genres in art but you can't help but admire the depth and beauty of this eclectic collection. Simply the best of the best of each period, Persian, Egyptian, Greek, Roman, Chinese, French, English. Each piece, be it a Persian carpet, Roman coins, Ming Vase, Islamic Lanterns, all ten of them are displayed in such a way that you flow from one to the other spellbound. The museum is airy and spacious, giving you time to reflect and enjoy.Whenever we go (three friends) to view a collection we play a game where we are allowed to choose one piece we would take home with us.Mine would have been the Islamic lanterns, but such a difficult choice at this museum!The Lalique Jewellery is exquisite.Please go you won't be disappointed.We went on a Sunday and it wasn't too busy, but the day before it had been pouring down and they had been packed.As another reviewer said the taxi driver drops you at the exhibition centre not the museum!

Well worth the visit. An excellent museum with a wide range of exhibits collected from most periods in history and across all of the continents by this private collector. Everything is beautifully displayed and I particularly liked the Lalique glass and the Chinese porcelain. Well worth a visit, with a modern art gallery on the same site. Some of the exhibits in here were not particularly to my taste but very thought provoking!Also has an excellent cafe for snacks and light lunch.
Perfect collection. It was very interesting to discover the eclectic taste of the owner . Loved the chinese part and all the incredible Lalique items .

Beautiful museum. Terrific museum with a lot of Arabic influence. Set in lovely gardens that are very extensive and relaxing in the middle of Lisbon. Nice place for time out from the hustle and bustle.

Perfect for a rainy afternoon. Enjoyed both the museum and the modern art centre, two different buildings on the same grounds. The display spaces are lovely! Easy to get to by metro (Saõ Sebastian). Very nice cafés.

The Cliff Notes of Museums. If you are a museum person but your husband or family are not, THIS is the museum to take them to! It is a stop on one of the Hop on Hop Off bus routes and well worth the hop off. It is a private museum of a remarkable collector who had only the best of each period starting with Greek and Roman antiquities, beautiful coins and pottery, and touching on all that is lovely from world wide civilizations up to the early 20th century: beautiful rugs and pottery from the middle east, English furniture, a variety of paintings, and silver, Japanese kimonos, Chinese jade and vases, and ending with an exquisite collection of Lalique jewelry. However, there are only a few examples so no one is trudging from room to room endlessly.And if someone doesn't like the objects, they can enjoy the lovely museum, itself. There is a pleasant cafe and lovely garden.

Small and eclectic collection. I thought this was a find. A small but varied collection which reflects the collector's taste. Note that cabs drop you off at the administration building, not the museum. The person at the counter spends all day re-directing guests. Either have cabs drop visitors at the actual museum or spot for some clearly marked signs.Considering the size of the facility, this is an impressive collection and should be of interest to most serious art museum goers.

Eclectic collection of artefacts. Really enjoyed visiting the museum and getting through the large rooms showcasing a very eclectic collection. I wish I had given it a bit more time as there is a lot to get through! Would recommend walking through the park surrounding the museum.

A jewel in a lavish crown.. With so much to see in and around Lisbon, it appears this museum gets a little over looked as far as tourists are concerned. But, in my opinion is has some of the finest collections outside the large municipal collections in places like London, Madrid or Milan. Although I visited in early May the gardens were mature enough to provide enjoyable walks and a pleasant setting for the gallery buildings.

Excellent Museum - plan about 2 hours. This is the collection of one, very wealthy man.  He left his collection and an endowment  to a foundation, which is still robust.   The collection is interesting as it reflects the tastes of one person.   He collected both ancient and modern items - always the very best of what was available.  In addition to items from Ancient Egypt, there are paintings, carpets, ceramic ware, and paintings by Rembrandt, Renoir, Manet and others.   Thrre is a good collection of items made by Rene Lalique, who was a personal friend. You can tell he liked Venice, as there are 14 paintings of this enchanting city.The museum is free on Sundays so it is a it crowded and they ran out of the audio tours the Sunday I visited.  A friend said when he visited during the week  it was also crowded. So this is a popular place.    There is a nice gift shop downstairs.

Beautiful art collection!. This is a wide-ranging and well displayed art collection, stretching from ancient Egypt to the early 20th Century. It is fairly evident that Gulbenkian had very good taste as far as art is concerned! Highly recommended for art lovers visiting Lisbon!

Fascinating exhibits beautifully displayed. One of the best designed museums I have seen and every exhibit made me think or feel something. A modern, single-storey building with plain walls throws all the emphasis on the exhibits. The highlights for me were the jewellery and glassware in the Lalique Room, the Pre-Raphaelite paintings, the Turners, the impressionists, the Ming vases, the Iznik tiles and the centuries old carpets. Many museums pour an avalanche of exhibits over the visitor but here the spaciousness adds to the intensity of your reactions to what you see. The museum cafe is good value, serving croissants to main meals. Easy to get to by Metro. Definitely worth a visit.
Small is beautiful ! . A lovely place. Small but good collection. The gardens are the best and, of course , the famous Lalique collection! It pays the trip !

One of the best Museums I have been to. I was told about this museum a few years ago as a must see in Lisbon. Although this museum is not so known about around the world I must say I travel to many places and this is one of the best museums I have been to. It is relatively small. It took approx. one and a half hours to get around and is full of treasures. This is a private collection. I took a few friends there and they were blown away by this Little Gem. Highly recommended.

A collection of masterpieces. A very high quality accessible collection. Because is smaller and not stuffed with lower quality fillers can really spend time enjoying the items without the pressure to move on because in larger museums there is so much to get through.This museum reminded me of the Getty in LA. It runs from Egyptian to carpets, pottery and painting. Each section is quite small but each item is fantastic. Some staggeringly beautiful pieces to enjoy. Set out in a modern easy to navigate building. Really enjoyed my visit. Good food for the soul.Had lunch in the cafeteria which was fine.

Amazing personal collection. What an amazing personal collection that this person amassed. A wide variety from many periods. It is a real deal at 5 euros. To top it off we happened to go on a Sunday and it was totally free.
History through the aged. There was many exhibits to see ...the paintings, articles and objects were so well displayed and written in English ...Very interesting and well worth a visit

Museum Lover's Paradise. What a gorgeous museum in an amazing park setting! Even if you do not like museums' please visit the park in which this museum is built. It is free to visit the grounds. The contemporary building that houses the museum and the landscape around the museum are as interesting as the museum. The collection is expansive as is the building but easy to understand and very pleasant to be in. You are not overwhelmed. There is enough space between the works so that you can view and enjoy each piece. Excellent experience.

€5 down th e toilet. At least I didn't pay the full 16! Go to the Berardo for free instead.. No wonder you can't find the price on their website- 16 euros for the whole collection. Yet somehow the Berardo Collection is bigger, better, and free. I elected to pay for the modern section, and was rewarded with a sinking feeling in the pit of my stomach. I felt like a sucker. The disappointment on the faces of the people leaving should have been a clue. It seems they can throw any old crap in a museum and people will leave good reviews. If I went on a free Sunday I may have gotten my moneys worth, but not my time's. The garden was nice (and free) though.

Great collection. From Egyptian,Asian and Roman artifacts to french17 and 18 th century decorative arts , Mister Gulbenkian had a very special eye for high quality. Don't forget the special Lalique collection with some stunning pieces!Although the museum has not changed much ( was there 9 years ago and it is exactly the same) their collection is one to be seen!

Fabulous museum, beautiful gardens and a very good restaurant for lunch. The museum was fabulous. I particularly liked the 18th century furniture. But the 8th century Muslim glass, the Middle-eastern carpets and the pottery were beautiful too. Since we are seniors (over 65) the entrance fee was very low, I seem to remember EUR 2.50 per person.The grounds were gorgeous, with flower gardens and water fowl, and we were pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food in the small restaurant on the grounds.The museum shop has items by local artists, and for a very reasonable price, one can find nice presents to take home.The museum is located where two tourist bus routes intersect. We were there on a very rainy day. We took the bus through the North part of the city, got off at the museum and then took the other bus to Belen. In spite of the rain, we had a great time!
Outstanding collection. Outstanding collection of one man of the highest quality. Coins, carpets, pottery, sculptures, and impressionist paintings of the highest quality. Beautiful!!! A gem.

If you like design, you will love this museum. This museum is a little out of the way, but with Lisbon's excellent subway system, you can be there in no time. This is an outstanding Museum and a testament to one person's keen need to collect the best examples of a range of arts and their influence on Portuguese culture. The carpets and the tiles are simply spectacular - and with a photo-positive approach (no flash) you will bring back these wonderful designs to your home to marvel about the intricacies of the work at your leisure. The museum sits in a garden, one that his shared with the Art Museum. The garden stroll readies you for the excellent displays within. Do not miss this treat.
Nice collection . Nice collection from many continents, from Egypt to asia, I particularly have enjoyed the French collection of painting, silver objects and furniture (desk, cupboard,...)

Don't Miss It!. We are so lucky that this Wonderful private art collection was donated to the public. The art spans over 5,000 years. The collection includes furniture, master paintings, sculpture and middle eastern art. The small cafeteria has wonderful food. There is a small museum shop.

Underwhelming. I was surprised to find that a major art museum in Lisbon was so ... ordinarily boring: some Egyptian, a couple of Rembrandts, a few pieces by impressionists, two - three Rodine sculptures - a standard collection that a middle-sized city can boast about, but I expected more from this one. The adjacent garden is wonderful: serene, beautiful ponds and sculptures, well planned and masterfully executed. I would skip the museum and just walk in the garden. The latter is free.

Fabulous collection. This collection is well worth a visit as it represents the very varied cultural interests of Calouste Gulbenkian.The foundation also presents concerts of classical music which are excellent.

Enjoyable Museum. This is really a great museum to visit. It contains Oriental and Classic art as well as European art. There are paintings and statues throughout. There are areas containing rugs from Turkey, Iran, and other parts of the Middle East. There is pottery from China and items from Japan. The European section contains furniture dating back centuries. We visited this place on a Sunday afternoon and it was enjoyable. We had lunch in the cafeteria and the food was quite good.

Um dos melhores lugares de Lisboa . Such a wonderful and well maintained garden. The museum is worth visiting, with a splendid collection. Lovely place. Having lunch at the canteen is a good option as the food is inexpensive and nice.

Amazing collection. This museum has an outstanding collection of art, crockery, sculptures, clocks... you name it. Very well organised and displayed. The audio-guides come in handy to know intimate details of each piece. Give yourself a minimum of three hours to do justice to the major part of the exhibits.

FANTASTIC Museum BUT… at what cost !?. Everything has been bought & payed for from commissions from wheeling & dealing w/ oil & all it entails of human misery, wars, destruction, etc…Is there enough make-up to make a rotting corpse look desirable ?Because that's what this collection REALLY is :Badly applied make up, in the hope you don't see how much it all has really cost to mankind !!As if not enough they are preparing to do the same in the Algarve, risking - just like THAT.. - the livelihoods of hundreds of thousands. Criminal ? I'd say..But then, a bird can't change it's feathers even if it wanted to & all that is born crooked will never grow straightRot in hell Gulbenkian !

An Absolute Gem!. Museu da Fundacao Calouste Gulbenkian is an absolute gem of a museum. What a tremendous collection, and to think it was one wealthy man's personal collection is mind-boggling. For history or art lovers, this collection is not to be missed. The collection literally reads like a who's who of art history.

It is a must. Whenever in Lisbon do not miss a visit to this museum and its outstanding collection of works of art from Eastern and Western. Don't miss the gold Egyptian mummy mask, After enjoying the magnificent art collection, stroll along the beautifully tended gardens. The museum closes on Tuesdays.Also visit the Modern Art Centre, containing modern and contemporary Portuguese and foreign art.

Extraordinary and eclectic collection. I planned to spend two hours here and ended up spending about four fascinating hours , admiring this beautiful, beautiful collection -- so well displayed and written up. It is varied and interesting, and will surely widen anyone's understanding of visual and fine arts. Portugal is so fortunate to have this collection available to its citizens.The gardens and cafe are worth a visit too. The museum shop has exquisite reproductions for sale -- great gifts for those special people in your life.Easily reached by Metro . Visits are free.

Art, music, great garden. I live in Lisbon. Whenever my "Australian" son comes home with family, Gulbenkian Museum, garden and self service restaurant are "must go's" at least twice or three times. The museum and the modern art gallery are very good. The performances and temporary exhibitions are always of top quality, surely a safe value. For Lisboners, it's also a place to study, to read, to relax, to enjoy a nice meal. The garden has a great original design, was recently very well redesigned and is very well cared of. I love it.

Fascinating museum. I'll start with a warning... If you are going by metro, be prepared to ask a local for directions, as the signage seemed to disappear as I left the station. However, the museum was definitely worth the effort - it is set in a beautiful garden. The building itself is very simple and spacious. The collection is laid out in groups eg European art, Turkish ceramics etc. All the labels are in English and Portuguese, so you don't really need an audio guide. The exhibits are beautiful. Definitely worth visiting, whether it is to escape the heat of the sun, or the rain!

Incredible collection. The collection in this museum has a little bit of everything. The number of different pieces from east to west, old to relatively new has something which will interest everyone.There are a couple of paintings by Turner which were highlights for me but there are many other items to go and see.We went on a Sunday (when the museum has free entry). We didn't have lots of time so decided against an audio guide. We also didn't have the chance to look round the gift shop or café so I can't comment on those aspects.One thing that did strike me about the museum though is that the building itself is a little dated. Perhaps we are fortunate that museums now such as the Tate in London or MOMA in New York have loads of natural light. The Gulbenkian museum is all ground floor and surrounded by a lovely garden. This however means there is not much natural light so it seems a bit dark. Only a minor comment.If you are into museums and enjoy a broad spectrum, I would recommend a visit here.

An incredible privately owned art collection. Fascinating that one man can leave his entire art.collection of over 6 000 pcs to the Portuguese nation who were so welcoming when he had to flee from Paris in the war. 1200 pcs are on exhibit here and you will.see the best of European and eastern art. Best 5 Euro ever spent! Worth getting the audio for the extra info.
Great collection. Great collection. Brilliantlyrics displayed. Super gardens. Good cafeteria. Collection broad not deep.

A simply amazing museum . It is listed as one of the best in Lisbon for very good reasons. The museum has examples of quality pieces of art from a number of eras. We especially liked the manets, and Rembrandts. We will order a book of the collection.

An astonishing collection. Eclectic, the collection gathers art pieces originating from all over the world. The centuries il covers and the various schools of art it presents recogniza the richness and the evolution of mankind.

An world-class art collection set in a parkland landscape. Opened in 1969 in the Parque de Santa Gertrudes, following an international design competition won by a team that included architects Alberto J. Pessoa, Pedro Cid and Ruy Jervis d'Athouguia (1917-2006) with the landscaping architects António Viana Barreto and Gonçalo Ribeiro Telles, the building is very much of its era, slightly brutalist in character. The Calouste Gulbenkian Collection is very comprehensive including ancient works from Greece, Egypt, Assyria and the Middle East with quite a large focus on ceramics including from China and a good display of early illustrated books, followed by European art and a strong collection of French 18th century furniture and decorative arts including a room dedicated to the glasswork of Lalique and other displays of silver and ivories. The art collection is world-class and certainly worth visiting; the lighting and the heavy 1960’s emphasis on concrete and timber creates a slightly monotonous interior which does the artwork no favours and it is a relief to see the outside park through some of the windows, when conservation considerations allow.
Worth a visit. Great value for money. 5 euros to wonder this private collection, beautifully presented pieces. Would definitely recommend a few hours spent here.

Wonderful atmosphere and great art. A really great collection - archaeological artifacts through to 19th century. Couple of Rodins, couple of Turners, Gainsborough all very well selected. Collection of middle eastern rugs. In contrast to the rest of Lisbon there is a distinct lack of tiles ;) An inspiring afternoon and all for EUR 5.

all kind of art. you will see the private collection of one man that loved art. there are paintings, art objects, jewlery, porcelain, furniture and much more things to see, each one very beautiful. is impressive what collection could one man gather in his life time.

Interesting museum, manageable size. Enjoyed this museum very much. We visited with our two young children and were able to see most of the museum before their attention spans expired! One minor annoyance was that they ran out of audio guides despite the fact that it wasn't an overly busy day at the museum. Also, not that you go to a museum for the food, but the cafeteria here was above average for a museum which was a bonus. Would recommend spending a half day here if you are staying in Lisbon for more than a few days. If you're in Lisbon for a short stay, would recommend spending your time exploring the neighbourhoods of Lisbon instead.

Eclectic collection in beautiful grounds. Calouste Gulbenkian collected a broad range of beautiful things. This spacious gallery honours that collection in a lovely setting. It is a must for anyone visiting Lisbon.

Eclectic collection of everything and anything. If you are mostly interested in paintings and other objet's d'art, you will not find overly much to look at here. But if you like furniture, porcelain and rugs also, you can feast your eyes on an abundance of collectibles.

Expecting more to see, and actually mostly related to Portugal/Lisbon history.. It's interesting but definitely not a must for tourist in Portugal. As a traveler I have seen much more and richer collection of art. It's nice but not if you have just several days and limited time for museums.
Very interesting!. We liked a lot to visit it. Too bad that there is no way marked in the floor to have a guided visit... we got lost sometimes.

Wonderful museum packed with history. Wide variety of interesting items to see, furniture, paintings, books, all fascinating; Lalique jewellery especially pretty and a delight. Delicious food in cafe but had to queue for ages on a Sunday.

Fansinating museum. It's hard to believe that one person could have collected all he did and with so much variety of items, countries, and time periods. The museum is laid out with plenty of room to stand back and take in the huge wall scenes of tiles, carpets, tapestries, etc. And then you can get close to the coin collections, plates, vases, jewelry, etc.

Beautiful collection. This museum mostly holds one man's art collection (Calouste Gulbenkian) Therefore my husband and I were surprised at finding so many beautiful pieces of art especially from Asia and Europe. The ancient Egyptian, Greek and Roman pieces were also very interesting. This collection also includes books, furniture, costumes, precious objects and jewelry. The museum is not too large so we were able to see everything without tiring. I also appreciated how the pieces were arranged and displayed. We highly recommend a visit!

Loved this museum!. small and very beautiful museum! The collection is remarkable all very beautiful pieces. You can sense that they were picked for a collector. I really enjoyed the textiles and carpets. The paintings were also amazing. The Degas and Monet paintings are some of the most beautiful I have ever seen. I would highly recommend this museum!

Small, but excellent art museum.. The exhibits were all owned by Mr. Gulbenkian, so it is huge for a private collection, but smaller for an art museum. However, the items are absolutely of the highest quality and some are the best examples I have ever seen. The lighting and display treatments are excellent. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit.
Fascinating. One man's collection that he gifted to Lisbon because they sheltered him during the war. Displayed beautifully. Such a variety of items.
Very nice modern art museum.. We really liked the modern art in this museum. They house works from a range of local and international artists. The cafe and surrounding gardens are also nice.
Amazing. We were intrigued by the personality of Calouste Gulbenkian, and would like to discover his vast collection of antiquities, paintings and works by Lalique
A good museum. From the earliest trinkets of ancient civilizations to 20th century painting from throughout Europe, this collection is nice and not too big.

A Nice Museum. This museum has some very interesting and ancient works that are wonderfully presented. It also has a Monet painting of a winter scene that was absolutely stunning. We didn't go to the modern section, so I can't comment on that.
The complex is set in a nice park.

High quality art collection from Ancient Egypt to Impressionism and Lalique Art Deco . For those who prefer quality to quantity: amazing modern building with garden packed with chef d'oeuvres from different time periods which do not make you feel tired or culturally overdosed )))

Worth the trip to see it!!!. We visited earlier this month on a Sunday. It's free on Sunday's and something to remember. My wife loves the impressionist artists and loves Claude Monet's works. We did get to see several items by him. There are many, many more masterpieces displayed here at the Gulbenkian by western European artists such as Rubens, Rembrandt, Rodin, Renoir, Van Dyck, Degas, Édouard Manet,, and Thomas Gainsborough, to name only a few! You won't be disappointed! Take plenty of non-flash photos too! Well worth an hour or two to visit this museum!
amazing exhbhitons and amazing building. gulbenkien is my favorite modern art museum, discrete, elegante and vey charming, the gardens are trully amazing, the permanent exibhition is trully great

Great Gulbenkian!. A bit out of the way but you will not be disappointed with the wonderful collection! A bit of this and a bit of that: Persina Rugs,Roman artifacts, Chinese vases,Classic paintings,Egyptian artifacts,furniture.. quite an eclectic collection. Surrounded by a beautiful park. Go on Sundays when it's free admission.
Excellent. My wife loves art and thinks this is one of the best museums we have visited. Well chosen items. The highlight of our trip to Lisbon. I posted some pictures of a few of the pieces.

A Small Gem. A quiet refreshing way to spend an hour or so next to the beautiful park. There is a good collection of textiles, tiles, in addition to the expected museum displays of paintings, sculptures, silver and earthenware. A small group of hair ornaments are quite exquisite.

Great variety on display. Had earmarked this museum as one not to miss and was delighted with the great mix of exhibits on show.A pity that some floors were being renovated while I was there, but there was still so much to enjoy.The staff there was really helpful too.I found the Gulbenkian a little difficult to get to but well worth the effort.Charge was very reasonable too.

a must do. I enjoyed this collection with some very special Lalique pieces, some key Impressionist paintings as well as a Rembrandt and many unique Asian and Middle Eastern pieces of art. The museum is surrounded by lovely gardens that offer a break from the city. it is also possible to get something to eat & drink there.

Interesting Collection. Poor signage from the metro,as mentioned by previous reviewer, but well worth a visit. Being a collection, it's very mixed which can be a refreshing change from visiting exhibitions.

Eclectic museum. It is a bit out of central Lisbon, but on a metro line and well worth a visit. The exhibits are excellently presented and cover a wide range of styles. The building itself is a 60s style concrete structure not unlike the South Bank, but inside there is ample room and good lighting

Sober, interesting and rich as you would never imagine!. Besides the obvious part of the building itself, the gardens and the amphitheater, the colection is a wonder from the furniture to paintings, from asian treasures to egitian and persian tiles and carpets.Free admission on sundays and a coffeeshop and the museum shop waiting for you!

A well set out and varied collection. The Museum is based on the private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian and is housed in a complex that includes the headquarters of the foundation, a concert hall, a modern art museum and a garden. It is a short walk from the Sao Sebastiao Metro but with a surprising lack of signage to direct you. The first part of the complex you arrive at from the Metro is the Modern Art Gallery and there is no indication that this is not the main Museum - we bought tickets after indicating we wanted the main Gulbenkian gallery and were then directed out of that building and through the gardens. We ended up in the concert hall building and were then directed through that to the art gallery. Having eventually arrived, the museum was very nicely laid out leading from Egyptian artifacts, through Greek and Islamic art to decorative tiles, 19th Century art and Louis XV and XVI furniture to a small Lalique collection which together with the tiles was the highlight for me. All in all it was a varied and intersting collection which I thought was very well displayed. There is a cafe downstairs although we did not stop there having had a hearty breakfast before visiting the gallery. However, the prices seemed very reasonable with plenty on offer. All in all a very pleasant couple of hours.
Lot's of Tile. Do this tour if you have a special interest. This was a haphazard display of the tile making tradition famous in Portugal. Interesting for the uninitiated, but not a must see.

Like a John Lewis showroom for antiques!. Great artifacts displayed in a sixties architectural box.So much space to see the great collections of eastern, Arabian and French origin. Topped off by a fab display of Lalique Glass's and jewellery. The guy had good taste, and a lot of money!The space inside is stunning, and beautifully calm.Cafe/restaurant was a bit 70s in more ways than one, but had good coffee, and a great outside space.
Excellent collection and well presented. The museum was well planned and contained a great collection. Not too big and very good value at 5Euro.

Another reason to vote Brexit?. Little or no signage from the metro station, coupled with the near useless small scale maps on offer from the tourist office meant it was a little hard to find. Imagine getting out of the tube at Russell Square and there being no signs to the British Museum! You can't , can you? Well, that's what our Portuguese friends manage to do with the Gulbenkian! It's a wonder anyone goes there at all. Especially when, as we found out and contrary to all the guide books, it's actually shut on the day we tried to visit--a Tuesday!!.Intriguing to see that the Gulbenkian "administration block" next door to the museum is about 10 times bigger than the museum itself. More to do with jobs for the boys (and girls) than anything to do with curatorial needs , I think . If this wasn't Portugal, I would suspect "Spanish practices" at play here.

Stunning Collection. Well worth a visit but please note the museum is now closed on Tuesdays!It is open all weekend and on Mondays, but not on Tuesdays.The cafe in the grounds to the south of the museum is also very good and the staff are very friendly!

More than a great collection, a very pleasant park - hidden in the city centre!. Mr. Calouste Gulbenkian was a remarkable and generous man and, through his foundation, not only the Portuguese, but everyone who visits Portugal, can enjoy (usually, for free) a lot of artistic and cultural expressions, while relaxing at the Museum's park (a small paradise, hidden in Lisbon's centre). It's a very safe place to visit solo, or with family (children or elders) or friends, colleagues, etc.

Great Place to Visit.. A worthwhile visit when you are in Lisbon and love history. You will see the old maps of the first voyages to the New World, beautiful porcelain from China and lots of other artifacts from around the world. Whilt you are there, visit the gardens which are just beautiful especially in the Spring.

Excellent collection, nicely presented!. Very much enjoyed all this museum and the property is sit on. Lovely green space and duck ponds. Modern museum building with excellent collections and multi-lingual narrative (EN, POR, SP) on much of the art work. Great visit for a rainy day!

Portugal symphony orchestra rocks!. The maestrina, as Joana Carneiro is called, conducted this excellent orchestra in a 1-hour, 3-piece performance, featuring a world renowned marimba player (surname Diaz) -- she conducted with her whole body and heart, it was inspirational to watch AND listen in the gorgeous, large auditorium of the Gulbekian. The seats are among the most comfortable I've experienced in any concert hall, and the audience for the Sunday concert (only 10€) included dozens of children, including babies and toddlers -- and there was not a single breakdown or meltdown. Whatever Portuguese parents are doing should be patented... But back to the Gulbekian. After the concert I visited the museum, which is free on Sundays. A magnificent collection of middle eastern and Asian art is perfectly displayed, with signs in Portuguese and English. Among the European items, the Rene Lalique jewelry and ornaments collection is a standout. But whatever your taste, there's something to oooh and aaahh over here.

Wonderful experience. There are a lot of beautiful exhibits there and you can easily spend long hours walking round and looking at the examples of fine art. My personal favourite was a collection of works of Rene Lalique. Truly exquisite pieces!

Guided Tours on Monday morning. This is a superb collection - Gainsborough, Turner, Monet, Rembrandt were all there along with Lalique and a most fabulous collection of French Jewellery. They do guided tours on a Monday morning, only 8euro, and if we return to Lisbon that will be high on our list. Be aware, they are closed on Tuesday.

Top notch, don't miss. Without rehashing all the other great reviews, it was great! If you like beautiful things you could easily spend 3 hours here. Be aware that the entrance is on Berna 3 blocks west of Campo Pequeno. If the weather allows stroll through the extensive gardens. We had a nice meal at the cafe. Around the corner facing west is the Modern Art Museum (you can get a combo ticket). Right next to this building is the concert hall where we were lucky enough to see the world famous Gulbenkian orchestra one evening.

Spectacular. One of the best private art collections I have ever seen. Every piece is an excellent representation of its kind. From Middle Eastern artwork, to the largest collection of Guardi I know of, to an amazing room filled with Rene Lalique jewelry...this museum is not to be missed.

Unique collection, not to be missed. This collection of fine and decorative arts must be one of the most fabulous private collections. Gulbenkian was obviously rich, had a great eye for art and a pathological hoarder. Fortunately his collection was preserved after his death in 1955 rather than broken up. It comprises antiquities, Islamic art, European particularly French art and furniture and is topped off with a room of Rene Lalique glass. The museum is easy to find, metro stop San Sebastián. Don't miss it.

Selected collection of great artworks; Intimate and very conducive to appreciating art. We visited the musuem early Friday afternoon and it was free of crowds. Excellent collection of Alexander the Great gold coins, tapestry, fabric, Chinese and Japanese porcelain/pottery, furniture, paintings and sculpture. The displays are well curated with very choice pieces from Rembrandt, Rodin, etc. The smaller displays and more intimate layout also encourage better appreciation of the pieces - and each one deserve appreciation because of the artistry and talent behind them. Definitely a good place to spend an afternoon - maybe sketch, look and just soak up all the beauty in this place.

Just Right. For me, this is the perfect museum: not a vast warehouse, but an excellent, eclectic collection that can be enjoyed in a short afternoon. From East to West, and from ancient coins to European masters, everything was a pleasure. Rembrandt's Portrait of an Old Man held me for a long time. It's a short walk from the São Sebastião metro station. Only 5€.

Great Museum. We enjoyed an early morning visit to this great museum, which was free of crowds as we were some of the first through the door when it opened at 10:00The exhibits are well laid out in a lovely building

Attractive museum in a stunning building surrouned by a relaxing green park. Beautiful museum not for from the Eduardo VII park where you can find Rembrandt, Van Dyck, Rubens, ... in a unique and impressive building. There is a coffee bar in the museum. The museum is located in a beautiful green area not far from a modern art museum. If you are Belgian, the memorial of the poet Herman De Coninck is nearby (Rua Marques de Sa da Bandeiro 74)
Great collection. Both my husband and I really enjoyed this museum. It is nicely laid out and isn't nearly as overwhelming as many other museums. The audio guide is also worth getting.

great place and ok museum. This museum has a permanent exhibition that features art from many different countries and eras, all part of the foundation and his founder Mr. Gulbenkian.As for the exhibition it is good although not spectacular since you see so many different common and not so common objects that in the end none of them really impress.However the gardens, the building and the surroundings are well worth a visit: they are a great getaway from the city rush, like an oasis in the middle of Lisbon.
Amazing!. One of the best museums ever! It's not centrally located but it's definitely worth visiting. Impressive collection!

Peaceful and full of beautiful things. €5 and 2 hours well spent - a quiet building within nice gardens houses a very varied collection of intricate decorative objects. These range from egyptian figurines to elaborate page decorations in the koran to paintings by Turner, Monet, Manet, Renoir and so on.

One of the best small museums I've visited. This museum is a little bit out of the centre but well worth the visit. Full of beautiful ceramics, carpets, artwork from Turkey and the East. A stunning collection that is very easy to walk round in a couple of hours. We spent much longer there than we intended - if it hadn't been raining we would have explored the lovely gardens too. The Modern Art Museum on the same site is worth a visit if it's your type of thing.
Very Accessible Museum/Art Gallery. Some amazing art here from ancient Egypt to the paintings of great artists including Rembrandt, Rubens, Monet and Manet.

Gulbenkian - Very choice collection. Lovely setting with some excellent choice selections of material across many centuries. The collection is not large but is in many instances definitive. There is a collection of Roman Coins that are in mint condition and show the excellence of the original casting in a way I have see nowhere else. Some of the chinese collections is unique. Visit on Sunday, it's free. and there are some cool duck habitats around the entrance pathways.
Cheap Museum. As it only costs 5 euros this is worth visiting. If you are into looking at ancient objects in cabinets, this is worth visiting. We found the paintings the most interesting.

A museum that should be more widely known than it is, a true hidden gem!. Located away from the tourist crowds but a short walk from a metro station you need to pay a visit. The museum contains art from most periods and many major artists are represented. The museum is not that crowded which is a shame for the quality of works. Also the museum shop was the best I have seen, it only contains items based on pieces in the collection! Normally 5 Euro, admission was free when we visited on a Sunday. Also a handy cafe with good prices allows for a nice afternoon break.

All kind of art. I visited this museum over twenty years ago and it was excitinlg to visit it again. I remenbered the the old books and their amazing pictures and it was the same. There was not any changing exhibition but neverthess is worth of visiting. Old art, islamic and chinese art. furniture etc.

A must when you are in Lisbon. The Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation is a major cultural institution including many varied activities.It´s located in a beautiful park just in the centre of the city. There´s also an independent building boasting modern art works. Although the collections are outstanding, as contemporary art leaves me cold in most cases, unless you are really into it, I would recommend go straight and visit the building devoted to antique art, especially if you are short of time.I´m sure you will love this unique private collection. There are lots of pieces on display, some of them very old, others up to the nineteenth century, including Oriental and European art. The Oriental art was what I liked most, but everything is outstanding and varied.No only the contents, the building itself deserves a comment. It was built in the 60s I think in the brutalist style so common then, concrete walls and wooden floors abound. But is perfectly adapted to the contents, it has a somehow winding labyrinthic layout, spotted with small garden patios, as different rooms are connected not in a linear way. Nice atmosphere: quiet and relaxing place, soft lights. It makes a big difference to other major european museums which are a bit overwhelming with so many huge rooms covered with so many works on display and with so many people everywhere. Gulbenkian offers a slow paced and relaxing experience, considering the collection is big but not huge, and most of all, varied.One advantage is the ticket price, just 5 euros, and there is a shop, a library and a decent cafetería that is not the rip-off you would expect in this kind of place.It definitely is one cultural strong point of this incredible city.
Magnificent collection of Fine Arts. Museum and Park, built to receive a magnificent collection of Art belonging to Calouste Gulbenkian, an Armenian refugee .
Nice collection and museum. There is a very beautiful collection in this museum. It's interesting to see how objects are exhibited

Well worth the visit. Plenty to see, especially for the price (€5), with a varied selection of exhibits. Nice to see the cafe isn't the normal museum rip-off. 5 minutes from metro, well worth half a day visit

Phenomenal Museum. Gulbenkian was a phenomenal collector and we were so thrilled to see his collections. The museum is made up of collections of art, rugs, fabrics, antiquities, paintings, jewelry, tiles, sculpture, and furniture. Each piece in the museum is outstanding. It is located in a beautiful contemporary building near the Eduard VII park just north of the Avenida de Liberadade area.

Outstanding. The Best sight in Lisboa: an impressive collection of art - islamic and European: Rembrandt, Rubens,Manet, Degas, Guardi, Turner, Nattier, Rodin are represented as well as ceramics,silver, tapetries and wonderful Lalique jewels - all collected by the Oil magnate Calouste Gulkerkian, WHO was once considered one of the richest men in the world

High point of our trip. Closed every Tuesday! We made that mistake and arrived a day early. Anyway when we got there on Wednesday it was so worth the return visit. Our first stop was the cafe for a quick coffee and obligatory cake to give us energy. It seems that locals go to the museum purely for the cafe - the food and prices are astonishing. We had two coffees and cakes for about £3.50 then later we had an excellent canteen style lunch with deserts for about £13 for both of us - best value for money anywhere. I digress - the collection is housed in a different building to the one where we entered - the Modern Art section - so we made our way through the beautifully designed gardens to the main building. We loved the architecture of the place - mid century and a bit brutalist but really interestingly done. The gardens knocked spots off the Lisbon Botanical gardens in terms of being well cared for and a pleasant place to hang out. There were loads of walkways and seating areas - I expect it would be perfect for escaping the summer heat. The exhibits were just beautiful - I spent a lot of time sketching designs from ceramic pots and looking in awe at the skills of the artists and artisans. The exhibits were well laid out and annotated in English and Portuguese. I think we spent about 2 and a half hours there then went back to the modern art collection. We didn't enjoy the exhibition at all - one or two interesting pieces maybe, but to us phillistines there was quite a bit of stuff we really didn't understand at all. The exhibition space was great and interesting to walk around. Also, I can't remember ever being in such well appointed lavatories - huge and with bidets! Really worth a visit and allow extra time for the gardens and cafes.

The best museum of Portugal. This is an extraordinry museum in the center of Lisbon. We went there by metro. It is an impressive collection of art of different cultures of the world. Probably it's the biggest museum of Portugal with great collections of classical greco, roman, egypt, asian and european art. It's like taking a ride around the diverse expressions of art in the world.

Incredible show of mind-blowing wealth. Fabulous collection of artworks and antiquities from around the world. It's an eclectic mix of paintings, furniture, ceramics, fabrics, coins, sculpture.... whatever took this phenomenally rich man's fancy. A fascinating and mind-blowing collection.

Stunning. Quality artefacts on display ,uncluttered & able to be viewed from many angles Mainly chronological order with the early Egyptian exhibits of the highest quality ,breathtaking.Excellent value as OAPs are entitled to a 50% reduction on non free days, but the normal fee is a very modest 5 Euros each.A wonderful visit.

Lovely Museum. This is not the largest display for a capital city but the quality is incredible. All the exhibits are very well displayed and labled. The ivory diptychs and triptychs are amazing - so intricate. The museum is set in a lovely little park with ducks, geese and terrapins around the ponds.

Really interesting. A really cool museum, near a metro, filled with trinkets and artefacts from all over the world. Also set in gorgeous botanical gardens. And the cafe is lovely. Only 5 Euro! Not to be missed!

Extraordinary: Enormous collection, beautiful park.. It is placed a little outside the center, so a taxi (cheap in Lisboa) or other transport is necessary. It is not possible to view the whole collection in one day, so we concentrated on the special collection just now: The English Collection, which was lovely with a lot of high class works. Later the European part of the museum, enormous, with exciting works from many periods. Later on some food in the very good café, and a stroll in the lovely park area. Gulbenkian was an armenian billionaire, making mostly his money on oil. He give this collection to Lisboa.

Eclectic Permanent Exhibition. The museum houses two "collections", Classical Greco Roman and European Art. Therefore are exquisite sculptures, gold, silver and decorative objects. The Lalique collection of glass and jewels are fabulous. It even has the most amazing tapestry worked with gold and silver thread!!!

Museum, but not only.... As a museum it is a fabulous private collection. Not possible to compare with the great museums of the world, but it is definitely worth a visit. Besides it is surrounded by a beautiful and relaxing garden, I would say maybe the best or at least one of the best in Lisbon
Us other good Lisbon activity. A nice selection of things to see and a good indoor rainy day activity. Good for solo, couples or family interested in culture.

A true gem. We visited the museum with our teenage sons and were a bit worried how will they take on... There was no need! The collection is so nice that everyone could find something to admire. We enjoyed our day and recommend visiting the museum. The gardens are beautiful as well - we spent the whole afternoon there taking photos.

Incredible. Free on Sundays, it is cheap at other times.
This is one of the most amazing personal collections in the world.
The items range from a asSyrian antiquity to Modern times and the standard is invariably of the highest.
Great paintings and artifacts at the Gulbenkian museum. Fantastic paintings and artifacts.. You can get 15% off on big bus tickets.. tickets are not too expensive.

Amazing!. I would consider myself a connoisseur of museums, a former art history major. This is a true gem. The quote stating that Gulbanian only collect the best of the best - is a truism. Well displayed and well organized. Not too large to overwhelm.

Excellent museum. This is a great rainy day activity. The most amazing thing was that this collection was all owned by one amazing man. Wide variety of items - Chinese pottery, Lalique glass and jewellery, art (including 2 Rembrandts, Turners, impressionists etc), Iznik tiles, Egyption, Roman and Greek artifacts... The list goes on.And a very nice cafe, with the best custard tarts we've had so far (we haven't been to Pasteis de Belem yet).

Spectacular Museum and Collection. I spend almost 2 hours here - it is beautiful! The variety and different antiquities here were fascinating. I learned things about textiles and other art that I did not know. I highly recommend this museum.

An Armenian gift. A trip to Lisbon must include a visit to the Gulbenkian. There is always something contemporary to view and the permanent display of furniture and classic collection of marvelous pieces from Egypt and Greece a wonderful paradox.. The feeling of education is also great and children will love to interact in the way the museum allows. The building is as unLisbon as one can see when you arrive but inside the objet d'art are well worth the visit,

An interesting place to visit . This museum is really interesting. It has a lot of stuff that you can see. There are things from all around the world and all of them are old. So if you love old stuff then you better visit this museum.

Best museum in Iberia?. I was hesitant to believe Rick Steves and Frommers that this was a museum on which to sacrifice precious Lisbon time. In Madrid everyone has heard of the Prado, so you go. And it is a great museum. Well Rick and Frommers are professionals and by golly, this is a really fine museum for two reasons. 1. Contents and 2. The building itself.Don't go for the Impressionists. Very limited painting selection. Go for, and this is something I am not really interested in, the Egyptian, Greco-Roman, and Mesopotamia/Islam section of the building. Wow. Really fine and beautiful specimens. Best quality and beauty I have seen all in an exquisite setting. The Two Rembrandt's are awfully nice too. But this earlier era of art is astounding. Then at the end of this wing of the museum is the best exhibit of art nouveau jewelry I have seen. Twenty or more pieces, each a masterpiece.It is a simple Metro ride out to Sao Sebastian station on the blue line. Exit Aguiera Avenue and walk down hill keeping an eye out to your right. Tucked in you will see the Museum's signage.wayne iNLIsboa

Wonderful and varied collection. Very interesting museum (only 5 Euros entry). It's well laid out (natural flow takes you around the rooms) with a very varied collection of artefacts, pottery, paintings, sculptures, murals, etc over a wide range of centuries. The café downstairs is very pleasant. Easy to reach from Sao Sebastiao metro.
Stunning Islamic art. A wonderful personal collection full of beautiful things: carpets, tiles, cloth, and manuscripts. It also has a very enjoyable collection of European art.

Delightful. This museum is gorgeous. It has a good mix for those interested in fine art, ceramics, furniture, textiles and religious artefacts. It's very good value for money and is very doable in a couple of hours.

Well worth a visit. It doesn't look very far out of the city centre so we walked - a mistake in the heat. Take the underground. The museum is well worth a visit with a fantastic selection of paintings, textiles, ceramics and jewellery. The grounds are also worth taking in. A place to visit if you are wanting to escape the heat, or rain? Or if you just need to lift your spirits

Good cafeteria, delightful museum. We had lunch here on our first day in Lisbon after flying from Edinburgh. The basement cafeteria queue moved very slowly (Sunday lunchtime). But the food was good, the selection fine, and the price very reasonable. And we enjoyed the museum afterwards.

Gulbenkian Museum. Amazing collection of objects by one man. Ranges from Egyptian to 1930's. Pottery, paintings, sculpture, furniture, jewellery/ my favourite was the Lalique collection of Art Deco jewellery. A bonus was great food in the museum restaurant at reasonable prices - sitting outside in the lovely landscaped garden

Lisbon's Gem of a Museum. The Museum was built with the private art collection of the highly influential Calouste Gulbekian, an Armenian oil magnate who called Lisbon home. The gardens around the museum are wonderful to walk through, the art collection is hugely international and varied in material, epoch and nature. I could not recommend this museum more highly. Oh and the café and restaurant have a large patio that spills into the gardens.

Astounding and well worth a visit.. We made a mad dash to get to this place before closing time and we were so glad we did. Neither of us really care about museums but the exhibits here are wonderful. Nothing is behind glass or too distant to see and the range is all encompassing: jewellery, paintings, embroidery, statues, period furniture and old clocks all still working! Go on a Sunday when entrance is free and also take time to enjoy the gardens.

A Beautiful Place to Visit. This intimate museum is a delight. It is wonderful to have a private collector's lifetime achievment made available to the public. The surrounding garden is tanquil and worth a wander on a hot summers day.There is a couple of little gift shops with some qualty things for sale.The Cafe is OK but I would find somewhere else to eat when visiting Lisbon as there are thousands of more traditional places. I am also pretty sure it has free entry before midday on Sundays, like a lot of the city's Museums.

A Hidden Gem, could have spent all day there. We visitied on a Sunday and found to our surprise the museum was free. The halls are light and tranquil and it's very easy to while away the hours strolling between objects of significant historical value. It's a museum and gallery rolled into one. The gardens are also well planned and the cafe is excellent.
The best cultural center in Lisbon. Great classic artwork as well as musical shows with a great simphonic orchestra. Visit their website for detailed & vast cultural programs.

Fantastic. Fantastic. Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian is a fantastic space. There are two spaces in the museum to explore, the founders collection and modern art, both fantastic.The foundation is located in the heart of Lisbon, all the space is surrounded by beautiful connected individual gardens, some small water lily lakes and in the center a lake where you can find (and feed if you like) wild ducks!The colección of the museum is absolutely great, goes from the antiquity untill the nineteen century, covering islamic art, Armenian art and the far Est.There you can marvel at painter, ceramics, and general artifacts of comma life.
It's always a pleasure. It's always a pleasure to come here and revisited this beautiful Museum, art, music and a lovely garden.

Great works of art, magnificent gardens. This is one of my favorite spots in Lisbon to cheer out. It has several exhibition rooms, mainly for temporary exhibitions, which is great for us locals that never get tired of art and culture, and also several cafeterias and terraces. But one of its best features is the incredible garden that surrounds the buildings and makes forget that you're in the middle of the city. If you like art it is mandatory to come here, and if you just want to relax and get some nature bath, this must be the place.

What a surprise!. After so many museums and so many countries, you probably think you have seen it all. But you have not! This is an extensive collection which includes the great masters, modern works and decorative arts. You have a bit of everything in one small museum. I really enjoyed the exhibits and did not feel overwhelmed by the sheer volume of the collection. This museum is a jewel and should not be missed.

Beautiful objects, beautifully displayed.. Every artefact was top quality, well described and displayed in calm (as long as the school visit is avoided) galleries surrounding peaceful courtyards. Audio guide well worth it (very similar to the Queen's Gallery, London). And...the cafeteria in the basement appeared astonishing value for money. The shop too.

awe-inspiring. When you visit Lisbon, you absolutely must include this - the collections of a man who loved quality and beauty: the glass, china, carpets, paintings, an oriental section and for me, above all, the Lalique jewellery- absolutely fantastic. Some superb examples staged in a way that can be admired with space and light, and beautiful garden courtyards beyond the windows. If you are 65 or over you get half price reductions. The park it is in is peaceful with seats, ponds and statues. Take the metro from the centre to Sao Sebastien.

WOW!!!. Rated as one of the best museums of the world it did not disappoint. Extremely reasonable price to enter and free map to guide you round the rooms full of the most exquisite artifacts ever created. Every item is the best example of it's type which was the rule of the day when Mr Gulbenkian amassed his varied collections now held here in one beautifully designed building. Go and enjoy and be awe struck.

Beautiful Grounds and Very Nice Art Collection. This is a beautiful museum in the middle of park. Find it, and enjoy it. Don't rent the audio tour because it was not very helpful. Use the map issued during admission to guide yourself around. Also, don't miss out on the outdoor cafe which serves above average food in a beautiful setting. In addition, do you need to do some shopping before or after? There is a Corte Inglese mall a short walk away.

€5 TRIP AROUND THE WORLD. The Gulbenkian Museum provides an awe-inspiring trip across cultures and through time to create a sense of wonderment at the skills of mankind.From the textures - various rocks, glass, porcelain, silk, metals - to colours & shapes, the mind is enchanted with the diversity but universality of amazing craftsmanship: an exquisite 2700-year-old alabaster bowl; the beautiful collection of Hellenic coins; Japanese prints; unique René Lalique jewellery, rare pieces of Chinese porcelain and much more! From Asia, Africa and Europe Gulbenkian houses some of the finest pieces ever created. One appreciates the unerring sense of quality and beauty plus financial generosity of the owner of this world-class private collection. A visit to Lisbon MUST include a visit to the Gulbenkian!
The best Lisbon museum. Although it is a small but very interesting exhibits , especially art from the Middle and Far East .

A must. After leaving in Portugal for the past 18 years, I decided it was time to spend some hours in this beautiful Museum.I went there with my wife and my two daughters. We visited the museum of Modern Art, very difficult to understand for my children....Then we went to the gardens and had a big tour of the Museum itself where you can find beautiful paintings from french and english painters (Monet, for example). Beautiful room with egyptian art, superb sculptures....The restaurant is also worth a visit and not very expensive.As it was the first Sunday of the month, like most of the Museums in Lisbon, the entrance was free of charge, so....We will go again and enjoy the beautiful gardens and ponds as soon as the weather will allow...

Eclectic collection. Uplifting experience moving from room to room. Wonderful objects and art works from a wide range of periods and places, such quality and taste. Treasures were well displayed and surrounding gardens well planted. Cafe light and pleasant. Good way to reach it was by using one of the 'hop on and off' buses. Half price entry for Seniors, amazing value.

Spectacular!!!. Great Exhibition, especially the Gulbenkian Collection, which includes great mix of best world craftsmanship from different historical periods.Beautiful park and fantastic restaurant, with an extensive choice of food and drink.The whole experience is very tranquil and relaxing.
A jewel of a museum. A feast of very high quality objects. The middle eastern fabrics and ceramics were really new to me. Each section was excellent.

Nice time in museum. Located in the good area in the Parque Santa Gertrudes,it's modern architecture building.Parque,with a lot of plants and trees is beatifull with lake and ducks in it.The permanent exhibition includes classical,oriental and european art.Collection consists of perfect artifacts fm 14 to 19 centuries.In the temporary exhibition gallery you can always find some good collections.In the local caffe you can find good choice of dishes and drinks for reasonable price.Nice place to visit for the moddle age people.

A world class museum. Many of the best museums began life as private collections. The oil billionaire Calouste Gulbenkian's eclectic taste and passion for collecting precious objects and works of art has left us with a museum of marvels where everyone will find something to enjoy. Of particular interest is the room dedicated to the work of the French glass and jewellery designer René Lalique (1860-1945).

Amazing historical collection. Mr. Calouste Gulbenkian was an amazing collector of antiquities with a taste for the absolute best. It's hard to appreciate the quality of works he put together from so many different points and places in history. I am no history expert and I found it fascinating, but that's the kind of person I am.Definitely worth the visit if: - You love history and all the ways it can be represented - You want to see period pieces from almost every important time in historyNot worth going if: - You like history, but it doesn't rock your boat - Get bored looking at old artifactsNote that the building that houses the collection looks nothing like what you'd expect (modern back in the 70's), so don't look for the grand museum building you see in most other historically important places.Very close to the Lisbon Metro station and easily walkable.

NIce museum if you are in the neighbourhood. This is a nice museum if you are in the neighbourhood. Impressive to see what one man can collect during his life. Nice placed in the area and the building is great.

A Stunning Collection. Wonderful Museum.. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is a gem. From early Roman coins to the most gorgeous art nouveau French jewelry, this collection of a very cultivated family is packed with interesting and choice paintings, objets d'art, paintings, Asian porcelains and a stunning Islamic collection of carpets, bowls, tiles and more. This is a beautiful museum that rewards repeated visits, but, definitely go even if only once.

Rich collections.. It is a beautiful museum for its variety of collections and its architecture. It offers from many halls various garden views, very well designed. I enjoyed the Persian artefacts and the Lalique splendid pieces.It's worth a detour while in Lisbon.

Good for value for 3 euro especially on rainy day. Disappointed that there were no Impressionist paintings as had been led to believe that there were some ( none when we visited) but very light and airy exhibition space. We found it difficult to find the building as not well signposted. The cafe is excellent with great selection of cooked and cold meals- far better that we would have expected- so helped the disappointment over the lack of Impressionist paintings.
a highlight of the trip. extraordinary collection and a phenomenal temporary exhibit. beautifully displayed objects one of the best museums of its type... do not miss this place

Perfect for a rainy day . The collection of porcelain and pottery is very good. The paintings are pretty much what one would expect of such a museum, with a few outstanding pieces. The annoying parts were the absence of public parking and the fact that a major gallery was closed for "rearrangement." Definitely worth a visit.

Amazing collection. This museum is well worth a visit. It has a wide range of art from immaculate Roman coins to old masters. Gulbenkian amassed a huge are collection of over 6000 items of which 1000 are exhibited here. The entry fee was €5.

Loved it.. The Gulbenkian museum is housed in two buildings, The main museum and the contemporary collection. Pay for each separately or buy one ticket for all. We visited both, enjoyed both very much. Favorites were the gold coins, Persian ceramics and rugs, the Rene Lalique collection (don't forget to seek it out), and the special exhibition of Sonia and Robert Delauney paintings (now closed). There is much more to see though and you can look at some of the pieces online. They also host music events. We spent two half-days at the museum. We had lunch at the cafe. Careful of the pigeons. Don't walk away from your lunch if you eat outside or they will take over. I wish we had been verbally warned when we paid, it would have been most helpful. Overall, I highly recommend it and would recommend investigating the website first for special exhibitions and music events so that you can plan your visit. You'll want to make note that the museum is closed on Tuesdays.

Fundacao Gulbenkian. Nice museum with artworks from different time periods, so suitable for all tastes. It's quite nice to see some old roman coins and then switch to Rubens and van Dick. Nice garden as well.

Amazing building + amazing collection. Gulbenkian Foundation is a must see if you love art and go to Lisbon.The building is whole building is stunning and has a wild garden which is great to enjoy, read and relax.Also the museum has great permanent collection and expositions are up to the level.If you are lucky enough to catch a concert it will be a life experience.
Porugal in History!!. An outstanding history of Portugal at your fingertips in this beautifully laid-out museum - from antiquity to the modern era. A must-see if you are in Lisbon.

Go see it on a Sunday. We had about an hour left in our Lisboa card on early Sunday morning so we used that to travel out to this Museum. The Museum is free on a Sunday. Set in pretty parkland, the museum is attractively modest in size so by the time you have seen both permanent and temporary exhibitions, you don't feel exhausted.Highlights for me include a wickedly naughty little boy in one of the Children Playing tapestries, the Lalique gallery and Janniot's The Spring or Homage to Jean Goujon. But the sheer range of Gulbenkian's collection means there should be something to please most visitors' tastesThe temporary exhibition on British taste in art was fascinating.A decent cafe and toilets means a long visit is enjoyable

Best museum of Portugal. Is not like I've been to all Portuguese museums, but among those I've been, this is the best for sure. I start with the architecture that is gorgeous, the gardens must be pretty to walk also (It was raining a lot the day I went), the collection is not huge but is really diversified. It's easy to walk in the museum and imagine that is an amazing source of learning for those who live in the city. I missed more information in the rooms to help me explore better the artwork and unfortunately one of the sections of the museum was being rebuilt. Well, it was the perfect way to relax during a rainy day and after I could go to El corte ingles, that is near the metro station.

Wide variety of beautiful objects. We really enjoyed this visit. The Egyptian room had stunning objects covering over 2000 years, not many but each beautiful. There was art from the Middle East, China and Japan which was fascinating to compare with European art at the same time. Stunning Rembrandt and Turner.

Small museum with one great painting. The museum is on the bus route. It is easy to access. the museum is quite small but nice to walk around. Not many well known works compare to other museums. But to my surprise, there is 2 Rembrandt paintings. And one of it is my favourite.

Well Worth Visiting. There is something for every kind of art and antique lover at this fabulous museum. It is set in peaceful gardens and the buildings are fascinating 1960s concrete structures, layered into the garden landscape. Within the museum housing modern art and ancient art as well as some fabulous glass, porcelain, silver, gold and furniture; there is something for every one.

Excellent. Got off our tour bus to find this museum, only to discover it is closed on Tuesday! Not sure if this winter timing or permanent, however we set off again on Wednesday and are glad we persevered. It is indeed manageable as one guidebook described it. The exhibits are well displayed, often in individual cases, so often museums display loads of items in one cabinet and it can be difficult to work out what is what. Not so here. Some lovely things, how nice to be able to collect what you please from around the world! Don't miss the Lalique exhibition, it wasn't well signed and we almost missed it, at the opposite end to the entrance to the main collection.Reminded us of the Burrell collection in Glasgow, both are well worth a visit!

Even if you don't go to the exhibits, the gardens are amazing!. The permanent exhibit is very good and (depending on the personal taste of each person) the temporary exhibits are also very good. The staff of the museum is very helpful and everything is well explained/guided. There is a canteen for lunch or a simple coffee with an amazing view of the garden. To finalize, the Gulbenkian orchestra is one of the most prestigious in the country and the gardens are a little heaven within a full city. Very easy access from the metro station.

Impressing arts and antiquaries collection. This armenian Calouste Gulbenkian left a wonderful heritage to the public... in a surprising museum in a very confortable green parc ... also enjoy the coffee place in the museum next to the little lake ...

Off day? . Was at loose ens on a rainy Sunday morning so took some TA advice and visited this museum. The exhibits in the general display were good especially the period furniture. The exhibition staff were surly and unhelpfull, with regard to tickets. I only realised when I arrived the tickets for general display were free and you had to pay for the other two floors. No one explained this or offered further tickets meaning a bloke chases you down and basically asks you to leave! Charming. The cafe however was brilliant staff very helpful and a great selection of meals and snacks. The adjoining modern art gallery was also excellent.
