The best Museum we have visited out side of London. The museum is stunning, It has a very wide range of items and periods including wonderful paintings of the 17,18 & 19 centuries. It is very well laid out. In our opinion it is the best museum we have visited in Portugal. It is in a league of it's own.A pleasant surprise was that in one of the rooms towards the end of our tour on the museum we saw and heard on octet practicing for a concert of baroque music that they were to play that evening in the concert hall forming part of the Gulbenkian complex

Juwels of the world. Take the metro to P. de Espanha, the blue line; once out, go straight ahead on Av. de Berna and then...you cannot miss it. Sundays FREE.I read something about Gulbenkian and his passion to collect beauties, before reaching the museum. And indeed, starting with old Egypt ( my passion ) to Dutch and Flemish painters and Art Nouveau, you are among juwels.Impressive pieces of furniture ( in a very good condition !), old Persian carpets and to top it all...you can look Rubens straight in his...paintings.The Far East is also very well represented.What's more, you are allowed to take pictures, but no flash, please ! You can leave your coat and everything which might disturb your visit at the cloakroom. There is a shop and a café, too.There is a parking too, but I know it's not for free...not much of a piece of information, is it ? :)
Nice collection. Need taxi from Baixa to get there. Museum has great variety in the collection. Not all paintings available due to construction

Great collection. The collection at the Gulbenkian was fantastic and a real treasure in Lisbon. I went with few expectations but was thrilled at seeing these world class exhibits. I think a must for any art/decorative arts lover.

Great museum and garden. It's not a big museum but it has a nice collection and well organized.
The building itself is a real piece of art. Don't miss the garden! It's really amazing.
It's highly recommend and it's also free on Sundays.

Top tip for a rainy day...... A great escape from the rain. Plenty of Cloakrooms to store your umbrellas.
One disappointment, the Impressionists were not on disply due to refurbishment of the displays.
This did not dull the experience due to the quality of this superb Museum and it's exhibits.
This is a must visit for tourists in Lisbon

One of my favorite places in Lisbon. It is just the right size. I have never seen so many beautifully organized exhibitions (e.g. the ages of the sea). The garden surrounding the museum is amazing and peaceful.
You can also eat or have a drink in one of their the café.

Rainy day at the museum. . What to do in Lisbon when the weather says rain all day, go here and get the all day pass. If you are a senior, remember to say, tickets are half price.
Walk through time and art at this wonderful museum.
Fantastic museum. This was an amazing museum, don't visit Lisbon without paying a visit. A Hugh collection includes a wonderful collection of Rene Lalquic
Worth a visit. Not a huge collection, but worth it nonetheless. The main collection has some beautiful Islamic, Greek, Far Eastern, and European pieces.

Take time to experience beautiful things. This beautiful building, along with its excellent restaurant and gardens, takes time to visit. Savour the artefacts, the coins, the pottery, the paintings, the furniture. There is so much to take in, it is a feast for the eyes, and a second visit may be advisable. But it is easy to get lost and maybe miss something important amongst the vast halls.
Very good museum and amazing gardens. This museum has one of the best art collections in Lisbon. It is very central and is surrounded by an amazing garden. Free tickets on Sundays.

A must in Lisbon. This an eclectic eccentric collection of a nomadic wealthy, and apparently homeless Turk, who's eye was caught by almost all kinds of beauty in objects and paintings and shared them with us.Go and see it and browse until to amble out in to the tranquil gardens and take tea in the delightful cafe in the grounds.I don't normally review 'attractions' as I prefer hotels and food but this one is worth your time
a museum that is a garden that is a museum. One of the most important cultural landmarks of Lisbon, where you can find that unique space you need for that particular mood.

A fantastic collection. The private collection of Mr Calouste Gulbenkian covers a period from 24th century BC to the 20th century AD. It s an excellent collection that must be seen. From Mesopotamia to Lalicq, including one of the largest collection of Greek and Roman coins. An excellent collection of flamish painters, mediaeval manuscripts and Persian carpets, among many other surprises.
Spectacular venue. Fantastic place! The gardens are spectacular, inside a very good permanent collection and interesteing exhibitions. There is a reason why it is world-famous...
A must in Lisbon. I heard this museum years ago, We visited recently, I was especially impressed by İslamic and far east section. Anyone who visited Lisbom must spend some time in here
Amazing collection!. This museum has beautiful art works and the most amazing Lalique glass collection. I highly recommend a visit.

Good when fully open. We were very disappointed to find that the 19th century European art rooms were closed for refurbishment. The available collections of Egyptian, Greco-Roman and Islamic art were impressive but didn't make up for our disappointment.

What a perfect gem of a museum. Possibly the favourite activity we undertook in Lisbon.The museum had a simple, but wide range of impeccable exhibits - much more approachable than somewhere like the British Museum. Disappointing to find the Lallique gallery closed for refurbishment. And the objects would have benefited from more narrative. But we loved our trip.Less successful was the gallery of modern art, admittedly.Don't miss out on the excellent cafe/restaurant, nor on the opportunity to saunter around the grounds.We wrapped off our visit with a slow saunter back into town through the Parque Eduardo VII and Avenida Da Liberdade. Exquisite!

A most beautiful - and manageable - collection of fine art.. I admit, I'm a museum lover, and one of my most favorite museums are those that are not too large to be taken in in their entirety without becoming completely overwhelmed. This is one of those delightful museums! A wonderful selection of pottery, tiles, rugs, followed by a stunning collection of European masters in paint, bronze and wood. Very special; shouldn't be missed if you're an art lover!

Beautiful museum. I have been to this museum three times, and it is always a pleasure to come back. There are no really famous pieces,, but the variety is amazing. From ancient egypt to the contemporary art, there is basically even age period covered. Soe of my favorites are the paintings by the Venetian Francesco Guardi, and the Oriental art displayed.I also really liked the temporary exhibition called Treasures of the Royal Palaces of Spain!

Wide ranging high quality exhibits. From exceptional Greek coins to fabulous Persian carpets and an important collection of Guardi (Francesco) paintings there is a lot to like in this museum. It's not huge - 2 hours is more than enough, but well worth it. Make sure to stroll around the gardens too.

Culture. It's a very pleasent spot to chill in the gardens, just reading, earing the ducks or even hanging with friends. The library is very rich of authors and reading stiles and the events: high quality. Always surprising! And the orchestra top 5. Totally recommend it, no doubt.

Don't miss!. Spectacular collection, lovely gardens and a good cafe to sit outside. Being partly refurbished when we were there but this didn't distract from our enjoyment, and a highlight of our visit was the temporary Wentworth Fitzwilliam collection exhibition which was 11 out of 10!

Museum with interesting collections but more information needed on most. I was slightly disappointed when visiting the famous Calouste Galbenkian that the 19th century galleries are completely closed for renovation but there was still plenty to see. For me the absolute highlight was the Lalique jewellery which came at the end but was worth the wait. But again, like most museums in Lisbon (but strangely not the churches which make a real effort to engage visitors) there was so little information about the collections. For example, the Lalique room gives you absolutely no information about Lalique himself. This did detract from my enjoyment somewhat but am still glad I went.

Few nice peices. This was recommend as a museum to visit whilst in Lisbon and it was pretty average in my opinion. However, if you like art pieces then you would probably enjoy it more. The have a variety collection - from Egyptian, Chinese and British pieces. It's worth a look if you like this sort of thing - no my thing to be honest. I expected more from the recommendation. However, it was good as it was free to enter on Sunday

Much better than expected. From the outside it's a pretty unimpressive building but this belies the contents. It's quite amazing that this was a private collection that was donated to Lisbon. Some fabulous artefacts especially the Renewal Lalique room.An excellent cafe/restaurant is available looking out on the gardens.Really worth a visit and I'm not a museum buff.

Very nice private collection available to public!. This was highly recommened, so we made it a point to go. It is small and easy to navigate. There is a little of everything including a stunning collection of Lalique! Nice on a rainy day.

Absolutely gorgeous!. This is a definite must!One has not lived if one has not visited the Gulbenkian Museum.OK. Exaggeration? No, it is really amazing what Gulbenkian has given the world: top attractions of all sorts: not much maybe, but the quality is often superb.Ifyou're looking for an egyptian, a persian, a chinese, japanese, italian, dutch highlight:you will find it. It is the best museum for an overview of art and culture of all times and places, except for "primitive" art: african, (south)american indian, polynesian art.

a jewel which you must see. A small but complete private collection of perfect taste, including everything from antiquities to great painters and exquisite decorative arts. An example of what one man can achieve over a lifetime of collecting. Unmissable, as is the surrounding garden, carefull made visible from inside the museum at startegic points through panoramic windows.

Amazing exhibits. When we arrived, people were queuing to go into the café (and the food did look inviting!). However, we paid to go into the main museum and modern art section. The latter was a waste of time for us but the main museum was full of fascinating items from the past. Wonderful treasures indeed. No wonder Gulbenkian did not want his collection to be split. You come out with a sense of awe!We also enjoyed the gardens around the museums. Great place for a picnic in the summer?

If you only have time for one museum in Lisbon - This should be it!. We were told about this museum by someone we met on our cruise which ended in Lisbon. We were so glad we acted on her advice. It isn't huge, but all the better for that. It was after all one mans collection and in that respect not unlike The Burrell in Glasgow, Scotland. Every piece and painting is of superb quality, and there really is something for everyone. Allow lots of time, and it is not that easy to find, but we used the metro and got there easily enough.

A beautiful setting for a Modern Art Museum. I visited the modern art section and discovered the paintings from the Portugues Delaunay Group. I specially appreciated the world timeline comparing all the key events that marked the lifetime of these painters.

Large eclectic collection - try to get a guided visit. I had a last morning to spend in Lisbon and that musuem had good reviews and was not far from my hotel.Upon arrival, they had an ad about their Monday morning visits in English for 3 extra Euros (the simple entrance was 5) so I registered.The Monday's visit lasted about 1.5h. The guide we had that day was really great, knowledgable and spoke excellent English. She took us around the collections (which are organized in chronological order).On the museum's website you can even have a preview of what's inside with a virtual visit.It's really a visit I do not regret doing due to the presence and choice and quality of all the pieces of art coming from many places and many epochs. The big plus was the guide we had too.

Amazing collection. I visited alone whilst the museum was nearly empty in the middle of a working day, couldn't have had better conditions. Every single artifact is of huge value, one can feel it. The span is very large, everyone who's reasonably interested in art and history will find a section that resonates with him/her. Much space between exhibits, it's relaxing and makes the visit enjoyable though a bit austere in some parts.

An impressive gallery and museum.. It doesn't rival major art galleries in other Europen cities, but it is a very impressive collection by one man. It reflects his interests so in the main building there is more pottery, carpets, and manuscripts than paintings, but they are of the highest quality. I don't normally spend much time looking at these crafts rather than paintings, but they demand attention. There is exquisite Persian, Turkish, and Chinese pottery, and carpets, and the miniature illustrated manuscripts are remarkable.We didn't visit the special exhibition, or the seperate contemporary art museum, so could have seen more 'art' if we had wanted to. We only had three hours and there was more than enough to keep us interested, including the very good cafe which had excellent coffee and savoury snacks.The building and gardens are attractive, and it is easy to reach by metro. Well worth a visit.

A Small Museum. It certainly has many interesting pieces. However, there is nothing that will take your breath away. Very well organised and pleasant setting. However, it is a small museum that can be completed in less than 2 hours.

A place not to miss. If you are visiting lisbon, you have to visit this museum. A very rich collection. Entrance fee is 5 Euro. The museum is free on sundays. You can reach by metro (Metro Station: S. Sebastião, blue line)
large collection. has a very large collection of persian and turkish carpets, chinese and turkish (nicea) porcelains, europain paintings.a very nice and busy cafe with a large garden.
Grat building. lovely location- wonderful garden and architecture. we liked it very much. if there hop up the hill for magic views.
Amazing. Difficult to imagine that a private citizen can put together such a rich collection of art which turns this museum into o a jewel, the visit of which should be mandatory for all art lovers

AMAZING!!!!. The one museum not to miss in Lisbon!!!
First there is the beautiful architecture of the buildings and the amazing gardens!!! It is one of the best museus i have been to.
They have a different display on the Contemporary Art Museum on the next building, it is a walk through the garden away!!!
DONT MISS IT!!!

A little bit of everything!. From Egyptian artifacts to Persian, Chinese and Turkish items to 17th century masters to the amazing 18th century room, this museum has it all! Spacious rooms and pleasant layout. Set aside at least 2 hours to absorb all the offerings!
One of the best private collections of the world. It was a fantastic surprise to us to know this collection . I will tell all my friends that is a must when you go to Lisbon

Mr. Gulbekian certainly had taste!. This was an excellent museum in a beautiful park. Please make time to walk around the park and go to the adjacent Modern Art Museum if you can. The museum is laid out well with different areas focused on different regions and art forms. Audio guides are available. Many stools are available to rest or draw. The sculpture “Spring: Homage to Jean Goujon” by Janniot was wonderfully placed at the beginning of the walk-through. It was delightful to see museum guides explain details to teams of school kids. The Lalique exhibit at the end was small but definitely exquisite. The gift shop is small but the cafeteria was also excellent and surprisingly moderately priced. I didn’t go into the library, but I saw many books from the doorway.

Mr 5% Had a Fabulous Eye for Beauty. Calouste Gulbenkian left a legacy. This collection is stunning in its quality. Gulbenkian was apparently a very tough businessman, who traded in oil mostly, and always demanded 5% of every business deal. Glad he used his money so that we can enjoy!The modernist building housing the collection and the gardens are also worth seeing.

World-Class, and approachable. Beautiful collection of old-world art, furnishings, glass and silver. Housed in a wonderful modern, architectural significant building. Be sure to not miss the Lalique exhibit. Very friendly staff and on a Wednesday morning not at all crowded.

Great Museum. Exceeding half a century, it is one of the most important foundations of EuropeHow to get? The Gulbenkian is situated very close to the El Corte Inglés. Nearest metro are the Spanish station. (blue line) and San Sebastian (blue and red lines). The walk from the Marques de Pombal, city center is 20-30 minutes.The Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation in Lisbon has one of the largest private collections. That you can find in Europe and worldwide.The complex of the Foundation consists of entities and distinct spaces: the Museum, the Modern Art Centre, the Library, the Gardens, the Library and Auditorium .
For those who love beauty and art. Take some time to visit this place and its garden. If you are a beauty fan, you will find it amazing.

Well worth a visit. One cannot help but be impressed by the friendliness and helpfulness of the Portuguese and this was true at this museum. This is a wonderful place to spend a rainy afternoon, is well laid out, has some stunning exhibits (do not miss the Lalique glass room), has a great and reasonably priced café and should be included on the to do list for Lisbon.

An astounding range of art and decorative objects. A modern building in beautiful gardens house this enormous private collection of art and decorative objects. We could have spent many hours here but it starts to become overwhelming as there are so many rooms of so many things. If you can, concentrate on the objects you want to see most.

Collection of superb taste. We liked this museum very much, as the Collection shows superb taste of the collector. Depending on what you want to see, but if I have to select one museum to go in Lisbon, I select this.

Not to be missed. I have visited many galleries and exhibitions all over the world, and this rates as one of the very best. The collection is beautifully presented, and the sheer quality of the exhibits in each and every one of the sections is extraordinary. In some ways it reminded me of the Frick Collection in New York in reflecting how a collector of extraordinary wealth was able to amass a collection that outstrips many national galleries and exhibitions. If I have one small niggle it is that the postcard collection in the shop was disappointingly small. Otherwise, this was the highlight of our visit to Lisbon.

very rich museum. We visited this museum when in Lisbon as it was reccomended by some family friends. The museum hosts alot of paintings, furniture, statues, art of any kinds all owned by Mr. Gulbenkian. if you'd like to see different collections one at the same plice, then this is the right place to visit.

World class museum. Great, traditional museum with layout all on one floor. You wander from room to room of beautiful artwork. For a real treat, wander over to the Center for Modern Art once your done (in the same park complex, just a short walk away).

Lovely varied collection. Good spread of items across the centuries. The building is set in lovely gardens with streams and pools. Water birds wandering around. Beware the nearest Metro station is hidden on the roundabout so you need to cross a wide busy road.
Well worth a visit especially if it's a rainy day.. This museum is well laid out and the descriptions of the objects on display are in both Portuguese and English.

An eclectic private collection. From égyptian to modern art, This muséum reflects the sensibility of a gréât collectionner. Lalique works, xviii century fournitures, chinese poteries are amoung the best.

A man with taste and diverse art interests combined w deep pockets - recommend. The Museum is not so much a reflection of a certain art space or history, but rather a full reflection on the taste and quality combined with great taste and a very broad interest. How else would Greek Art, Medival Ivory cuttings and Monet fit under one roof? What brings it all together is the high taste of the founder/benefactor. Recommend

Nice for a rainy day. I enjoyed the visit, everything was well organized by periods in history. The story behind this Museum about the collector Calouste Gulbenkian is extraordinary. There are some fine pieces of art from all different eras and a lot of azulejos as well. It's free each first Sunday of the month.

One of the finest. Outstanding eclectic collection though not necessarily Portuguese. The Lalique is for us the most remarkable collection. The restaurant serves a reasonable lunch and the resident duck entertains if you sit outside

ugly building, exhibitions in the 70ies style. A very well accessible by metro building in a very pretty garden. The building itself is an ugly concrete block, not much better inside. The collection is not bad, with some Monet and a lot of English painters, good collection of rugs and fine china. 2 good stores and a cafe place. Very good free internet.

Beautifully curated private collection. Perfect rainy day activity, this museum houses the private collections of Calouste Gulbenkian, and avid collector of Asian, Egyptian, Japanese, Impressionist, Islamic, and other art. Love the Lalique crystals and jewelry, and the Islamic rugs were lovely. Clearly he cherished his objects and now we get the benefit of his care by being able to view them!

Small Gem for the Discerning Few. On a recent business trip my husband and I slipped off to this museum, which we'd read about in a book. What a delcious feast for the eyes. While I sympathize with the reviewer who was expecting Portuguese art, those of you open to a fine sampling of world art collected by someone of refined taste and seemingly unlimited budget will not be disappointed. I've recommended this to many, and have received warm "thanks yous" afterwards...

Beautiful collections well presented. The two 'sections' of the collection are well presented on a scale that is not overwhelming. Items all have important qualities that make many worth observing carefully. As such we found this visit very informative. We also enjoyed walking in the gardens which we found simply charming, even in winter. A museum that should not be missed.

Wide range of magnificent art works! Unmissable!. The breadth and range of the collection is astounding. The layout on one floor is very clever as visual overload is avoided. Historically sequenced, the variety of exhibits range from the Mesopotamian, Greco- Roman, Egyptian,Ottoman, Japanese and Chinese eras. European treasures like Anne of Cleeves' Book of Hours (with many other examples!) and Renaissance medallion portraits are there plus French eighteen century furniture and a magnificent art and sculpture collection. The Impressionist collection alone would make the visit worthwhile. Do not miss!

I was expecting Portuguese art. This is a nice enough museum however I was hoping to see Portuguese art as opposed to one man's particular art collection from around the world. It's also a bit out of the way if you don't drive. I wouldn't recommend this as a must-see but it's nice enough.
Must Must Must!!! . Museum has a great collection and it's just unbearably awesome and unique! I will go again again and again very impressed

Surprising. This museum is quite interesting, as it presents very different art pieces - from Greek coins, to Ming and Qing dinasty vases, to paintings and French writing desks. It doesn't take too long to visit, you don't get bored and for 5 Euros, it's worth a visit.

Not too big, but great quality. This museum is free on Sundays, which is a bargain. Its size is moderate, but the quality is great. Personally, I enjoyed one of the Rembrandts and one of the Turners a lot. But the collection is varied enough to have something for every taste, including Egyptian coins and Ming vases.

Much overhyped. No idea why this is ranked so highly in guidebooks and Trip advisor. We left way before our allotted time. This is NOT some mini Louvre or British Museum. Been to smaller museums that were better. Not very good explanations either

Exceptional!. We had three days to tour Lisbon before starting a tour of Portugal and Spain. One day we decided to tour the Gulbenkian Museum because it was close to our hotel. Never did we expect such an amazing art collection. It’s not overwhelming, nor does it include a robust collection of all art periods. Instead it reflects the eclectic interests of one wealthy art lover—from Egyptian and Greek art, to Chinese porcelain, Persian tapestries, European paintings, and French 18th century furniture. Be sure to visit the museum shop! The organic architecture of the building blends into the beautiful garden and large park that surrounds it.

this guy had real money. There is something for every art lover here. From 1200 BC right through impressionism. This is not the Louvre but you wont get overwhelmed or lost either, and you can still find a Rembrandt along with Roman coins, Manet, and Lalique
Great small Museum. A small but excellent collection wonderfully presented. There were many art works that I have anted to see in person and the presentation was excellent. WELL WORTH THE VISIT

Eh. Average at best. Hard to love this museum when you've been to so many amazing museums in Paris and Florence. Probably not worth it. But my husband and I believe in going to at least 1 museum in every city in Europe so probably an ok one if that's your goal too.

Excepcional Group of Museums. This Museum belongs to the Gulbenkian Foundation Created by the famous Armenian Calouste Gulbenkian. During the Second World War he came to live in Portugal and stayed until he died in the fifties of last century. He was enormously rich and a passionate Art Collector and he left a great part of his fortune and his art collection to a Foundation that he created to support Arts and social activities.This Museum is really exceptional as it houses all the art collection that Mr Gulbenkian collected during all his long life covering almost all civilazations old and new. It is a must visit.

The Gulbenkian Museum is a treasure you cannot miss while visiting Lisbon. I don't have enough words of praise for this museum ... just magnificent.. The exhibits span civilizations and cultures; Mesopotamian, Egyptian, Greek, Roman, Islamic, Persian, European, Oriental, etc. and are meticulously organized and presented. A must for the lover of history, art and human development. The tour ends with a priceless collection by Rene-Jules Lalique. Also take time to visit the art library in the basement ... it is a bonus.

Lisbon's most underrated museum!. The exquisite collection lovingly put together by oil mogul Calouste Gulbenkian is displayed in this beautiful space, inside one of the best parks in the city. The museum is a must see for art lovers. Remember to enjoy a "galão" and a toast afterwards in the cafeteria.
Quick visit to the gardens -- free. It was a quick visit to the gardens with no time left to visit the museum. Cool place, with several animals walking by the park. It's free so go for it.

NOT to LOOSE IN CULTURAL LISBON. Lisbon is a beautiful town with a speacial brightness and incredible views. But its cultural side is also vey importante. related to it you can´t loose this museum with always great expositions. you also have a great garden surroinding it.
Great collections. The Gulbenkian museum is one of the most interesting and most important in Europe. Excellent museum's permanent collections are a means of knowledge to adults and children.

The Best, Nothing but the Best. There are two museums very close to each other here, both Gulbenkian founded. The one with the good stuff in it is the older of the two, and what wonderful, beautifully displayed art it is. Gulbenkian must have had several experts sweeping through the world buying the best of ancient and modern on his behalf. It starts with ancient Egypt and finishes off with a room of superb Laliques. Furniture, sculpture and paintings all of exemplary quality. Go!

CALOUSTE GULBENKIAN-- A DISCERNING COLECTOR- A BEAUTIFFUL SETTING. The Gulbenkian Museum is part of the Gulbenkian Foundation Headquarters in Lisbon. The whole ensemble is set on beautiful landscaped gardens with a a pleasant self-service restaurant overlooking the greenery. The main Museum houses the personal collection of the Armenian Oil Magnate and philanthropist ,Calouste Gulbenkian. It is a specialised museum with a fine Islamic collection, a good section with art nouveau jewellery (very beautifully displayed). The main emphasis of the collection is eighteen century French furniture and painting.This is a somewhat "frozen" museum as per Gulbenkian's will , the collection cannot be added to. On the opposite side of the "park" is the Contemporary art Museum, hosting occasional fine exhibitions of Portuguese and International contemporary Art. Worth checking.

Wonderful Museum. We had been to Lisbon in 2005 and I wanted to go back to this beautiful museum They have great collections and Rene Lalique Jewellery is outstanding. We went on a Sunday and the entrance was free.

Museu da Fundacao Calouste Gulbenkian. It´s very interesting, value art, rich cultural expositions and have a good and enormous garden with lake and animal species, fish, birds and ducks, an auditorium in garden. This Fundação have a magnific envorinment.
Unmissable!. Excelent and varied collection, absolut amazing objects namely of Oriental Art, fantastic Renée Lalique items, marvelous pictures and furniture pieces, unmissable !
Lovely art . A relaxed gallery - free on Sunday with a lovely collection and relaxed staff. Check it out. It also has a small gift shop and an alright cafe (cafe is nothing special).

Amazing museum. When you enter you don't want to leave this place. Big garden with buildings, when you enter in this museum you start with egiptian things until european art.If you are in Lisbon go to see this amazing collection!

Eclectic museum. Eclectic collections but all of very high quality. Worth visiting for a couple of hours. "Oriental rug" collection very fascinating as were the Chinese/Japanese ceramics. Recommend visiting.

Not to be missed if you like art. This museum offers a wide varierty of art that was part of the collection of Mr Gulbenkian. A nice setion on islamic art. Various scuptures and paintings Worth seeing. One needs about 3 hours to visit the museum. The park around it is also Worth visiting.

one of the best european private collections. from ancient Visit the FCG Museum and get to know some unique pieces, from ancient Egypt to Modern Art, all around the world and times. My favorite ones are the impressive Lalique Art Nouveau jewelry and some beautiful Flemish paintings with awesome very tiny details as well as Rembrandt’s dark portraits… Also available in the surrounding buildings very high quality art exhibitions and the Modern Art Centre. Impossible to miss the beautiful and peaceful gardens, with ducks swimming in the ponds, many other the birds flying and nesting around… right in the middle of Lisbon city you forget about traffic and time.

Excellent 4,000 year museum you can do in 2 hours. This is one of the best thought out museums I have visited. Starting in the first of 17 rooms you go back to ancient Egypt. You advance room by room century by century all of which can be done in two hours. The art is spectular. Turner, Corot, Flemish masters. All there. Two rooms devoted to René Lalique. Worth a visit. Half price for seniors !
Must see!. Fabulous collections of Islamic decorative art, European paintings, furniture and much more. Great shop too.

Not very larger but amazing quality of exhibits. Built around 3 courtyard...gardens it is easy to walk around and the exhibits are neither overwhelming not boring.lovely collection, eclectic and obviously assembled with care and good taste.

Phone before going!. Phone before going because they open when they want: usually all museum in Lisboa close in monday but the Gulbekian changes its free day when it wants: we went to visit it the tuesday 8 december 2015 and it was closed (they told us that this week they opened the monday 7th!). What a shame!

Lovely museum with eclectic assortment of finely chosen art. Gulbenkian had a great eye for art. This museum has absolutely gorgeous samplings of artifacts from Asia and Europe, ranging from ceramics and carpets to European paintings. The collection includes two Rembrandts, Corots, Millet, Van Ruisdael, Monet, Degas, Rodin, Sargent, Rubens, and more. Takes about 2 hours to see and well worthwhile.
Best private collection ever!. Such a well selected collection. May you rest in peace Calouste Gulbenkian! You have left the world with your beautiful legacy.
Great Concert Venue. Went to see Rufus Wainright (Opera 1st half, him performing with orchestra and singers in 2nd half). Great concert and great venue!

Best private museum in Lisbon. Well worth a visit! The Gulbenkian Museum showcases an outstanding permanent art collection and temporary shows. The Lalique gallery is exquisite. A separate modern art museum is also on the grounds. Free on Sundays!
Nice museum. Remembering that Portugal only has 10 million people, the collection is about 5% the size of the NY metropolitan museum and can be seen in about 60-90 minutes. Nice small collection.

Fantastic private collection. Visited on a Sunday, that has free entrance and was reasonable quiet. The collection, acumulated over the years by Gulbenkian, has nothing to envy other bigger museums. It is a nice mixture of different periods and items, and because of its manageable size it doesn´t get repetitive. I could easily had spent longer if the collection was larger. I liked specially the room dedicated to René Lalique.Really recommended.

A gem, not to be missed. The museum is located in the middle of a quiet old garden, to rest your feet and read a book after the visit. As a personal collection, it has the most amazing variety of unique pieces from a rich collection of very old coins dating more than 3000 years ago to impressionist pieces. One of the most enjoyable museums ever

Well Worth Visiting!. Went to this wonderful museum on the second of our 4 days in Lisbon. We took an inexpensive taxi to get there as the museum is just a few miles north of Lisbon's city center. We even got "Senior" discount admission tickets for just €5 each! While the "English" audio tour equipment had all been rented out - we found this was not a problem as most of the exhibits have signs in multiple languages. Recommend before going that you do at least a little advance research so you can choose what you would especially like to see. The collection is so large that it's just not possible to see everything in only a few hours or even a single visit.Seeing the art nouveau Lalique collection of jewellery, glassware and ivory that fills an entire room at the end of the suggested tour route is a great finale.

What a surprise! Well worth the search. Yes it is very hard to find and off the beaten path but what a great find. Amazing collection, oriental rugs, amazing ceramics, jewelry, painting,sculptures by the worlds most renowned artists. Beautifully laid out and arranged, the flow from room to room is staggering. Make the effort to find your way there, you will not be disappointed. There is also a gorgeous garden outside, a good cafe and library attached.

Must see in Lisbon. This museum is located in a park which is part of the experience . What is making this museum so enjoyable is that it was designed to serve this very stunning and homogeneous collection . It shows and you really feel in harmony with this place. One of the best in the world to my point of view and the very best in Lisbon. Don't miss it
Hard to find but worth it . Fab museum with amazing selection of artifacts....something for everyone, the lalique jewellery is breathtaking

Exquisite. A beautiful (personal) collection of historical and artistic pieces starting with Egyptian, including Greek, Roman, Persian, Turkish, Medieval, Renaissance, Impressionist. A testament to what one human can accomplish in a lifetime. Not at all overwhelming; just the right number of very high quality items. I was through it in under an hour and delighted by every minute.

Stunning collection and a great way to send a couple hours. This museum is the perfect size to enjoy without it being an entire day of your trip. The cost to enter is reasonable at 5 euros, there is a coffee shop and cafeteria if you need a break or a quick bite to eat and the collection is beautiful. Islamic, Asian and a beautiful collection of furniture as well as paintings. The Lalique pieces are stunning. Worth the visit and the surrounding park is also lovely.
A must in Lisbon. The private collection of the oïl magnate Calouste Gulbenkian is just extraordinary by its ecletic taste and high quality. A must in Lisbon

Perfectly sized museum, fantastic collection.. A gem of a collection, with stand-out pieces in seemingly every major genre, nicely sized as to not be daunting, well laid out, and a great cafe to boot. Free on Sundays, too! If the weather's nice, sit in the garden or have a walk through the grounds.

Free on Sundays. Calouste Gulbenkian was an Armenian oil magnate, who came to Lisbon during WWII. Over the years he built up an amazing collection of art and artefacts, which he left to the people of Portugal on his death in 1955.His collection is housed in a purpose-built museum, set in a beautiful park. It spans 4,000 years of art history - starting with Ancient Egyptian ware, and finishing with glassware by his good friend, Rene Lalique. The museum is spaciously and logically set out, with each room covering a different era and topic. There is something to appeal to everyone. You do not have to be an art connoisseur to enjoy it.The museum is open from 10am - 6pm every day except Mondays. Entry is 5 euros, (concessions half price); and free to all on Sundays.There are good toilet and café facilities.

It's nice to be rich. This building is a purpose built museum and research foundation funded by the Calouste Gulbenkian estate, a Turkish oil magnate who made his fortune in the the US by owning shares of many US oil companies. He invested his considerable fortune, in many periods of art, from ancient Egyptian and Greek pieces to 18th and 19th Century European art. There is also a fabulous Lalique glass collection. All of the pieces are of significant quality. The building is a modern 1969, one story structure and separate 3 story research facility set in a park. The museum is a bit out of the center of town. Getting to the site was real easy on the Metro and a wonderful experience. If you have a Lisboa Card, admission is free as is the Metro. Since my wife and I like all forms of art, we spent 2 hours here. It is most worth the trip.The displays, signage and lighting are spot on for their enhancement of the art, sculpture, rugs, etc. If you've been to the great museums in New York and Paris or elsewhere, you won';t be disappointed.

Some great pieces but.... Clearly Mr. Gulbenkian was an avid collector with eclectic taste. However we felt that the museum did not display the artworks well. In many of the rooms the walls and floors were mid-tone wood. The lighting was dim, especially in the Arabic rooms. Many of the old paintings were framed behind glass which created a lot of glare.

Fantastic collections. You will need about 2 hours for this museum and it well worth your time. I recommend renting the audio guide. Each collection was terrific. My favorite being the Lalique collection . We had lunch at the cafe and it was reasonable and good. Definetly one of our favorite experience in Lisbon
Beautiful tiles. Beautiful tiles in a beautiful old mansion. But that's all. The teenagers in my party were not very interested.

One of the best museum experiences I've had. I was amazed at how close you are allowed to get to the masterpieces. No barriers, just a yellow line on the floor which if you happened to cross, would prompt security to approach you and ask that you step back. No restrictions on photography either. Very unusual in this day and age but it did make the experience quite something. Well worth the visit.

Excellent collections. Excellent collections and exhibitions.... a must see, not far from centre of Lisbon and accessible via the subway. Have lunch at the restaurants.... very affordable... locals lunch there!!! walk the gardens... beautifully laid-out!!!
Lovely place. This has to be the loveliest museum in Europe, I think. It is very well organised and the atmosphere is just wonderful,

Many artifacts but very few great pieces. This museum shows the numerous collections of the defunct Calouste Gulbenkian: paintings, sculptures, precious furniture, carpets, chinese vases etc. There is a bit of everything but very few great pieces. Although it is located in a beautiful park it is not really worth the visit unless one wants to see a lot of minor artefacts which have very little in common but the fact that they belonged to the same man.

Excellent smallish museum. This museum is human sized and better for it. It may only have one or two Rembrandts, but it keeps you from feeling overwhelmed or overloaded by the presentation. It also wasn't crowded, even on a Sunday afternoon when it's free. You can spend as much time as you want near the displays you really want to see. It offers a pleasant way to spend the afternoon.

stunning collection. This is a very interesting collection of paintings,artefacts, ceramics,glass(Lalique) and furniture. Entrance is amazingly cheap for such a stunning collection. Don't be put of by the rather brutalist design of the building. Inside it is lovely.

Great Cruise Port. We took a Transatlantic cruise and this was one of the stops. We used a tour guide for this amazing city. The tile work in Portugal is beautiful . We brought some home for our kitchen and also bought a hand painted ceramic basket. What beautiful craftsmanship!

Rene Lalique collection was superb!. We went here really to see the Rene Lalique Art Nouveau jewelry. The pieces on display were really exquisite and they were definitely the highlight for us.There are many other pieces from famous artists as you wind through the galleries in a chronological way including wonderful illustrated manuscripts, Rembrandt, Frans Hals, Turner, as well as Corot, Manet, Monet, Renoir and Degas all displayed beautifully. The Lalique jewelry was really memorable - such attention to detail. Worth a visit.

Must see. Serious.. In fact, we were in this museum in October 2014.Review will be short. Simply, go there. World's art and history from all periods of human civilization, not only paintings, sculptures, but also furniture, books etc will be in front of your eyes. And there is room dedicated to Art Nouveau jewelry of René Lalique. There are Rembrandt and many other great names of World's art, but that room, for me, was one of highlights not only of visit of this museum, but visiting Lisbon.

Small with beautiful masterpieces!. The museum is an amazing experience in many ways. It lays in the centre of the luxurious garden, like a pearl, and you have different glimpses of it through the magnificent architecture of Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian.You can visit the museum according to different perspectives: an historic overview of eastern/western culture, the lovely and exquisite Lalique collection, the oriental antiques. If you're an art student, you also have the art library in the same building. Don't forget to take a look at the museum sho. You will purchase really nice souvenirs.

You can not miss.. The Museu has a incredible display of eastern art, beautiful pieces smartly shown. Pottery, glasses, statues, urns, rugs, etc... More than deserves a visit. But don't be misled by my enthusiasm, there is a lot of other pieces from Europe that are also overwhelming.

Comprehensive Museum. The Gulbenkian is an outstanding museum covering art from 4 millenias. The collection holds just about everything from sculpture and painting to glass and textiles. The museum is organized chronologically and one can effortlessly move from Egyptian art through classic Greek and Roman art and right up to 20th century art. The presentation of the individual pieces is excellent, with close attention paid to lighting and the accompanying text. The Gulbenkian is a world-class museum and a must for any art lovers visit to Lisbon.

Quirky and cool, small but excellent. The antiquities are unlike anything I've seen because their condition is so beautiful. The French furniture I rushed thru because I can't stand that stuff, but there is also a small collection of lovely paintings and the Lalique jewelry was ah-ma-zing! Great cafe downstairs, then exit thru the park. Very glad we went.
Fantastic!. This museum has the most wonderful collections. It is not huge, but every piece is a masterpiece, in perfect condition and very well displayed.

As good as the guide books say it is!. This was saved for the last day, so we were tired and grateful for Rick Steves' precise instructions on how to get there from the metro and his descriptions. The collection is extremely good and so well displayed even if the building is not lovely.

Diverse and wonderful. Great way to spend a rainy day. A diverse and wonderful collection. My husband always has to be forced into a museum but he really enjoyed this one. The cost wsa 5 Euro and well worth it. We covered it all in about 1 1/2 hours. Cafeteria was too packed but it smelled wonderful.

"Only the best for me". This apparently is a quote by Calouste Gulbenkian himself, and he clearly was a man of his word. This is undoubtedly a world-class art museum. The building itself is custom-designed with great exhibition spaces and with the added feature of the occasional view out into the garden that surrounds the building. The pieces themselves are exceptionally well-displayed and lit. This is not a cluttered museum with an overabundance of exhibits. The relatively small number of pieces allows one to admire and inspect them on an individual basis without distraction. But the overwhelming and overarching impression, showing that Mr Gulbenkian kept his word to himself, is the quality of the pieces displayed. Without exception they are all in quite wonderful condition- ceramics, carpets, paintings, furniture, and coins. A quite superb range of art works in quite superb condition. The one quibble I would have is that many of the explanatory panels were unusually low for an average-sized person and therefore difficult to read. But this is a minor quibble. If you interested in art, history, museum design, or philanthropy this museum is a must see during any visit to Lisbon.

Surprise Art Collection is Lisbon. This museum consists of the eclectic collection of Calouste Gulbenkian, a wealthy business magnate of the early 20th century who died in Lisbon in 1955. The collection ranges from antiquities from Egypt and Greece to 19th century painting. He managed to amass some of the most beautiful and well preserved works for each period that he collected. There are ceramics from China, carpets from Persia and glass from the middle ages to Lalique. I absolutely loved the art nouveau jewelry and pins. This is not a well-known museum outside of Lisbon, but is an absolute must for art lovers.

a must while in Lisbon. I love this museum, I´ve been in Lisbon twice and have spent half a day there on every visit. Not pretencious at all, very well curated, a hidden gem in the city. The architecture is very unique and I love the gardens, and the collection is small but interesting and well preserved. I work at a museum myself, and this is one of my favorites.

A very well organizem Museum in the heart of Lisbon.. This Museum is one of Europe's finestes. A classic and a Modern areas surrounded by a beatufil garden. There is aliso the possibility to see some of the best Classical music performences and Jazz concerts.

Amazing Ceramic Collection. We went to this museum our last day in Lisbon w/o terribly high expectations. I was blown away by the ceramics collection much of which is Turkish in origin. If your time is limited, think about just looking at the ceramics. There are other interesting pieces--Lalique comes to mind.
Museu de funda. Great way to spend a half day....can combine with a very nice lunch at yheir cafe and walk through the parks.

A perfect museum of exquisite taste. This is the perfect museum. There are rooms of the finest examples of every era and artefact through history and none of the average padding of many larger museums. We spent a happy hour and a half wandering and enjoying everything we saw, but it was not too large. It is also very well laid out, logically and chronologically.

Terrific collection. The Gulbenkian is a wonderful museum with a terrific collection ranging from ancient artifacts, tiles and lovely paintings. It is reminiscent of the Frick as the reflection of a world class collector.

Very good. . Incredible art collection. The last rooms were the most interesting in my eyes, I should have spent less time in the Greek and Egyptian collection ( but this is personal taste of course). Worth the detour and readily accessible with the metro. Do not hesitate to pick nick in the nice park. It earns definitely its place in the top 3 attractions of Lisbon.
Enchanting gardens. The museum is very attractive and contains some beautiful treasures. It has a little bit of everything, plus some amazing Lalique jewels.

Superb collection. This is a fascinating collection which is extremely well organised and displayed. There are many remarkable items on display including a wide and varied collection of paintings. The Lalique collection is fabulous and worth the visit on its own.

Great place! . Great place And with many cultural options. Near praca de espanha and Corte ingles. You can visit expostions, listen music and orchestra. You can buy a book and they have great gardens ...
INTERESTING IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN ART, POTTERY AND HISTORY. Great place to visit,a huge museum with different exhibits. There are outdoor gardens and eating areas. Food very well priced.
One of the best places to visit in Lisbon. You have it all. Museum, grest gardens, music concerts ( classical, jaz, etc.), dancing shows. If you are coming to Portugal you sould visit this place.

Not as good as it used to be. I went to this museum in 1986. It was great. Now it seems to have less on show. The shop was better in the past too. Bit of a shame. I would have rated the 1986 version as a 5.

Cultural Jewel in Lisbon should attract anyone. Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation museum - this was one of the best museums ever! One of the exhibits gave me the opportunity to see Ming pottery; another French furniture from the eighteenth century, providing a glimpse into the opulence of the French aristocracy and Middle Eastern art artefacts including the most beautiful carpets...... even the cafeteria was of a very high standard.

Excellent Museum. The great thing about this museum is that you can walk through history from the ancients through the modern era and it's got a small number of quality pieces from epoch after epoch stretching over the entire world. But you can see it all in a visit. Find the metro directions to get there -- it's worth the trip.

Very good!!. Small but very interesting museum . It has a variety of art in so many forms and from so many locations. You can see masterpieces from different artists such as Rubens, Vittore Carpaccio, Renoir, Rodin, and many more. You will need two hours of your time to see everything.

A worthwhile visit. The museum is a short walk from the Praca da Espanha metro station. Get out through the Berna exit and it is a short walk once you are out of the station. Entrance fee is E5.00 and 2.50 for those 65 and over. Kids 12 and under get in free. The collection is separated by historical periods and types such Egyptian period, Graeco Roman period, then tapestry, furnitures etc. the information sheet says there are 6,000 items in the collection. It is quite an interesting collection...ancient greek coins ( silver and gold) medals, paintings including Gainsborough, Manet etc, Lalique collection, chinese, Turkish and Japanese porcelainware, and extensive silverware and furniture collection. We spent more than 2 hours exploring it. I think itis a worthwhile visit if you are interested in these items. Did not try the cafeteria, there are plenty of cafes, restaurants in the surrounding area and we enjoyed a good lunch nearby.

The collection consists of works from Greco Roman period through impressionists. Extensive and well presented.. Spent a rainy Sunday at the museum. I took a taxi from my hotel. Though public transport is available, the weather and some confusion on my part made a taxi more sensible. Collection is much better and larger than I anticipated. I enjoyed it a lot. There is a pretty good cafeteria there. Sunday there is no charge for admission. There were lots of people so plan for slow lines. Well worth the trip.

Cultural visit. This museum contains the pieces of art Calouste Gulbenkian collected for about fifty years of his life. It is very diverse, presenting objects from Egypt, Ancient Greece and Rome, Persia, Japan, China and Europe. There are ancient objects, paintings, sculptures, jewelry and decorative art. One of the best museums I have ever visited!

A Most Unique Museum and Gardens. Every item in this collection is a gem. We only regret we had only a morning to spend there. In addition to the wonderful collection, the grounds are magnificent as well and open to the public and the public were indeed enjoying them that Sunday morning.

Beautiful grounds, fantastic collection. We spent a rainy Sunday afternoon here and were so happy that we decided to come. The collection includes everything from ancient Egyptian statues and Babylonian coins to Chinese and Japanese porcelain and grand Master oils. What a fabulous private collection! The layout was perfect. Each room had a different theme and we found it very easy to move about. I think this is because the museum spaces the pieces apart so well. Although it is free on Sundays, another bonus, it was not crowded at all. (We are so used to museums in NYC, which an be crowded and hot. ) This museum was such a nice treat. We spent about 30 minutes walking through the lovely gardens. (The museum also features a separate building for temporary exhibits, which we didn't have time to visit). If you are interested in art and culture, visit this museum! You'll be happy you did.

Extensive collection and nice park. The park is great, the museum is OK. I missed more depth in the information with the items. Eg you would see "two chinese cats in porselain". But I would like to know what they were used for. I can see that it are two cats...

Don't miss this amazing collection. Few museums or galleries can boast such a wide variety of art in so many forms and from so many time periods and locations. - quite remarkable. We particularly enjoyed seeing the Chinese porcelain and the Islamic glasswork, and the stand-out section is the one devoted to the Lalique jewellery. There's plenty of pre-revolutionary French furniture and then you'll come across a Rembrandt and a Turner just when you thought you'd seen everything. Excellent for a rainy day, no charge on Sundays (and our visit coincided with a free jazz concert in the foyer) and a very good value lunch at the popular cafeteria.

worth a visit. it is very intersting museum that shows masterpieces by european artists and collection is well displayed in this museum, it is worth a visit and you must not miss it while you are in lisboa.
Must. Small and interesting museum . Beautiful gardens around the building.Don't miss it , it worth a visit. No need more than an hour , so if you have a short break ir in a rainy day - go there.

Great museum and collection. We spent a very pleasurable afternoon at this amazing museum. The collection is well presented and lit in all the galleries. I was amazed by the imagination of the Rene Lalique collection. Do visit the special galleries as well. The restaurant is nothing special and more of a cafeteria.

Excelent. Gulbenkian's motto was "only the best", and hence the museum has masterpieces by western European artists such as Domenico Ghirlandaio, Rubens, Rembrandt, Rodin, Carpeaux, Houdon, Renoir, Dierick Bouts, Vittore Carpaccio ....

Must see. Outstanding collection beautifully displayed. The Egyptian pieces and all the early ceramic tiles and objects were particularly interesting for me. The extensive display of furniture form 1750s onward was excessive in every way. Beautiful park grounds and nice cafe. The entire staff was helpful, efficient and positive.

A fabulous collection of art. Having heard very little about this museum before arriving in Lisbon, I was pleasantly surprised, no, amazed at the breadth of the art which was collected by one man. There is a very interesting story about how he amassed enough money to collect this treasure trove but I suggest you find the story on your own. The collection ranges from some spectacular pieces of ancient art from Egypt and Greece including a krater (vase) from ancient Greece which does not show a crack or a chip. Apparently Mr. Gulbenkian dedicated himself to collecting perfect pieces when he could. Some of the Egyptian objects were stunning. Then, there are the paintings from a collection of the greatest artists the world has known. I wandered into one room and my gaze was drawn to a portrait of an old man which was riveting - In two seconds, I realized that only Rembrandt could have painted that - and it was indeed a Rembrandt. This is a relatively small museum (think of the Frick in Manhattan) but do not leave Lisbon without going.

Top notch Museum.. FREE on Sunday.. Top Notch museum rivals with Europe's Best ones. huge collection or art objects, paintings sculptures.You get a 20% Discount if you buy the Lisbon card!Tip you can eat a great meal at the local cafeteria!

Truly a must see. I can understand why this is #1 TA Lisbon choice! In addition to all the other accolades received, I want to add the fact that you can actually get VERY close to the art pieces without alarms going off! Don't miss the carpets. They are absolutely beautiful and displayed on the floor the way carpets were meant to be seen. Your time will be well spent at the Gulbenkian and the senior discount brings admission to €2,50. If you just want to catch a quick sandwich, hit the cafeteria in the modern art building. The cafeteria in the main building was staffed with a single tray line server.

Disappoint. What a piece of disappointing feelings here, I mean yuck, no story whatsoever to glue the pieces together, very sad and most definitely a celebration of the small here in the calouste gulbenkian. And the shop is not so big worthy either.
Superbly rich and interesting. Ranging from Egyptian artifacts to Impressionist paintings, the collection of this museum is a must-see if you happen to be in Lisbon. Also, entrance is pretty cheap.

Amazing collection of artwork and treasures from around the world. This has to be one of the best museums I have ever visited. It is a must for visitors to Lisbon. The Chinese section was amazing. It's a great place to visit. Not so sure young children would appreciate this place.
a must see. twenty minute walk from the hotel set in lovely gardens. An amazing collection of art, pottery, sculpture, furniture.

Excellent, Interesting Musuem. Diverse and well-curated, the Gulbenkian provided the opportunity to see many pieces spanning both Europe and Asia, ancient to modern. I particularly enjoyed the Roman medallions depicting Alexander the Great, an Assyrian relief, and some Chinese vases. There is an impressive European painting gallery - I wasn't so much interested in the European furniture or Ottoman carpets, but the variety gives me the impression that one will find something that resonates with them and will make the trip worthwhile. A visit of 60-90 minutes will be best, but one could probably cut it to 30-45 in a pinch and still have an enjoyable visit.

An absolute delight. We fortuitously stumbled upon this lesser known private collection of art when seeking shelter on a very rainy afternoon in Lisbon. What a surprise! The collection turned out to be one of the highlights of our trip. From ancient artefacts, through mosaics, pottery, furniture and art, it was a delight to browse through. While eclectic, the collection was of exceptional quality and highlighted further by the building in which it is housed, with its full length windows giving views to the beautiful gardens. The fact that it was not overcrowded, like a lot of museums, was an added bonus. A definite must see in Lisbon.
A Must Visit Museum. Gulbenkian was Armenian by birth and sheltered by Portugal during WW II. His personal collection over the course of 40 years is his gift to Lisbon. It is exquisite.

A wonderful surprise. The Gulbenkian is absolutely brilliant! Read a short history before you go, or just go. So manageable. Just one room each devoted to various times and periods, so it is not overwhelming. Beautifully done, magnificent pieces. Many of which came from one collection. Easy to take the metro here, free on Sunday. And their Museum of Contemporary Art is right next door. Also free on Sunday.

Badly curated. While it is understandable for a private collection like this to be fairly eclectic, there wasn't anything memorable that we could recall not only now, but just days after our visit. The pottery collection is vast, but that's a very niche form of art that doesn't appeal to most visitors. Definitely had potential, just never lived up to it, which was disappointing considering how much we liked their modern art museum next door.
Must see. One of the main attractions in Lisbon, for the collection itself and the building, with its amazing gardens.

Mark it on the list. Easily accessible via the metro and very interesting, the collection is comprehensive, with all kinds of artefacts from different eras and cultures, well structured and easy to walk through.

Fairly new Museum with Gardens. This is the latest Museum in Lisboa, it has a good garden encircling it which makes and ideal attraction for families on Sundays. It features two restaurants and is near the Plaza Espanha.

An Eclectic Collection. This is a truly amazing collection - as you enter there are ancient Egyptian artefacts followed by a vast room displaying oriental rugs and beyond that old master paintings including a magnificent portrait of an old man by Rembrandt. The museum is a little out of the way at the top end of the Parque Edouardo VII, but there is a Metro station nearby. This is a must for fine art lovers.
A good place to visit if the weather is not up to much. Easily accessible and very interesting. Loads to go at, I especially liked the Turners on display. Corot too.
A fine collection of Chinese artifacts................... An interesting museum , open on Sundays , gardens and a cafe , has many mid - eastern items of interest

Visit on a Sunday morning its free!. We'd been past on one of the tour buses and my husband had been before many years ago. As it was recommended by a tour guide we should go on Sunday as it was free until 13.00hours.It's a very well organised space with some superb works of art, sculpture, furniture and antiquities all beautifully exhibited. Not somewhere I would take children under 10 but for adults its fine. We took the Metro but you can get there by hop on hop off buses and possibly by tram too.The guide is a massive book in its own right and most people seemed to use the audio guide available.I have never seen Lalique ware so close up, it is exquisite. The Chinese pottery, stunning clocks and works by Monet, Manet, Constable, Gainsborough, Rodin and many others are a real treat.

More People Should Visit. The main collection is one floor, laid out in a rectangle, and arranged chronologically. Unusually, the floors are polished wood boards as are most of the exhibit walls creating a warm environment in which the collection stands out. I visited Sunday, which is a free day, and a cash donation was not accepted. Unlike major city museums such as the Met, Prado, or Louvre, Gulbenkian is easily covered. Also unlike those museums, it was uncrowded; good for me, not so good for those who miss out. Take the Metro and see a very special museum in a world class city.

Diverse and surprising collection. The Gulbenkian collection is extraordinarily diverse, spanning a so-so Egyptian collection, some interesting Graeco-Roman material, some fascinating Persian textiles, Chinese porcelain, some Armenian material, stunning European medieval manuscripts, a collection of French empire silver and furniture and an extraordinary collection of European paintings, including some masterpieces. Quite a smorgasbord! The museum is well laid out and curated, and the surrounding gardens are a delight.
Beautiful Collection. We were lucky enough to go on a free admission Sunday. The museum is beautifully laid out and contains some really stunning pieces. The gardens are also beautiful
Fantastic museum. We loved this museum and the way it was layed out as well as the building and the story behind the family.

Go on a Sunday for free. Tickets are free if you go on a Sunday, but just make sure you ask for tickets to the contemporary galleries as well because the guards won't let you into those with just museum tickets. The museum was nothing special. I'd recommend exploring the gardens instead!

Fabulous. This ranks as one of the world's great museum's - encyclopedic in scope and rich in contents. This is a place to enjoy over a decent length of visit rather than rushing to see "greatest hits". It is a truly enriching experience. Enjoy.

A lovely private collection in a gorgeous setting. It was a little tricky to find the building, but we were glad we persevered. The Gulbenkian collection is certainly limited to one art lover's interests. But his interests and tastes covered a lot of territory and he built a wonderful collection. The building is set in a beautiful park and was thankfully free of crowds.

Good for a rainy Sunday afternoon. Expect an interesting mix of pieces - some quite unique - from most corners and times of the world. Do not expect too much information about them, they are basically sorted into different rooms and displayed in a rather conservative manor. Entry is free on Sunday, and it was not very crowded when we went there on a rainy Sunday in early October.

Impressive collection. We spent a morning at this impressive museum. We were almost overwhelmed by the amount of art objects. Beautiful setting with nice views of the surrounding park in between. I found the history behind the collection part of the charm.

A slightly uneven collection, but at their best the exhibits are amazing. Calouste Gulbenkian was a phenomenally rich man able to indulge his interests in the arts - and the collection here shows that in spades. Stretching as it does from ancient Egyptian artefacts up to 20th century glass by Rene Lalique, it could never hope to be complete, nor yet of an even quality - his collection of Impressionists is not terribly impressive, for example. But the highlights of the collection - in particular the carpets and the Turkish and Persian ceramics - blew me away: the collection is simply stunning.The main museum is one part of the complex: there is a second exhibition space at the side and the Centro de Arte Moderne is on the other side of the park. I paid just to visit the main museum collection.The gallery is housed in a building that is the embodiment of 1960s brutalism: but it has been fitted into a public park area that makes it genuinely beautiful. If you didn't fancy the art inside, the park is a good place to sit and contemplate the world going by (and the museum cafe, which serves decent food at reasonable prices, is accessible from outside too)

A private collection of an oil tycoon. It is the private collection of the Armenian oil tycoon Calouste Gulbenkian who died in Lisbon and left it to my country. I no longer wish to visit big museums where, due to the crowds, one can no longer see anything. Better choose a small museum like this one which keeps a marvelous Turner and a good Manet. There is also a recent building - of Modern Art - which I did not find attractive. After a long day visiting other places the Gulbenkian Gardens are a blessing. There is a beautiful cafeteria where you ca eat.

Don't Miss This. This is a must see museum while in Lisbon. The collection is eclectic and dazzling. There is jewlery from ancient Egypt, rare Oriental rugs, sculptures from the 14th century, impressionistic paintings, furniture. Everything there will amaze and impress you. This is a must see.

Great museum in Lisbon. I think the layout, flow and presentation of the art work is outstanding. It follows a chronological timeline from Egyptian art through to the 19th century. The ceramics, carpets, tapestries, book bindings and furniture are all very well preserved. The audio tour is very helpful. We spent about 2 hours in the museum and arrived just before the opening at 10am. By the time we left it was much more crowded.

Glad I visited, but feel no need to return. A good place for people interested in decorative arts, works of antiquity, and fine art from the 15th to 19th centuries. Easy to get to by metro, and close to El Corte Ingles. I think they should reconsider charging and extra admission for their special exhibitions. Paying once should be enough. I favor modern and contemporary art, so I enjoyed Museu Coleção Berardo far more.

Worth the effort. On the edge of the city, pleasant walk up through the park with good view over the city. A great worldwide collection of many interesting and unusual items. Not to be missed if in Lisbon.
Amazing collection of arts and crafts. Calouste Gulbenkian collected art objects from all over the world. I was amazed how much one man can collect. This museum has something for each interest.

This museum is PHENOMENAL.. This museum is PHENOMENAL.What I'd like to call out specifically, though, is the building itself. It's a midcentury modern design lover's dream. Worth spending some time having a coffee in the cafe (which is a retro slide-your-tray-along-the-line cafeteria) or just sitting in the various corners and taking in the light as it streams through the galleries.
Impressive collection of art from most relevant periods in great building. Modern building with very well exposed broad art collection of this remarkable immigrant from Armenia.

A little disappointed. Perhaps I was expecting too much after reading all the reviews. Honestly this is a nice little museum with all kinds of exhibits from all over the world but can't really compare it to museums from other major European cities. It's just not there yet.

Great mid-sized museum with unique exhibits. The Gulbenkian was one of the highlights of our trip to Lisbon. It's a very nicely organized mid-sized museum with many unique exhibits, including ornate tilework and carpets from the 1400s through 1600s that we've not seen in any other European museum. It was quite amazing to see these spectacular ornate rugs that have survived virtually intact after 500 years of use!

Antonio Charrua retrospective in modern art building. The retrospective of Antonio Charrua in Gulbenkian Museum ( Modern Art Building) seems to be a major event. First it is a very comprehensive presentation of work of an artist who chose to be a provincial painter in Evora, Alentejo. Second it shows the almost complete oeuvre of the artist practically unknown to most experts, art historian and to the public at large attending modern art shows. It is, indeed, a breath taking event. Organized on two floors of spacious exhibition hall it allows to see and contemplate his work with necessary perspective to compare miniature sketches of the artist’s notebooks (numerous of those presented in small glass-boxes) with some monumental size triptychs and canvas displayed on the white walls. An overall impression is one of an artist in a constant search of identity. It starts with Modigliani-like faces in cubistic perspective and moves on to very original constructive paysages of boats,, places ant things done with an excellent sense of proportion and very tame in using colors. Those pictures were created in 1950, the artist being in his twenties and are absolutely original and promising. What happened next was the gradual abandoning of constructivism and acceptance of colors as the major form of expression. Here he seems pleasant but somewhat repetitive and lacks originality. He seem to be aware of losing his painting voice and, to compensate for it, he adapts symbolism of simple signs or letters and transforms them through kaleidoscopic use of colors. Under impression of or the imitation of major abstract American painters, at least according to the written explanation of curators, he seems to be desperate to be en vogue in grasping major themes of contemporary dramas. Here he fails admirably and his paintings of tribute to Hiroshima victims seem the weakest of the whole exhibit. Next comes incorporation of letter symbols into color fields with mixed results. Miniature sketches are moving, large canvases partially destroy intention for sake of grandiosity. There is, however, a very interesting, new trend in later pictures. Instead of adopting masters and luminaries of modern art, particularly Americans, he starts looking at his own work as the source of inspiration. He transforms his own pictures endlessly. Surrounded by his own paintings (he almost never parted with them) he paints them better and better as if in search of ultimate self-expression. And here he succeeds again being a provincial painter in a small Alentejo town who had overcome the fruitless efforts to be inspired by famous masters and found the originality in his own paintings.
Petite jewelbox of a museum. Possibly the best museum I've been to, small but excellently curated collection that is world-class from beginning to end.

Every single piece is absolutely beautiful . The guy knew what he was doing!. The cream of collections. Head here on a rainy day. We were especially bowled away by the Islamic section and the European art but if you like Lalique there's a whole room full of it!

Visit to Gulbenkian in Lisbon. Excellent small museum. Perfect exposition and right amount
Amazing Roman and Greek coins
Problem with the parking : parked across the street
Must go there. Building of the Museum nice..paints are very nice ;we Spent 3 hours at the Museum and I felt very happy.İf you'll visit Lisbon Must go there
One not to miss. The range of dates is hard to fathom. Started tour in coffee shop. They have a wide variety of foods all very tasty. As trip advisor ranks this is clearly number one.

Two excellent museums on one site. As with most of my reviews for this trip, because my partner is on crutches I am commenting first on access for people with mobility problems. For a new building in lovely landscaped grounds this one was particularly poor. Aesthetics have won out over function so paths with a slight incline have been laid out in many shallow steps rather than a gentle slope. An accessible ramped path that runs parallel to a couple of flights of steps ends in more steps! The museums themselves were well laid out; we went primarily to see the modern art museum which I have reviewed separately.The main museum was an eclectic collection with not too much of anything so it managed to hold one's attention pretty well. In particular there were some interesting paintings, with works by Manet and Degas and a couple of fine Gainsboroughs; for me there was insufficient explanation of their context.

Don't miss it!. We have spent a wonderful time at this foundation compound (two museums, lovely gardens and open air music show in the summer time). The Gulbenkian collection is quite stunning, don't miss it! It contains a beautiful and quite eccentric collection of art and artifacts which are very well displayed. And its not too big to tire you up. Great Cafeteria and beautiful gardens. Have a pick at the contemporary art museum as well (situated at the other end of the gardens) - we thought it was not as interesting as the collection, but surly worth a visit.

one of the best museums in Lisbon. the collection is comprehensive, with all kinds of artefacts from different eras and cultures, well structured and easy to walk through, exhibiting a reasonable amount of top value items. Surrounded by a nice park, where you can wander around to complete you visit. I went on Sunday morning (for free), so there was a queue (not too long though).

Beautiful Foundation with superb art. Well located in the centre of Lisbon this is one of the most known foundations / museum in the City. Historically rich, not only because of the art and the person who wanted to create it, but also for all the projects that the foundation, through the years until now, keeps doing.
A must see Museum. This museum is a gem. It has excellent artifacts collected from around the world which are very well displayed.
amazing private collection. Splendid museum. Almost every peace of the collection is worth admiring for at least 10 minutes!!! Great shop too.
The joy of the Gulbenkian. It is full of the most wonderful things and not to crowded. such a joy. to be able to stand so close was a really great experience

A truly great museum. Although away from the tourist epi-centers of Lisbon, this terrific museum is well worth a visit. If you are interested in classical antiquity and/or Eastern Islamic art, this is the place to go. Pieces are in fantastic shape and exquisitely laid-out in very large airy rooms. Ceramics, fabrics (especially rugs), gold objects, and glassware are shown off to great advantage. As expected from a "private collection", there are also smaller (and in my mind, weaker) assortments of Chinese articles, European furniture, and mostly late 18th and 19th century Western wall art including works by Gainsborough, Turner, Manet, Renoir, Degas, and Monet to name a few of the more fashionable artists. An added bonus is a wonderful room filled with jewelry creations by Rene Lalique. Unusual for a museum, the cafeteria offers a fine menu of hot and cold foods at very reasonable prices.
