The associated bookstore is quite good and offers some fine Gulbenkian Foundation Art books, including a large 215 page collection highlight summary for a bargain €18. If you need some fresh air, the museum is set in a large stroll-through park. The only downside -- searching for on-street parking.

Sumptious artifacts from around the world. Dont stint yourself. This museum deserves every hour you can spare. Take a day or even two to enjoy not just the museum but its wonderful garden too. There are often free concerts in the nearby concert hall, and don't forget the the Museum of Modern Art which shares the grounds.

A varied and interesting museum. I went to the Calouste museum on a Friday and thoroughly enjoyed the exhibition. The displays were varied and well described. There were a few other visitiors but I didn't find it busy, I probably spent two hours inside. Definitely worth the 5 Euro entry!

World Class Museum Experience. While not in the city center, this museum nevertheless is an absolute must for any visitor to Lisbon with even the slightest interest in art. The collection is as eclectic as it is massive. Exhibit after exhibit demands your time to view wonderful pieces. Other virtues include an absence of the crowds one would normally expect at this type of sight, a very nice cafe and a superb reasonably priced book covering the museum's collection available in the book shop. All in all, an absolute delight.

Hidden Gem. Well worth the effort of three Metro changes and a short walk.Eclectic collection of art all of which is top draw.Pleased to find a few Edward Burne Jones who is my favourite artist amongst the mainly European collection with a fine smattering of the Oriental as well as some of Laliques finest.

Watch out for the line on the ground!. Deciding to acces this museum on a day when the temperatures outside were 30 degrees centigrade was an excellent choice for us. The air conditioning, the peace, calm and plenty of space between the exhibits was the perfect way to spend several hours. The collections really need no comment, as they speak for themselves. The only piece of advice is beware that in front of some of the paintings are lines on the floor beyond which one is not allowed to step but we had not noticed them until one of the attendants pointed them out very quietly, so caught up in the beauty of the artistry we had not realised we had moved too close. Some of the labels are rather small for those who need to read them at close quarters but their positioning is set at a hight for those in wheelchairs. When we visited, the museum was quite empty - a real pleasure to be able to share these collections and in spite of the floor markings, still be able to view them at close quarters.

worth a visit... stop 15 on red hop on hop off bus. private collection of arts and valuables. Lovely setting. good café and shop. easy to reach on hop on hop off bus. great variety of ceramics , Persian rugs, work of famous artists.

amazing art display. They have a wonderful selection of different artworks here and its very comfortable to walk round as the security is unobtrusive. felt very privileged to see so many wonderful paintings at such close quarters.
Very well orgtanized and impressive collection. A wonderful exhibition and very well maintained and impressive facility. Several exhibitions are on at the same time so each is priced separately.

Engaging, eclectic collection. This was most pleasnt cultural curiosity, an idvidual's personal collection dedicated yo yther classicL and oriental arts. The benefactor for whom the museum is named apparently mader fortune in oil in the early and mid 20th century, and spent much of it on obsessively collectioning some 6,000 pieces, from ancient coins, one his favorites, to exquisite pottery. Also plaques and textiles,and a smattering of early European art, all well displayed in an agttractive museum that did not seem to get very crowded.
Great experience. The museum is one of highlights of our trip to Lisbon.You will never want to miss this place.The exposition is rich, interesting and well organised.

Recreation from too much sun and heat. A Musuem that reminds me on our Wallraff- Richartz- Museum in Cologne, Germany. I was glad to se the extra exhibition of Lourdes Castro. I never heard about her and I bought the "Deutsch- Hefte" a wonderfull very personal book which she made for a friend to help him learn german. Also I was surprised about two pictures from Turner. The ship wreck impressed me much especially the mother who take care of ther child. I love the impressionist painters Monet, Manet and Renoir. So I were glad to find there paintings from them. Even the modern part is worth to visit. I spent a whole day there and in the surrounding park.

roger1278. This is our third visit to Lisbon & it was only because of the suggestion of our tour leader that we chose to visit this museum. The Museum is quite handy to the city centre a short taxi ride. As seniors our entry fee was minimal. It is incredible to learn that this was the collection of an Armenian financier & contains some 6,000 objects. Initially collecting Greek coins,rare books,pottery,Lalique the range now includes Art,Sculpture,Tapestries,Furniture & stretches from Ancient Egypt through to France in the 1930's. The collection is spectacular & beautifully presented. I would urge any tourist visiting Lisbon to add this Museum to the must do list. We very much enjoyed the couple of hours spent here.

Free on Sundays!. We visited this museum Sunday morning and it was quite full; the entrance is free on Sundays, all other days is 4 euros per exhibition. We enjoyed modern art exhibition a lot - there is a piece of art, into which it is possible to crawl on four!

Unique & Refreshing Portraits grip your attention!. It's not often that you see an exclusive Portrait Exhibition but the Gulbenkian featured precisely that! This of course was the temporary show apart from the permanent collection of ancient and medieval art. We were fortunate to visit on Sunday when the entire Museum is free. A variety of styles and media were on display in the Portrait Exhibition as also spanning several centuries of work. Truly unique!
The best in Lisbon. A really incredible Museum, well worth a visit. The Egyptian art is very good and it always has a good variety. The garden surrounding it is excellent.
Fascinating museum. A really interesting collection, allow plenty of time to explore the many and varied exhibits. We enjoyed the garden as well.

A beautiful diversified museum. A beautiful museum with a very diversified collection: paintings, furniture, sculpture, china. It has a predominance for the XIX century and Art Deco period, but a lot of variety that enriches the experience!

A must do - excellent musem. Truly the highlight (aside from the food) of our stay. The collection is amazing and the park is lovely. We spent at least four hours there going to the various exhibits as well as the museum. Free on Sunday, so that made it extra nice.
Beautiful and worth visiting. Fantastic museum and peaceful garden. Wide spectrum of precious objects from an art-loving collector - for me a must-see in Lisbon.

Magpie museum, worth seeing. This museum was highly recommended. It's a magpie collection so it lacks a bit of coherence and the information was fairly minimalist and could have been more informative. Also, it's hard to find. However, there were some really excellent pieces. We particularly liked the portrait of a clearly fed up Mme Monet.

Beautiful collection and well presented. This is a great museum of one man's collection. It takes you through history with examples of art etc from the different eras. The presentations are great. Well worth visiting.
Fvourite smaller museum. One of my favourite small museums, mostly for its Egyptian and Mesopotamian artifacts which are elegantly set out. .

Worth a visit! . Be it for the Museum, the classical music, the gardens, the peacefulness, or simply to explore a new place, if you're in Lisbon you have to stop by Fundacao Calouste Gulbenkian. What a fantastic place for a visit!

Beautiful Museum!. This was a total surprise and a delight. The collection is very broad and consists of high quality pieces. Gulbenkian was the Getty of Portugal, but he had a better eye. You could easily spend an entire day here. One of our fun surprises was that the 18th century clocks in the collection were all running and keeping the correct time! Museum cafeteria was very good. A 'Must See'! Easy access from the Metro.
Impressive. This museum contains a lot of different arts.We enjoyed the collection of vases, asian arts, carpets and living rooms.

One of the best Museums in Lisbon. On of the best Museums in Lisbon. Has several collections ranging from modern art to antiques. The surrounding gardens are some of the best in Lisbon. So you can go there also to enjoy them have a bite or just relax near the pounds.

One of the finest in the world. This small museum is one of the finest in the world. The exhibits are laid out very well in both space and how they are done. Quality rather than quantity. It is absolutely amazing what this individual was able to collect and is now displayed. Admission is free on Sunday and photography is allowed without flash. Definitely not to be missed when in Lisbon.
One of the best museums in Portugal. Internationaly well known for the dedication to all art forms the Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian museum is part of that reality with great works from all ages.

A must-see!. This is a superb collection, housed in a specially-designed building which, in turn is situated in beautiful grounds.Based on the collection of Calouste Gulbenkian himself it covers an extensive geographical area and over three thousand years of art history.Unlike many other museums and galleries, it is sufficiently spacious for all the exhibits to be seen clearly without being jostled by others. You should allow something like three hours to appreciate it fully.

On a rainy day...... Premices: made in the 70' and look really old fashion plus glasses are not always cleaned properly. No big museum and not so many paintings. Lots of antique Turkish / chinese without any clarification on the reason why they are there.Exhibition interesting but nothing astonishing. Too little explanations on the art if you do not hire the electronic devices. Bit of a disappointment by all.

Worth so much more time!. We had only five hours at this amazing museum and could easily have spent a couple of days. The vast collections housed here are truly amazing and so incredibly interesting. The exhibit are well lighted and spaced so that each piece can be viewed on its own merit without interference of another piece to distract your attention.I plan to return again in the Spring.
Wonderful museum. Wonderful museum; some real treasures. Small enough to see it all, but still plan on half a day if you want to see most of it -a few hours if you're just looking for a diversion.

The architecture of the museum is as interesting as the collection inside. What can I say? This museum housing personal collection of Gulbenkian is one of the very best small-medium art museums I have ever seen
A little gem. Free on Sunday's a wonderful small very interesting museum. Three star Michelin rating. Beautiful paintings, incredible French furniture and best of all Art Deco Lalique!

Interesting but Small Collection. We by chance visited on a free Sunday - no admission - what a bonus. This gallery has some nice pieces but is easily done in an hour. We love great art galleries - this one was ok not great
Great little museum!. Great range of quality objects! Fantastic example of quality over quantity and well displayed! The Oriental items and Ancient Greek coinage , medallions were my favourites.
i liked the Persian Art. I am not a fan of art museums , but this has interesting and informative collection set in a lovely park

One of everything!. A little out of the main centre, set in its own lush green oasis is the modern museum building of the collection of Calouste Gulbenkian. It really does have one of everything (a quote I stole from a Canadian lady I met at lunch at the Cafe Martinho) - one Rembrandt, one Turner, etc, but an abundance of 14th century Turkish tiles. It's a really interesting collection and worth visiting if you like arty things. Also worth noting is it's brilliantly air conditioned so a great place to hide from the scorching Lisbon sun. There is a cafeteria in the basement which has a terrace overlooking the gardens - I can't vouch for it as it was so busy I couldn't get in! Also, the gardens were also very pleasant to walk around.

Awesome collection. This has to be my favorite museum in Portugal. Great paintings. And if you're lucky you can catch one of the brief expositions. Overall, it is a very nice space, with a beautiful garden where you can spend some time after the visit to the museum.
Awesome. Free on Sundays- we went for the Lalique but it is a wonderful museum in a wonderful building in a wonderful garden! You can spend hours here.

Good for a brief afternoon visit. It's not one of the most impressive museums I've ever visited, but worth it as a reprieve from the hot, sunny weather. The collection contains a variety of art - textiles/rugs, ceramics, paintings, scupture, and furniture from a broad range of culture and time periods. There are many works acquired from the Hermitage that are absolutely lovely. The scale of the museum is a little underwhelming.

Fascinating museum. We enjoyed a family visit to the Gulbenkian. Each room is packed full of fascinating pieces from the early Eqyptians to beautiful Lalique jewellery. There's interesting Islamic rugs, early coins, beautifully illustrated books, some great pre-French Revolution furniture and a collection of pictures including some Impressionist pieces (which were my favourite). The visit took a good couple of hours. We followed it with lunch in the restaurant which was reasonable and a walk through the lovely gardens.

Not TOO big, eclectic and every single item top class. I have been around the museum a couple of times, most recently with my 30 year old (how did that happen) daughter - not previously known to be a museum buff. We had a great hour or so. The collection starts with Egyptian antiquities then ranges far and wide with French furnishings, lots of splendid Persian carpets, some very good pre-Raphaelite English paintings, equisite porcelains etc. etc.I easily run out of concentration in a Louvre/Uffizzi size gallery but you could, if you wished, get around most of the Gulbenkian in forty minutes. So I like that. And every piece displayed is absolutely top class. If you find a class of items which you particularly like you are in for a rare treat.Each time I have been there has always been groups of very young and extraordinarily well behaved children sitting on the floor listening to their teachers and that, too, has great charm.Finally, the gardens around the museum are well worth a short wander, with a lot of water features and a lovely calming influence.A memorable place to visit.
Cultural fun day. One of the Best cultural spots im town, with fabulous exhibitions and one of the most beautiful parks... Perfect for a cultural and fun family day

Pure magic!. This is the good reason to go to Lisbon. It is an amazing museum - what riches and how brilliantly curated. The wealth of extraordinary paintings (two major Rembrants, huge number of impressionists and a whole room of Guardi) speak for themselves but other exhibits (from Egypt, Greece and Middle East) are jaw droppingly fantastic too. The Lalique jewellery collection (the last room) will quicken your heart as well.It isn't a huge museum and you can easily see most of the permanent exhibits in about 4 hours. If you feel tired, you can pop over to their cafe which has good food and some outside tables overlooking the lovely gardens. Relax in the sunshine, with the ducks walking by, and then return for more culture on the same ticket.One of my favourite museums in the world. Do not miss.

An awesome gem. The museum is one of the best I have ever visited. It is the essence of a well curated and displayed collection. The building is an exceptional space for displaying art, each piece in the collection is top quality and the thoughtfulness with which they are displayed stands out. This is not a crowded museum... the pieces are well spaced so that you can focus on, and enjoy each piece. It is not like the Louvre with hundreds of pieces of each type. This museum shows you one of two of the best examples.
Excellent museum. If you only have time for one museum, this is it. It's amazing how close you can get to a Renoir,Rodin, Rembrandt. Everything was so interesting, get the audio...

Stunning. If you go to one Museum in Lisbon , this is the one. Its a diverse ans visually stunning collection that is of the highest standard and equals many much better known international museum collections. It is housed in a wonderful complex and it is exhibited beautifully. Go enjoy!

Small museum. Its easy to reach. Unique jewels. Fantastic!. Small museum full of artworks. 10 minutes by car from downtown.
The works are not all excelled, but the jewels of Lalique are extraordinary workmanship and creativity.
Some forniture have been very apprezziate.

Just the right size!. The magnificent but understandable collection is beautifully and spacially displayed, allowing you to take in everything without the overwhelming size of some of the larger institutions. The nice cafe could do with some good sandwiches and wraps rather than just hot food or cake! Very reasonably priced for such a major museum. Go see! But don't mistake it for the theatre which faces you on arrival. The entrance is on your left side.

A very special and unique museum. it is housed in a building specifically designed to share Mr. Gulbenkian outstanding collection in a warm environment surrounded by beautiful gardens. You'll find the best Isnik ware outside Turkey, amazing Lallique and Persian old carpets, as well as exquisite decorative arts objects and great master's paintings.

Old and interesting. Entrance fee 5 euro, but a discount for students!Most of the artifacts are of Mesopotamia, those which are not are of a similar style: very old, very interesting, and also very old.

Very calming after being in Lisbon for several days.. Great place to spend 1/2 day and it is outside city center which can be both dirty and congested. We toured museum first the strolled through gardens had a great lunch for two for only 13 euros and then toured modern art museum. Ticket was 10 euros and another 4 for the audio guide it was best day we had in Lisbon.
very nice. very nice museum,very decorated with a big garden outside with some bar and restaurants.inside you can find also very interesting pictures and other interesting things.

Something for eberyone. The staff in this museum is wonderful and accommodating. There was absolutely no line and we had the museum almost to ourselves. As we entered I realized what a wonderful and varied collection they have. I visited with my toddler ( that is very patient and well behaved) and my 9 year old. We admired all of the masterpieces they have from every corner of the world and afterwards went downstairs where they have a lovely cafeteria with an outside terrace. To our surprise, the cafeteria opens out to a beautifully landscaped park full of waterfowl and shady places to sit and relax( or to run around in case you are still a kid). They provide baby changing station in the museum and there is a small souvenir shop as well. I would definitely recommend this museum, and in case you are traveling with young children, is doable in about 1 hour.

Interesting collections in a beautiful setting. Loved the way that the interiors linked with the gardens outside. varied and well presented collections of art and artefacts spanning early Egypt and Greece to early twentieth century. Good audio tour. I especially liked the islamic tiles and the Lalique jewellery.

Gulbenkien as a thoughtful and sensitive collector.. A must do in Lisbon. This museum has a very esoteric collection of art and artefacts, well curated, in different languages. The Turkish porcelain collection is amazing! The European Masters are well represented in the art collection. As for the 18th century furniture, it is fabulous.

Rich, classic, cultural.. We visited the museum today, on Sundays you will always find free entrance tickets.
There was all sorts of ancient art: from Greek, to ancient Chinese, Baroque French and more contemporary french painters.
Very pleasing and recommended - if you're an art geek you cannot miss it and you can easily spend 2hrs+ in it.
Great!. The museum is really great. You are amazed with the colorful tiles and ornaments you see.It is one of the best museums you shoulld visit.

Revel in luxury.... An insight into what wealth could/can buy if you have refined taste. The ceramics and carpets are fabulous (visit the tile museum BEFORE coming here or you will be very slightly disappointed) and the paintings lovely. French ormulu leaves me cold but there is plenty for those who love it.

Go Gulbenkian!. No visit to Lisbon would be complete without a visit to this wonderful museum with its stunning tapestries and tiles from 15th century. Also surprisingly satisfying collection of Impressionist paintings, If you do visit (and you should) you will understand my thoughts that William Morris gleaned much from this era...An eclectic collection from a discerning collector. Cafe looked extremely welcoming too.

The museum is a cab ride away from the center of town - and worth the trip. The museum is open Wednesday to Monday from 10 to 6. I had to take a cab out to the museum (from the cruise port) and the trip was well worth the trouble. I caught a cab for my return in front of the museum - as others used taxis to get to the museum.The European, Egyptian, oriental and Islamic art and objects are excellent. Please read the full story of the Foundation Gulbenkian and collector Gulbenkian before you visit.

A nice way to spend an artly afternoon. The museum is a nice way to spend an artly afternoon in Lisbon. Displaying hundreds of artifacts from all over the world it really makes it a small wonder on how so many artifacts were collected during one man's life. At least they are now on display for the people to see and admire.

It was an amazing expereience.. A must see collection of furniture and rugs.Gulbenkian has been a supporter of education for so many years.He has offered excellent opportunities to families for many years. Now seeing their collections brought tears to my eyes.

Quiet place in the city. If you seek a cultural moment in a quiet Place in Lisbon, Fundaçao Calouste Gulbenkian is the place. It's gardens make you forget that you are in the city. The library is very quiet and filled with awesome books about art. The museum always has free exhibitions and sometimes concerts. A definite place to visit for art lovers and students.

Modern Art Gallery - disappointing but lovely gardens. I only went to the modern art gallery and not the main museum which is also situated in the same park.The massive Yoruba shrine was colourful and impressive. This was located just before the door into the main gallery - which was just one large space, the size of an aircraft hanger. A fantastic space, but wish I'd done more careful research on what was being exhibited. It was all good stuff, but not to my taste and mostly in a similar vein.

A superb collection. I think this might be my new favourite small(ish) museum anywhere in the world. It's difficult to believe that this is the collection of one man. One man with superb good taste. Set in beautiful gardens, in a post-modern building, the galleries are arranged around lovely green courtyards. I loved everything about the museum apart from the restaurant, which can't decide whether to be a self-service canteen or provide waiter service. So it gets you to queue up with a tray and then have someone put your salad on a plate for you. I forgive them though, because the food was good, pretty cheap, and the coffee was brilliant. Plus I got to eat it on a lovely outdoor decking area in the pretty gardens. The Gulbenkian is a bit of a hike (or metro ride) from the centre of Lisbon, but worth it.

A cool gallery for a hot day. set in beautiful gardens this Bauhaus sixties style building houses an impressive and electric collection of art from the ancient world through Rene Lalique with some Manets and Turners along the way. Only 5e entrance fee. An absolute must for anyone staying in Lisbon.

Great private collection. It is almost unbelievable that a single person could amass such a diverse and fantastic collection. The museum is laid out well and visiting and viewing are a very pleasant experience. The day and time (late afternoon) the place was almost empty and we had a wonderful time strolling through the rooms at our leisure. It is worth reading up in advance of going, on the collections represented here, as the diversity is really wide-ranging, from tapestries, paintings, furniture, porcelain, rugs, and on and on. The place was lovely.

OK, but not impressive. If you have the Lisbon Card it's a free entry location, which makes it worth your time. But otherwise, I didn't find it very impressive. Lots of ceramics and religious cult objects, average paintings. I did see some interesting pieces of furniture.

Not to be missed.. This is a great collection. A bit like the Chester Beatty in Dublin. Some amazing things to see. Great cafeteria & lovely gardens.Check out opening times, think it opens Monday but closed Tues.

what amazing collection or art and antiques.. The best spot of Lisbon. Quiet far from the city center nearby Benfica stadium, it's a real experience for art addicted and lover. If need few hours to visit all the differents section of Gulbenkian collection: you will be astonished in front of Rembrandt, Monet, Manet and antiques from Siria, Turkey , China etc. Walking though the garden in priceless and you can get the collection of modern art. Thanks Mr Gulbenkian

Superb Arts and Crafts. Although we had some trouble finding the museum once we did we were amazed by all the artifacts on display medallions, pottery, rugs, furniture, paintings (French English and Italian artists). and all well presented - although you are not told before hand take note of the tape on the floor and cross it at your peril - security is very quick at arriving and telling you to stand behind it!!

Must for the Art and Crafts lovers.. Exquisite collection Egyptian, Syrian, Greek, Chinese and Japanese artifacts some of them going back 3500 years. Exceptional Lalique collection and paintings by Turner, Constable and Francesco Guardi (of Venice).
Superb. Superb collections of art, potteries, carpets, etc.. from the Muslim world. Very well organized. A feast to the eyes.

Passing through several centuries of art. It is an impressive art collection belonging now to ”The Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation”.Worth to spend few hours to visit this collection of ancient and modern art.
Great Museum. Lisbon should not be left without a visit to this fantastic museum. It is a must! New exibitions all the time, music, dance etc.

Wide range of exhibits nicely exhibited. Worth a trip to this Museum. The entrance fee is very reasonable and there is a wide selection of exhibits from different eras. The gardens around the museum are also very nice. Easy to reach on the metro

everytime I get a chance I go there. Gulbenkian Museum and gardens are a fab place to spend some time, to go back to ...
Not only there is plenty to see, but the atmosphere of the architecture and gardens are something unique.

Exquisite collection in the heart of Lisbon. Probably one of the most beautiful and exquisite museums I've ever seen. The connoisseur eye of Mr. Gulbenkian assembled an impressive collection of artifacts ranging from antique Egyptian statues to 19th century paintings and sculptures. By far, it has the most brilliant collection of antique coins.

A very pleasant afternoon!. We were invited to go to this Museum by a couple of friends. This Museum belongs to a Foundation created by a philanthropic mam that collected all his life the most beautiful pieces of furniture and accessories and jewelry. And also a very special collection of Egypt valuable art objects. We spend a few ours learning a lot and filling our eyes with beauty things.After the visit we walked along the very fresh brutally gardens and it was so good special in these hot summer days.I strongly recommend a visit to the Museum and the gardens.

The best that money can buy.. Their collection covers art from Persia, Turkey and the Far East that one is not likely to see elsewhere. Their European collection contains some exquisite items too. The modern collection was closed for renovation when we visited.

What a treasure!. Given the scope of the collections in the Gulbenkian Museum, it is hard to imagine they were gathered by one person. Art from various periods of history and geographical regions, Antiquity to early twentieth century, is displayed in very noteworthy buildings in a tranquil park setting. Unlike most museums, there is abundant natural light, with the windowshelping to maintaini a connection with the surroundings.The museum has such a breadth of offerings it should appeal to all, and the quality is amazing. There is a cafeteria, and the location is close to downtown.

One of the best museums in Portugal. In this museum you can see a big and different collection. Since artefacts from 2000 B.C. to things from the last century. From Europe to the orient. It's a must go in Lisbon. The best thing is that this museum is free in the sundays

Gem of a Museum. This is a gem of a museum. It is intimate enough that you can get through it in 1.5 hours, so not too tedious. Amazing, varied collection of paintings, period furniture, sculpture, jewelry and more. Didn't need an audio guide as everything had good signage in English. ONLY downside: it is in the middle of nowhere and finding a cab back into the heart of the city wasn't easy. Guards only suggested looking for a cab stand across the street (which I couldn't find). A cab driver took pity on me and scooped me up, so it was fine. In July, the museum had discounted admission on weekends, so it was inexpensive and wonderful.

Gulbenkian Museum- small but full of surprises!. easy to get to, was across the street from my hotel, not crowded, and as I remember, it was free? the jewelry, which I usually don't care for, was exquisite.

So glad we went. Beautiful museum. It had a wide variety of exhibits but in a spacious surrounding so it did not feel overwhelming. They offer student discounts which was great as not everywhere does. So glad we visited.

beautiful. Beautiful and eclectic collection. Well worth visiting and the Lalique display is stunning. The lighting could be better. This is one man's private collection and you get to see beautifully preserved art (Monet, Manet, Gainsborough, Rembrandt, Rubens, Troyon and others), furniture, Persian rugs, Aubusson tapestries, Sevre and Chinese porcelain.

Beautiful. 19 year old daughter and I went while teenage son was surfing; it would be his idea of hell. The classical and oriental art is fabulous. Beautiful pieces just allowed to speak for themselves. Wear comfortable shoes, we were there hours. Don't get the audio guide, the receptionist confided it is 'lousy, just a cheat'.
well done. great museum featuring many many artists from all over the world from centuries past. beautiful gardens; performance space, restaurant and many exhibits. Not to be missed!
Incredible!. This is an amazing, very personal museum. It is a fascinating collection. This is not to be missed! Be sure to check the dates/times it is open. Highly recommended!
excellent coverage of many periods in our history. A very fine museum with a good taste of what to show people and prioritise not to put to many things into the exhibition.
Must to see in Lisboa. One of the best finest museums in Lisbon. An historical journey from to the time of Greek to the fabulous collection of Lalique !!!!

Superb collection of beautiful objects. Wonderful place to wander around, Gulbenkian obviously had an amazing eye for all sorts of collectables and interesting objects - one is left gasping at the money he was able to spend on high art, Turner, Rembrandt, Manet and a fine collection of oriental porcelain are highlights here. But don't miss the gorgeous Lalique - my favourite was the most beautiful glass dragonfly. Well worth a visit if you are in Lisbon.

One of my favorite european musems. This museum alone is a reason to visit Portugal; but, note that, unlike other museums that close on Mondays, the Gulbenkian closes on TUESDAYS!...None of the guides (published this year) mentioned it, which forced us to reorganize our limited time in Lisbon. Three things I loved about the museum: a stunning collection that ranges from antique Persian ceramics, to Renaissance painting and modern works of art. You will necessarily find something to love and to discover. Second, the museum is just the right size. You can wonder around, taking your time, going back, and leaving, knowing that you have not missed anything. We were there on a Sunday (it was free too), but there were few visitors; the space is wonderful and peaceful. We had lunch in the cafeteria which is very nice. You can seat outdoors in the garden if you wish.

Very good museum with a diversified collection. I highly recommend this museum. It has some excellent sculptures, paintings, glass and pottery, and jewelry. In other words, something for everyone. Artists include Rodin, Rembrandt, Gainsborough and Manet. Note that it is closed on Tuesday.

2nd time lucky. We visited this wonderful museum today. Well actually we tried to visit on Tuesday and got all the way there by public transport to find it is now closed on Tuesdays! We had read such great reviews that we went again and we are so glad we did. The collection is quite amazing and really well displayed. The museum is modern, air conditioned (lovely as so much in Lisbon isn't and it has been very warm for our stay), and it has a very calm and spacious feel. We paid for audio guides and it helped our understanding especially of the Eastern Islamic art. The audio guide is not for every exhibit and it is easy to understand - not too detailed and wordy. This is a wonderful museum and well worth the entry fee.Note: there is a lovely garden too so if you have kids with you it would be a good place for a picnic.

Don't miss this museum!. We spent a very pleasant and interesting morning at the Gulbenkian Museum. The collection of artifacts beginning from ancient Egypt and progressing through different cultures and time periods was presented beautifully. The collection of oriental rugs and tiles was amazing! There were also some first-rate paintings by famous artists, including Rembrandt, Manet and others. The Lalique collection was also awe-inspiring.

Good Museum for Furniture and Carpets. This museum has a very nice collection of carpets and furniture. There is only 1 piece from Mesopotamia, but it is a stunner--a larger than life-size statue of one of the kings, probably from a courtyard, and in excellent condition.

Extensive collection of art set in beautiful gardens.. A short metro ride from the city centre, the Gulbenkian is worth a visit if only to see the beautiful gardens. We went on a Sunday when it was free to go in. It wasn't too busy even for July.

A trove of treasures at the Gulbekian. This museum is not like others, it is a real art collection with very beautiful items. The Collector was very wealthy and in a time of oportunities made very lucky adquistions like pieces from Eremitage in St. Petersburg. But his connection to the middle east allowed him to understand and collect it like few people in the western world. The information is sparse and even the audioguides do not substitute a good guide.

A Feast for the Eyes. A beautiful small gallery packed with treasures, this gallery/museum is very well laid out and the exhibits are beautifully presented, any lover of art will find something to enjoy. It is small and intimate but never claustrophobic, we went at the end of August when Lisbon was hot and full of tourists, but the gallery and gardens where like an oasis of cool tranquility. Enjoy the day, but possibly not for small children.
A wonderful place. I really enjoyed the place. The garden is very beautiful and big. You can sit there and relax. The museum is worth visiting. I really liked how the things are organised there.

Wonderful Gallery, Hidden Treasure. I had read reviews of this gallery as housing a wonderful collection of treasures from the Hermitage collection and was determined to visit while we were in Lisbon. However I was not prepared for such a beautifully displayed and varied collection of wonderful art, including breathtakingly beautiful Persian rugs and ceramics, European paintings and a wonderful collection of Lalique jewellery and crystal. The Lalique collection included some preparatory drawings for an exquisite haircomb and other pieces. It was a unique gallery, not too crowded and not to be missed. Marina and Bill from Australia

Small collection worth seeing. Gulbenkian has managed to acquire a small collection that is worth seeing. A good representation of art from the Far East, Persia and Europe in a beautiful setting and gardens.

Interesting Museum. This is not a very large museum; it houses the items Gulbenkian collected during his lifetime. Gulbenkian is quite well known in the oil and gas industry and since it was highly recommended in most tourist guide, we decided to take a look. The collection included Persian rugs, Chinese porcelain vases, paintings, furnitures, etc... But the best part of the museum is a tiny room on Rene Lalique. There are some beautiful pieces of jewelry on display. I really enjoyed it.There is a cafeteria on the first floor of the complex and it seems quite popular. We didn't get a chance to try but saw a lot of locals going for lunch.

Amazing collection.. True to it's reputation, this museum boasts a spectacular and varied collection of some of the most central art pieces and styles. From ancient Egyptan relics, to Islamic tiles, to Rembrand and Turner, there's surely something for everyone here.

Surely you didn't miss the Gulbenkian?. Great art museum, maybe you came for the art deco Lalique jewelry, but look back at Rembrandt. Check out the incomparable Turners, admire the furniture if you like that sort of thing. Free on Sunday morning when we went.

Good collection. Treasures galore. Well displayed but wish there had been more labels. The outdoor areas which one could view from inside the museum were planted with exotic plants but most of the windows were covered with shades to protect the art from the hot Lisbon sun.

Mid morning visit. Definitely worth 1-2 hours out of your time in Lisbon. It's close to our hotel but easy to get to by metro, as well. It's incredible to think the entire museum is just one mans collection of beautiful things. Lesser known works by major artists were much appreciated and you can't beat the €5 ticket price!! A must see for art lovers.

Beautiful Contents. Beautiful Grounds.. We absolutely loved this museum with its amazing, somewhat eclectic, collection. The building itself is not pretty; although most probably was cutting edge when it was built. The museum is, however, set in absolutely beautiful grounds (with plenty of bird life). The museum cafe terrace on the lower ground floor allows you to enjoy this lovely setting, I would thoroughly recommend this museum.

Amazing museum - definitely worth a visit!. We had read about the museum on TripAdvisor and checked it out in our Rick Steeve's Portugal which was of the same opinion as most of the reviewers. It truly is a gem and although not well known, it contains an eclectic interesting collection of art and artifacts presented in a beautiful modern tasteful building. Following our visit, we had a snack at the lovely cafe overlooking the gardens. The museum is only a short taxi ride from Rossi Square (about 6 €) and a five minute walk from the huge El Corte Ingles department store. Like the Pergamon in Berlin which is also not well known and was a wonderful surprise, this too was a fortuitous find and helped to make our stay in Lisbon a memorable one.

A great collection . A very good museum. The collection is not big but it's very interesting and high quality. Audio guide is for 4 euro which I believe it's expensive. No enough audio information about the majority of items but it's a great place to visit.

Understandable why it's in the 1000 places to see. The Museum brings together the works of art all collected by the man who idealized the Museum The pieces are arranged chronologically from Greek/Roman to Islamic to Chinese and more then recent works by European masters, including Rembrandt and Rodin. The final room has a collection of jewelry that is definitely worth the entrance. The entrance to the main museum also gives access to the museum of modern art on the same grounds (or the other way around if you start there). Getting to the museum is easy, just get off the metro at the São Sebastião stop on either the Blue or Red lines and then walk to the museum. As with most other museums in Lisbon, if you go on Sunday the entrance is free.

Small, but pretty.. Not the biggest museum I visited, but it is most definitely worth a visit. A lot of beautiful objects to see and some famous paintings scattered among the exhibition. The garden outside is really beautiful.

It was closed ;(. They changed the day of closure to a Tuesday. I had save the museums for my last day and was very disappointed to not be able to go here. The taxi didn't tell me it was closed either which was disappointing.
Very Diverse Expo. Nice visit, very diverse exposition various reasons cultures Egypt, Persia, French etc.Cost 5 euro, children free, if in town worth the visit.
Great place to visit. Perfect place "to see" or must see in Lisbon. Good cultural and educational place with huge art collections from all over the world.
Not to be missed. Amazing collection beautifully presented in a building that blends with the surrounding gardens. Take your time to visit on a Sunday morning, entrance is free until 14:00 hours.

delightful and sometimes surprising museum walk. From the most ancient pieces of art to the contemporary beautiful exponents. Spacious, beautiful and welcoming, surrounded with garden, Gulbenkian museum has a great collection to find for everybody, fond of beauty. Enjoy. Don´t forget it´s free on Sundays until 14:00 as the rest of museums in Lisbon. Loved it!

Art museum. Beautiful collection of art. From paintings, to large rugs, to sculpture, to jewelry....
the museum is situated in a very nice area. almost a university feel to it. There is a cafeteria with very good food. You can eat inside or out. I'm not typically a museum person, but really enjoyed myself here.

Eclectic art rangring through Egypt European and Far Eastern arts. We used this as a an opportunity to escape the heat of the afternoon but were entranced by an amazing collection which had us captivated for far longer than planned. The range was amazing and we were able to view without any crowding. The gardens were also a pleasure but do not bother with the cafeteria as customers seem to be viewed as an intrusion by staff.

Must See in Lisbon. We just spent a very enjoyable afternoon at this wonderful museum. A far ranging collection ranging from Egyptian, Greco-Roman and Far Eastern works to European art and furnishings of the 19th Century including some spectacular pieces by Lalique. Very modern surroundings set in gardens contribute to a peaceful non-crowded experience. If you find yourself in Lisbon, don't miss The Gulbenkian!
wonderful. its very rich collections of greek,egypt,ottoman etc...you have to visiy absolutly and Sunday is free.

The most eclectic quality art collection in Lisbon in a beautiful park.. My favorite museum in Lisbon ,most beautiful and eclectic art collection in very beautiful and relaxing garden.Exquisite pieces or jewelry and oriental art .A Lisbon gem.

Breathtaking art and artifacts. A must see. This collection is truly with seeing. The museum is beautiful and has a nice atmosphere. You can sit outside and enjoy your lunch and there is a nice cafeteria also
Beautiful and valuable collection. as above very well exposed in a new building with nice surrounding gardens in a nice quarter of lisbon
Visit. Your soul will grow a couple miles.. Just follow the itinerary, and do not miss the last room. Closed on Mondays, free Sunday morning. Amazing!

A unique collection of art treasures, a gift to Portugal from an oil baron. Calouste Gulbenkian was a Turkish-Armenian oil baron born in Turkey in 1869. During World War II, he sought sanctuary in neutral Portugal to escape the antagonism of the Allied powers.As a sign of his gratitude for the protection he was given by the Portuguese, he created the Gulbenkian Foundation which today, sixty years after his death, continues to provide the majority of funding for the arts in Portugal.His foundation established several museums and galleries and the museum that bears his name in Avenida de Berna in Lisbon is perhaps the most impressive. Housed in a relatively modern building in a lush, landscaped park, the museum's priceless collections include Eastern and European paintings, tapestries, Lalique crystal and precious metal artefacts.Perhaps what makes this collection so special is the sheer scope of the exhibits. Here you'll find ancient gold and silver Greek coins, Chinese porcelain, paintings by Rubens, Rembrandt and the Impressionists, colourful Islamic art, Japanese prints and so much more, all under the same roof.This is an unmissable treat for art and history lovers. One of the richest private collections in the world left in Calouste Gulbenkian's will to the Portuguese people. What a gift!

Not in Lisbon centro but not to be missed. Unfortunately we left this fabulous museu until our last day and did not have enough time to appreciate it fully but I would highly recommend anyone to have a look at this fabulous private collection. Calouste Gulbenkian had a very fine aesthetic sense and this is evident in his masterful collection which was formerly housed in Paris. The building was tailor made for this and is situated about 4km away from lisbon centro. It is set in splendid and tranquil gardens. I found that each area in the museu led quietly into the next and was connected in some way. From ancient Egyptian art, through roman, Persian fabrics, French furniture, amazing old clocks, small marble sculptures, small area of paintings and Lalique works. Gulbenkian's eye for exquisite art shows in the unusual and strangely compelling pieces displayed. It's not all art and not all furniture, hard to describe but wonderful to view. The final section of Lalique pieces are alone worth viewing. We spent a long time looking at the beauty and workmanship in this one room. Altogether diverting and worth the trek. We taxied it there and walked back into town. Only a few hours but wish we had longer there. Take a picnic lunch to eat in the gardens. You will not be disappointed and you can photograph the pieces there. Loved it!

One Of The Finest Places you Never Heard Of. This is a true Gem. It is simply amazing that someone would have amassed this collection. It has not "theme" or preferred medium. It simply reflects the unbelievably fine eye and taste of one individual and it is presented in a most attractive way. All by itself, it could justify a trip to Lisbon.

We Love Art - especially in a beautiful uncrowded setting.. The Gulbenkian attracted us from the reviews we read in the States. We set a day aside for our visit - my wife and i are very slow museum people, we read everything. We could only visit the pre-1900 portion of the museum as the more recent art works were on loan to France. However, after several very intriguing hours viewing ancient art, we spent several hours in the cafe nursing a glass of wine and enjoying the college students engrossed in their studies at adjacent tables and in the beautiful park surrounding the museum.We look forward to returning to Lisbon and completing our visit.
Great unknown museum. This is an exquisite small museum in Lisbon. Eclectic collection of Asian art and European art. No need to spend a day. Don't miss it if you are in Lisbon.

More than enough to enjoy!. You'll need a whole day ... Or more to do this museum justice! Paintings, jewellery, furniture and much, much more. Remember to,catch the special temporary exhibitions too.
amazing museum. refreshing time from the sounds and smell of the city.we spent there 3 hours enjoying the beautifull and interseting art this man collected....
Excellent. Fascinating collection in a beautiful building - extraordinary range of objects - cafe excellent value too

The Iberian Peninsula: It Takes Two .... Visiting the Exhibition 'A História Partilhada - Tesouros dos Palácios Reais de Espanha' was quite a revelation in all senses ! To be in touch with a wide range of artistic examples of the Iberian Peninsula shared history was something not experienced before . . .

Don't miss this interesting museum!. One of my favorite museums which shows all kind of arts - means Pictures, sculptures as well as beautiful applied arts like jewelry, ceramics etc.
It's especially nice to have the interaction of the interior with the beautiful garden outside - there are big windows which almost work as frames of the outside....

Amazing Art Collection!. The city of Lisbon should be very proud to have such a jewel of a museum!The collection includes works from Egyptian antiquities to more modern 19th & 20th century works. The manuscript collection was impressive. As well as their Asian collection. The Renaissance works as well as the Impressionists were our favorites! Their galleries are beautifully laid out chronologically. Downstairs there is a very nice indoor/outdoor Cafe which serves reasonably priced delicious selections. A gift store, library, and Special Collections gallery is also downstairs. Staff is very friendly and helpful! They offer a Senior discount for admission.
Excellent complex of cultural amenities. Very good collection of items - plus an amazing modern art museum (Charrua was being exhibited when we visited in July)

Wonderful eclectic museum. Had a wont full afternoon at the museum Gulbenkan. It is set in a beautiful park with walking paths and lots of natural beauty in a wonderful part of the city. The museum has an array of collections ranging from beautiful antique carpets and pottery to expressionist paintings among many things. The layout of the collections were well layed out and flowed well from period to period. There is also a modern art museum adjunct to the main museum and you can enjoy both and the grounds in half a day. Well worth a visit.

By tuk-tuk to the Gulbenkian. The metro was on strike the day we chose to visit the Gulbenkian Museum. Expecting the buses to be packed and declining the services of a surly taxi driver we arranged to go by tuk-tuk instead. What a delightful collection! The spacious galleries encourage you to wander and there is plenty to see. We loved the older and Asian exhibits but felt the furniture and modern paintings were stretching the skill of Mr Gulbenkian. What a generous gift to his adopted country.

Plan a visit!. Superb collections of art! Paintings, decorative and oriental art. The space is very comfortable. Try the cafeteria and esplanades. Stroll in the garden. If possible, go to a musical concert in a magnificent hall with excellent acoustics.

Impressive collection. This is one of two Lisbon's main museums of fine arts. It contains a large and impressive collection of not only European art, including works of Rembrandt, but also Asian, especially Islamic Art. It is located not very far from the center of the city.

Great examples of everything. Gulbenkian is an unmissable museum because it has great examples of works from every period and style dating from ancient Egypt through French Impressionists (with everything in between). Also, free on Sundays! Definitely don't miss this museum if you enjoy art and are visiting Lisbon!

À rare pearl. À long time ago, i had the chance to visit this tremendous museum. Of all the museums i've visited this one is the first coming into my mind, as one of the most remarquebable museums i've ever seen. I was overwhelmed by the grandeur of the collection and stunned by the amplitude of the gift from mister Gulbenkian. I specially liked the works of Klimt.

Outstanding Collection and Cool Building. Calouste Gulbenkian was quite a collector of object d' arte of all varieties. Everything was in fantastic condition and beautifully displayed. Tapestries, furniture. ancient gold coins, a large collection of Lalique ornaments, Severe china, porcelain from the Far East and on and on. Lovely the way the gardens outside the windows are integrated into the building which was built in 1969. Cafeteria in the basement is unbelievably inexpensive and there is nice outdoor seating, apart from the aggressive birds competing for your food!
Lovely Art. Beautifull place with great pieces of art collection and gorgeous gardens to walk by, wonderfull to see.

Excellent, one of the best smaller museums in Europe.. Situated in its own pleasant park, this museum houses a wide range of art, pottery, rugs, tiles and furniture from west and east, and from ancient times to contemporary. We were thoroughly impressed with the layout, range and quality of the museum. Perfect size for a couple of hours' wandering through. So much to see in every room, the variety was impressive. We really like art galleries and museums, but don't want to traipse round huge collections of each type of art, paying exorbitant amounts each time, so this was perfect for us. Would suit families and couples alike, and easy to reach.

A highlight of our visit to Lisbon. So enjoyed our visit here, it really has something for everyone to enjoy in a not too overwhelming way. I particularly loved the Chinese porcelain and the paintings, though it was all amazing. Very spacious and adequately lit, with Portuguese and English descriptions of the exhibits.We visited on a Sunday afternoon and didn't even have to pay an admission charge! There is a cafeteria you may want to visit afterwards in order to rest your feet and recharge your batteries and also a small gift shop.A definite 'must see' if you visit Lisbon!
Great manageable museum. Great manageable museum - high quality works from various time periods without overwhelming you with quantity of so so artists and pieces.

A museum to remember!. Incredible collection of tiles, ceramics, Lalique and Oriental carpets beautifully presented in an elegantly simple and clean manner. Impressionist paintings as well. Definitely worth the time even if in Lisbon for only a few days. Short taxi ride North to outskirts. Grounds are gorgeous, also.

A fantastic museum. This museum houses what was described as one of the best private collections in the world. Ranging from amazing Roman coins and Persian pottery and rugs to French furniture to paintings by Monet, Renoir and Manet, the quality of the objects and the displays are first rate. There are sufficient places to sit throughout the museum for those with tired feet. We think this museum should be toward the top of any visitor's list for a trip to Lisbon. The cafeteria food was lacking, but a stroll in the adjacent gardens was restful and pleasant.

A must stop for anyone visiting Lisbon. Everyone has heard of small museums like Isabella Stewart Gardner museum in Boston or Frick Collection in NYC. But not many people have heard of Calouste Gulbenkian Museum in the US. If you ever go to Lisbon, it's a must stop. This museum is basically a personal collection for Calouste. This museum is divided into eight different concentrations: Egypt, Greek, Coin, Middle East, Far East, 18th Century French Furniture, Western paintings range from quattrocento to impressionist, and Rene Lalique. The best part of the museum is probably the 18th century French furniture. The collection here is as good as any large American museum. There is a huge collection of French silver which is very rare as most French silver were melted down during wars in 18th century. I would say their French silver collection is better than Metropolitan Museum in NYC or Waddesdon Manor in London.Another highlight may be the large jewelry collection by Rene Lalique. Most people when they hear Lalique they think of crystal vases. But during Art Nouveau period, Rene Lalique was arguably the best jeweler during that time. Two of the best examples of Rene Lalique jewelry is actually housed at this museum: Dragonfly Broach and Serpents Pectoral. The pieces are actually quite large in person and they are absolutely exquisitely made. Like all artwork, you have to see them in person to appreciate them; photos do not do them justice.
A thing to do. Could not get a combined ticket since the art museum was closed. Good exhibits well presented as expected and not crwded.

Spectacular collection in a beautiful setting!. If you love fine art, don't miss this wonderful museum. It is an eclectic collection of pieces from many places and eras, and the museum is designed to display everything to its best advantage. It takes a couple of hours to see the collections. If you are there on a nice day, be sure to walk around the extensive and beautiful gardens that are designed for a relaxing experience of natural "art." The cafe has an excellent selection of lunch items at very reasonable prices, and there is a nice patio dining area as well.

World-class collection in a small museum. We took a taxi here and the driver let us off in front of the foundation headquarters instead of the museum-- our first clue that this gem needs to be better publicized! This collection is phenomenal-- great Moorish/Islamic art, medieval art, and Lalique jewelry/vases! We were ready to buy in the museum shop, but were sadly disappointed in the very limited selection-- the collection is so good that this place could be making a mint and spreading the word about the pieces here! We had to ask for an extra English guide, but the entrance staff were helpful with this.
Spend an amazing morning here. Amazing place to visit. Well worth it to see this collection takes no more than one and a half hours.

One man's taste. Interesting museum- lovely ancient art / coins followed by Islamic art- didn't';t really take to Chinese Art or 18th Century French furniture but some surprises here- two Burne Jones paintings and a lovely Mary Cassat- proincipally intereting to see what a mega rich person decided to spend his money on!
Great museum. We went on a sunday - on sundays its free of charge. Great museum, took a couple of hours. Good space, not to crowded.

Outstanding treasures for a small museum.. Did not take long to get round and something for everyone. However, as with all of Lisbon, beware of pickpockets. A friend had her purse stolen in the museum earlier in the month.

Beautiful and diverse collection. When in Lisbon this is a must see. I have been to fine arts museums all over the world and I enjoyed this one as much as many of the others. It has a very diverse collection crossing many genres and time periods and it is also just the right size! An additional bonus are the attractive gardens surrounding the museum, it was like a small oasis in the city. Highly recommend it.

Wonderful collection. Eclectic and great. It is something like 6000 pieces - this is his personal collection - from all over the world. Ancient Egypt, Greece, Islam, Europa and Japan - everything is represented here. If you just look at the European paintings - Rubens, Guardi, Degas, Monet, Renoir or the glass works of René Lalique it is more than enough. They have a separate floor for temporary exhibitons - we saw an excellent colelction: The Russian Tsars and the East - different gifts what they got from Turkey and Iran.

One of the Best!. This was a small museum with absolutely fabulous art---but the best part was the way it was displayed. The rooms flowed into each other and the art was in chronological order. It was outstanding.........don't miss this one. It rivals the Louvre and the Prado---not in size, but certainly in content and style.

A Must to See When Visiting Lisbon. Calouste Sarkis Gulbenkian's wonderful collection of ancient world and European art of the 20th century, assembled under one roof. I was pleased to see Rubens, Renoir, Monet, Cassatt among the collections. It is eclectic in that in addition to the type of art mentioned in the previous sentence, you may also view Persian carpets, ancient Egyptian and Japanese artifacts, antique furniture, as well as a collection of Lalique, to name a few of the many items on exhibit. I enjoyed a highlight exhibit on the caricatures of Don Quijote de la Mancha, which ended on June 14.. There is a nice little cafeteria downstairs, where visitors may enjoy a light meal inside our outside in the garden area. The museum shop is quite small. The admission fee is 5Euro, but for seniors it is half that.

Exquisite. Eventhough I'm very used to see excellent quality art, this Museum was an amazing surprise for me; never seen such good taste in the selection of the works of art in one space, Mr Gulbenkian was definitely a man with extraordinary taste, really a wonderful day for me in Lisbon...I am very grateful for the opportunity to have seen so many marvelous pieces!
Perfect!. Don't leave Lisbon without having seen this art collection. It has very important pieces of many arts ,of different ages and from many parts of the world. Excellent gift shop

Incredible Artifacts,something for everyone. Take 2 hours in Lisbon to view this incredible private art collection of C. Gulbenkian on Av de Berna set in the Parque Santa Gertrudes,the setting is already worth the visit: www.museu.gulbenkian.ptPermanent Exh. Galleries house Egyptian, Greco-Roman, Mesop.Eastern &FareasternEuropean 15-17th,decor. arts France 18th Cty.paintings by Guardi,english portrait painters,2 seascapes by Turner plus Corots,Degas, Monets,Mants and Renoir.The lalique Art Nouveau room is also special with jewellery and glass.Students under 30 and seniors are free.A well done Audio Guide is available in engl, French, Spanish

Jewel box of a museum. If you love art like I do, be sure and carve out an hour or two for the Gulbenkian Museum. It is a small, beautifully curated collection of exquisite art, my favorite collection being that of European art, but there are also classical collections and a lovely Lalique room. There is also a lovely small cafe and gift shop.

Incredible Museum of Ancient Artifacts. The Gulbenkian Museum was rated as the best in Lisbon, so we made the trek to see it. We walked through the gardens surrounding the museum, which provided much needed relief from the heat. The modern art collection is closed for renovation. However, the ancient, middle ages, and 1900 century artwork and artifacts were impressive. We really were amazed at the Roman and Greek coins, medals and jewelry that would rival anything produced today. Definitely a must see for history buffs.
Free or very low cost price exhibits near the river! great. Free or very low cost price exhibits near the river! great museum, very nice to go on a bike tour and have a stop here.

Extraordinary Collection. Reviews I read about this "collection " have all been modest.The sculpture park and buildings house a most extraordinarily collection. From some of the most beautiful Tiffany masterpieces of decorative arts you will ever see up close to the Egyptian, Persian,Turkish treasures. Don't miss it if your in Lovey Lisbon

Free concert piano/accordeon Sunday 6June. Magical...Buenos Aires and Astor Piazzola revisited...I was there by chance that day...the Calouste Gulbenkian is stunning...the gardens an oasis...and the free concert was incredible. Thank you for this nice surprise!

Do Not Miss thia!. Although not a large museum, there is an exceptional selection of art works in a wide variety of categories.The grounds alone are worth the trip. Also, there is a delightful outdoor restaurant and a terrific gift shop. We used the hop on hop off bus to get to the museum.
hidden treasure in the middle of lisbon. extensive collection... including Asian artifacts; museum cafeteria food was also decently good & reasonably priced.

most important art collection in Lisbon. park is a must, collection interesting, nice display of lalique's creations, as result of private collector's donation, there is no strong point but many different areas and objects, form painting to carpets, jewelry etc.
Thank you Calouste, you had great taste. Eclectic collection, a little difficult to find but worth the effort and a great afternoon away from the heat and pace of Chiado and the waterfront
A must see museum!. This museum is absolutely worth the journey! The collection of Calouste Gulbenkian is stunning. Do not leave Lisbon without seeing the beautiful art that he collected.

Go Sunday. If you can, Sunday morning entry is free from 10-2:00. Go early and enjoy the gardens and art outside. Watch out for the ducks! Wide variety in the museum; Moorish glass, ancient coins, Renoir, Monet, Sargent...Easy to get around as the exhibits are spread out
impressiv collection. if a guy can collect al these superb items, he must really have been a real good collector. Also the museum is a nice architectural building. The surrounding parc is great also.
amazing museum and its free!. this museum is in Belem, it has quite alot of modern art all categorised into the kind of art it is. Really enjoyed my visit here and would recommend.

The centre of culture and cultural formation in Lisbon. If you ask any Portuguese where did he or she started to see modern art or what concert was more memorable in their recollections, I'm almost sure that the answer goes to be Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian. The history behind the choice of Lisbon for the permanence of the collection is interesting enough but the permanent collection is an absolute must and most of the temporary exhibits are of enormous quality. The Fundação has restaurants and the gardens bring the other necessary fruition for the soul.
Eclectic Collection with Cool Gardens. A very popular sight, so early admission beats the crowds. The gardens and water features in the park outside are lush, peaceful and cooling on hot days.

Nice and intersting museum in Lisbon. If you have some time to spend in Lisbon, dońt forget to visit this atypic museum. You can see a lot of dunexpected and different and beautiful things and learn a lot about European history from centuries.
Beautiful building. The building is just amazing, but they only have 3 exhibits at a time, and when I was there only 2, which were not as great as I expected.
great museum in a nice quiet park. this is a truly fantastic museum a little away from the old center of Lisbon. The museum has a great selection of modern art and is located in a very pleasant park.

A cultural highlight. Situated in an attractive park close to the centre of Lisbon, the Gulbenkian Museum houses Calouste Gulbenkian's exquisite bequest to the nation of Potugal. A museum where everything is interesting and excellently displayed. Entrance is inexpensive and English language headsets can be rented for a small fee which give background information on the Museum and exhibits. You can get around all the exhibits in less than 2 hours then retire to the pleasant on-site restaurant and watch the ducks and geese. Highlights for me were the Eastern costumes and carpets, the French and Russian silver tableware and the splendid Rene Lalique room.

A superb gem!. I visited the Gulbenkian on a previous trip to Lisbon and couldn't wait to get back. It may not be everyone's cup of tea but if you like the Chester Beatty Library in Dublin (and I do - a lot) then you're going to love this. In a modern building; well laid out; from very ancient carpets and glass right through to Lalique with paintings, sculpture, furniture, clothing, jewellery .... Superb, uncluttered, not crowded. The gardens are a lovely oasis and the café at the interpretative centre lets you sit outside in the shade with a very inexpensive coffee and free Wi-Fi. I also visited the modern art collection this time and proved to myself yet again that I don't get it - or at least I don't get this collection, apart from the rather science fantasy insect drawings and the deer sculpture. So I'm a Philistine.Don't miss it!

world-class collection. We first visited this museum 25 years ago, and it lived up to our memories. Everything is displayed extremely well, with good explanatory texts. Some stunning items, particularly the engraved gem stones and the tiles from the Near East.

Excellent collection. Wonderful collection of Eastern and Western Art - dating from the Egyptians in 2500BC through stunning ceramics and textiles of the Middle East to Renaissance and Modern Western Paintings. Great display area with no crowds, close proximity to the objects, tastefully displayed in a modern building. An example to the rich of the world what to do with their ill-gotten gains, the museum is a tribute to taste and generosity.
Not to be missed!. Like the Burrell Museum in Glasgow, an outstanding collection of art and artifacts acquired by a single individual with exquisite taste, excellent advisors and deep pockets!
Amazing. Perhaps the best example of modern architecture in Lisbon. It contains a very interesting and diverse collection.

Astounding collection of art and artefacts. Beautiful collection of Ottoman tiles and carpets. Amazing to get so close to the work of Monet, Reubens, Gainsborough and Turner. Gallery set in very pretty gardens, worth a visit themselves.
Good but small. good if you are particularly interested in precisely what they have, which I wasn't. Has ancient Egyptian and Persian items. Current exhibit was Don Quixote.

Most Impressive Museum You've Never Heard Of. Maybe I've led a sheltered life, but I was previously unaware of this collection, which rivals the National Gallery. The fact that Lisbon is off the beaten track is the only explanation.Egyptian artifacts, Renaissance and Flemish masterpieces, major Impressionist works, and a gorgeous selection of Lalique and Art Nouveau jewelry. And the cafe is excellent too.Easily accessible by Metro.
Excellent museum! Well worth a visit. This is an amazing museum! Loved the diverse collection. It is a small museum but contains some very excellent world class art.

A very personal collection. Calouste Gulbenkian personal collection is exposed in a chronological display in a very pleasant and peaceful setting of the surrounding Gulbenkian garden. it as pieces from ancient cultures to modern XX century item. A special remark to the Lalique jewellery collection.

Quality over quantity. While nowhere near the size of places such as the Louvre, British Museum or the Metropolitan museum of art, this less famous museum really is a gem for lovers of art as well as "art is great but I don't want to spend -all- of this beautiful day in a museum"-persons such as myself. Visited this place for about two hours and what I liked the most was the fact that almost every single piece in the very well arranged collection was in great conditon.

Great museum. Museum has great paintings, sculptures, glass work, furniture and jewelry from many different periods and centuries. It is all on one floor and arranged by type and century so easy to see it all without walking for miles. Great cafeteria downstairs as well.
Rich collection. I liked several kind of collection.Especially carpets and Iznik tiles.I admire silk Bursa fabrics.How nice museum ıt was.

Beautiful.. Visited on a Sunday morning. Lovely grounds with a lot of walks and water features. The Museum is free on a Sunday. Not sure if there are charges on the other days. The standard of art in its various forms is extremely high, in my opinion and there is just enough to take in in any one visit. Should not be missed.
A visit to Calouste Gulbenkian Museum. French art nouveau jewels, wonderfull tile collection and the excellent organisation of this museum.

Breathtaking collection. Not to be missed! The museum building alone is worth the visit with the gardens. The collection it houses is pristine, with high quality objects and art in every category. Plus a lovely cafeteria/restaurant indoor outdoors/ food is good.

One of the Most Overlooked Museums In Europe. Outstanding esoteric collections from a variety of cultures and periods. If you visit Lisbon, this is a "must" stop. Allocate some extra time during your visit to this museum complex to stroll through the adjoining gardens and have a light meal at one of the two reasonably-priced and informal restaurants. Local residents of Lisbon make the gardens and restaurant part of their mid-day work/school break,

I like small museums and this is almost small - beautiful objects. Our hotel was nearby so we walked over. The museum is on large grounds and the best way in is not clear. But never mind - you'll enjoy the grounds.The museum is not large but has much to see. I'd say it emphasizes what's beautiful - you could look at any piece for a long time in appreciation. Hard to pick a favorite, but the oriental vases stick in my mind along with the Lalique jewelry.
Not to be missed. Excellent collection, well arranged. Comfortable place to rest in lobby and good restaurant (be sure to check opening hours of restaurant)

Excellence. The venue itself has a pleasant garden setting, very good standard restaurant and reasonably good shop which should have much better postcards. the ancient and Middle Eastern exhibits are outstanding, much better than the European collection which was not as good as I expected given Gulbenkian's reputation for "only the best." The Iznik and Persian ceramics, lamps, carpets and exquisite fabrics are of the highest quality and the mounting outstanding.

An invaluable treasure and gift to Lisbon. Hidden away from most other museums in Lisbon this was an invaluable gift to Lisbon and Portugal. Many antiquities from one persons private collection generously displayed for all to see.
A MUST SEE when you visit Lisbon.
Large collection of varied art. Could not see entire collection. Liked all that we could see. Four block walk from Metro. Nearby lovely park.
Beautiful small private museum. We spent there around 2 hours in a rainy afternoon - it was a very good choice considering the circumstances. Beautiful small museum, deserves a visit.

Rather specialised but good. We visited the modern art section which is worth a visit but concentrates on Portugese artists, it is important in so far that it give a good insught into the effect of the dictatorship in Portugal on art of that period.

Worth visiting if only for the Laliques!. This is a great museum. Very calm and well curated.
I particularly loved the fabulous collection of Lalique items.
Definitely a must-do if you're visiting Lisbon.

World-class. This somewhat eclectic collection is magnificent, particularly its examples of things not normally seen in a general museum - carpets, manuscript books, textiles etc - and worth the visit just to see its Lalique room. Set in beautiful gardens, it's easily reached by metro - and if you go on a Sunday it's free - don't miss!

A perfect Museum. The collection of Calouste Gulbenkian is housed ina purpose built museum of the highest standard, arranged around 2 huge courtyard gardens that lets in the oiutside light and creates a wonderful, peaceful atmosphere. The collection meanders chronologically from ancient Egyptian, Greek and Roman, Islamic (amazing), Oriental, through to European art that begins with Medieaval ivories and Books of Hours and proceeds to present us with first class works of art by the likes of Van der Weyden, Carpaccio, Ghirlandaio, Rembrandt, Rubens, Van Dyck, Hals, Gainsborugh, Turner and the Impressionists, plus a huge collection of 18th century French furniture and decoartive art and a great collection of Rene Lallique. It's an absolute treat and although some way away from the waterfront, a taxi only cost 7 euros for about 2 miles, so not expensive to get to. It's my favourite place in a city full of wonderful things to see and do.

Decent size; eclectic mix. Think it cost 8euro. Some lovely paintings inc. Rubens ( of Helen Fourment), Turner,; great tapestries, tiles, a Rodin or two including beautiful marble Flora; Lalique- lots of it; Book(s) of hours; plenty to look at but not too much you feel overwhelmed. Could be better signposted from the metro ( praca de espana)

Great period collections. It is amazing what one person was able to personally collect of beautifully objectsfrom different time periods. The ceramics are magnificent and the 19th century French furniture is unbelievable. Do not miss this one if you are in Lisbon. There is also a senior discount ticket but you have to ask

An amazing collection of artifacts from all over the world. It was the best private collection of Arts that we have ever been to! Works from Rodin, Turner, Monet etc to name a few! Beautiful Egyptian, Chinese and Persian Arts all in amazing condition! Also, the presentation of the works is very impressive and well thought out! Very cheap entrance fee for the very high quality museum this is! Even big reductions for people over 65....

A 'must see' for art lovers!. The museum is laid out in chronological order, and in such a way that you will pass all the exhibits as you proceed.The museum is quite small, and a visit could easily be made an hour or two unless you especially wanted to take longer. Our favourites were the Islamic art, old masters, and the Lalique gallery.The cost of entry to the museum is €5 per person.

Wonderful Museum. The collection of art was very extensive and varied. I think the history behind the museum deserves mention as well. To have someone donate that wonderful of a personal collection th the city that gave him refuge is very touching.
Space quiet but pretty empty. It's ok to meander if you know what you are looking at but most of the time I didn't. Bored a little but a pleasant diversion all the same.

Cool collection. On a hot day, this is the perfect place! Exceptional collection of the best art has to offer. Everything arranged and catalogued. Well spaced and divided into sections that affords the visitor plenty of personal space when viewing the many objects of interest
Lalique. Worth visiting to drool over the Lalique jewellery in the last room Also good setting in a park but lack of signage make finding the place difficult!

Impressive private collection.
