This large private museum has an eclectic collection of European, Asian, Middle Eastern and Egyptian art and artifacts I found the bookends of the gallery walk the most interning: the Ancient Egyptians artifacts at the beginning and the 19c paintings at the end.The audio tour costs 4 Euros and is a little flaky but worthwhile. A guided tour is not offered.
Amazing museum. Lot of walking sine each venue is in a different building, but it was worth it. The gardens all around the museum felt like you were in the best park

Fabulous. The only problem with this museum is that it totally mucked up our day, as we couldn't make ourselves leave. What a collection. Particularly enamoured of the Near Eastern gallery. Beautiful Iznik titles, Persian carpets and amazing glass mosque lamps. The museum also holds oriental ceramics, European furniture, sculpture and paining, and Belle Époque jewellery. Allow a good three hours (minimum) to make your away around,Only major disappointment was the lack-lustre shop. Would have loved a souvenir.

A great break from the city. A wonderful collection of amazing artifacts. It isn't expensive with the Lisboa Card and the tapestries, tiles, furniture, and of course portraits are all exquisite. It's very easy to follow the flow of the building as well. It's relaxing and informative. I would definitely go back even with the same pieces permanently on display.

Perfect way to spend a day. The Museum's exhibitions were excellent and superbly displayed. Loved the Lalique in particular. And the surrounding gardens are inviting. We ran out of time. A great reason to go back and take in the Modern Art exhibits too!

Great variety, not too much and just enough of everything. Really enjoyed this museum, great collections, from Egyptian and Greek artefacts, to old masters and great sculptures, but the best bit for me was the Lalique collection, which was just stunning, even if you dont generally like this type of thing paying the €4.00 entrance fee just to see the Lalique is worth it!

Extremely well planned museum. The Museum has one of the best interiors and plans of any I have visited. The collection is very diverse and may not be for everyone. I advise checking their website. One unique part was the excellent.Lalique collection. The gardens are integrated into the total experience providing views from the museum as well as walks.

An Amazing Collection. This an amazing collection of stunningly beautiful items. The collection may not cover a wide spectrum of periods of history, but what there is, is fabulous. Egyptian, Chinese , Islamic, Turkish and Armenian. A must see collection
the best by far. A mini victoria and albert museum collected by one man!. Probably the best collection of Lalique jewellry anywhere a must for anybody on a visit to lisbon

Great inside and outside. The collection is so diverse and beautiful - well worth the visit. The added benefit for me was walking around the extensive lovely grounds outside the museum: paths, sitting areas, water features, views....really very nice place to just chill after your museum visit.
The only good museum we could find. The place is nice and well worth the visit. It's not as small as I expected it to be and they have a great variety of exhibited items.

Now this is collecting. It is amazing what one man collected in his lifetime. What is special is that he gave this over to be museum. Everything from paintings by great artists to ancient artifacts to antique furniture to high end jewelry and on and on. Spend a few hours here.
One of best places in Lisbon. A beautiful garden surrounds this beautiful building and inside there's a rich art collection. Expect very enjoyable moments can be lived there.

Must not miss. Arrived by yellow on off bus. Truly one of the beautiful mouse ms I have visited. Only 2.50 euros per person for seniors. Took 2 hours to go through. Breath taking and beautiful. Walked the gardens a must do with the carp fish in pond and many ducks around

Marvelous collection, lovely inside and out. We loved the collections of classical art, from precious tapestries, ancient glass, paintings, well housed in the museum. A surprising delight were the grounds between the museums of classical and modern art, where visitors mixed with locals who picnicked in the grass. Grounds are extensive, literally a breath of fresh air in the big city, and we had to tear ourselves away to go inside, where we also had a pleasant quick meal.

Fantastic Art Collection. Beautiful and interesting museum. Located inside a beautiful garden you'll find this precious gem hosting the collection of one of the biggest art collectors of the 20th century. It is really worth a visit

Calouste Gulbenkian Museum and Foundation. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museu includes an eclectic collection of outstanding paintings, sculptures, decorative objects, jewelry (the extraordinary René Lalique works collection), archeological artifacts, with some unique aspects, for example the large collections of works from Armenia and Islamic Middle East, Persian miniatures, etc. Most of these objects came from the private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian, and one exciting aspect of this museum is to see how the taste of this cultured man transpires in the collection. The Museum is very pleasant and very well organized, the quality of the exhibits extremely high. The Modern Art Museum, the Foundation central building and the gardens deserve to be visited as well.
Excellent museum. We had several hours before our flight to Madeira so we came here. Not a huge museum, but manageable for a short period of a few hours to see some lovely art and furniture.

Good museum with well presented exhibits. Firstly, Portuguese signage leaves a lot to be desired and we fund it quite difficult to actually find the entrance to this museum, eventually entering through a door marked art library.Once inside we got a discount entry by showing the 72 hour Lisbon cards we had bought (excellent value at 39 euro each). You are allowed to take non flash photos. However, the exhibits are so well lit that you don't need flash. A very enjoyable couple of hours wandering round followed by a good coffee in the cafe after.

Amazing Art Collection. This museum is very well planned and organized, with objects so well preserved I have a hard time believing how old they are! The collection is arranged by region and by century, and includes Egyptian, Greek, Roman, Ottoman Empire, Chinese pieces from various dynasties, French, Italian, English, and a few German pieces. There are paintings from famous masters, tapestries and rugs, porcelain, glass, tiles, sculptures, tableware, manuscripts, etc. A little bit of something for everyone. Well worth the 5 Euro admission. I believe there are other areas to see, such as special collections/exhibits, for a higher price, but I only had time for the museum today. Every item is displayed under glass and in dim lighting where needed, and the items are spaced far enough apart they can be appreciated clearly. The captions near each piece are in both Portuguese and English. Also, no cell phones are allowed, which I didn't notice when I walked in, but the result is that the place is quiet and peaceful, and one gentleman was even taking a nap on a bench in the middle of a display area. I have to apologize to the staff for my phone ringing during my visit. I am sorry! I turned it off as soon as I was notified to do so.
Very nice museum. The Lalique exhibit was absolutely fantastic. There is both a modern art and older art section which are housed in two different buildings in a beautiful park like setting.

Fantastic Collection of Ancient Middle Eastern Artefacts and European Art. Extremely interesting and eclectic collection of ancient Egyptian, Greco-Roman and other Middle eastern items, to gether with a surprising collection of European Art, including a couple of brilliant Rembrandts. Well worth a visit.

Exquisite collection beautifully displayed. This is a rather small collection, but every area includes fabulous pieces. (Well, I am not a fan of Lalique, so not there.) The Egyptian pieces (cat with kittens) are lovely. The Persian textiles and ceramics are a marvel. Even the European paintings include some real gems: Manet; Renoir. Getting into the building via a walled park was initially difficult. We thought that walking from Av Liberdade via the Edward VII Park would be a good access, but that was not the case; the Gulbenkian is over past a contemporary shopping center, and it's important to enter on the correct street. Interesting shop choice: no postcards. The same was true in the Museum of Modern Art, where we purchased Fernando Pessoa's Tourist Guide to Lisbon (he is a well respected poet of early 20th century).

User friendly. 20 years plus since our last visit - an hour and a half max will suffice and the Lalique is superb easy to reach by public transport 15E entrance is waived on Sundays so come early or round lunch timewhen we visited last week there was a free classical concert going on on the lower floornext time we will try the modern section - wont wait 20 years though!
love it. Excellent cafe beautiful building and wonderful collection I loved the paintings and thecarpets,the building was surrounded by beautiful gardens.

Magnificent. Everything about this museum is excellent from the architecture to the displays and the food outlets. There is the most marvellous range of artefacts, all beautifully laid out and clearly labelled. Both inside and out this museum is lovely. Well worth visiting.

Money can buy the very best. Calouste Gulbenkian made money big-time from oil concessions and his foundation was charged with spending it. His instructions must have included "Buy the Very, Very Best"! The range of objects is extremely wide but all are the best of their genre (even if some of the items will provoke 'hideous' from some). Equisite craftmanship in perfect condition, spaciously displayed.(The park and restaurant provide an oasis of calm in the city centre - worth visiting even if you are not into a museum mood).
great collection, friendly staff. great collection of asian art. staff are friendly, cafeteria is also nice.

A worthwhile visit. A very pleasant surprise that entrance was free on the Sunday morning we visited. A most interesting collection of carpets, rugs and tapestries from European, Middle East and Far East countries the viewing of which filled several pleasant hours in a well laid out rooms. Well worth a visit.

Fantastic museum- no sign of damage to ancient artifacts.. Don't miss this museum! As you walk among the several rooms you span centuries and continents. The collection is broad and varied and beautifully displayed in this modern building.
good museum. not enough labels on items, a shame really! I loved the Lalique collection but I would have liked more info on the artist

nice museum for a Sunday visit. I have been there with my mom some time ago, it was Sunday, I don't remember if enter wasn't free on that day, nice exhibitions of modern art, nice garden outside around museum, good cafe place in the museum, they serve cafes, cakes and lunches. Good point in the city to visit for an art lovers.

Amazing collection on one man's art. Beautiful setting, very airy and light. Organized in an appealing manner. In 90 minutes, you are done and it is not overwhelming or tiring. Nice outdoor cafe if you want to rest after your visit.

Treasures of the world. While not a huge museum, it houses some exquisite treasures. Gulbenkian specialised in collecting perfection and achieved just that - the best of everything. Definitely worth a visit.

Not to be missed, great museum for location. Much to see and take in at this museum. Kind of a mini National Gallery and Smithonian. Go on Sunday for free and 65 and over get 1/2 price. Worth the visit
Gulbenkian Museum. Liked the ancient Greek and Roman artefacts. Couldn't get excited over 14th century Persian carpets and bits of old furniture

Lalique collection. This museum is worth visiting. Great collection of ceramics from China, oriental islamic art, Luis XV and XVI furniture. Even Ruben´s and Rembrandt´s, Monet´s paintings. And the highlight is René Lalique´s collection. He was a french jeweller of the Art Nouveau.
Earlier visited by a flight stop. Mostly the jewellery of Lalique,but the whole collection is excellent.Do not ask of the origin of the money...

A Mini British Museum and National Gallery, all-in-one. Great little museum. Go on Sunday when there is free admission. Even if you have to pay to get in here, its a great collection of fantastic artwork and artifiacts spanning several millennia. Well worth a visit.

Mini Louvre. Wonderful Museum! The Gulbenkian has a wonderful array of artifacts, that can easily fascinate you over a few hours visit. We particularly loved the size of this museum because we could take our time visiting, cover the entire museum, but not feel overwhelmed by the sheer volume of art. Oftentimes, in some of the larger museums I have felt rushed to see everything in my visit or have felt that there were too many artifacts to apprecaite at once. The Gulbenkian was a great, because its size allows you to focus on the wonders it holds.
Nice Art Collection. We're from Chicago and familiar with great art collections. This museum with an awkward name has some good stuff. Located in a park, it was difficult to find the front door.

Moving, a wonder. I cannot overstate how wonderful this museum is. Every single pice is simply wonderful, perfect, moving. Elegance, rarity, all well exposed, perfect premises. Spend a day there and you will miss it. Not to miss in a lifetime!

Several hours well spent. After spending a lot of time in "classical" museums, the arrangements here were a breath of fresh air. Well spaced and well paced, each room having wonderful pieces of a type, whether hand woven carpet or the stunning Lalique room.

Excellent two hours. The Museo is excellent! Not overwealming like many big and famous museums (Louvre, Prado etc) but high quality suff from various epochs. The garden itself is worth a visit. Architecure is interesting. Can be visited in one hour, worthy to stay longer
Loved this museum. Incredible collection of art from Egypt, Asia and Europe in a beautiful museum. Thoroughly enjoyed visit.

the museum to see. I am portuguese, I live closer and a visit to this Museum makes part of my sunday mornings. A private collection not too big, in a beautiful modernist building surrounded by a park, where you can see some wonders not usually seen in museums. Amazing old oriental carpets beautifully displayed, great collection of turkish ceramics (Gulbenkian was armenian), two great Rembrandts, lots of interesting classical furniture, a whole room with Guardi´s Venice and several beautiful painting by one of the most interesting and underrated 19th century french painters: Corot. And a whole room by Lalique, with all you have to know about decorative art-nouveau. On my sunday mornings, much better for my soul than going to the mass.

Incredible luck that we went there. what an experience a few years ago. we arrived in Lisboa and had 3 hours to wait. It was suggested that we visit the museum near our hotel. We stayed until it closed and went back the next day. Fabulous unpromoted heritage.Our chance meeting with Gustavo this morning at Westin Denarau in Fiji, from Cintra in Portugal brought back lovely memories. If you visit Lisbon, dont miss this incedible find.

Large and varied collection. The Gulbenkian museum is definitely worth a couple of hours. The collection is so varied that you can't possibly be bored. Mary Cassatt paintings, Lalique jewelry, Ottoman carpets, Ancient Chinese pottery... there is a lot to see here.
One of my favorite museums. a museum not to miss.! It is a private collection in a lovely building, set in a park. There is a small restaurant, where you can enjoy lunch outdoors in the sunshine

Excellent classical collection. The museum's collection contains 6000 pieces of art. Presented artifacts from oriental to European art. Amazing painting is very good preserved and displayed. Such a beautiful furniture I have never seen before. Lalique collection at the end not to be missed!
Excellent museum. Wonderful museum with an extensive collection of national and international art and sculpture. Well laid out for a quick or extensive tour.

The contemporary art. We've seen a LOT of art museums around the world and their famous paintings, so we skipped the main collection to take in the collection of Portuguese contemporary art. It was interesting, not spectacular, but a good view into what's going on in the art community in Lisbon today.
Great concert space. Treat yourself to some quality classical music in a great comfortable space - it was one of the highlights of our trip. We'll do the gallery next time.
Must Go. Nice Place to visit. WIth very good expositions, some temporary some permanent. The gardens are great and you can lunch in one of their restaurants.
Beautiful things. The museum is fantastic, there are so many wonderful things inside, I suggest to everyone. It has a garden with a cafe,too. Very near to the airport, you can see the planes landing.

Breathtaking. With his unerring eye, money, and passion for the arts, Calouste Gulbenkian collected 6,440 exquisite pieces of coins, jewelry, paintings, furniture, rugs, ceramics, plus other items. He began collecting old coins as a young man. Attracted by the intrinsic beauty of objects, he spent a lifetime negotiating with the best experts and specialized dealers--all strictly authenticated-- dating from antiquity to the early 20th century. His good taste is evident as you pass by the collections. I have never seen pieces in such good condition in any other museum. Take a look at the silver collection--dinnerware. The platters will amaze you. Eat at the cafeteria--on a good day outside--and stroll the beautiful garden complete with pond. Plan on at least half a day. Metro (S. Sebastiao--blue & red line) or Praca de Espanha stations (blue line), Bus: 713,716,726,742,746, 756 or Yellow Bus Tours (blue line--Tags). Museum is open Tuesday to Sunday 10 a.m. - 6 p.m. (last admission is 5:30 p.m.). Closed Mondays & holidays. 5 Euros entrance fee. Discount for seniors over 65 and students under 30. Audio guides available.
Not to be missed!. Great art collection. Has a lot of paintings from Hermitage, also has rare impressionists paintings I have not seen before.Very good lightning and disposition.
Worth a visit. Allow plenty of time if you want to visit the museum and exhibitions. Would recommend the museum if you are pressed for time - approx 1-1.5 hrs.

Don't miss it. A remarkable collection in a beautiful setting. The collection is so diverse that that it is unlikely than anyone will appreciate everything, but there is in it more than enough to enthuse every museum goer. Save some time to stroll through the beautiful park within which the museum is housed.

Birthday and family trip. Worth the visit. Fabulous collections.The restaurant at the museum is very good too, We were there on a sunny day so people were having lunch on the terrace with a beautiful garden to look at.

Small but exquisite. A rich man's eclectic but impressive collection of antiquities and paintings. Very small compared with the world's great galleries, but some wonderful pieces here, and well displayed. As for the modern collection, no comment.
Nice collection. Very divers collection throughout history - loved especially the Lalique, China and French rooms. Entrance is only 5 euro.

Left us agape. How could one man have put together such an amazing collection spanning centuries, art forms, materials and styles? Every section was worth much more time than we had to give. Ancient Egypt, Islam, European painting, sculpture and decorative arts, rugs, old Bibles. You name it. Gulbenkian probably has it. Must get back for an entire day. There's a good café and plenty of parkland places to sit outside when you need a break.
splendid collection. It's one of the best museums in Lisbon, built around what was originally a private collection. The Egyptian, Islamic, Far East sections are really best in class.

Amazing extensive private collection. This museum has it all---rugs, pottery, paintings, furniture, sculpture, jewelry and more. This is all the collection of one impressive guy. Not all of the collection is displayed, which means there isn't too much of one thing in the galleries. Free on Sunday mornings! You could bring kids who like art. It's not exactly in the tourist district but easy enough to find; there's a subway stop five minutes away.

A very good interesting mix.. This museum is well laid out and with just enough artifacts of the same type to stop you from being overloaded and dulling your interest. There is a discount for seniors.

Great Museum and Gardens. It's a modern Museum, very pleasant and well structured to visit. I strongly recommend the Lalique collection part, at the end, as it is small, but quite beautiful.The gardens are beautiful and always well groomed, and it's amusing to feed the ducks by the lake.The coffee shop has an outdoor balcony, great for a cup of coffee in the Spring or a soft drink in the Summer.

Amazing Collection. A well designed, modern museum, housing the collection of Mr. Gulbenkian. How he ever managed to acquire such extra-ordinary paintings, antique Turkish tile work, Persian rugs, illuminated manuscripts, and Lalique jewelry is anybody's guess. Do not miss seeing several paintings by Ruben, Hals, all the major impressionists, about 5 Rodin sculptures, not just the metal ones which can be reproduced but also one-of-a-kind in marble.I would have liked to purchase a high quality catalogue to take home. However, only the ceramique pieces and the rugs had brilliant, beautiful photos in their catalogue. The paintings were badly lit and considerable darker than the originals.
best museum ever. The Gardens are calm and peaceful. The galleries are just wonderful particularly the permanent exhibition with the Lalique glass. Free entry on sunday.
Treasure of a museum. Just a little jewel box of a museum. Carefully chosen and representative of many cultures. REally lovely.

Wonderful private collection. Very divers. Some top pieces.. We enjoyed the feeling of walking through someones private collection. There is a large variety of things to see from ancient Egyptian art to the impressionists. We especially loved the 2 Rembrandt paintings, the 3 paintings from Rubens, 1 of Turner, some of Manet and Monet, 1 Renoir, several statues of Rodin and especially the room filled with artwork from Lalique.

First rate museum. Museu Calouste Gulbenkian was reputed to have one of the best collections in the world. Though considerably smaller than other museums, the selection was superb. Lighting was much better than many museums, The crowds were small and admission was only €5.
Fantastic art collections. Very interesting art collections, including paintings, ceramics, sculptures and decorative arts. René Lalique colletion is a must.

Pleasant surprise. Far from the most paved routes but close to our hotel, this museum surprised us with its pieces of art, ranging from the Roman era to the last century. It is not huge, but it is well organised and it is placed in a wonderful garden.
Great collection. Amazing collection - lovely grounds - eat early to enjoy the nice cafeterias. The modern collection is not as exciting as the older material.
Gorgeous place. Beautiful. Go on a Sunday when the admission is free. I want to steal the gorgeous ink box with the kimono blowing in the wind.

Excellent museum. Amazing display of one person's vast collection of art thru the ages. Fine pieces of sculpture, painting, and other types of fine arts from ancient Egypt and China thru modern and contemporary works. There are also gardens and a reasonable cafe.

Breathtaking collection. Wow - what a stunning collection! We visited on Good Friday and casually strolled around the exhibits without feeling hurried or rushed in any way. The museum is laid out in chronological order and every piece is well displayed AND beautifully lit. There are too many great exhibits to mention but for me the highlight was the Lalique collection at the end of the tour. Great to see the items 'in the flesh' and appreciate the detail and workmanship. Allow yourselves 2-3 hours for a relaxing visit. We also took the audio guide which gave a good background to some of the key pieces. Oh yes, The coffee shop is good too!

Well worth a visit. An interesting collection with something for everyone. The art alone is worth the visit - the highlight for me the two Byrne-Jones- but there are Turners and the usual French Impressionists as well.And the grounds are also very pleasant and relaxing.

Great experience - museum worth visiting. The Gulbenkian is a wonderful museum to visit. Loads of masterpieces. Well laid out and displayed somewhat chronologically, which made it easier to take in. We didn't take the audioguide (4€), and we didn't have the feeling we should have.The modern arts museum (Centro de Arte Moderna) is just accross the courtyard and always organises interesting exhibitions.We spent some 3 hours there, in total.There's a wonderful park surrounding it. The self service restaurant is very good quality and a good place to eat on a Sunday, when much in Lisboa is closed.Metro to S. Sebastião.
Fabulous museum. Not only the pieces of art inside the museum are beautiful, the musem and garden themselves are great works of art. Definitely worth a visit!
Good Museum. A very well managed Museum though the number of items on display are somewhat limited. Entrance fee is reasonable.

Beautiful Private Collection In Lisbon. I have been to this museum several times and each time I see new parts of the collection. This is a small museum that houses one of the most interesting collections in Europe. It was a private collection of a person involved in the oil industry and he made this vast collection available to the public after his death. It is hard to believe that one man could amass so many valuable, beautiful things in his lifetime. The collections range from Egyptian, Greek, Persian, Asian, French and other European furniture and art. The paintings range up to, and including, Impressionist works by Manet, Degas and Monet, among others.This is truly a gem and one of the less visited museums in Europe. It is a "not to miss" venue. It is free on Sunday.
Morning at the museum. We went on a Sunday morning. The museum has a nice collection Turkish art, but also a Rembrant painting. The setup is very spacious.

Small, manageable museum. We did not feel overwhelmed in this museum...no pressure to see "everything", as it contains a very good collection of art, but not too much for an afternoon. Enjoyed the visit very much.

Very interesting and eclectic museum.. This museum features old masters, wonderful tapestries, coins, old books and much more. Check the web site for more about the collection. You could easily spend several hours inside and an additional hour outside walking the gardens. The museum is well laid out and the pieces are well presented.

interesting collection. nice place to visit, if you are art lover, bit hectic collection of everything but lovely to explore. with walk through Parque Eduardo VII and garden around museum, cup of good coffe and nata's in museum cafe and later with shopping and exploring wine shelves in el cortes ingles...one day spent perfectly

world class museum. A very varied museum,but each exhibit is the best of its kind, the private collection of a conisure, large but not too big so you don't get bored. The eating facilities are good so you can stop for coffee, or a snack.
amazing garden. Great garden to enjoy the nature, ducks, flowers. Even is spring, a lot of flowers, trees were green. Nice place, very close to the Hotel Princepe Lisboa and Il Corte Engles.

Fabulous collection of decorative and fine arts. This is one of the finest eclectic collections of the decorative and fine arts in Europe. Not too big that you can't get round and not too small either The section covering Islamic and near Eastern art was particularly impressive. You can also have an excellent but very reasonably priced lunch in the self service restaurant.

Enjoyed very much the classic collection.. Liked very much the classic collection in the main building.
Less the modern collection at the modern art building.

Sunday morning at the Gulbenkian museum. Decided to visit as fits with our interests and was a short walk from our hotel.Wonderful collection of artefacts and art,topped off by stunning Laliique jewellery and glass.All in spacious building,beautiful gardens and an ace cafe.thoroughly recommend this place-and the free admission on Sun. Morning a great bonus.
a cultural oasis in the city. a modern museum in a garden setting with great variety from paintings and furniture to ceramics and textiles

World class collections. Although the collections on display are smaller than I had expected everything in them is an absolute gem, so it still feels like an amazingly rich experience. Nice terrace cafe in the gardens as well.
Quick Stop. Lots of great art in the museum. We were pressed for time, so we did not get to see the modern art though we would have liked to. Nice shop downstairs once you've finished.

from classic to modern Art. At Gulbenkian's museum you will find bothe classic and modern art, with separate premises. Just adjacent to it, you will encounter, perhaps, one of the three most beautiful Lisbon gardens and also a fine theatre, of of the central points to hear great classical music. It will be, altogether, a fantastic experience, if you decide to visit the Gulbenkian Foundation site.
Culture in the City Center. A NGO that has the best gardens and museums in the city centre , a must visit for a relaxed confortable afternoon .
Art and nature, not to be missed. Old and modern art, nature, good food in a noisy but pleasant restaurant. Go, you will not regret it. I'm sure you will love it.

Perfect for a half day. A city oasis, the museum is surrounded by a beautiful park. Inside it's a great mix of art and history and a beautiful collection. Don't miss tha last room with René Lalique jewellery, magnificent. The museum is free on sundays.

Amazing collection of priceless art... We visited on the last day of our visit to Lisbon and was pleased we did..It houses a huge collection of art from the pre byzantine period right up to the turn of the 20th century. Was amazed to see peices from Degas, Turner to Monet all in the same floorspace with art from the old Chinese dynasties .Impressive stuff ..If art is your thing

Excellent collection in an excellent place. Well located in a big green area. The collection is varied and beautiful, ranging from ancient times to modern times. The place is nice to be, the pieces are well lit. Even if you do not want to enter, pay a visit to the garden!!

More than a wet day option. We were recommended to visit here but in truth only went because it was a wet day. Glad it rained! The place has a truly fabulous collection of art from BC to Monet all of which are prime examples of whatever genre they are from. I loved the Egyptian art, the tiles from many places, the illustrated bibles, the Turners, the Rembrandts, the Van Dyck and the Lalique collection. But there was much more than that. Go!

Architecture and integrated Landscape. This proved to be the unexpected highlight of our brief visit to Lisbon. Not only a superb collection of art, but an architectural and landscape delight. The main administrative building is an imposing 125m of linear concrete, granite and bronze glass designed in the early 60s. It includes conference facilities and two auditoria. The museum itself is a separate structure, again linear modern movement in design, which sits elegantly in its landscape and contains an excellent cafe where one can sit outside and enjoy the views over the park. The Landscape design is quite remarkable. Undulating lawns and a lake with an open air auditorium give way to secondary paths of stepping stones which lead through dense planting of Bamboo, tall grasses and Eucalyptus to secret ponds. Children clearly love the hidden paths and water features, unexpected sculpture in secret openings, and the different ground levels. Water plays an important part in the design, and in hot summers this must be an oasis of shade and quiet. A third building houses the Modern Art Centre, designed by Sir Leslie Martin, with stepped sections providing planting and shade for the gallery space, and again incorporating a linear rill of water along the front of the building much loved by promenading ducks. A small but good bookshop too.
Nice afternoon walk. The grounds have lots of potential , but do appear to need some work . A nice place for a relaxing walk .

Beautiful building, presentation and art. Spaciousness, gardens, cafe, amazing art! Turkish and Syrian tiles, ancient art, carpets, Roman coins in great condition, well preserved and cleaned paintings

Fabulous museum. A collection with something for everyone. We came for the Rembrandt but greatly enjoyed the wonderful Middle East collection, the Persian carpets, the Lalique Room was a terrific finish. And it was free on Sunday we visited, my favourite price!

Too Lovely to be missed!. If you are a lover of Art, interested in concerts or just want a beautiful place to walk at leisure,then this is the place.With a wide range of classical art , orchestra and concerts there's always an activity of interest every week. For people studying art,the library offers study opportunities with a good collection of books.The garden is beautiful for a walk,with little ponds and ducks. There is a cafe and the museum itself is surrounded by lots of 'pastelarias' and just a stone throw from the El corte ingles shopping mall.
A "must" to visit. Amazing collection of beautiful objects, paintings, statues, jewellery, rugs and more ranging from 2000 b.c. to present day.

Great !!. Hello Travellers, to those who like art, sculpture here is the place. Always with expositions of art or sculture you can visit, also have a library and beatifull gardens that you can relax and take a walk ist a very nice place to go.In the surroudings you have lots of shopping!Dont miss it!

One of the World's best. A collection unrivalled of the choicest classical art from Europe, Egypt and the Orient. Purchased by a collector for whom only hype best would do and housed in a cool modern purpose built gallery with a pretty good restaurant.

A little piece of time out. Well displayed with fascinating oriental and Persian artefacts. Don't miss the Lalique exhibition at the end even if your feet are weary. The cafe is also good, allowing for a rest before exploring the gardens and walking back into the city.

A Must See If A Museum Fan. Quite A Collection.. Had been to Lisbon many times. And never made it to this museum as I'm not a fan of decorative art. Finally made it and what an impression and collection of beautiful pieces. Not to be missed. On a good day you can also enjoy the beautiful grounds. Relax. Have lunch or take a drink. Lay on the grass and take it all in. The Centre for Modern Art is also a part of the Gulbenkian and should be added to the visit. It's also on the same property. Both are free on Sundays!

Magnificent art museum. Having been to the Gulbenkian Museum in the past, we were prepared to be disappointed on a return visit - but were not. This is truly a great place with wonderful exhibits. Don't miss the stunning Iznik pottery and Lalique jewellery. The building itself is a masterpiece of 1960s Brutalism, softened by plants and set in a beautiful garden. We have not visited the (separate) modern art section.

Marvellous art oasis. I went here with an organised meetup group. It was a surprise to find an extensive collection of fine works throughout the Modern art Gallery and the Museum. The restaurant and the park make the visit a very pleasant one.
Something for everyone!. Excellent collection, ranging from Egyptian artifacts,Rembrandt paintings, French furniture and fabulous Lalique.Well worth a visit especially on Sunday when entry is free!

Beautiful museum with beautiful things. This a great museum with a lot of beautiful things. Amazing collection from ancient to modern. Great french furniture and also fantastic Italian paintings all the way to a fantastic Lalique collection
Everyone interested in art must visit this museum, it is very special!
a great mans arte collection. under one roof you can go from pre history to modern arte, and in the evening (in season) catch a concert or opera
Worth a visit. Be aware that there are several parts to this museum. The modern arts section too. On Sunday's it is free. The gardens are worth a walk about.

Few time enough to see history. Is a smart museum were in a short time you can have an idea of the past trought different cultures and epocas. From one room trough a door you're in a different world. Half day you see all.
Beautiful museum. The collection in the main museum is amazing and it is displayed in a beautiful space. We also found the modern art museum to be fascinating.
Top museum in Lisbon. This is a must-see museum in Lisbon! For art nouveau lovers, they have the best Lalique jewelry collection anywhere.
Aeons of art and artefacts. We liked following a map of 10 must sees, but quickly realised there were 10s of 1000s of must sees. Amazing collection. Spend a day there

a MUST- amazing collection. By far the best museum re art in Lisbon. I could not believe the artworks in there- from masterpieces done by well known painters- you name it, he had bought it, to Lalique to ceramics. It is absolutely amazing. A bit out of the way to get to- but a metro stop nearby on the blue line- but A MUST...
Great collection!. Really interesting collection. Lovely old masters, interesting rugs, ceramics and incredible art nouveau jewelry. Well worth an hour or 2 while you're in Lisbon.
Solid collection. Very nice sampling of art from a wide range of periods and styles. Not so huge that you feel overwhelmed to get through the place

Little Gem of Europe. As you may have read, this museum is funded by the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation. Gulbenkian was an Armenian oil magnate who found refuge in Portugal the last thirteen years of his life. While the exterior's super minimalist modern poured concrete facade reminds me of the Federal building in Boston, the gardens around make it quite nice. We visited in February, and still people were sitting on the lawns and outside enjoying the environment.The museum contains classical sculptures (statues) from Rome and Greece, European paintings from the Renaissance period, decorative arts -- specifically French furniture, and some beautiful pieces of jewels and glasses.I was quite surprised to see work by Rubens, Rembrandt, Rodin, Renoir, Degas, Édouard Manet, Claude Monet, and several other well-recognized artists.This museum takes only a few hours to walk through. We walked their from our Bed and Breakfast, so I am not certain how easy it is to get to via public transportation.
One of the best art collections. One of the best art collections, a luxurious garden in the middle of the city. The atmosphere you can't describe, just go there and see for yourself.

Worth the Detour - A treasure trove.. Wonderful collection of precious objects, Art and Textiles. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit, we just about had time to see everything in the 90 mins we had spare before we left for the airport.

Marvelous. Its a unique Museum create by Calouste Gulbenkian in the seventies... or earlier...all type of culture, expositions, music, everything, and a lovely garden where you can seat down an relax.

Great place to see a concert. I highly recommend the museum as a whole, it's a great place to visit or just rest in the gardens. But we also went to a concert there, it was so beautiful! Don't miss the chance to go there!

Small but worth a visit. This museum is small but that makes it do-able in a couple of hours. The collections contain some very interesting artefacts and because there are a few in each it isn't overwhelming like some bigger museums where you either slog round and take very little in or pick and choose and risk missing something great.The Lalique is exquisite and some of the small Egyptian pieces are quite lovely. In fact there are many things I liked about this museum including the café although don't sit outside or you will be pestered by pigeons landing on the table and trying to eat the food!Go on a Sunday when entrance is free.
a museum not to be missed!. The museum is on a human scale (-of a ground floor), but what wealth!Paintings, decorative arts, jewelry, furniture, archeology make it a must / quite interesting!!

Art Of All Types. The variety of the collection plus the audio guide which paced the visit perfectly ensuring that some images will stay with me for a while. I was lucky to have perused my guide book in advance of my visit so knew a lot about Gulbenkian himself plus the range of what to expect.€ 5 is the admission cost (free on Sunday AM I think ) plus € 4 for the audio guide. Please remember that photo ID is required if renting audio guide. I had a driving licence which is retained at the reception desk & returned on surrender of the audio guide as you leave. I think that a € 50 deposit is acceptable should you not have photo ID to hand.

Great tour through the history of art. Wonderful art collection from pre-history to the Impressionists and all perfectly manageable. A series of rooms which give an overview of a particular period in art from Egyptian, through Greek and Roman, to Chinese and then Europe of the 18th and 19th centuries. Artefacts, sculpture, rugs, furniture and paintings, all are the finest examples in this marvellous private collection of the Armenian oil billionaire, Calouste Gulbenkian. Highly recommended.

Impressive private collection. This extraordinary private collection encompasses works that range from the ancient to the contemporary. There are two art museums on the campus. One houses modern and contemporary works and the other everything else. Among the contemporary works, I was pleased to find pieces by artists new to me. The Gulbenkian Museum proper offers a sweep of one man's extraordinary collection. There are Egyptian and classical works, Turkish carpets and ceramics, Renaissance master works, impressionist paintings, art nouveau jewelry, and much more. But, while the collection is broad, it is not very deep: It represents an important private collection, not an exhaustive "encyclopedic" one. Admission is 5 euro for each museum.
Small collection of high quality pieces. High quality pieces. I especially liked the Islamic room with iznik tiles. Nice size without being too large. Have to check your coat and backpacks.

Nice museum. We visited this museum based on a guide book recommendation. We caught a taxi from downtown Lisbon for about 5 euros. The museum has a nice collection of artifacts but not as many paintings as we're used to seeing. It took about 90 minutes to see everything at a leisurely pace. We did not have time to see the nearby modern art museum. I wouldn't call it a "must see" but definitely a nice to see attraction.

Wonderful Private Collection. I visited this museum on my second visit to Lisbon. It is well worth a visit and easy to find as it is close to two metro stations. I would suggest reading up on the items on display before making a visit and then being selective on what you wish to see as there is a variety of items on display. I was particularly interested in the art collection but spent rather too long looking at the porcelain and carpets and silk hangings therefore leaving little time for the art. I will return next year!There is a very good cafe on the lower ground floor. It has an outside seating area overlooking the lovely gardens.I was disappointed in the shop as I felt the choice was limited.

A rare and beautiful collection. Such a diverse collection of beautiful and unusual objects brought together by one man over a great many years. They also host music events. The café has great local cakes. The shop also has good gifts.

Great museum. one of the great museums i have visited- really fantastic private collection, its one of the best private collections in the world! Plan at least 3 hours there- you will really enjoy it.

Fantastic collection. This is a wonderful museum, devoted to the art collected by Calouste Gulbenkian. The selections are well presented and cover a wide variety of times and styles. It includes works from well known artists, sure. But there are also works from unknown craftspeople, from lesser known artists, and the like. Statues, paintings, carpets, pottery, and more. It is also free all day on Sundays, which was a nice surprise. Any art or history buff would do well to visit.

the finest art museum in Portugal!. well, in my opinion, this is the finest art museum in Portugal. It is the personal collection of Armenian oil baron Calouste Gulbenkian. The museum hold a very wide variety of art. None of them are large but they are of quality. They include artifacts from ancient Egypt, Greece and Roman. There are fine Islamic, Renaissance and Medieval decorative pieces. For me the highlight was the fine collection of 15th to 19th century European paintings. There very good works by Rubens, Rembrandt, Monet and Renoir on display here. On a historical point, a lot of what you see here was purchased by Calouste Gulbenkian from St. Petersburg's The Hermitage back in the 1920's. The museum many strong traveling exhibitions that pass through Lisbon. If I had a beef about the place, it would be that I disliked the exterior of the building which was I thought was very unwelcoming and sterile.

Impressive collection in a beautiful building. The Gulbenkian has a very nice collection of Western and some non-Western art. We particularly liked the collection of islamic textiles and ceramic items. The art is displayed in a beautiful series of galleries, each item hung in its own space. The museum is not so big as to be overwhelming. It was free during our visit on a Sunday, and not particularly crowded.

A true treasure. Having a couple of hours to spare, and having been given a tip about the museum, we walked the grounds, then entered the display space at opening hour. There we found room after room of true treasures -- paintings, sculpture, furniture, porcelain, tapestries, and so much more. The exhibits are well organized and displays are done to show the items to us in the best possibly way. The value for your admission is incredible. A must see!

A Jewel. Praise to the heavens the collecting skills of citizen Gulbenian and, moreover, his generosity to his adopted home, Lisbon. The museum is a tour de force of paintings, carpets, ceramics, clocks and so many others objet d'art that one could easily go back each day for a year and find new insights. It is simply a jewel.

Carefully curated masterpieces shown in beautiful building. This museum is a gem. Compares favorably to the Frick in MYC or the Kimball in Fort Worth, Texas. Small collection of fabulous paintings. Beautiful park setting outside the museum.

A must visit in Lisbon. There are many museums in Lisbon, but Gulbenkian one's are definitely at the top. Many of the art pieces that you will see here are unique. It has one of the best art collections from artist René Lalique, among many others. Do not miss this.

Museum plus concert hall. This a must for Lisbon visitors. A modern building houses a magnificent collection of Asian art and a concert hall where the Gulbenkian orchestra plays often. The gardens enveloping the building are also worth a visit.
Stunning collection. This is a great diverse and interesting collection, and the display standards are top of the range. Worth the journey.
Modern Art show was great. The older Museum in need of some attention to the paintings which seemed in need of cleaning but the Modern Art Museum was a great space and show.

A world class level museum.. Contemporary art museum with a spectacular garden surroundings. When we were in Lisbon was a jazz festival in the gardens at night for an amazing price, We went every night we could. Large collection of paintings by famous painters.
Endured by teenagers. We were able to have a brief visit here once we had found the front door. Endured by teenagers well I particularly enjoyed the Egyptian exhibits.

Don't miss. Elegant contemporary buildings immersed in a beautiful garden. Very good contemporary art collection, but the heart of the museum is Calouste Gulbenkian's collection. An extraordinary man who built his fortune on Middle East oil in the 30s, he was an astute and idiosyncratic collection. I especially liked some Greek statues, some beuatiful renaissance paintings, and most of all a fantastic Rembrandt portrait - one of the best Rembrandts I've ever seen. Go!

Good for a rainy day. A fantastic collection. I found the first galleries with egyptian and other early items fascinating. The later european furniture less so but there should be something for everyone. Mediocre cafe so go to local cafes.
You must go. One of the best antiques colletions I have already seen. Very interesting Middle East carpets and tiles. And old western clocks that work. You must go.

The best ever private collection. We walked up through Lisbon main park from the rail station to the exhibition building finding an un marked section of an 19 century tiled ruin on the way. (East side of the park). The museum is in a tabular angular concrete and glass sandwich surrounded by tranquil gardens. Inside is the most exquisite selection of art we have ever seen. Well laid out well lit and helpfully well described on the audio guide. The carpets are incredible especially that one from the Amber palace in Jaipur. The sculptures breathtaking. Don't miss this amazing place

Disapppointing. Lunch rather "canteen' like which is disappointing considering the setting and especially the outdoor seating area Service was non existent and very unhelpful I asked for vegetarian options and was reluctantly shown pastry dishes that had been standing for some time,unimaginative salads etc - not at all tempting Would recommend eating elsewhere but the outside seating area is delightful for a drink
Gulbenkian. Fantastic collection in a classic modernist building. It makes you wish you could ' do a Gulbenkian' and leave tour collection tonthe nation !

A Definite Must. Calouste Gulbenkian is possibly one of the most important people of the 20th Century for having played a crucial role in negotiating Western access to Middle Eastern Oil reserves. Visit the museum and see for yourself, the money accumulated from his business ingenuity was put into good use. The building style of the complex is simple and clear-cut, the straightness of the cubical and rectangular forms softened by the surrounding gardens (bring some bread or seeds to feed the ducks!). The interior design is simple and elegant; there is nothing to distract the attention from the displayed objects and each artefact is given its own space to stand out without being clustered by its neighbours. Between the exhibit halls, there are corridors with window walls facing interior gardens and armchairs to rest. The exhibition is astonishing and much like a superb meal must be enjoyed patiently, one bite at a time. We took our time and stayed inside for a good 3-4 hours, absorbing the details of the workmanship manifest in each and every exhibit. The section with the heavy and kitsch rococo furniture seemed to contrast the elegance of the Chinese vases and Islamic miniatures, but that surely is a question of subjective taste. Be sure not to miss the gallery room of Rene Lalique's work on your left in the corridor that leads towards the exit of the exhibition!
Best collection ever seen. Cngratulations as this is the best personal collection including Turkey.ı am very happy to be there last minute for two hours.

Top quality classical music. Top quality art museums. The Gulbenkian Foundation has a very active and variate cultural programm, including concerts with its own fantastic orchestra and inviting best world soloists. The art colection, both in the "classical" and in the "contemporany" museums, is one of the best in Europe and in the western world.The beautiful gardens and the buildings deserve a visit.Even the museum shops have a good choice of souvenirs

A Really Wonderful Collection. This is a small museum but has a wonderful collection. We really enjoyed every room and the collection is very well displayed. We were there on a rainy day and it was a great way to spend a couple of hours. If it would have been nice, the surrounding grounds are beautiful, but only the ducks were enjoying them that day. Their cafe is also very good, we enjoyed lunch there. We went on Sunday so it was free.

One man's collection. Pretty museum in modern part of town easily reached by subway. Art and artifacts from Egyptian times to Impressionist. Impressive to think all in one collection. Furniture, tapestries and porcelain are beautiful in addition to paintings and ancient artifacts.

A lifetime ambition achieved!. My husband has wanted to visit this art gallery for a very long time, so we did on his 60th birthday! As a non art lover I spent several hours sat on the comfy leather chairs in the massive entrance hall, people watching and reading my book. My husband said it was an excellent museum for ancient artefacts and an interesting collection of 20th century paintings. There is a very good café in the basement which serves reasonably priced food and drinks including pasta, pastries, soup etc. A walk through the grounds takes you to the Museum of Modern Art which is free if you have paid to visit the other gallery. An enjoyable visit for both of us.
Great taste, great history. Calouste Gulbenkian was a unique man who managed to gather an amazing collection of art works. Not to be missed!
The man had an eye for art. What a fun little museum. The collection is eclectic. The cafe is a nice little place to get a bite to eat. This is a great place for art lovers.

Intriguing mix of art and not too big to be daunting. Very eclectic mix of art and items from thorough the ages and global cultures - Egyptian, Persian, Iberian peninsula, Great Masters, Turner, impressionists and a small dedicated Lalique room. A very entertaining way to spend a couple of hours and not too expensive - free entry on Sundays, I believe (we went on a Saturday)
OK Museum. If you want to understand Spanish and Portuguese history, this would probably be a good place to go. However for us it was too much history and not enough art.

Lisbon Treasures. Gorgeous collection here in the Gulbenkian. Nice café downstairs too, tasty food and reasonably priced. Lovely outdoor garden layout also. We sat outside -in January - and watched the ducks wandering about. But the collection is really the highlight.

eclectic museum. great variety, compact exhibits under one roof. amazing story how the museum was founded. nice mix from ancient to present, could easily do in 1-2hrs. We have phenominal museums in Washington DC that I never get to go to so I do feel guilty about that

Outstanding Museum. The Gulbenkian Museum is a must see place. The private collection is an amazing collection ceramics, paintings, rugs, furniture, and unusual types of pieces we had never seen in any other museums. The Muslim glassware was fabulous. It was interesting how many items in a category Gulbenkian had collected. The finale of the museum is the Lalique collection presented in its own room. It is a fascinating collection of beautiful Art Deco objects. We truly enjoyed the experience.
Impressive. Many artifacts, art, etc. from all over the world. Quite a collection! There was too much to take in in the time we allowed. The glass and silver collections were outstanding.

Great museum. I am not a huge fan of museums however I really enjoyed wandering around this one. The Egyptian section is small but very interesting with some magical old pieces. The art collection also had some lovely pieces by various European artists. The museum is small enough to wander around in a few hours without feeling too overwhelmed.
Give yourself time to study and enjoy. This art museum has English and Portuuguese audio guides, which are worth the 4€ price tag. Take time to learn about the items in the collection!

Two separate museums, worth it just for Lalique. The main museum houses a fantastic collection of ceramics, oil paintings by most of the great masters and various other items. The admission price is only 5 euros and its worth it just for the last room which is devoted entirely to objects by Renee Lalique which are simply breathtaking. They are housed in well lit cabinets which allows their real beauty to shine. There's a nice cafe with outdoor seating downstairs and then wonderful gardens (which are free to wander around without having to pay to enter) between this building and the larger museum of modern art. A must see if you have the time in Lisbon
gulbenkian. very nice and interesting place near espanha square.there is also a big garden around where you can see some birds and different kind of trees.

Stunning. This is a most fabulous and varied collection and we felt privileged to have seen it. The ceramics, painting masterpieces, the Lalique collection and so much more are all very fine indeed. The gardens are beautiful and the cafe serves a mean custard tart.
This is a real must for the visitor to Lisbon.

A real delight.. A wonderful building with excellent displays. All items were so expertly presented and it was very easy to follow the history. Very impressive museum with such high quality display techniques specially built for the items. So refreshing to visit such a high quality museum. The building itself was a delight to walk around and was of equal interest to the treasures. The gardens are excellent - a real place of tranquility in the city. Even though there were plenty of visitors it had such a lovely atmosphere.
Superb collection. Spacious, well labelled displays of the phenomenal array and range of his acquisitions. Was surprised at the range of Lalique objects on show.

An extensive collection beautifully displayed. This collection is quite breathtaking. The early Islamic section was my favourite area, with such quality and bright colours. Everything is displayed to perfection - the pottery and tableware, silk fabrics and carpets, sculptures, paintings, furniture. At 5 Euros, it represented excellent value for money and was well worth the visit.

Great Experience. It's not the Louvre, but considering this is ONE guy's collection, impressive doesn't begin to explain what this is- Renaissance paintings, Egyptian artifacts, Renoir, Degas, Rembrandt... Not to be missed

See our main review of Lisbon. Worth the trip out of the city by Metro, inexpensive and worth the time and effort to get there. Has good cafe, peaceful park, art museum and venues for concerts. El Cortes Ingles department store is within walking distance.
Great Collection. Great but not comprehensive. Reflects the tastes and interest of the benefactor. One of the ones to see if you are Lisbon and have time.

Look for the Lalique. It's always fun to see artwork, and the Gulbenkian has some standout paintings that you want to be sure to see. But the best part of the museum is the Lalique collection. The Lalique items are exquisite gem-encrusted confections that beg for close, extended examination. Total treat! Over all, the Museum reminded me of the Barnes in Philadelphia, a quirky collection gathered by a private citizen, and both had the wabi-sabi water feature at the front entrance. A great way to spend an afternoon.

Excellent Museum. Excellent museum with wide range of classical and oriental art.......decorative rugs and tiles from Turkey and Persia, statues and paintings from Europe, vases from China. Lots of beautiful things. The building and grounds are architecturally interesting. Beautifully laid out gardens.....perfect for a stroll. Well worth the time to visit. Easy access from metro.

Thank you, Mr Gulbenkian. Words almost fail me (but not quite!). A chilly January Tuesday morning is neither the time nor place to expect such a rich and rewarding experience, but do what we did, enter at ten o'clock and leave after midday with wonderful memories. The garden setting is perfect with windows showing the outside just often enough to allow one to take a breath of nature and to digest the sight of all the wonders inside. The displays are beautifully set out with space and a calm and unhurried atmosphere, there is enough information available but it is discreetly offered. What a collection of truly fabulous things. God rest your soul, Mr Gulbenkian, and thank you for giving us the opportunity to share in your collections.

Stunning collection of world class artefacts. It felt like having access to a private art collection which indeed it was......treasures from Persia Turkey Ming Quing, ALexanderia gold coins.....Lalique glass.....lavish paintings.......concerts on a Sunday......extremely fresh healthy food in the cafe.......large windows looking on to trees and nature......what a wonderful place.

The best museum in Lisbon. The Gulbenkian museum was the one in Lisbon. A bit far from the center (do not walk there, take the subway), it's relatively small but everything there is very interesting and the collection varied. Gulbenkian was an oil magnate and his collection was considered the top in Europe in the 30's and 40's. I would recommend the cafeteria for lunch. It was very good as well.

Interesting collection . We were staying very close to the museum and were able to walk to it. This is a small museum with an eclectic collection from an individual donor. Starts with ancient Egyptian pieces and ends with Lalique pieces, with everything in between. Can do the whole museum in 1-2 hours. had a few Monet And Renoir paintings. Worth the visit if you have the time.

wide appeal for all tastes. Special exhibitions throughout the year, concert series, grounds to relax, great cafeteria and boasts a grand collection of sculpture, silks, paintings by Impressionists like Degas and Monet.Noteworthy collection worth a visit in Lisbon.

What an amazing collection. Unbelievable that one person could amass such a varied collection of interesting objects. In addition there is the modern gallery at the end of the park which is well worth visiting

Don't miss this. Loved the contemporary buildings that housed the museum and the grounds. The displays were very well done and well lighted. Unbelievable that one person could put together such a fantastic collection. It contains a lot of middle eastern art but also asian and european pieces. A perfect way to spend the morning and they have a little cafe for lunch. The menu was minimal but you can grab a table in the garden area if the weather is nice.
great museum with lovely grounds worth a stroll.. Check out the restaurant as well....good food at great prices. Nice outdoor section to the restaurant.

Excellent museum!. Visited the permanent exhibition - excellent exhibits in a museum with wonderful interior "architecture". Did not have time to visit the special exhibition but perhaps next time. You need around 4-5 hours for the permanent exhibition.
GREAT. free on sunday, great place for lunch, great place for lunch, loved up in the garden, must do this in lisbon portugal
GULBENKIAN GOOD. Be careful here because you can pay a lot to go around all exhibitions. Otherwise, allow yourself time to cover a very extensive and varied collection.

Lovely museum of modern art - worth the entrance fee to see the gardens alone!. OK modern art galleries can be a bit like the 'king and his new clothes' - lots of people oohing and ahhing about canvasses with a couple of paint splodges with a fake fox stuck in one corner.. This museum has lots of that - and some of it is really funny.. but there is some really good stuff here too that wouldn't look stupid above the fireplace.I especially liked the surrealist paintings in vivid colours that looked like they were painted by small children.The building itself is a wonderful light space with polished floors and lots of smaller gallery spaces.The grounds are wonderful. Lots of tropical planting, streams and fantastic sculpture, populated by ducks, pigeons etc.. and some parakeets that seem to have gone wild and flap about terrorising the native birds..A really good day out. Take the camera as photography is permitted and unless you can produce photographic evidence your friends won't believe what passes for art..(The garden shed in the lobby made from rotten planks of old wood is one not to miss!)

Excellent visit. My wife and I enjoyed a few hours on a dull weather afternoon. The listening devices are a must for a full appreciation of the displays. The display were extremely varied in topics a d time lines. Great value.

Great Place to Visit in a Sunny Afternoon. The Foundation has an excellent museum and great surroundings (several cool places around are also worth a visit). Inside there are nice cafés and places to chill-out and check-out your email in the free wi-fi taking some sun in the garden. If you feel more cultural go and get yourself a guided tour to their temporary or permanent varied art exhibits, you will certainly enjoy it. Otherwise enjoy your latte in the sun. Highly recomended!

Exquisite pieces beautifully presented. The collection is eclectic and of a wonderful standard. Well presented displays of a lifetimes's collection. The Islamic art section is outstanding. I recommend the guide book at €7.20 to read as you go around and afterwards. It has good explanations of key pieces and a good summary of each section. The restaurant serves excellent food at very reasonable prices and the gardens are pleasant and relaxing. All very good at only €5 for the museum.
beautiful pieces of art. beautiful pieces of art in a very beautiful scenery.It is a pity that , on Sunday, when the visit is for free, you have to wait so long to get a ticket!!

One of the best museum in Lisbon. If you like Art, Painting, Sculpture and Decorative Arts, this museum os for you :) For me, it's one of the best art museum in Lisbon. The museum is located in a middle of a beautiful garden from Calouste Gulbenkian foundation. Entrance is free in Sundays morning (entrance of gardens is always free).
Wonderful museum. Saw the Lalique and it is gorgeous. The whole collection of the museum is well worth seeing. Don't short the gardens, they are worth a walk around.

Exciting collectio for art lovers & anthropology geeks. It was wonderful journey and a rare meeting of East and West, ancient and modern, all in one place governed by the excellent taste of a hihgly-successful individual... Loved it!

Wonderful gardens and exhibitions. The modern art centre in particular is a must to visit. Big space, lots on show and you feel totally cultured in the end. Spend time visiting the gardens, there's lots to explore and art everywhere.

Beautifully Curated Museum. The Gulbenkian Museum has a relatively small collection of very high quality paintings, sculptures, carpets, pottery, ceramics and furniture. From a Greek vase and an Egyptian statue of a pharaoh, through a Florentine hottie by Ghirlandaio and an old man by Rembrandt on to Corot and Monet, the collection touches most artistic eras before the 20th century. It is all beautifully displayed with informative descriptions on Portuguese and English. The antique clocks are all ticking and even miniature illuminated manuscripts are easy to see and appreciate. The museum's namesake benefactor made his money by acquiring 5% of the stock in BP and Shell in return for middle-east olit rights. Nice that he gave back by providing his collection and a museum worth of displaying it.
Modern Museum. Beautiful museum, modern and with many different and interesting exibitions, attractions and with a nice and quite park on the outside where you can relax and take nice pictures.

What an amazing art collectIon!!!. During my visit the museum hosted the Treasures from the Royal Palaces of Spain (22/10/2014->25/01/2015), which was extraordinary but I will not exaggerate if I comment that my breath stopped from the museum's permanent exhibition!!!

A jewel of art. I was a bit sceptical about visiting this museum because I thought, well, how much/ many artifacts can a person collect? And I was amazed by how large the museum was and how many pieces of so many different arts were presented there. So even if you do not like art, there is a lot to see and experience because of the way the pieces are put together. It is a bit hard to find not only the location but the museum itself inside of a park, but it was Worth the effort.

Eclectic art. Lots of interesting exhibits from all forms and ages of art, marred by the 25 minute wait in the queue at the ticket desk (more staff please). Especially liked the lalique section and the clocks.
Art. I consider both museums of high level, the modern art museum has regular new exhibitions.I Adore the beautiful garden,.There is a good restaurant

Amazing private collection!. We visited Lisbon in March and interspersed small bus tours and hop on hop off with a few treats. The Gulbenkian was one. This collection can be "done" in a couple of hours and with its gardens, provided a nice oasis and retreat from Lisbon. While this may not be for the serious museum addict, I enjoyed it.
One man's passions. An eclectic collection of fine pieces from many cultures and ages.Not to be missed, although, being an individual collector's choice, not all may be to your liking - or mine
Outstanding collection of art, old and very old. This collection is unbelievable and very well organized. You need at least two hours to get some idea of the best objects. Visit also the park.

Urban oasis . The museum houses a diverse assortment of ancient Egyptian, middle eastern, Asian, and European art and artifacts from Gulbenkian's collection. Apart from the permanent collection you can expect to find fascinating special exhibitions. If you tire of antiquities, the center of modern art is nearby and special price tickets are available. The surrounding gardens are a lush and tranquil oasis in the midst of urban Lisbon. If you have a couple of hours to spend, it's worth the price of admission.

A must-see. You must go for the Lalique collection alone, but the rest of the Museum is a delight. We had lunch on the terrace and enjoyed the gardens, then took our time to wander through the rooms. If you've been to the Burrell in Glasgow, you will know that a museum designed to showcase a personal and manageable collection is the ideal way to spend an afternoon.

Small but absolutely lovely!. Think that it´s “must to visit” in Lisbon! Has wonderful collection of furniture, painting, glass and other essential decoration tools of last 3 sentries… Manage to transmit the ambience and way of leaving… Absolutely lovely museum!

I was expecting more. Too small collections, I was expecting more for this so well-known institution. Good website, with all the information. Beautiful collection of ancient furniture. The gardens are marvelous, take time to walk or even have lunch there.
Quiet and insightful. It is a very nice and calm place, always providing interesting cultural activities to the audience. It is easy to reach by public transport.
Grand. Very typical monastery cathedral. Well preserved and marked. Near Belem, and Coach Museum so do all the same day.

Great out of the way Museum. Depiction of Portuguese/European history seems the aim. Different eras have their own displays that make it easy to spend time in an area of interest. Quite eclectic collection from Lalique to Medieval art. Sunday free. Recommended to take subway to visit this museum.
Excellent exhibits. Free on Sundays. Have a lot of beautiful objects on display. It also have a good cafeteria and beautiful garden. A good place to spend a couple of hours.

great museum in Lisbon. The collections in this museum follow the personal interests of Mr. Gulbenkian, who started to put them together at the beginning of the last century. They are varied: European paintings starting with the 13th century, up to the impressionists of the 19th century, then sculptures including several by Auguste Rodin, a collection of Greek and Roman sculptures, glass and coins and another one of Mesopotamian Art. There is a large collection of Islamic Art from the times of the Mamluks and the Ottoman Empire and also one of ceramics from China and Japan from the past few centuries. Finally, there is a collection of works by Lalique, with outstanding exhibits. It is also worth paying attention to the temporary exhibitions: when I visited, there was one with outstanding works of art from major Spanish museums. The Gulbenkian museum is worth also attention for itself, as it was built specifically for this purpose and it has a very good layout. It is certainly one of the top museums in Portugal and it is highly recommended.

Beautiful setting for a fascinating if very personal selection of artefacts. Well worth the visit even on a day of heavy rain when the garden can only be glimpsed through occasional plate glass windows. A good deal of middle and far eastern artefacts through history, but also a satisfying representative selection of European classical painting, furniture and some sculpture all expertly displayed. It's an individual man's taste which he was able to indulge with his purchases and this is reflected in what you can see; you make your own choice as to which to study and admire. A very good art shop, and at lunchtime a very crowded restaurant with such a huge slow queue we to abandon our idea of eating there (and couldn't find anything else in the immediate area.)

A must to visit. Modern paintings: Fernand Leger, Arshile Gorky and Antonio Dacosta among others. There are also good examples from the national art scene. Free on Sundays, other wise the entrance fee is 5 Eur. It is very close to the Sao Sebastao metro station.

Excellent self-service. The food is well made, good and various choices -- very good value and right in the same building as all the good museum/exhibits/concert halls, etc. of the Fundação. The queue is enormous every single time we've been there! My suggestion is that they try to have a solution so people do not wait so long. Delicious (home cooked) food at a very good price.

A very personal collection. Mr. Gulbenkian, whose treasures are displayed in this museum, collected very high-quality examples of all kinds of fine arts and crafts, including paintings, sculpture, ceramics, jewelry, glass, even rugs. Unfortunately, he and I don't share the same taste in art. To me, the collection seemed quite conservative, muted, even gloomy. In the whole museum, I didn't find a single piece that really fascinated me or touched me emotionally. I learned some things but I didn't have a lot of fun.

Lovely gardens. This place is a cultural foundation. It has a good art libray (under subscription) and regular exhibitions. But, in my opinion, the garden is what makes the visit worth it. It's calm, nice, with some really quiet spots. Good for children, for reading, for doing nothing. Nice choice for a sunny day.
It's a museum with a garden.. Less than what we expected since we always visit museum. It's a museum with a garden so it's good to have a walk if you have the extra time.

Eclectic collection at a quiet, tranquil location. The collection here is not large, but has a little bit of everything and everyone can find something that suits their taste. The Lalique Collection was particularly stunning, definitely not something you see at other museums. Admission is only 5 euros, an absolute steal. Take some time after visiting the museum and enjoy the small garden on the grounds of the Foundation, a great place to relax with the locals especially on a sunny day.

Do NOT Miss It. A visit to the Gulnenkian complex is a MUST.The museum is, I think, the best collection one could wish to see. Formerly the private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian it contains perfect examples of art and culture from all over the world ranging from ancient Egyptian, Greek and Roman to modern European and Oriental.The Art Gallery features permanent anf temporary exhibitions - old and modern.The Concert Hall stages frequent concerts with wide-ranging styles.The various buildings are located in beautiful well-kept gardens.Numerous cafes and conveniences make this a great place to relax and enjoy art and music in tranquil surroundings
A R T. Pure art and culture. And nature. And science. All this in Lisbon and in one place. Don't forget to visit the lovely gardens and sorroundings. Near tarnsports and center of Lisbon.

A bit off the beaten Track. We had a short time in Lisbon whilst on a cruise and the weather that day was drizzly.. We took the tube from the main square on the sea front (by the port) and went about 5 stops.The gallery was a bit difficult to find as it wasn't well signposted and we had to walk a bit back on ourselves.On entering (it is the building on the left) we asked the price of admission and it was 15 euros. .A bit steep,-- however it was free that day.-Wow!The exhibits were interesting and varied, from pottery, furniture, sculpture and paintings. You could tell that it was a lifetime's collection. The paintings covered Dutch, French impressionists, one Turner (I never liked Turner until now) , lots of Portuguese painters I've never heard of (sorry) and about 20 Cannallettos which were all together in one small ante room. .It took us about 2 hours to go round and we enjoyed every minute of it.---and it was about 20 minutes brisk walk back to the ship.

Best Lisbon Museum. A must. You can see modern art, contemporary and ancient art. Also a very nice collection of jewels and glass pieces. Temporary exhibitions always are held and a nice auditorium with a music, ballet and theatre shows always running. Good library also.

great collection. It is an amazing collection of beautiful art and ceramics, furniture and pottery, interestingly presented and finishing off with breathtaking Lalique pieces. Great way to spend a rainy day.

Incredibly Impressive. A wonderful, wonderful facility. The presentation of the exhibits and the beauty of the grounds are reminiscent of the incredible new facility in Bentonville, Arkansas named Crystal Bridges.
Wait an minute! It must be the other way around. Crystal Bridges is reminiscent of the Gulbenkian Museum. Either way, both are experiences not to miss.

Fantastic Museum. I love visiting Gulbenkian. The gardens are amazing, with demanding ducks ;) and the exhibits are well chosen, well explained, well planned... Amazing. My favourite was Fernando Pessoa's, a couple of years ago...But this time I saw the "Shared History" between Portugal and Spain (from the Spanish Royal Archives).Well worth the 5€ entrance - and the 1€ for the Audio-guide: try it.
