from the finest. millenniums of fine art, carefully and passionately selected by the great collector Calouste Gulbenkian - take a morning or an after-noon in this marvelous museum

Compact museum that doesn't skimp on the works of art. Compact and beautiful museum that has a bit of everything. Perfect for a visit on a rainy day. Audio guides are not needed especially since they often malfunctioned.
amazing collection. to me this is a hidden gem - and the audio guide made the visit all the more surprisingsome pictures I took with my phone (the turkish tiles!) now make the nicest backgrounds
April, 2013. Best collection I have ever seen. Truly, this is the best museum in Lisbon. The quality of the collections is without comparison.

Treasures Galore. Great museum with an outstanding scope of art. Very good restaurant on site. Check what traveling exhibits are available. I saw the Treasures of Spain, a wonderful exhibit. Easy to get to and you can spend hours here.

A spot of excellence in Lisbon. The site is composed by the 60’s modernist Foundation building and the 80’s Modern Art building, both set in the magnificent gardens, designed by Gonçalo Ribeiro Telles, the actual ‘dean’ of Portuguese landscape architects. The first building is a must for architects and it offers: the museum with the Calouste Gulbenkian’s collection (top art pieces of all times and a small precious Lalique room), the auditoriums (classic and erudite music programmes are generally very good), several temporary exhibitions, a self-service cafeteria/restaurant with esplanade in the garden, an art history library, a bookshop...The second building presents a couple of very good art galleries, a bookshop, a great food self-service restaurant/cafeteria. The top contemporary Portuguese artists have, sometime in their lives, a retrospective exhibition here.Take your time to enjoy the gardens which are extremely rich in hidden corners and ponds and utmost beauty. If you’re around, don’t miss the August jazz festival, concerts at night in the garden amphitheatre by the lake: each year, it features the state-of-the-art performers from all around the world (book in advance). Also pay attention to the sculptures in the garden (Henry Moore, Clara Meneres,...), the temporary art installations and the performances – some are really worthwhile.
Great museum. Outstanding collection in a beautiful setting -- buildings and garden worth a visit. A must-see stop in Lisbon.
Great for art lovers, and for relax. One of the Lisbon places not to miss. A great art gallery, a beautiful garden in the center of the city, and several temporary exhibitions to enjoy. Great
Lovely museum for a brief stop. The Museum is of modest size but has an extremely varied collection of art and objects from aniquity to recent times. The grounds are beautiful.
Amazing collection. I have never seen such an abundance of beautiful artifacts!! It's an absolute must if you're in Lisbon.

A Real Gem! (Oh, That's Been Said, Already!). My partner and I visited this little treasure of a museum today and took the audio tour which, if you stop at most of the highlighted works, takes about 2.5 hours. Calouste Gulbenkian amassed a wonderful collection of art, often it seems by buying works from governments (the Soviets in Russia in the 1930s, the Nazis in Germany also in the 1930s) that were attempting to either "purify" their national museum holdings (the Soviets sold him a number of works that had belonged to the Czars and were in the Hermitage) or raise some cash. He also traveled extensively collecting from around the world many small gems, some by great masters (there are Rembrandts, Rubenses, Monets, Manets, Renoirs here as well as a number of Renaissance masters from Italy and Holland), but others equally interesting by lesser known lights. Many of the works here share cousins in the National Gallery in London or the Metropolitan in New York. The building itself is gorgeous and architecturally interesting, and reminded us in some ways of the new Barnes Foundation building in Philadelphia. Definitely worth a visit! There is also a modern art center, but we were museumed out so saved that for our next visit to Lisbon!

Great attraction!. Great way to spend a rainy day. Even on a nice day, take some time to explore the museum but don't forget to visit the park itself, with its bamboo trees and little ponds its a great way to pass a sunny day relaxing in the sun. You even forget that you are right in the middle of the city. There is also a little white cafe in the park that has some very delicious ice cream and wifi!
“Amazing exibitions”. Great gardens, Modern art museum and the ancient art museum. A must see in Lisbon,The garden do not forget, it is a delightful space with lush vegetation and well kept.

What a rich man he was. Nice museum showing off the wealth of one family's collection of Asian, Persian, European, and other worldly arts. Good rainy day attraction, but don't spend touch time unless you are really interested.

Treasures of Spanish royal palaces exhibition.. Visited the exhibition. Good overview of Spanish royals and connection with other countries. It is in these connections and cultural relations that a country or nation gets shaped. Beautiful portraits and items. Especially ecce homo by titian incredibly beautiful. Furniture less interesting. Make sure to get the audio guide to get to understand it all better and not to miss out on the detail.

A real gem of a museum. We had planned to visit this museum anyway, but to find such a place on a wet day was a real bonus. The collection is not huge but the quality of both the exhibits and the layout of the exhibition is extraordinary. The first range of galleries covers early history - Egyptian, Greek and Roman and then there is quite a lot of near and Middle Eastern work with some slightly later Chinese and Japanese wareWe stopped at this point for lunch in the cafe - v good - and returned for the European galleries with some spectacular paintings - Rembrandt, Rubens, Hals, Gainsborough, Turner, Corot, Degas, Manet, Monet and Renoir as well as sculptures by Rodin and a gallery devoted to Lalique.None of the galleries was crowded and there was time and space really to enjoy the works on show. Enough to fill 2 or 3 hours but not so much that museum fatigue set in.Fantastic value at 5 euro (or 2.50 for the over 65s).

Wonderful smallish museum. Even though small, the Museu Calouste Gulbenkian is one of the world's great museums, an absolute must when visiting Lisbon. The grounds are beautiful, the building a great example of museaum architecture and the collection, comprehensive. The building houses fabulous treasures, but words can't do it justice. We loved our visit.
What a treasure!. Among the best curated museums I have visited. Allow time to savor it although in size it is not overwhelming.

Amazing Experience. A real delight. The collection comes from the personal items collected by Gulbenkin. Very wide ranging but the Middle East department is the best we have seen. Try to leave some time for a walk around the gardens. Get there by Metro or cheap taxi. Do not miss it.

Wonderful Gem. Easy to reach by Metro, this smallish museum holds a very well curated collection, with particular strengths in middle eastern and islamic arts. A nice combination of art and other objections - carpets, furniture, etc. The cafe is nice and reasonably priced, with a wonderful relaxing terrace if the weather is nice.

Overwhelmed with pleasure. It's so wonderful coming across something so unexpected. The weather was abysmal. The rain just bucketing down and no hint of letting up so this was on my list of possibilities along with the museum of tiles. We had one day in port and having spent a holiday in Lisbon previously we were just going to wander and people watch. I'm so glad we went. The joy of coming across a rich man who shares his wealth instead of stashing it greedily away in a bank vault. The setting is a charming park but rain drenched when we were there . The building is another piece of architect 's brutal insistence on concrete but the rooms were spacious . It was the contents that left me speechless. Two Turners here, three Rodins there, Gainsborough ,Rembrandt ,Rubens . Madame Renoir by Monet or was it Madame Monet by Renoir? My brain was reeling and I had to stop. It's somewhere to return to. The tiny gold winged victory pin, the crystal duck, the japanese lacquer boxes, the bust of Moliere. I hope I never forget what I saw. An absolute gem.
Nice gardens, good ancient art collection. Nice gardens, good ancient art collection. Different periods and styles are well organized. Modern art is also available and very nice sculptures.
Good museum love the garden!. Went for the third time with my grandmother. It is a great way to spend a sunday afternoon.But what I really love is the garden. Must see!
Collection. Main collection very impressive - especially textiles, ceramics, glass and metalware. Modern art section weak.

fantastic place to fill a couple of hours with. Time to kill on last day so thought a museum would do.This is such a lovely collection of artefacts, so perfect and exquisite that they belie their age. Quite a domestic collection- art, persian rugs, religious artefacts, furniture, ceramics/china, silver, fabrics, illuminated books etc no arms or militaria. I enjoyed it so much I purchased the guide book to look at items at leisure. Reasonable entry charge and near to large shopping centre for some retail therapy after visiting.
Not to be missed. For us this was a highlight of Lisbon. A remarkable collection of artistic treasures from around the world.

THe Armenian warrior and the beauty. You must visit this interesting culture area, expositions, classic music and many other musical events and others, a foundation build for the sake of beauty. Kaloust gave to Lisbon a spot to remember. And of you are around in August go and see a Jazz concert.

Totally worth visiting. The museum is not very big, but it is quite interesting. I especially liked the carpets from Persia, the azulejos and the Lalique hall. The European art section is not bad either. Although it was raining when I visited the museum, the garden seems very beautiful.

A surprise in Lisbon. A lovely museum that contains the collections of a very rich man, the museum itself is elegant and beautifully designed. It contains a little bit of everything and is located in a park -like setting.
Well worth a visit. What a great museum. Amazing the wide variety of this man collected over his lifetime. Really enjoyed our time there.
Idea for a rainy day. Interesting and somewhat eclectic collection. Not too large, so one is not overwhelmed. Worthy of a couple of hours, especially on a rainy day.

Best 2 hours in Lisbon. The museum is wonderful. Great collection of the Masters, lots of artifacts, easy to walk through, benches to rest and not crowed. Grounds beautiful and a good spot to grab lunch. Price only 5Euro for two seniors. More enjoyable than the Louvre because of being able to see the collection.
3 enjoyable hours. Amazing collection built up over a lifetime by this man. It took 3 hours to see the artefacts in a purpose built museum set in beautiful park with cafe on site

Gulbekian Foundation and Museums. Easily reached across Praca De Espagna the foundation has 3 main exhibits The permanent exhibit, a separate very good Spanish exhibition from the Spanish Royal palace In a separate building there is a modern gallery as well Don't expect a huge gallery but the quality is very good and it is well worth the visit Ask the reception they will be more than glad to give you the details After a peasant walk in the garden you can find the Modern part of the gallery which is very interesting as well Price is 5 euros each very reasonable I wrote this review because the foundation and Museum are listed as 2 separate entities in fact they are one located in different proximate buildings regards Bobby

Warrants a few hours.... This private collection is marvellous and incredibly extensive.The Persian and Syrian artefacts are particularly beautiful.He was an avid collector whose tastes varied from ladro to jewellery.The art is varied and whilst not liking everything that hangs one cannot be but impressed at its vastness.Spanish school kids are VERY well behaved when on an excursion !Walk around the park….a lovely shady and quiet hour.

Not to be missed.... The garden, the gallery itself and the collection are all wonderful.This man's passion is self evident.Enjoyed the temporary exhibition on Spanish Royal Treasures.Most enjoyable and worth spending a few hours here.

Beautiful Museum, Worth a Visit. Currently the museum has a special exhibition of Spanish Royal Treasures. This alone is worth the price of admission. The permanent collection is interesting as well. If you time is limited, just pay for and view the special exhibition.
Very variety art exhibition. I love everything about the Gulbenkian Museum. Architecture, Garden and many kind of exhibitions... Even I like coffee at Museum cafe.

Quirky museum. This houses a private collection, so you don't see things in every category, but the pieces they have are arranged by era, or place or some connecting idea. The collection is of excellent quality and worth a visit.

Stunningly beautiful things from a very wide range. From the incredible Egyptian pieces, Greek medallions, 14th century Islamic glass, to Turner, Corot, Monet and on. Not a huge collection but so much to amaze and admire that you shouldn't miss it if you are in Lisbon.

A highlight of the trip. An astounding collection of art from many periods and cultures. The Rembrandts were stunning as were the Persian ceramics and the illuminated manuscripts. We visited on Friday afternoon and it was very quiet. The galleries are large and spacious so that works are beautifully displayed. Highly recommended.

Lived up to our high expectations. For years we wanted to go there. Two year ago, flying back from Faro (Algarve) to Brussels, we decided to make a stop at Lisbon and visit the museum. However, that was on a Monday, and....they were closed on Mondays. The collection is rather small compared to wellknown musea but the selection is magnificent. Also, make sure you take a walk through the surrounding park.

Best Museum in Lisbon. Wow! We loved this museum. There was everything from paintings, sculpture, textiles to furniture. Set in chronological order from Ancient Greece forward, we were fascinated. Took us nearly 4 hours!!! And we expected only a couple at most. Every room was a delight. Can't imagine going to Lisbon and not visiting this museum.
Good for an afternoon.. Nice grounds and cafe. Worth a look but each part is separate entrance fee so decide what you want to see.
Wow. An amazing art collection, carpets, coins, porcelain and paintings, all beatutifully dispyed. A great way to spend a couple of hours? Terrific value for 5euros

Wonderful experience. Both museums are really good, the modern art one and the european & eastern art as well. The collections were really interesting and very diverse, I saw a lot of great pieces and they are also very coherent. Don`t get a audio guide though, they were really boring. The place is worth a visit when it`s sunny and warm, the gardens are very beautiful and offer a interesting break between the two museums. You can take a nap on the lawn, feed the ducks, or even have lunch, even though the line for the cafeteria was very long.

FANSTASTIC MUSEUM. the works of art and the whole collection is amazing for a single collector. There was also a show of Spanish Treasures of the royal family from Spain that was quite interesting.This museum cannot be missed while in Lisbon.

Great place. It is one of the very interesting places in the town. The park outside the building is great and a must visit place. The building itself is also very interesting with the grass rooofs. The museum is really great.
Excellent. Great collection! It is a must place to visit. There is much to learn. And the park behind it is very enjoyable.

Excellent museum and fantastic concert hall. Well worth a visit to see this truly excellent personal collection of artworks. The concerts given by the Gulbenkian Orchestra are a must for us when we are in Lisbon.
Well worth a visit. Well laid out eclectic collection. Spacious galleries and helpful staff. Audio guides available. Poor signposting from public transport.
Taste. Every piece that Calouste Gulbenkian collected is outstanding. His taste was clearly excellent. The museum was a pleasure in every respect.

One of the worst. Had penciled this one in for our last day in Lisbon as a fan of anything historical and really looking forward to it. On arrival, given the options to pay for all the additional displays but due to time restraints, went for the main display only.Bought our ticket and went to enjoy the display to met by two security officials who insisted my back pack be removed and handed in and was directed to the cloakroom. The female at the counter was most official and took offence that I was unhappy that many others were taking larger bags in, as mine contained passport, cash etc? Once inside several of the exhibits were obscured by school groups and visiting parties, who were not going to move!The staff were most intrusive making you feel like you were like a criminal if you went too close or go too near. I have never felt so ill at ease in a museum.I appreciate the value of the exhibits but surely you should be able to enjoy and appreciate them without having to watch over your shoulder.Would never recommend the Gulbenkian as there are far better museums.
Best Museum in Lisbon. If you've never heard of Calouste Gulbenkian or don't know what he represents, then visit here it's a must.
nice trip over the time. the collection is amaizing - you get a full picture of each region and time. from ancient egypt to monet, oyu can check everything. must see!!!

Amazing park and environment. This is a place you feel quiet, connected with nature, art and culture.It has a surrounding park, pretty nice to go with family and friends, with many wonderful trees and flowers, and little rivers.Inside you can find an amazing art and culture place, that you can search to see what is on charts at the moment.
culture island. Great institution. Nice place to watch a concert. Beautiful itineraant expositions. Even the food is ok
Fanatastic collection. Fabulous private collection. Beautiful paintings by famous artists. Good collection of tiles and pottery. Enjoyed the visit.
Beautiful art collection. This might be my favorite art museum in the world. It spans centuries, and is cohesive because everything is incredibly beautiful.

Impressive Collection. Based on trip advisor, we dashed to the museum on a Sunday afternoon after arriving in Lisbon later than we had planned. It's accessible by metro and definitely worth visiting. Unusual groups of items - furniture, rugs, tapestries, silver, many Egyptian items, fabrics, and jewelry as well as paintings. We didn't have time to see the visiting collections which was too bad based on the quality of what we did see. The only reason I can't give this museum five stars is that I compare it to others we have seen around the world and it's smaller and doesn't have the quantity of the Met in NYC or the Lourve in Paris, etc.

It is no less Pleasing on a Sunny Day. The museum itself is beautiful, with the visitor moving between interesting exhibits on the inside, and beautiful views of the surrounding park through the windows in the galleries. The collection is interesting too, and is displayed by subject matter (e.g. Egyptian Art, European Art, Eastern Islamic Art), with each subject having a physical section all to itself. Mr Gulbenkian, who collected all of these objects had good taste and a good eye, and so the visitor is given a quality tour.Previous reviewers mention that this is a good place to visit on a rainy day, but if you do not have any rainy days during your visit to Lisbon you should visit the museum on a sunny day. I did, and do not regret it.

Well displayed collection. In Lisbon, spend an hour or two at this excellent gallery and you won't be disappointed. It is not a huge collection, but it has plenty of standout works from the likes of Rembrandt, Rubens, Gainsborough and Renoir. The Egyptian and Islamic art is fascinating, and there's a nice basement cafe to round off the visit. Entry is free on Sundays.

Nice Collection. It's a bit out of the way but worth finding. Lovely location outside city center but accessible by public transportation. Nice he made it available for all. Very reasonable for seniors.

Peace. It was teeming with rain that day. Even so walking through the grounds was a pleasure. Pomegranite trees were full of fruit. A display in the Modern Art Gallery set me following up Jose de Almada Negreiros. We were rather damp by the time we arrived at the main gallery, but as usual, it's a good collection with so much work worth looking at. There isn't a gallery I've visited more calming than this one.

Don't miss out. Mr. Calouste was obviously a man of resources and had a wonderful taste. As a result, he achieved a very impressive and eclectic personal collection: from Egyptian pieces to rare Roman medals, tapestry, vases, tiles, center pieces, Asian art and wonderful paintings from several periods. The museum is also very pleasant to walk though and the objects well lit. I have just spent 3 weeks travelling around Portugal, and this was the best art museum in the country in my opinion. I just wish they had more audio guides. A group that had just arrived took all of them.
One of everything. This museum has an excellent collection of exemplars, that is one painting or sculpture of each artist. The nearby modern art collection is not worth the time.
Remarkable museum experience. Beautiful selection and presentation of artworks from all over the world. I should say one of the best art museum in Lisbon!

It's FREE on Sunday. We arrived in Lisbon on a rainy Sunday as part of a tour group. Our tour director informed us that the Gulbenkian Museum was open to the public on Sundays free of charge. It was the perfect place to be on a day where the skies were gray and filled with rain clouds. We were thoroughly surprised by the immense number of beautiful artifacts contained in the museum. It was as other review's had commented upon, a "world class collection". While Lisbon has many wonderful sights to explore, I cannot think of a better way to spend a Sunday enjoying the beauty and wonderment of the items contained in the museum.
wonderful museum, contents and space and lighting. A great museum, I visited on a rainy day and had a terrific time. The art was fantastic and the setting lovely, inside and out.
A great museum. Well worth a visit. 5 euros for adults and free for children. Some fab items , especially the silver items. Nice cafe and shop too.

A fab museum. Only 5 euros to get in and free for children. Didn't much like the building outside but what was inside was amazing. What's. Great collection. Love the silver items especially. Nice cafe and shop too.

Worth a visit. This museum is world class and a pleasant and interesting forray into art, interesting to see what one person acquired. The gardens are also an attraction in themselves, and worth a visit.
absolutely a must. amazing what aman with deep pockets and superb taste has collected. The building with modern art is a bit disappointing
Best Museum in town. recommended anyway I made a beeline for this, it is superb and easy to access. The collection of jewellery was unexpected and a highpoint.
Don't miss. Lovely interesting museum with a good restaurant. Mr Gulbenkian was a discerning collector. Make sure to visit.

very rich collection. Liked parts of the art collection especially the impressionists , the Art deco collection and the chinese objects.
Disliked the show-off & lack of any specific Aesthetic taste especially all the furniture and miscelenuous scattered objects/

Wonderful. The museum is lovely light & airy. Absolutely fantastic items on display. If you love old carpets & fabric then his is the place for you. We were there for just over 2 hours and will keep going back so that we can take it all in.Disabled access is very good.My husband is blind & I'm over 60 so our entry fee was 2.5 Euros. Adult cost is 5Euros per person and 2.5 Euros if over 60.Cafe was very good and reasonable priced.Shop was disappointing very little that interested me on sale, but I did buy a lovely glasses case. The range is not as big as museums here.I have kept to a minimum whats actually on display because you must go & see for yourselves, ancient glass, Chinese porcelain, jade, paintings etc.We will visit this museum againWhat we didn't like, and only because my husband is registered blind, is that light coloured items were displayed on a light coloured background

fantastic museums. The Gulbenkian Museum has two separate museums - one that contains amazing art in all from dating over a couple centuries - including works from BC and AD - including Greek, Roman, Egyptian, Persian, and other European. The specific pieces of art in this collection, the presentation/layout and curation are so superb and so well done. The museum is a gem. The second museum is of modern/contemporary art and its collection is not as astonishing but it is similarly beautifully presented. These museums should not be missed if you love art.

make the effort. this museum is small enough to enjoy thoroughly and the quality is worth the effort to find it. the restaurant is also good with tasty entrees and a nice patio and lawn for sunny days. it is a personal collection of a collector with a discriminating eye. the exhibits are also well displayed for showing the best qualities of the objects. humor, color acuity, rarity and quality all make this collection very worthwhile. as a decorative arts museum guide, i would return.

THE art museum of Lisbon. Beautiful building containing a collection of multiple centuries of fine art...including ancient plus Rembrandt, Ruben, Hals, Renoir, Monet, and Rodin. Discount for seniors. Located close to metro.
Great art collection. LOVED: Building, surrounding gardens, collections. Quiet atmosphere, well-lit art. Will come back soon.

Veryimpressive building. Has a collection of Middle East art; chinese art, Lalique glass and period furniture.. Excellent cafeteria; inexpensive tickets. The park around the museum is a must with beuatig=ful paths, a running stream and a lake.
What a pleasant surprise. Friends recommended that we visit. We are so glad we did. There is an excellent collection of very diverse items. It was a very enjoyable afternoon for all of us.
Small and fairly interesting. This museum is a little out of the way but taxis in Lisbon are very cheap. Personally I didn't find the contents that interesting.

Very nice museum i a pleasant park.. A private collection of high quality; artefacts from Egypt and Greece, Persian silk and velvet, beautiful tiles from Turkey, Chinese china, old Flemish masters (Rembrandt and others), French furniture, Manet, Monet, Turner etc etc. The rooms are spacious and the surrounding park is nice, with a small café (there is one in the museum as well, that they only served cakes until noon).

Great Museum. Something here for everyone. The ancient artefacts were fascinating and sourced from all around the world. The selection of carpets, tapestries and silks was very good and the pottery from both China and the Arabic world was most impressive. There was an interesting art collection and finally the exquisite Lalique collection. All very well chosen and just the right amount in each section to sustain interest without becoming bored. There is one big negative for this museum and that is finding it. When you come out of the Metro there is no signage for it at all and even in the gardens where it is situated there is no indication of it's location. Despite having a map we had great difficulty in locating it, however we were thankful that we persevered!

Outstanding small art museum reflecting a portion of a great collector. C Gulbenkian was a businessman who purchased and curated an outstanding art collection. Part of the collection includes furniture which are a bit over the top. However the art is amazing ranging from gold coin/pieces from the time of Alexander to Manet and contemporaries. The Boy blowing bubbles by Manet is fantastic. We learned a lot about Giovanni Boldini, a painter of the stars so to speak who figures in the Marthe de Florian apartment which lay untouched for 70 years in Paris. Boldini painted de Florian and one of these paintings was found in the apartment which is a whole other story. There is a wonderful Boldini portrait of Painter Brown ( a contemporary artist in France) and his family. It is a warm and vibrant painting of Brown, his wife and daughter, caught as if being photographed entering a show. There are multiple examples of Persian, Chinese, Japanese, Mideast art and design such as carpets and pottery. France, England and the USA fought (figuratively) over obtaining this collection. Lisbon won as Portugal had sheltered Gulbenkian during WWII. The museum design is well laid out. There is a beautiful garden and walkway to the modern museum on the other side of the park. There are concerts and an outdoor amphitheatre. They have a nice gift shop and a cafeteria. It was one of the highlights of our trip along with the Berardo.

Super cool. Awesome day spent at the museum on a rainy day in Lisbon. I paid a little more to get the full access pass for all exhibits. I won't even pretend to understand some of the "artistic" exhibits (really, a room filled with shredded newspaper is considered art?!?) but it was still a great day.

a delightful surprise. This museum was very enjoyable. I didn't have high expectations but the art is exquisite with big names such as Durer, Rembrandt, Manet, Monet. There is a park to walk through which was delightful and I highly recommend the restaurant. Had a delicious meal on the patio.

Lisbon's best art museum. It has one of the largest collections found covering many different eras and art frameworks, outside of Paris, New York or London. A must see for art lovers coming to Lisbon.
A jewel. Everything they have is top notch. The Lalique collection, by itself, is worth the visit. Both the Egyptian and European areas are superb.

Vast Collection. I understand why this is the art museum to visit in Lisbon. It has an excellent collection that ranges from the Ancient to the 1800s. It is somewhere that every visitor to Lisbon needs to visit. My only complaint is that it is far off the beaten track sort of off by itself (by the modern art museum).

Diverse collection, reasonably priced. The museum had one of the most diverse collections I have ever seen. From Chinese porcelain to Rembrandt and Rodin, Gulbenkian had it all. Even though the collection is not focused on one art specialty, it is still holistic in the setting. And it was a bonus that the entrance fee was very reasonable: € 5 for an adult and free for children younger than 18.

One of the Higlights of Lisbon. One of the best museums you can visit. The architectural design of the building and the layout of the exhibitions are excellent. There are quality works in many disciplines;statuary, painting, furniture, tapestries and old world crafts. The entry fee is nominal and a lovely garden restaurant downstairs makes this a wonderful experience.

Excellent museum. This museum is a little hard to get to, but the exhibitsmake it worthwhile. Although it is smaller than manypublic museums, the art is excellent and well organized.It is like "Prado-lite", which is not a bad thing, allowing anenjoyable 2-hour journey through very good quality art. Wewere there on Sunday, and admission was free, at leastwhile we were there, so that wasn't bad either!

a treat for the eyes and the ears. this collection is a spectacular walk thru the history of the world and of art. the dedication, imagination, creativity and wealth required to amass a collection like this is mind boggling. the museum is very simply and beautifully organized; the design of the building and the lighting will enhance your visit. I arrived at noon on a sunday; a pianist was accompanying an soprano so my visit was a delight for my ears too. not to be missed. also, the gardens are beautiful and very serene.
beautiful museum. Beautiful setting, a little bit of everything. Really nice place to visit for a couple of hours. I was impressed by the lighting and the way the objects were displayed.
A real gem. Beautiful setting and wonderful collection! Sorry that the audio tours were sold out when we arrived. That would have enhanced our visit because written info is skimpy.

Good things in small parcels. A very easy museum to enjoy. Bound to be something you love, all in manageable amounts. Perfectly possible to do it justice in half a day if you choose only what interests you. For me the highlights were the Chinese pottery and the Lalique jewellery, all stunning. I saw beautiful things that I had never seen even examples of before. Reminded me of the Burrell Collection in Glasgow, one man's eclectic gathering of beautiful things. You will also get a very decent lunch in the cafeteria with pleasant, helpful staff.

Brilliant without being overwhelming.. The challenge of large art galleries for short-term tourists is hitting that balance between a great and eclectic collection and just plain wearing us out. The Louvre is, famously, the worst offender in this regard. Great collection but one has to sprint between masterpieces in order to take in all the key exhibits. The joy is just leached right out. The Gulbenkian, however, hits that sweet spot. Some of the best is the fine 20th C jewelry toward the end of the galleries, which provides a nice lift on the way out the door. The range is enormous and the galleries are large enough to facilitate a 360 survey before settling on the piece you most want to enjoy. Another reason to go back to Lisboa.

Great way to escape the rain. We didn't originally plan on visiting the Gulbenkian, but decided to stop by for a couple of hours to avoid the rain. What a welcome surprise! A great and varied collection of art. Our favorite museum in Lisbon.
the best. If you do nothing else in Lisbon do go and see the Gulbenkian Museum it is a joy to stand so near to such wounderfull things.

Must see. If you want to view a one-of-a kind art collection, this is the place for you! The museum is well laid out and full of master pieces that will astound you. The Lalique collection alone is worth a trip, but the French masters along with French furnishings will please you as well. It was a highlight of our trip to Lisbon. It is part of a large complex and gardens. It was a privledge to have visited the Gulbenkian.

Enjoyable Lisboa. I like the weather, the green areas of the city, the historical places and monuments. Our stay was a short one - so this was the only thing a didnot like=let us hope we shall have another possibility to come and stay longer. Wish I could see the new districts of the capital, and more museums - for example Museum da Fado. We have seen only the coche exhibition near the monastery - remarcable and may be unique.
Excellent. Excellent museum-gallery where you can find great pieces of art within the collection of Calouste Gulbenkian!Very smart guy
Don't miss it. This is an amazing museum with a wonderful, small collection from one man who gave so much to the city. Don't pass it up.

Fantastic Museum. It has some of the most exquisite artifacts collected in one place that I have seen for some time and some very well known paintings by some of my favourite artists. Gulbenkian was clearly a man of refined tastes and a visit to the museum is very worthwhile.
Fine art at its best. Quality and quantity of fine art. It is a real treasure in Lisbon. You could see the whole history of arts from ancient Egypt to modern times. Astonishing.
Good museum and galery. All expositions are fantastic, Rembrand, Monet, Manet, Lalique, Persian art, modern artists. Very nice garden with statues of Rodin and More
Good to relax and get culture. A place to be if you would like to get some culture environment and some space to relax in a nice garden. Nice place to grab a coffee to.

A Wide-Ranging Collection. It's quite rare to find a single museum covering such a wide range of eras and styles, and doubly so in a compact collection like this. It means you'll see art that perhaps you wouldn't bother making a visit to a specialist museum to see.It was a little tricky to find from the Espana metro - you seemed to need to cross a dozen roads at a single intersection, and the building is quite well hidden next to some administrative buildings.
The best kept secret in Lisbon. Always a great pleasure to visit. The permanent collection is superb and the garden an ocean of peace.
Great private museum. It's not just great paintings, this museums has everything from Egyptian era, middle eastern, Chinese antiques, etc.

Save your energy to get through the whole thing!. We were so intrigued by every last detail that by the time we got the the renaissance paintings we were exhausted so we didn't get to spend much time appreciating the Rembrandts / Monet, etc. Definitely go to this museum, it's wonderful! The tiles were my favorites.
Don't miss it. From Ancient Egypt to the 20th century, the Gulbenkian collection offers a wide range of interesting and beautiful objects
Not Portuguese, but worth seeing!. It's not a place that's really connected to Portugal, but you'll see a fantastic collection of art and different historic items. And the entrance is free.

A wonderful and eclectic collection!. A wonderful collection of objects, art, porcelain, silver, furniture, carpets, textiles etc. which covers several thousand years of history.The surrounding gardens are beautiful and peaceful.
Excellent museum. This miseum has a great art collection . Very near from the metro stationAudioguide is very superficial!
Good but small. The collection is nice but if you have a little time in Lisbon and good weather it is better skip...Still Lalique jewelleries are outstanding.

Lovely museum. The art museum had some very interesting tile, pottery and tapestry displays from around Europe. There is a decen number of masters, Dutch, French and British on display I enjoyed the period furniture pieces. The modern art section is under construction, though, the Armenian-American artist (Gorky) on display was quite extensive and well done. A pleasant way to spend an afternoon, as wel as grab a delicious and reasonably priced meal. The hot food selections were week-prepared,mgenerous portions and delicious.

Very peaceful garden . This is a very peaceful and quiet garden. We walked through on a rainy day on our way to the museum. The extensive vegetation and narrow walkways made you forget you were in the city. Very peaceful.

It was okay.... This is an interesting museum and my first time to a semi-private museum. The collection was nice but sort of all over the place in terms of what was there. It was also very noisy and the people working there weren't stopping people from using flashes on their cameras nor were they shushing people, so it was pretty distracting. I also didn't think the audio guide was worth it, it pretty much just said what was written in English next to the painting with an Art Criticism 101 interpretation of the work. It is also away from the city center so a taxi ride will set you back a few euros. Its probably only worth it if there is something in the collection that really calls to you.

A great collection of art. Great collection from Calouste Gulbenkian. Besides the permanent exhibitions, a lot of temporary ones take place here. There is also the Orchestra, workshops and conferences open to everyone. And, of course, the beautiful and pleasant garden right in the center of the city. There's also an interesting bookshop and a nice place to eat.

do not miss the visit to the unique , stunning Gulbenkian collection and the gardens of the museum. a stunning, rare and eclectic collection ranging from decorative arts of the 2 nd century to master paintings and silverware .a collection with a real point of view and unique vision.
Gulbenkian Offers Something for Everyone. Outstanding, incredibly eclectic collection of art. It was like walking through a survey of art history course.
Beautiful grounds. This is an amazing foundation that has grounds in the middle of city. The grounds were relaxing and beautiful. The noise goes away and you can be refreshed.

History of Art in one museum. Gorgeous collection of art from all epochs, media, styles, and from all over the world. Don't miss the Lalique jewellery - Gulbenkian was a personal friend and collected some real beauties.
Astonishing collection. This museum houses a huge and eclectic collection of the beautiful objects - and beautifully displayed. Stunning.
nice collection. Gulbenkian has a nice collection of art collected from around the world. It also features a nice romantic little garden and has a decent restaurant onsite.
More than expected. This is a great small museum. Really important Tiffany collection with lots of jewelry. The art is wonderful and the clocks that actually work are remarkable.
Wow & wow again!. This is how all museums should be! We thought it wonderful. Arranged in chronological order , it takes you though the ages.

Well worth a visit. Eclectic collection of great quality. The grounds are extensive. Entry is free. There seems to be a lot of educational activity going on. there are two main buildings. One houses the main collection d the other a modern art exhibition.

Very nice private collection. Central location and very accessible for a reasonable price, the museum offers a nice blend of historic artifacts, varying from old Greek coins to Impressionistic paintings.
Wow!. An intimate museum featuring a vast array of art, sculpture, furniture, coins and carpets....and more. Its an amazing place.
Outstanding. Difficult to determine which way to go from metro station., but well worth visiting. Outstanding pieces from many periods presented in an excellent manner. Not overwhelming

The place in and out - my way - now the garden part.. This is one of the musts from Calouste Gulbenkian. Worth to come even like we from Nazaré. Here in Lisbon this is only one possibility to visit places ja you can use time also in and out. There is the museum and often different kind of exhibitions and a outdoor walk in the garden is a worthile thing to do as well and maybe to visit the cafeterria as well. And while here in Lisbon anotherpossibility is to visit Palacio Nacional da Ajuda or Mosteiro dos Jeronimos or Palacio de Belem. There are so many places to visit but then you must have more time maybe even overenight in Lisbon and visit Sintra - a day or two there and on the way visit Palazio de Queluz, Monserrate or Palacio de Mafra. If you come to Portugal you must have time for yourself to enjoy culturelife as well.
Great art gallery. Really well laid out, just the right balance of content, great pictures, nice building, Cheap and pleasant cafe. Perfect venue
Spacious grounds and museum. This was a lovely museum for a rainy day and on a nice day the gardens would be worth exploring. The Rembrandt is exquisite.

First class, varied collection, attractively displayed.. Very eclectic art collection from many different places and periods of history. The collection is attractively displayed within well lit, uncluttered rooms. Highlights include Turner's Wreck of a Transport Ship and the Art Nouveau jewellery of René Lalique, the finest of which is a brooch, half-woman, half dragonfly, decorated with enamel work, gold, diamonds and moonstones.There is a pleasant cafe with good, reasonably priced food and drinks.
must do. Great building, wonderfull garden and broad collection of ancient and modern art. Don't forget to visit also the Modern Art Museum at the other side of the garden.

Unique Collection. The museum was worth a visit. The most incredible thing about the Gulbenkian collection is the condition of all the pieces. Most were in fantastic condition. I've never seen old Greek and Roman coins looking so good. Old pottery was whole, famous greek vases were almost pristine. Moorish rugs looks somewhat worn but still good. The next thing I would say is that everything was accessible. By that I mean that most things were close enough to touch. There were no barriers keeping you away from it. If my kids had been there I would have worried that they would start running and run right over the rugs on display for example. The gardens are also a nice respite from the urban landscape outside the museum block.
Lovely collection, lovely gardens. Small but excellent collection of fine and decorative arts, set in a lovely park, which also contains a separate modern art gallery.
What an amazing place!. Beautiful gardens, great art exhibitions, the best place to relax while enjoying culture alone or with friends.
All the art you want. Liked the variety and depth of display. The museum is small but covers the world history in art.Did not like much
Museum. Absolutely love the gardens and hanging around having lunch and tea and cakes, wonderful peaceful location
One of the best musea in Europe. A good eclectic collection, not too much but very high quality of the art that was collected. A must see!

Superb museum, one of the best in the world. It's a very refined collection, a bit eclectic but absolutely interesting. Not a huge collection but that is a good point. No endless rows of the same but high quality pieces of selected genres. A must do on your visit to Lisbon.
excelent museum. We loved the islamic exposition.The permanent exhibition is also marvelous. We enjoyed the eastern porcelaines, carpets and painting collections
Rainy day. Passed an hour when it rained and has a great Rene Lalique collection. Great collection and cheap as museums go €5 each.

Its a museum..... Unless you are a particular fan of going to museums, or have a particular purpose to see something specific, or have come from a town that does not have a good museum of its own, then you should go here. There is a beautiful park, with many places to sit and relax and feel at one with nature. Also, this is a nice place to stop by if you are visiting Lisbon for an extended period of time. If you come from a large town, with a good museum of your own and you have a short amount of time in Lisbon, your time could be better spent elsewhere. This is not a "must see" attraction. Its nice when you have nothing else left to see. We are from NYC, we have been to our museums a whole bunch of times, so to be brutally honest, we were not impressed and regretted having gone. There are train stations nearby, so it is easy to get to the old city. Or you could walk. It would be a 40 minute walk down (maybe less, depending on your speed and its a walk down the slope, so its easier). Either walking down Parque Eduardo VII or Av. Sidonio Pais, going around the Marques Pombal traffic circle and continuing down AV. da Liberdade, which is a beautiful street.

Only the best is to be armired in this istablishment.. Inside and outside you have amazing things as someone said - quality not quantity - very well said and in that way everything is just for you to admire. That pretty much sums up the collection – it is stunning. You just have to pay a visit and use some time.

One of the best world-class museums. This is a must when in Lisbon. The collection is easily viewed in one hour, but I went through twice. Highlights were the extensive collection of Persian and Turkish Iznik tiles and textiles, and the exquisite Rene Lalique Art Nouveau jewelry. Can't use enough superlatives to describe this museum.

A must in Lisbon. The permanent exibition or modern art is always a refreshing and pleasant time to spend and visit. At Plaça de Espanha with its beautiful gardens, coffee shops and auditorium closeby is a mandatory place to visit.
A very eclectic collection. The displays are well laid out and the rooms uncrowded. The Lalique room is amazing, unique items of jewellery .
fantastic. If you love the work of Lalique,here you can find is major collection, Carouse Gulbenkian,was his mentor,very nice gardens too.

Quality Not Quantity. Calouste Gulbenkian was interested only in collecting the best, so the museum is not overly large but it has quality exhibits. The museum was established in 1969 and the wide-ranging collection covers various periods and areas: Egyptian, Islamic and Oriental art, old coins and European painting and decorative arts. He subscribed to the motto “Only the best”. That pretty much sums up the collection – it is stunning.

Great exhibits. Visited the museum on a Sunday, when it is free to get in. What a great place, fabulous art, furniture, statues etc. So many wonderful pieces that you almost get a bit jaded from looking at so many great exhibits. The highlights for me were the Rembrandt & Turner paintings, and the Rene Lalique exhibition. One of the best museums I have visited.

Vast contemporary art collection. I visited the contemporary art building, which is gorgeous, and houses a fascinating collection. It's a bit off the beaten track, but a must for someone who shares that interest. The gardens are also fantastic.
Excellent Museum. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is a gem! It is situated in beautiful grounds and is full of and eclectic mix of exotic exhibits tastefully displayed.

Quaint museum. Nice displays of art, but the lighting is often dark and piece descriptions are often lower to the ground requiring guests to bend over often to read. Pieces are placed far apart therefore much crisscrossing across large rooms is required to catch all the displays.

A must see!. A wonderful museum and auditorium.
What a collection this truly is.
Art lover or not, you will love the Gulbenkian.
One of Lisbon's treasures.
Amazing Gardens. Great museum but amazing garden to relax in. If you are in Lisbon for a while you shouldn't miss it. Especially in August. The August Jazz festival is amazing.
BEAUTIFUL. We stayed six hours there, until we had to go as the museum was closing..unbelievable place !!! Sir Calouste Gulbenkian became my new hero !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

A wonderful collection of art. Clear presentation, few visitors, real masterpieces of art in the middle of a public garden in Praça de Espanha. I recommend the visit of this museum as you will appreciate Renaissance painting, Oriental art (such as Persian carpets) and XIX century paintings. It's a 2 hours visit, depend if you want to spend more time reading everything but it's worth it.

A world class museum!. My wife and I toured this excellent museum earlier this month. It is just a delight! The art, artifacts, and sculptures are presented in a relaxed, well spaced environment. Clearly Calouste Gulbenkian had very good taste and the money to support it. The Museum was free to seniors on the day we went and it was well attended, but the space did not feel crowded (except at the excellent cafeteria). The garden grounds surrounding the museum are also lovely. Ideal for a stroll in the shade. If you are in Lisbon, do yourself a favor and take time to visit this excellent museum.

VERY INTERESTING.. This Museum is a must on your holiday agenda. We had an excellent time, and all the exhibits offer visitors a continuous dialogue between Nature and Art. There are over 6000 pieces to view.The museum also has a cafe with delicious food and drinks which you can either eat indoors or in the garden outside.
An absolute must. One of the best resident art collections in Europe. The gardens are fabulous. Allways a temporary expo worth to see
Don´t ever miss it!. It´s really a treasure inside Lisbon. With a beautiful garden, yhis museum will take you from Egypt to many other civilizations. Take a trip with History!
Splendid eclectic collection. Good layout, good labelling of exhibits. Reasonable entry price. Very long, slow queues for tickets and at the cafe.

A paradise in the middle of the city. It is a great place for a stroll in the city, peaceful gardens and a lot of activities (concerts outside during the summer, amazing exhibitions through the year). Check the website to see what's on.

incredible collection. it is quite astounding to think that this collection was owned by one man. I'm not an art fan normally but the sheer quality of some of the pieces is stunning. from painting to panels to glassware to furniture all amazing. Spend a couple of hours her but don't dwell on the first things for too long or you will run out of steam later. Have a meal downstairs, the daily specials are really good and very reasonable
Calm nice Gardens and a play of jazz. This a must go in Lisbon! To assist a concert in the gardens in Gulbenkian is like a pray for your sanity. Fantastic place!

World Class Museum and Garden. Go for the collections of historic Islamic art, including a world class collection of rugs and lamps, and for contemporary and modern art. The café is delicious and the maze-like gardens worth exploring for a few hours.

Nice!. It is a museum with a great variaty of differenct styles. You have paintings, sculptures, tableware, coins and more... Also it come from a lot of different countries. Holland with the paintings, tableware from Japan, sculptures all over the world. On a sunday the entrance is totally free. And please if you go, don't forget the gardens. they are quiet and perfect to rest on a sunny day after your visit to the museum.

Eye opening art at Gulbenkian. We had a wonderful time at the museum and the grounds. Exhibits were worth while visiting, reasonably priced. It one of the a musts when in Lisbon. Pay a visit and afterwards have a wonderful lunch opposite the museum, in authentic seafood restaurant. Happy days. x
Excellent. Fascinating collection of treasures and very beautiful gardens. Visited on a Sunday so no charge, an added bonus.

Private Collection. Set in a beautiful garden, the Museum houses a extensive private collection donated to Portugal. Big enough not to overwhelm you, with some exquisite pieces. Personal favourite was the Renee Lalique collection
Fantastic quality collection. A fairly small collection but each piece is of the highest Quality. The Lalique jewellery collection is absolutely amazing.

"Only the best" inside!. Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is a museum in Lisbon, Portugal, containing a collection of ancient, and some modern art. It has oriental art and classical art on display in the Egyptian, Greco-Roman, Mesopotamian, Persian art from Islamic period, Armenian and Far Eastern art.There´s also sculpture, painting and the decorative arts, particularly 18th century French art.Of the about 6000 items in the museum's collections a selection of around 1000 is in permanent exhibition.

Must See. For the exhausted traveler, this museum is a delight. Without being overwhelming, its excellent collection is just the right size to be fully appreciated. The building next door offers some of the most unique modern art. The museum is light, airy and uncrowded so you can leisurely enjoy the various collections. If that is not enough, the glorious grounds are worth your time as well.
Great museum. Beautifully designed space and gardens with the opportunity to see the great Impressionists. Nice cafe, good history along the beginning of the museum pieces.

A gem of a museum. One man,s eclectic collection, it is quite compact and easily viewed in a couple of hours. We particularly liked the Rene Lalique jewelry...exquisite. And the cafe is good value too.

Art of Ages. We visited the Gulbenkian Museum on a Sunday, more out of curiousity, and were pleasantly surprised to learn that entry was free on a Sunday.Inside, the private collection commences with Egyptian art containing pieces dating back to over 2000 BC. A Greco / Roman collection, consisting largely of coins follows before some beautiful Turkish rugs and bowls are displayed.The variety of art on display offers something for everyone, although we quickly passed through the section containing furniture dating to the time of Louis XVI. In contrast, the collection contains some wonderful paintings from artists including Manet, Rubens, Rembrandt, Monet, Gainsborough and Renoir.We spent a good 2 hours viewing the collection and opted not to visit the temporary exhibitions, which were also free.
Extraordinary collection. On one floor, a personal collection of wide-ranging eclectic jaw-dropping art, with lots to appeal to all tastes, so go and enjoy.

A wonderful collection. This is a wonderful museum/art gallery with a wonderful little park around it. It is amazing to think that one man collected all the items within this museum and it is an amazing collection. Then to see it made public and not sold off is even better. This place is definitely worth a visit. It is such a diverse collection. You have Egyptian artefacts, a beautiful Islamic collection to a room dedicated to Guardi. I don't want to give too much away because it is one of those collections that is worth discovering for yourself. There is a good cafe on site with an outdoor seating area if the weather is nice. It is a well laid out museum. It also does not take up all your day but you will definitely be here for a few hours. It is almost an oasis of calm amongst a busy bustling city.

Huge for a private collection. Has a great variety of art (Egyptian, European middle-ages, Eastern,...). I expected it to be small since it was a private collection but you can easily walk around for 1.5 - 2 hours. Price was cheap (think it was 6 euros or so)Would recommend this place to anyone. Just get of Campo Pequeno metrostop and walk along Berna for about 5 minutes. Has a restaurant which serves a lot of food at really cheap prices too.

A wonderful collection. This is a beautiful museum housing a personal collection of treasures all very well displayed in attractive gardens. Wonderful Islamic ceramics and outstanding pieces of Lalique jewellery. Well worth a visit.
Great colecction. We were really amazed to see this private colecction., it has a little bit of everything, but very well displayed.The gardens were wonderful!

it has always something of interest to visit. Fundacao Calouste Gulbenkian his known for the quality they put in everything they organize. It is always a great pleasure to go there. The "downstairs" bar with some tables with a view to the small lake is the perfect place for an afternoon coffee or tea.
beautiful. The museum is not vey big so you are not exausted at he end of your visit. Nice building and very beautiful statues ans paintings.
free on Sundays. interesting museum worth a free visit on Sundays if you have the time; amazing that such a collection belonged to an individual

Beautiful museum. This was a very interesting museum with some beautiful things on display. The only problem that it was a bit difficult to find. Signage in Lisbon, or Portugal for that fact, is not always great. When we did find it we were happy that we had made the effort. Spent quite a while wandering around the exhibits.We also had lunch in the museum coffee shop - ok meal.
Gorgeous collection of art. Loved the Chinese section and the huge collection of paintings.I also read the biography of Gulbenkian which is impressive
Beautiful and pleasant. This museum has a mix of antique, modern and nature... the area that surrounds it is simply delightful.

A fabulous collection in a peaceful garden. The Gulbenkian Foundation is worth a visit for its collections and the peaceful garden setting of the museum buildings. Gulbenkian's collections are extensive and extraordinary and the setting of the museum on the Foundation's gardens make a visit here a relaxing break from the hustle and bustle of Lisbon. What's more it is located just a few metro stops from Rossio so is easily accessed.

Very nice place. When visiting a museum, I not only appreciate the collection but the overall experience: the real estate it's in, the surrounding areas, the store, all its visual stimulus. This place is a very good example of how the place merges with the collection and present the visitor with a very memorable experience. The building is beautiful, with a fantastic ambience, a relaxing atmosphere. The lighting, the furniture, all elements here make a contemplative space. The collection was nice too but what I remember quite clearly is that this place and the experience as a whole made me really happy. This is a private museum and therefore they charge a high rate for the tour. But, having said that, I still recommend it.

Great Museum. This a great museum to visit because it is eclectic and offers a wide range of decorative and fine arts in a modern museum building, set in a lovely garden. There are collections of Arabic Art. carpets, porcelain, furniture and silver as well as a range of masterpieces by Rembrandt, Rubens, Watteau, Fragonard, Houdon and Monet. Well worth a visit.
Gulbenkian Museum. Eclectic but excellent collection well worth visiting. Excellent museum restaurant if one is there for lunch.
Stunning!. Amazing art collection! Absolutely beautiful. Many different styles from different periods. A must-see.

Fabulous museum. This is one of the great museums of the world. What an exposition. This beats the most collections I have seen, such a wide range.
Be sure to visit!
Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian. Very good Museum and Art Center, with original pieces from several periods. There is also the possibility of watching music and dance concerts.

An amazing museum. It's an amazing museum, with a collection worth visiting. Near metro station. It's a great place to have lunch, study or even a pic-nic. It definately worth and is advisable to visit. One of the most prestigious foundations in Portugal. Great events throughout the year.

What a treat!. Very accessible gallery since only about 15 rooms. The favourite for me was the great collection of Rene Lalique glass.... But the Rembrandts, Chinese porcelain and Degas sculptures were good.

Something Really special. I visited a very Special Exhibition of different tiles from all over the world. Totally fascinating. Since my Agent and me stepped in just 15 minutes before the closure, we still were allowed to look at it peacefully. Compliments to the Service and the friendly watchmen.
Peaceful park, art and food. This beautiful park is placed in the center of Lisbon. It has several museums and a couple of places to eat. Lovely place to relax.

Very nice museum. The museum hosts a nice collection of arts, furniture, jewelry, and carpets - it is small enough to allow you to spend time looking at the paintings carefully, but is not too large to make you feel you need several days to really see it.

Interesting collection. It was a really nice and small museum with amazing collections.The entrance fee is 5euros but could be 4 if you have lisbon card.The interesting collection is worth to see,they do audio guide which gives more explanation or where the collection was from and bit of history, and also the cafeteria was not expensive but the pigeons were annoying.The park was also nice with the ducks specially-kids love this place.Rene Lalique's collection is amazing its worth seeing it.
Fantastic collection of art. It is a must in Lisbon. The paintings, sculptures, porcelain were donated from an armenian millionaire

Great place all around. Great place to spend and afternoon in.Go look at an exhibition, or eat/drink at the cafeteria they are usually worth the little you pay.If you are not looking to spend just go in and sit in the cool air conditioned rooms, bring a book, relax, or take your ipad and enjoy the free wifi.If you are seeking the heat go in the summer and sit outside in the garden.The gift shops located in various places offer a very nice selection of products and great gifts for you and your friends.
Fabulous Collection. I went to both the modern art museum and the main collection - lots of wonderful things to see. The lunch at the modern art museum restaurant was good value too,
loved it. I really love this place ..... you see so many different things and learn so much .... from antic Egypt to Chinese art .... to European paintings ......

Gulbenkian Museum. Museum set in beautiful gardens and with an exquisite selection of pieces from both modern and ancient eras. Noteworthy are the asian selection as is the Lalique pieces. The permanent collection contrasts with interesting modern exhibitions. The e shop stocks a wonderful selection of books and a selection of gifts that highlight the strengths of the collection.

Nice collection. It is worth doing a little research. . I was not planning on going to see this collection, but one of the people I was with had their heart set on it.I really enjoyed the time, but it is worth doing a little research before hand. As ot turns out they also have an audio guide available in several languages
Best small museum in the world. Everything about this place is wonderful, a small collection of beautiful objects by a man with impeccable taste.
Random collection. The museum is off the beaten track and surrounded by a beautiful park. Collection comes from collecting and this is what it feels like - a random collection. Still beautiful.
Do not miss this museum. The collection is simply breath-taking and is just as it claims 'one of the finest' collections of art in Europe.

Nice collection, free on Sundays. We were a little disappointed by this museum, though it may have been because it was so hyped - Rick Steves' guidebook calls it the only "must-see" museum in Lisbon. It's a little bit of a hike from any metro, so be prepared for that. The collection itself is quite small, but impactful. Each piece displayed is beautiful, and the collection spans thousands of years. We went through the entire thing in about 30 minutes - it's really not very big. I would suggest going on a Sunday morning when entrance is free. I think I would have felt ripped off if I'd paid 5 euros per person since we spent so little time there and it's kind of a pain to get to. I don't think I would have made a special trip out to see it if I'd known how small it is, nice as the collection was.ALSO - don't get this museum confused with the Centro de Arte Moderna, which is located in the same park and also part of the Fundacao Calouste Gulbenkian. The signage is extremely misleading, and we first visited that museum, thinking we were in the Gulbenkian Museum. If you walk through the park, the signs are also very deceptive and just kind of...stop at one point. We noticed poor signage tended to be a trend in Portugal, especially Lisbon. Better to walk back out to the main road and find the entrance. Make sure you have a map with you!* If you like my review, I appreciate you clicking the 'helpful' button; those of us who take the time to write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more :) *
hours to spend. Very interesting collections, well exhibited, one can spend hours at this nice museum, also has a good cafe

A total surprise - a must visit. Thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Pleasantly surprised when we arrived on a Sunday to find the admission free. Lots of people but it didn't feel crowded. Great variety and well displayed.

Must see. Paintings you have it all here. This place is for those who cherish culture. The tour busses do have a stop here and you can take the metro aswell if you wish. You can spent many hours here. Hungry? Restaurant O Police across the street offers you good food.
Stroll. It is most outstanding to go and visit this garden. Very quiet place, full with trees, good atmosphere, good temprature to have a good and long stroll.

The garden. I keep coming to this garden just to lay on the grass and read a book. I believe I only saw the Art gallery inside, it's ok.
There's a cafeteria and a book shop.
It's a nice afternoon plan, if you just need a break from the city noise.

Do not miss Gulbenkian. Beautiful quite garden in the middle of lisbon.
Very Good museum. One of my favourite places in town.
Just another museum... Nothing special but a beautiful park. There was some famous paintings, other than that it was not anything special.
A place to visit. Besides the magnificent grdens just on the center of Lisbon, a place to visit on a hot day. The quality of the art colection, merits the visit.

Nice, but slightly overrated. Note - the Gulbenkian's hours are 10 am - 6 pm and it is closed on Mondays.The Gulbenkian features masterpieces of many famous artists and ages, including Rembrandt, Monet, Manet, Turner, etc, etc. Yet the collection is not as good as that of the real top museums such as the Rijksmuseum, the Louvre, the Metropolitan, or for that matter the Museum of Islamic Art in Doha. Hence although very good, we consider it slightly overrated. Perhaps we are spoilt. The buildings musthave been very contemporary in the seventies and now look a bit dated with all the naked concrete and the wood panelling. The museum is set in a lovely garden though with sculptures. The restaurant in the Gulbenkian serves a decent hot lunch menu.

Been to Lisbon and not here-you did not visit lisbon. If you visit Lisbon and did not visit the Gulbenkian Museum, it is the same as not having visited Lisbon at all! An unbelievable museum, stunning collection from coins to Rembrandt, jewelry to carpets. Just make absolutely certain you do not miss this museum, which is one of the 10 best in Europe. Probably the only museum in the world that has more funds that it can possible spends. That comes to you when you hold 5% of a major world oil company.
Worth the detour. Excellent museum -amazing collection. A piece of hisory you will not be able to find anywhere else. Plan at the very least a two hour visit but could also make a five hour visit.

Superb Collection. The best world-class museum you've never heard of! Oil tycoon Gulbenkian shrewdly amassed an extraordinary personal collection of decorative and fine art, employing a true connoisseur's knowledge and discernment in the process. Particularly strong on Islamic and East Asian decorative objects, including Persian carpets, textiles, Turkish tiles, Japanese lacquer ware and Chinese porcelains. The European section contains a varied selection of furniture, tapestries, paintings and sculpture by many well-known artists, and what is reportedly the world's best collection of Lalique items. Everything is presented masterfully in a way that enhances the overall experience. The café serves excellent food, with a dining room and a deck overlooking the museum's surrounding gardens. Makes for a lovely outing!

A treasure chest of beautiful art. The collection is eclectic and marvelous. The gardens are lovely and peaceful. The cafe is pleasant and serves good food. There are concerts in the garden on some evenings.

Breathtaking!!!!. Best museum in the lisbon,place where you can spend whole day and enjoy. Personaly could spend hours in front of the pictures of rembrant and rubens. Even if you are not used to go to museums do not miss the chance to go to gulbenkian museum because this experience you will remember untill the end of your life!

Extremely impressive museum, very well thought out.. This private museum should be on anyone's itinerary for Lisbon. Set in its own parkland just five minutes' walk from the top of Parque Eduardo VII, it is one of the best thought-out and displayed museums I have ever seen. It is not huge - but it is fascinating. Starting with Egyptian and Mesopotamian art, moving through Islamic and near-eastern sections, then far-eastern before a European section containing Monets, van Dycks and more, and finally a room displaying some gems of Lalique production, the layout is spacious and the lighting and presentation very effective. This is no dimly-lit rows of random crap in glass boxes (and we've all been to those!) but is a very well planned and enjoyable visit with some absolute gems. While I was in the Lalique room at the end I saw countless people walking past the door and leaving the museum without seeing it - don't! It is an absolute highlight of the whole experience! There are also other, temporary exhibitions in the neighbouring buildings, but we didn't visit those. The main museum, however, I cannot recommend highly enough.
Nice surprise. Located in an area the is not traditionally visited in Lisbon, this museum was a nice surprise, with a beautiful collection of porcelain and other objects like books and carpets.

A bit of a Gem. The main collection is absolutely brilliant and very eclectic. The range of artefacts is astonishing. The collection of Persian and Isnik ceramics is quite beautiful these are displayed alongside illuminated manuscripts worthy of the British Library. There are also some choices that will not be to every taste such as the Rocco Furniture. In the paintings the jewel is probably the Rembrandt although there is a fine range of paintings from this period of Netherlands painting.The café is really interesting and the food looked very good and was very keenly priced. The modern collection is much smaller with a range of Portuguese painters from the 1030s through to contemporary artists. While we were there it had a very interesting exhibition of contemporary sculpture/installations from artists from all over Europe. There is a small collection of work by Arshile Gorky who was an American Armenian which might have something to do with their acquisition as they are (or those on display) were mainly works on paper and not hugely interesting of more interest was the work of a painter called Amadeo de Sousa Cardoso who studied in Paris and work reflects Cubist and Fauvist influences he died in 1918 from Spanish Flu at the age of 30.

One of the best museums in Lisbon. It has it all - from all of the top names to the great garden. Definitely a must do when in Lisbon. Definitely make sure you have at least 3-5 hours to see all. Audioguide was very helpful.

A green oasis. At first you are greeted with an impressive garden, filled with shade and rivers, an amphiter art and preety much one of the quieter places in lisbon, coming in on the building you are presented with amazing exibithions.Defenitly a must go!
It's all here!. From music, library, paintings, seasonal exhibitions, amazing gardens, sculpture... it's endless. This is by far Lisbon cultural centre.

Fantastic place - if you are not interested in art, at least go sit in the garden. One of the best museum experiences I have ever had. Everything was great - the architecture of the building, compositions inside and of course mainly the garden itself was exceptional.

Excelent!. What kept my attentin was the exceptional conservation of all the collection: from the Louis XV's furniture, from the Lalicque's cristal collection, an amazing collection! A hiden gemn in Lisbon!

Only the best!. Gulbenikan museum is one of the best museums in Lisbon. It has masterpieces from all over the world (among others -collection of oriental and islamic art) and works by Rubens, Renoir, Van Dyck, Vermeer etc. Student ticket is only 2,5 euro (temporary exhibitions excluded), normal 4euros. As the museum is big you will need at least 2 hours to see everything. If not just go see highlights as indicated on museums map. Museum is surrounded with big garden with lakes and animals. great place to have picnic on sunday (just be aware that there will be a lot of people on weekends).There are two cafeterias to have coffee and eat something (try pasteis de nata here). Also foundation has a big art library open for everyone, free of charge, on working days.

High quality museum. Gulbenkian is one of the best museums I've seen recently. The number of exhibits shown may be limited in comparison to big museums like Louvre or British, but they are very well displayed. The cases are not overloaded, so that everybody can have a good view of all the exhibits; the halls themselves are very spacious, so that you can easily go there for a leasurely visit. Quality of the exhibits is extremely high.

great representation of each period. It is free on the first Sun of the month but otherwise it is just 3 Euros. We were pleasantly surprised just how well organised and comprehensive the collection is. There are huge Chinese vases, Monet, Corot, Turner. Well worth visiting!

A perfect private museum. Great museum & exceptional works of arts & crafts all achieved by one great connoisseur of art.You need at leats 6 hours with an audio-guide to see all the highlights of the museum only!Better to focus on the main works as there is too many too see, or if at least you want to spend two days at the museum.

around the world in one place. There really is something for everyone at this museum. Set in a beautiful park, the museum takes you through a tour starting with Egyptian artifacts and ending with Rodin sculptures, with everything in-between. The Pursian carpets I hadn't seen
Impresive. Exclusive collection showing a great philanthropist.Rich collection of paintings, porcelain, furniture, watches and so much more
Some good idea in the middle of nowhere. Some idea are really good, but the price is too high for this exposition with 10 installation and 40 opera exposed in "empty" block.
Good range of exhibits in lovely park. Lovely half day spent here relaxing looking at the artifacts and spending time in the park. Under 18's free too, which was useful.

A place for all sort of cultural activities and chilling out. This is one of the places that if you have no idea what to do with yourself, just go there and enjoy everything they have to offer: music events, documentaries, exhibitions... Also, if you're looking for a park where you can comfortably lay down and read - this is the right place in the neighbourhood.

Truly inspiring place. Not only is the collection worth a visit, the grounds and surroundings are quite tranquile and relaxed with garden paths, concrete design everywhere, trees and grass lawns, lounging people and lots of..ducks.
Very cool, especially on a warm day!

Outstanding. If you arrive on the metro walk to the main road, El Corle Ingles will be in front of you, turn right and the entrance is down the road on your right. We couldn't believe there wasn't a sign. The main museum, 5 euro per adult, was money well spent. The pieces cover a huge period in history and are remarkably well preserved with an amazing variety. The ancient artifacts were particularly well preserved with incredible detail visible. Although I didn't like all the pieces there is definitely something for every taste. The walk through the gardens to the modern art museum is delightful with sculptures dotting the grass on ether side of the path, the duck filled lakes offer some zen like tranquility. The modern art museum was very intriguing with interactive installations that drew you in, especially some of the sound boxes with film sequences - a very atmospheric experience! Due to an exhibition some of the normal pieces weren't on show but it didn't spoil the visit. Amazing disabled access with lifts and ramps throughout the complex also making it ideal for families with buggies.
