It is good to find an attraction that caters for all ages and abilities close to the city centre.

Eclectic collection. Walking from our apartment in the old town we were rewarded with a wonderful collection of ancient to modern collectables . We a all enjoyed something - Reuben's paintings through to Lalique pieces . Pleasant outside cafe afterwards

Exceptional, Wide-Ranging Collection. This was an amazing collection of art. I seemingly covered every recognized major art period spanning thousands of years, beginning with the ancient Greek, Roman and Asian periods, and continuing through to the Impressionists. The museum could almost be seem as a "sampler" with just enough of each period and style, as if it was trying to have at least some representation from every artistic era. Easy to see it all, without spending hours doing so. Perhaps that is what makes this modest sized museum so enjoyable. Recommended.
Interesting.... Interesting for art lovers. Quiet park, where you really can stress off.Near to some good restaurants and the El Corte Ingles shopping center

Small but mighty; do not miss!. Fabulous collection; billionaire Gulbenkian collected the 'creme de la creme' -- the best ceramics, sculpture, paintings, & more [some from Catherine the Great who was quite the collector herself!]One room devoted to Lalique, a friend of Gulbenkian's. Short walk from a metro stop [although when you exit the station, you cannot see the museum].Worth the trip, worth the little walk & worth every Euro! [Note Spain's consulate close by with guard in his sentry box outside.]Plus: on-site busy little self-service cafe serves good food & beverages at reasonable prices.Note: we visited on Sunday to discover entrance is free that day.

Very good Museum. The museum has nice paintings, its a modern building and modern galleries. There are some old paintings from the 30s which you need to see...there is a nice cafe area and the entrance is only 5 euros. The collection could be organized better. The art collection is impressive, you must visit this place.

Excellent museum in lovely park. Beautiful modern building housing an eclectic art collection. From early Greek and Roman artefacts to Impressionist art. Not a huge museum so not at all daunting to see it all.The museum building is set in a lovely park - don't miss out on a stroll through this.

If you have an extra time .... It's a nice museum if you have plenty of extra time. The collection is mass of various exponents but not really systematized or directed. Looks like "everything collected" there.
A great place in town. Great art collection; Great building; Great gardens. In the very centre of a busy area, just felt isolated fron confusion.
Nice modern museum. This time i went to the modern part. Nice paintings from the thirties as well as a new exihibition. Nice cafe. Well Worth the 5 euro entrance fee.

fascinating collection. Its hard to believe that one man made this great and eclectic collection. Just amazing, There were some superb Egyptian items as well as impressionist painting. There is something for every taste.

Great collection. Calouste Gulbenkian was an Armenian who made his money from oil and spent some of it collecting art. His collection is a tour of art history with over 6000 pieces housed in an airy and relaxing building in Lisbon. I particularly enjoyed the glass and ceramics - especially the various styles in use throughout the East. European art puts in a good showing too with some wonderful paintings, seascapes by Turner, various of the impressionists and sculpture by greats including Rodin. Lovely collection of Art Nouveau items too. Not too large so that you feel over-awed but not so small that you feel hard done by. We rounded off our trip with a good value and tasty lunch in the museum self-service cafeteria. There's an outside eating area somewhat plagued with birds after every scrap. The museum is set within tranquil gardens and it is a pleasure to walk through this before arriving to experience the art. Tickets were €5 apiece and we both felt we'd had our money's worth. Would visit again when we next go to Lisbon.
good environment of the garden and museum. Good afternoon program visit the modern art gallery. lunch in the museum and after take a nice walk in the gardens
small collection. regarding sounds be a private collection, it os very small and disappointed museum. You can avoid this visst and prefer several nice place is Lisbon
small collection. considering is a private collection, the museum is small and I was disappointed. can be avoided. I thing you can find a better options things to do in Lisbon

Mr. Five Percent's Art and Artifacts Lisbon Collection. Although getting to the Museu Calouste Gulbenkian was a trek from our hotel on the Avenida Da Liberdade upon arrival it met our expectations of an art museum although unlike any we have visited.The building that contains Gulbenkian's collection was specifically constructed in a wonderful way to highlight the art that covers roughly 4,000 years. The museum is located in a beautiful, quiet park that has a few small restaurants for coffee and sweets. We spent a. Little over an hour in the museum although you could spend more time.
Great museum!. This was such a unique and great museum with a lot of variety in its collection, which is very fascinating. I especially liked the room with the Egyptian art, very nice!
Lalique fan.. Went specifically to see Lalique room but the rest of museum is great. Beautiful location and wonderful art including two Rembrants. Cafe good too.

Great place to study, walk or just relax. Love the art's library, the museum, the gardens. It's a great place to escape the city traffic and just relax a bit. The museum closes at mondays and the art library is only for ages 16+.

Still a great place for enjoying culture!. With one of modern art's most important nucleus in Lisbon, the Foundation offers also temporary exhibitions and a vast array of cultural important information. The gardens are also beautiful and right in the centre of Lisbon. A Foundation created by will of the late Calouste Gulbenkian and still one of the richest of Portugal's Foundations. A well deserved visit!

Relaxed, airy. Not in the city's most attractive quarter but full of exquisite artefacts and artworks. There's a lot of material but most is given room to breathe. The place could do with a few more pews for those with city-break leg-ache. Free one day a week right now. Hop on the Metro and get there for great value. Stroll back (all downhill) to the city centre through the underwhelmingly modernist Parque Eduardo VII and down the Avenida da Liberdade, the epitome of a shaded European boulevard.
A hidden gem. This is a great museum of art from ancient times to modern. It is hidden in a 60s block in a quiet park in downtown Lisbon. Worth visiting, when you fancy a relaxing break.

Wonderful Collection. This is a private collection of Armenian oil tycoon M. Calouste Sarkis Gulbenkian also known as "Mr. 5%", because he always kept that percentage of ownership in his companies. Quiet place, good library, concerts series. While visiting it you will understand why both the UK and France did everything they could to get it. Gulbenkian was not very happy with the treatment during WWII and the collection came to Lisbon. An absolute must if you like art before the avant-garde.

Great Collection. Very interesting collection and a well laid out museum. Very pleasant gardens. Excellent value for money at €5 and also free on a Sunday. Not in the city centre but easily reached by metro.

great mix of artefacts. Went on a Sunday for the free entry and expected it to be packed out but it was quiet and a lovely place to visit - walk through the park first to get a feel for the whole space. Very manageable size and a great mix of sculpture, paintings, jewellery, carpets, tiles etc.
One of the best museum in Lisbon. The only modern art museum of the city, look for the temporary exhibitions. Activities for kids must be planned in advance. Enjoy the luxuriant gardens.

One of the more atractive museum I know. The speciallyty is that is a museum of the richiest men of 1920´s with a extraordinary good taste on all aspects of the art it is a small museum were you will find the best from Egipt to Art-deco passing by Japan or mediaval age,the artedeco jwelarry is incredible and it is a must (don't forget to give a walk on the backyard gardens
Amazing. The space has a very beautiful garden. There a lot of cultural activities and things to watch and do.

beautiful personal collection. This is a gem of a museum, set in tranquil and lovely grounds. Both the art and its presentation are selected with care. As an Armenian, this was a pilgrimage I had wanted to make for years and I was definitely well-rewarded.

Interesting collection, a bit far out. The collection is incredibly divers which makes it interesting even if you aren´t a fan of museums. I especially enjoyed the pieces of furniture at the end, the different clocks were fascinating. The museum is not very central though, so if you only have a day or two you might want to focus on other things.

One of the best private collections in the world. If you are a lover of the decorative arts, a visit to this museum is a MUST in Lisbon. We went on a Sunday and lucked into free admission. It is a museum of a private collection, so don't expect it to be perfectly curated, but there is so much beauty in the objects of the collection that every turn brought a new feast for the eyes.

A wonderful collection. One man's eclectic collection. Shunned by many countries at the outbreak of war, the Portugese had the good sense to offer a home to the collector and his collection. Artefacts from the ancient world up to and including the Impressionists and the most wonderful collection of Lalique jewellery.A visit to the rather haphazardly run but very pleasant self service restaurant with lovely outside seating area rounds off a visit agreeably.
Must visit museum in Lisbon . A great museum spanning many centuries of human art and accomplishment, this is a definite not-to-miss if you have 1 hour to spare while visiting Lisbon!

Beautiful and personal collection. Really enjoyed browsing this lovely collection of personally chosen items. The museum is divided into various buildings and exhibitions. We bought the 15 euro all day ticket which enabled you to go to everything. I enjoyed the collection of pottery, manuscripts, tiles and carpets which would be interesting to someone who wanted inspiration for designs. The modern art section is fun to visit as well and the buildings are set in shady gardens which soften the modernist architecture and make the whole thing feel like a cool oasis. We ate at the cafeteria in the modern art section which had a good selection of salads and desserts along with toasted sandwiches and burgers. This made for a very pleasant trip on a hot day in Lisbon - recommended. My only criticism is that there is not very much explanatory material, maps or signage - maybe we should have paid for the recorded explanation or signed up for the app.

It was alright. It was ok. A bit boring and the exhibits seemed a bit disjointed, but thats probably because its from a private collection. The ancient egypt room was quite good, and all the exhibits were well spaced out so you could appreciate the stuff.But for €2.50 (student prices, normally €5) its worth a visit if you have spare time, and enjoy this kind of thing

Very worthwhile visit. We were impressed by the collection and thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Senior rates made the entry €2.50 each. Easy to devote less than 2 hours and cover it in a leisurely manner. Be aware that you can be dropped off fairly close to the entrance-our taxi did not and my husband using a cane had a lot of waking to do to just enter the building.
worth visiting. It takes short walk from metro station Sao Sebastiao. It was interesting to see many materials from my country (TURKEY) and middle east.

Impressive. The Museum is very well organized by theme rooms and there is a lot of attention to details. As a previous reviewer noted, clocks are in working order and display the right time. Another example is the lighting in the Egyptian room which is very subtle and strategically placed. It's quite impressive to see the quantity, the diversity and the quality of all the artifacts that Calouste Gulbenkian accumulated throughout his life. Some Egyptian artifacts are around 4,000 years old while some Lalique pieces date from the 1940's. There are probably a dozen large Turkish rugs, hundreds of Chinese pottery items, loads of ancient coins, some ancient books and bibles (late 15th, early 16th century), many different pieces of furniture, hundreds of paintings (some Monet, Rembrandt, etc), a few Rodin statue, and the list goes on and on. There's definitely something for everyone. In my opinion, this place is a must stop while in Lisbon.
What a fabulous museum. Fabulous exhibits - paintings, pottery, jewellery, carpets and more in a very spacious, beautiful museum which is set in lovely gardens. A must if you're in Lisbon.

This man had good taste...as well as lots of money. The items were well presented, not crowded, and an interesting variety from a very personal collection. Nice open air cafe with good choice of food. Small git shop but good books.
Small Museum with Big Art. We went on a Friday and it was FREE -- you just had to ask for tickets at the desk. A wonderful collection of art from all over.

Private collection. Not an academic museum but rather like visiting the large private collection of someone with excellent taste. Fine attention to detail- e.g. note how the antique clocks are set to the right time. Very enjoyable. Surrounded by a large park, suitable for lounging. Senior discount [65+] available on admission. If taking the subway the stop is perhaps a 15 minute walk away, opposite a mall with an "El Corte Ingles" department store in it. There is a large supermarket in it, with several delicatessen shops included- I would suggest buying some food and wine [or whatever] for a picnic on the museum's grounds.

Tasteful museum, great collection, fine example of classical modernism. One superb Rembrandt (selected by Diderot for Cathrine II), two fine Turners, a memorable Monet and many other masterworks -- not to forget the Asian collection.
Nice museum. A nice museum with a lot of beautiful things. They also have extra exhibitions that change. Across the street there is a great place to eat lunch and they have food from Cabo Verde.

Visit if you have time. This is an easy to see "museum" but probably not worth the entry fee. This was the personal collection of Mr. Gulbenkian, an Armenian refugee who was allowed to settle in Lisbon. He gifted his collection to Portugal before he died. The collection truly feels like a collection and less like a museum. That is not the issue as it is a decent and eclectic collection. I just think that the entry fee is not justified and the collection is too thin to truly entertain museum junkies.

Almost the whole history of art. From ancient Egypt to art noveau of Paris this is truly unique collection. Also the collection itself isnt top big - you can see it through without being totally overwhelmed.

GULBENKIAN MUSEUM. A beautiful location in central Lisbon. Several Metro stops within a block or two. This museum has world class collections - collected and donated by Gulbenkian. Be sure to take in the ground and all of the museums. Skip the modern art portion!

Nice building, not that much art. A small gallery with two parts, one contemporary, one traditional. Neither would be international superstars like you would find in Paris, London, NY, but both worth a visit.
Do not expect too high!. A good museum but doesn't worth EU$15 for a all-in ticket. Not many visitors while my visit which is a plus on slow viewing.
Great journey through art and history. Great collection of paintings (especially Impressionists), Egyptian, Islamic and Lalique collections also worth a look

Eclectic. A personal collection of some of the finest examples of their kind. Very doable without getting overpowered or exhausted! Not in many ways dissimilar to the Frick collection in New York. The visit ends with a wonderful display of Lalique Jewellery.
great !. a great museum for different arts and period of time. you can see works from early Egyptian times to XXth Century. very instructive for children.

Interesting and Unique Selection of Art. This museum is like no other we have visited. It consists of several types of art that the donor liked and we thought his taste was outstanding. We were particularly interested in the Islamic section as we have so little knowledge of that type of art. Even the French furniture selection which covered an era that was my wife's least favorite was well done. We walked through the surrounding gardens and enjoyed them as well. We missed this on a previous trip to Lisbon and this was our number one priority. It exceeded our expectations.We had lunch at their cafe and the soup and salads we ordered were quite good. All in all, we spent over three hours at this museum.
Very good museum. Wonderful and broad collection, nicely presented and easy to reach by all kinds or transport.Especially the classical collection is interesting.

I love this museum!. Housing over 6000 items from the personal collection of Calouste Sarkis Gulbenkian, this museum offers and amazing array of items; pottery, textiles, furniture, carpets, Lalique glass, paintings.There is pottery from Ming and Qing dynasties, paintings by Turner, Gainsborough, Monet,, Manet, Rubens and Rembrandt to name but a few. I can honestly say I think this museum has the best array of historical artefacts I have ever seen in one place. We spent easily 2-3 hours here.There is also a decent restaurant offering full meals or snacks - the prices were relatively cheap and the quality was fantastic!It is a bit of a way out of the city centre - we decided to walk from our hotel on Avenida De Liberdade and it took us about 50 minutes. I would recommend getting the bus, however, as it is cheap and efficient and there are several services that stop near the museum. Although it took us a while to walk there in the pouring rain, it was definitely well worth the effort. Entrance price was only 4 Euros per person, a bargain for what the museum has to offer.

Must see!. I made a list of the various sights to see in Lisbon and after the Gulbenkian Museum, I wrote "Must see". It is definitely not to be missed. I really cannot add much more than has already been said about the private collection, but I will say that Calouste Gulbenkian was a visionary. One of the paintings on display was purchased by him from the Hermitage Museum in Saint Petersburg in the 1930s. There are paintings, sculptures, jewelry, coins, porcelain - objects of art that were breathtaking. There is an audio in several languages which was very good. Do some browsing in the gift shop. It's a stop on the yellow bus line!! No matter how you get there, be sure to go!!

First Class. I can honestly say that this is one of the best museum we've visited,and we've seen a fair amount.Would have happily gone back the next day if we'd had the time.If in Lisbon,this is a must!!

A Treasure. A beautiful setting and a very interesting collection of art. Rugs, furniture, ceramics, paintings. Mr. Gulbenkian collected so many different types of art. The building is beautiful as are the grounds.
dissapointment. maybe I was expecting too much, but we were very dissapointed. A lot there, but no real collection. Just a lot of very nice individual pieces.

Wonderfull place to see art, enjoy the green and plenty more. This is one of my favorite place to go when in Lisbon and have a good smooth afternoon or evening.
There´s a lot of green all around. You can see concerts, exhibitions and a lot more

One of the best. Dont miss the excellent Museum. I loved the variety of this great collection from all over the world. Even if you arent a museum lover this one is different as there is something for everyone. Set in a lovely park and has a reasonable cafe too.

Multi-cultural jewel. This museum is based on a private collection that spans centuries of art history. Everything is beautifully displayed in a contemporary setting. Like most attractions in Portugal it offers a generous over-65 discount for mature visitors. The Gulbenkian reminded us in many ways of the Walters Museum in Baltimore, MD.
astonishing. Beautiful museum, with a very interesting and varied collection. It is worthwile visiting, even on a sunny day

Epic Art collection in sublime setting. From Egyptian and Phoenician artifacts and Greek sculpture, Persian tapestries and Qing porcelains, Rembrandts, Sargents, Gainsboroughs, Turners, Manet, Monet, Cassat, 16 and 17th Century furniture and clocks and a Lalique jewelry collection with the infamous Dragonfly, all this in more set in a lush and sublime park designed to come inside from the outside while you stroll the museum. Don't miss.

Expansive and dense collection of the best of the best.. An epic collection in a magnificent setting that culminates in an exhibition of Lalique jewelry including the great Dragonfly. The surrounding park is wondrous and the design of the museum means it comes to you from outside while you are inside.

Excellent!. How can one person collect so much? The story is fascinating; the collection is marvelous; the building and grounds part of the excellence. There's so much variety that all are sure to find pieces that speak to them. It should definitely be on your "must do" list in Lisbon.

Great diverse museum. The Gulbenkian is a great museum. Diverse exhibits from rugs, silver, glass, to paintings and furniture. Paintings by Rembrant, Rubens, van Dyke, Turner,Gainsborough, Monet, Renoir, and Degas and many more masters. The collection is of first class works of art, not minor works of the masters. Well worth a visit.5 Euro entry fee, free on Sunday.
Not my cup of tea. Not my sort of thing, modern art is too pretentiousBut was free! Good for a laugh and the roof was good view

Great gardens and rich museums. The Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation is a little jewel in the heart of Lisbon. The garden is beautiful and well-kept, rich with ducks that will approach people for food. They are the perfect place to read a book, study, or have some time with your other half.Inside you'll find the museums, one for Modern Art and the other ranging from Ancient Egypt to Modern jewellery. The collection is one of the best in Portugal, well documented, and it is an obligatory visit.

A Wonderful Afternoon!. This was as enjoyable a museum experience as I have ever had. Gulbenkian was an interesting man, with a drive to create a collection of unsurpassed beauty. His story is special, his collection is special. If you are in Lisbon, don't miss it. It may almost be enough reason to go to Lisbon on its own. Enjoy!

Great taste. Thi museum is filled with treasures from around the world and thru the centuries. There is something for everyone (except modern art) from pottery, ancient coins, old Masters paintings, silver pieces, fabrics, rugs, oil painting across the centuries and much more. The exterior gardens are inviting. We were surprised by a duck family waddling by. However greater care needs to be given to the outdoor installations since we saw a duck fly into a slver sculpture and hit it with a loud thd.

fantastic museum. It was all fantastic. Incredible to think it was one man's private collection. So grateful that he decided to share it and give people the opportunity to experience all these amazing artworks.The gardens are amazing too

Remarkable collection of varied art. Just here to pile on to the positive comments of others. I was dubious, having been to many a museum in my time, but this one exceeded my expectations. Every piece was outstanding, and many were the best examples of their kind I'd seen. At one point, I was in the 18th century area and heard ticking. Several of the French/English clocks were not only running, but set to the correct time! What a surprising and pleasant detail. Highly recommended, and near the São Sebastião Metro stop for convenience.
A garden inside Lisbon. Really beatiful gardens in the middle of Lisbon. Also have good art expositions or concerts. A place to go in the summer

Art lovers Experience. This museum has a specialist collection but all artefacts are of fantastic quality and beauty. Islamic ceramics are just wonderful. Shape, form, colour, perfectly balanced decoration to the pieces. Great silver, French decorative arts and Rene Lalique collection. Also Ghirlandaio painting of a lady I could stare at for hours.

Fantastic Ecclectic mix of fine Art. Have you ever been to the Burrell collection in Glascow UK ? One man's personal art collection given to the public domain to enjoy well this is an even bigger fantastic collection which will appeal to lovers of Archeology numismatist Art Ceramics . Collected by A Turkish born Armenian who invested in iraq's fledgling oil industry in return for 5% of the profits this fabulously wealthy man built a great collection .
A Must See. This collection is first class. . I had never heard of this museum. Each and every piece of arts was a gem. The Tiffany collection was incredible. Don’t miss this collection.
Beautiful gardens, great museums. Nice gardens for a relaxing walk. Outdoor jazz concerts in summer at night are great. Both art museums are great.

Amazing collection of paintings and antiquities. This collection by Gulbenkian is priceless and is less than one third of his collection. The highlight for me was the paintings which include some work by Monet, Manet, Van Dyke, Rembrandt and Turner. Some of the antiquities are from ancient Egypt and you need at least one hour to scim through the collection. Excellent self service cafe with outdoor seating.

Most outstanding museum in Lisbon. We still cannot believe that one single man has collected all this in his lifetime. It is a marvel, regardless on whether you are interested in arts, antiques, or collectibles of any sort. Just awesome!

Excelent art collection. ranging several periods. Rene Lalicque by the dozens Canaletto, Guardi. Furniture, rugs and jewels. Gardens not to miss. 2 very cozy restaurants serving great food. A definately must visit if time is not short

Not to be Missed!. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museum in Lisbon is one of the finest private collections I have ever seen. As a artist that has traveled the world extensively, visiting museums is a passion. It is not often when I come across a collection of work of this caliber. Starting with the Roman/Greco coins and medallions to the unbelivable, breathtaking Lalique display. The museum was designed perfectly to showcase the work that it housed. It was a pleasure to walk through and experience seeing art and antiquities that were well lit and given the respect each piece deserved. Not to be missed!

Personal collection, with great variety. In beautiful landscaped gardens, this collection has some exceptional Egyptian pieces, carpets and tiles, as well as paintings up to 1th century. Excellent trip out
must visit. Awestruck! Should visit for sure... One of the best I have ever seen in my life! Don't miss it.. Lisboas best!!!!!!!!!!¡!!!!!!!!
more than you expect. Amazing art, with some surprising pieces. Doesn't get much publicity but is one of the best things to see in Lisbon. Better than the Fado museum or the Tile museum.

Thank you Mr. Gulbenkian for this lovely museum!. Although "further afield", this museum is well worth the journey outside the city center. Easily reached on the Azul Metro route, the Gulbenkian has a rich collection of Turkish, Chinese and Portuguese, tiles, porcelains, rugs and glass. Then you turn a corner and have a completely different experience exploring gorgeous European (Dutch, Italian, French) paintings and an amazing French furniture collection. Don't forget to see the Lalique collection of hair pieces and jewelry!
Alright. Good for a rainy day but if not I would give it a miss. There is an amazing picture of a girl in a pearl necklace though which makes it worthwhile
Just do it. I strongly urge you to spend a couple of hours here - you might just see the most beautiful object you will ever see in your life

An exceptional museum. Wonderful Islamic art collection as well as a lovely Lalique collection.. Wonderful Islamic art collection as well as a lovely Lalique collection. I like the size of the museum. It is not overwhelming but exquisite in quality. One of Lisbon's treasures. Don't miss it.
For Art Lovers. Visit this world class museum, small but superb collections ranging from western oil paintings to Iznik tiles, to Lalique jewelry. Comfortable cafe and set in a lovely parklike space

An extraordinary collection. Although the Gulbenkian is a bit out of town, it is very easy to get to on the metro (blue line to Saõ Sebastiaõ) and very much worth the effort. The collection of oriental art - carpets, tiles, manuscripts, screens, porcelains - is magnificent, and the European art is of the highest order, with extraordinary works by Rembrandt, Rubens, Cima da Conegliano and others - and of course, the glorious collection of Lalique.

A great day out. Easy access via metro, fabulous exhibitions, the Lalique, and Czars from the east were amazing, They also have an eclectic collection of the best from Greece, Egypt etc. We spent a day there and found the restaurant was also very good and reasonably priced. Walking in the gardens was a treat when the sun came out at lunchtime.
Worth a visit. For 5 euros you can visit the collections and there are a variety of Oriental, Islamic, Greek and European arts and collections and you'll spend a couple of hours to see everything.
the best contemporary museum in Lisbon. It's a small but extremely rich collection of romantic, modern and contemporary art. very library and stunning, wild gardens.

Gulbenkian was a hidden jewel. We knew nothing of this museum before we went on our trip. It is by far one of the very best museums we have ever visited anywhere. It is huge and you can just pick where you want to go. His private collections are beyond anything you can imagine. Be sure to visit this museum.
Definitely worth a visit. Liked the collection of paintings best. Also enjoyed the lovely grounds and very pleasant lunch taken overlooking the gardens.
nice collection. It was a nice collection, but want visit it again. I rather recommend the Berardo for contemporary art.

Free on Sundays. Free entry and recital on Sundays.We loved this eclectic collection of high quality items . The paintings represented examples of all major periods and styles and the Lalique is amazing.Do this one. Walk through the gardens to the Modern Art museum and go to El Corte Ingles 9th floor restaurant for the view and a well priced lunch.Walk down through Edward 7th park and go in the glasshouses. Amazing.

Hidden Gem. When we arrived at our hotel, we had a half day free so our tour Program Manager suggested the Gulbenian Museum, which was within wajlking distance. What a surprise. While we had never heard of the Museum, it turned out to be one not to be missed. The collection was enormous, but not overwhelming. We spent over 3 hours there, including lunch in a nice cafateria, and would recommend this museum to anyone who has an appreciation for ancient artifacts, paintings, persian rugs, sculptures, china, etc. The website will give a better description. The museum is located near King George Park, so it is a 6-7 euro cab ride from central Lisbon. We went on Sunday when museum entry fees are waived.

You must visit it!. Just near Praça de Espanha and Berna Avenue, here you can find an excellent museum and a modern art center with lots of art treasures. If you like museums, don´t miss this foundation. I´m sure you will love it...
A litle paradise in the city.... All the environment...the gardens are simply beatifull...The buffet of the Museum is very good. A Nice place to visit with the family or just to an afternoon study.

Excellent museum collection. The Gulbenkiam museum was a treat. It was located close to our hotel at the Corinthis and the collection was excellent, covering Egyptian, Greek, Persian, Chinese and European artwork. we greatly enjoyed the museum.

OMG! This man had taste!!!. A stunning, stunning collection acquired by one man. The design, layout and presentation in the is museum is superb to say the very least. A feast for the eyes as well as the soul! Another Lisbon MUST!!!

Great collection, accessibly shown. A wonderful collection, especially 16-17th century pieces. In my humble opinion a little heavy in 19th Century French paintings. Is there one other place in the world where one can admire one of Rembrandt's finest from nearby, in all quietness?

Who Knew?. I stumbled upon this museum by accident knowing nothing about Calouste Gulbenkian. Wow, what a pleasant surprise! The staggering collection of art from around the world is incredible. The museum's park/gardens are an oasis within the city - perfect for relaxing under a tree beside a pond or wandering the many pathways. I would definitely return here as there is simply too much to see during one visit.
A Must See!. An excellent museum full of fine art from Europe, Asia and Africa. You do not want to miss this. It is definitely a must see.

Great private collection. The Gulbenkian museum houses the private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian.The museum is a 5 minute cab ride from the town center(5 euros).Open 10-6 Tuesday thru Sunday.Non flash photography is allowed.Lovely garden area surrounds the museum.Restrooms and café on site.museum takes about 90 minutes to visit. The museum costs 5euros with an extra 4 euros for the audio guide(recommended).The first room you enter is a bit dull with some middle eastern exhibits and history.Next you enter the china exhibit ,which has many vases and exhibits from China. The main room has many exhibits of French furniture ,sculptures ,tapestries,jewelry and some priceless decorative silver.Some smaller rooms showcase some small exhibits. The art gallery is the center piece(non flash photos are allowed)Rubens,Manet,Renoir,Monet,Rembrandt are just a few of the many masterpieces ,that can be viewed in the gallery.One can only guess at the value of this museum.

Must visit. The collection is free to visit on Sundays and if you go in the afternoon there should be no proper crowds.The café looks good for lunch and the gardens are lovely. The visit to Gulbenkian Museum was one of the highlights of Lisbon for me with a carefully selected objects on display and a great architectural space.

Berst museum in Lisbon. The collection is free to visit on Sundays and if you go in the afternoon there should be no proper crowds.The café looks good for lunch and the gardens are lovely. The visit to Gulbenkian Museum was one of the highlights of Lisbon for me with a carefully selected objects on display and a great architectural space

Very good garden. I really liked the garden with all the ducks and lakes. The museum was closed by the time I was there but the building is also very interesting.
I think this is a great garden in the middle of the city

Gulbenkian's wonderful gift to Lisbon!. This fascinating collection is housed in a modern building in its own leafy garden. The art work is presented in an excellent manner and is shown to its best advantage. The collection covers a broad time frame and has beautiful examples of items from ancient Persia ( rugs, tiles, textiles and glassware) through to French Impressionism. The cafe was very good, with interesting food and pleasant areas to sit and eat. What a wonderful gift to the people of Lisbon and its visitors!

A monument to one of the world's great philanthropists. A beautiful building with exhibits from around the world including great British artists but see the finest examples of far east china and pottery.The furniture is amazing samples of the worlds great cabinet makers

Worth a visit. An eclectic collection which is worth the visit. Great paintings and Egyptian artefacts amongst others. Well laid out and presented. Cafe was good and cheap too with a nice sitting out area.

The Best Museum Collection I Have Seen. Mr Gulbenkian had collected some of the best art in the world. The trust he established before his death has tastefully displayed it in a well organized manner. You are not over whelmed because of the easy flowing displays and the quality of the art. This museum is a real gift to the world.

A beautiful museum with a varied collection. The Gulbenkian Museum is in a larger complex of museums and theatres. It is out of the city centre, but is easily reached by Metro and a 10 minute walk. Surrounding the buildings are wonderful gardens and you should definitely take an hour or so to stroll around after your visit. The collection is quite varied, including Turkish tiles and carpets, European paintings, Chinese porcelain, and wonderful Art Nouveau objects in glass by Lalique. Overall, the collection is of a very high standard. The building itself is beautiful, and allows the collection to be displayed to its best advantage. There are audio guides to supplement the printed documentaion. Highly recommended, particularly is you are spending a long time in Portugal.
What a collection!. As the collection of one very wealthy person, this was outstanding in interest and variety. An additional appeal was a reduced fee for over 65s. This was a museum not to miss.

A lovely small museum. This is a small museum with plenty of beautiful pieces to enjoy. Art is exquisitely displayed and well organized. There is enough to see in an afternoon without being overwhelmed.

One of the best museums in Lisbon. At FCG, you have 2 museums: the main museum, where we can look the fabulous Gulbenkian collection. Another one, is the Contemporary Art Museum. Don´t Forget have a look and a promenade in the gardens.

Park and Art. One of the best Art museums in Europe, the surrounding gardens are beautiful and they invite for a moment of reading or just to chill out. Inside the Museum, great exhibitions awaits you, the permanent one and seasonal ones. There will always be a moment of surprise.

Outstanding enjoyment!. When you choose Gulbenkian, you know the quality is guaranteed. Also, the choice of meals are close to gourmet and to the mediterranean style of cooking. Also, the meal rooms always have one of those amazing views to the famous gardens. not to mention the generous amount of food on each individual order. It is absolutely good to have a restaurant like this after visiting one of the most famous art collections in the world. How cosy and warming a meal can be, especially in winter...

A Museum Worth Visiting. At first I was not crazy about visiting this particular museum as it would take time away from the multitude of wonderful things to see and do in Lisbon, but quickly changed my mind. It was fabulous - first off the story of a man (Calouste Gulbenkian) who had collected all the best of the best artistic items throughout his life - and then to get the opportunity to see these items in person in a most favourable setting is well worth the price of admission. We stayed about 4 hours and I would go back there again - it was outstanding.
Museum. great museum to visit. wonderful spaces outside to walk and see the trees and everything around.the coffee shop is very nice.

A must. The gulbenkian museum is Worth it not only for the museum himself. The collections there are exquisit, the building a must and overall surrounded by a beautifull Garden. In walking distance from the top of the park facing the Avenida da Liberdade it's a good place to end a walking around this places

Nice Museum. The Museum is a “collector's museum”, so in my opinion you will not find here an astonishing collection... and you may ask why I rated this museum as “excellent”. Well, because better than the museum is the whole Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation site. The best garden in Lisbon (designed by the best Portuguese landscape architects), the coolest building in Lisbon (designed by the best modern Portuguese architects), a nice restaurant, a beautiful lake, great temporary exhibitions, an exceptional orchestra, and probably the best (and secure) place to rest, sunbath, read a book, or just take a walk.

nice gardens. its located in the centre of the town close to the underground.you can just walk inside of it because the gardens are beautiful and rest a bit in the cooffe shophave a look at the schedule because there are some concerts once in a while
Relax. If you wanna come down a little in the heat of Lisboa enjoy the amazing garden with chairs to sleep plus the wonderful art selection at the Gulbenkian.
Worth a visit. An architectural gem of a building, housing a fine small collection. Skip the paintings, but the rest is golden.
Art in Lisbon. A beautiful way to fill a morning or afternoon. Art from ancient to more contemporary, well displayed, cool gardens, 2 nice cafes. A most enjoyable museum that won't exhaust you.

Hidden gem in the city. Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian is near Praça de Espanha. You must see the museum, but the gardens are open to the public and free of charge. It’s a quite place for relax, read, see the lake and the ducks…. Well, you must see it!

Ecletic. This collection is certainly eclectic, but that is the main attraction. Many different artifacts and many surprises around every corner. Modern spacious building, note that the entrance to the museum is facing away from downtown.

Free on Sundays!. Organized well with more space than I imagined. Lovely shaded walking path with seating around the complex of many buildings. Pieces were interesting and the European furniture was my favorite part. Contains Persian, European, Ancient Egyptian and some Asian artwork/textiles. Cafe contains some delicious, delicious, delicious pastries and outdoor seating. WCs were huge!

lovely collection. Very nice, small collection - worth a visit. This was one of the few museums we visited in Lisbon and were very pleased with the smart collection of porcelains and carpets. Very nice lunch in the cafe too.

Lovely collection. We visited the Gulbenkian Collection in May and were delighted with the interesting works chosen by this collector. From paintings and sculpture to furniture and decorative arts, it was a very nice afternoon in a museum. The porcelain collection plus the rugs/carpets…just wonderful. We also had a very nice lunch there - lovely cafe.

Starts well but interest declines . We visited this museum when the weather was poor. Disclaimer - I am a Londoner so I am spoiled by world class museums. The Egyptian and Greek rooms were really good with high quality artifacts. However as you see these first, as the museum is arranged fairly chronologically, it was a bit downhill after that. I know that reflects my interests so others will probably enjoy all the French furniture more! There are 2 Turners and 2 Monets on display which were good, clearly there are better collections elsewhere. In summary the museum is fine to visit on a wet morning but I wouldnt make a special trip.We had lunch in the cafe, the food was good so I would recommend it. We had vegetarian pasta, a soft drink each and one pastel de Nata for 20 Euros.My complaint about the museum is that you have to view the whole collection in one go, you can't stop for a drink or toilet break half way round, on the standard 5 Euro ticket.

A General Collection. I was hoping for more ceramics and especially more tiles. The Tile Museum in Lisbon was better to for my purposes. The museum is quite small when compared with similar collections in other places, so for me it was not worth the time spent to visit on our short stay. My husband interested in Egyptology and ancient coins, had the same reaction. He was really disappointed. It really is a smattering of this and that and certainly not for anyone interested in anything specialized, i.e. tiles or tapestries or whatever. There are just a few examples in each category though the quality is good...the collections are very limited in scope. So I would recommend it for people with lots of time in Lisbon to spare..not for a one day visitor as we were. It eats up too much time for too little reward.
interesting collection. Good and wide-ranging collection (and not just painting) in purpose-built museum, in beautiful garden surrounds.

Good, impressive museum!!. Personal collection of the Armenian philanthropist... A definite must-go if visiting Lisboa, and if you want to be entertained by beauty... Very broad collection theme wise, i.e. anything mr. Gulbenkian liked, which means you'll enjoy yourself...
Interesting Museum. Very nice collection of Persian, Seljuk, and Ottoman fabrics and dishes, plates, bowls, etc. European art is unimpressive but overall it's worth the relatively small entrance fee.

Amazing collection but be selective. This is a modern and large museum, usually not very crowded. It houses a huge collection and, as with many museums based on the collecting of one individual, the exhibits are sometimes idiosyncratic and also repetitive. You need to go round selectively - from ancient Egypt through Greece, Rome, China and elsewhere (after a while, one Chinese dish looks like another, however magnificent in itself). Decent cafe, shop disappointing in its range of goods (postcard selection not v. good) and high prices. Did not have time to visit the Centre for Modern Art, nearby in the grounds.

Wonderful collection. This is a marvellous collection of art, crafts and artefacts. If the weather's good, the gardens are lovely too. The only slight disappointment was the cafe, which was mediocre compared to how fantastic everything else was.

An absolute gem. One of the must see museums anywhere in the world . This is a museum with a collection that takes your breath away. Whatever it is that is on display is of unbelievable quality. I have never seen such fabulous Chinese porcelain and glassware or tapestries and carpets that are from 16th century from the Middle East where the colours are so vibrant. Each display seems better than the previous one. The Lalique room is a wonder as are the many paintings. There is so much here to take in that this short piece can't do the museum justice . Try and set aside a couple of half days to take it all in. The setting is lovely as well ; set in lovely gardens to wander round and cool off on a hot day.

Eclectic collection. Gulbenkian had made a fortune in oil but had to leave the UK during WW2 as he had been born in what had become an enemy country. Portugal made him an offer he could not refuse - including tax exemption for life - and he left them his art collection. Though not huge for a museum, it is very impressive for the work of an individual, including ceramics, textiles, furniture, jewellery, glass and paintings, with a Middle Eastern emphasis. It is located in a lovely park not far from the centre and near a Metro stop. Two hours is probably enough here. There is also a modest but good Egyptian collection from another source.

If you have time.... In the museum it not allowed to take pictures. Admission fee is 8 euros but free with lisbon card. Calouste Gulbenkian is an oil expert and business man who was born in İstanbul. Besides being a business man Calouste Gulbenkian is a collector. Throughout his life, he assembled a unique collection. In the museum you can see precious pieces such as Portrait of Madame Claude Monet, Still life with melon.

Best day in Lisbon,by far. Sometimes you have to shelve the need to over-explore when time is of essence,and the weather turns sour. It was providence and the above reasons that co-ordinated our decision to spend afull day to absorb and appreciate the huge cache of treasures that this collector had amassed. It is without a doubt one of Europe's finest collection of art. The displayes are in spacious,well-lit galleries,many overlooking the garden's courtyards. The museum itself is quite small,however,each individual work of art,from the magnificent pieces that make up the rich display of Oriental and Islamic art,to the selection of European paintings and furniture requires from us a lot of adoration and amazement. The Armenian section is superb not only for its fine collection of Persian and Turkish carpets,textiles and costumes,but also extends to ceramics, as well. The Syrian mosque lamps,i wanted to exhibit in my bedrooms,and the bottle collection is pure whimsy,and delight. There are numerous manuscripts from the 16th-18th centuries,produced by Armenian refugees. My femme opted for a closer look at European art dominated by the French painters including Fragonard,Boucher and Watteau. One whole room is devoted to Venice with the output provided by the painter Guardi. Its a wonderful treat and had us lingering for a long time savouring the colours and the idyll spots that we recognised from our visits to the wonderful city. there is a small but exclusive British section devoted to the art of Gainsborough and Turner. More loitering ensued and discussions flowed. If you remember your mother's glass- cased sideboard in the parlour, full of hokey Lalique figurines,well,you have arrived in Lalique heaven,for here is a whole room devoted to the originals . I am old enough now to appreciate what my mother and everybody's mom loved about their little collections.  We had lunch at a nearby restaurant,only to hurry back to this wonderful treasure- palace

A nice garden in the heart of Lisbon. This is a nice and fairly large garden in the middle of Lisbon. Once inside you can forget the cars and the Lisbon noise. You can stroll around and you can also have lunch or just a coffee in two places. There is also a nmodern art museum.

Well worth a visit. This collection of Oriental and European art, furniture textiles etc is really impressive and there is just enough of it to satisfy without getting bored. Good value at €5 (€2.50 for oldies!)
Wonderful museum. Just the right size museum. they have many different types of art, rugs, furniture, sculpture, paintings, etc. Restaurant was also good-great spaghetti.

amazing collection. i was been there last year with my friend André Archie Cameron . he show us every corner of museu .very nice , bueatyfull & wonderfull painting which is inspire everyone.also we had lunch there .

NOT TO BE MISSED. If you enjoy top notch art and and other collectables this is the museum for you. As I ended the tour I realized the art had NO blood and gore. Just wholesome high quality paintings and sculptures by names you will recognize. There is also a very good cafetaria with outdoor seating. And in good weather be sure to walk around the grounds.

Calouste's personal taste. How to spend your money if you have a lot and a lot of taste.
Go even for the small but unique Lalique collection. Fine furniture from the 18th Cy too.
gulbenkian museum. Light airy interesting displays all well presented.and you get in half price if you are over 65 and use your E11 card

Soaking in the treasures of a collector. As a museum lover I knew I had to see this museum. We took an apartment within walking distance to assure ourselves that we would not miss it for any excuse. It is truly an amazing collection of beauty and genius. Reading the reviews one senses something special, even for a "seasoned" museum visitor. It will not disappoint. The design and layout of the galleries were stunning in the display of the treasures. Never have I seen oriental rugs, for one example displayed in so many ways and laid out in all their magnificence on chestnut floors. Who knew that Lalique was a master jewelery designer? How could one person amass such a collection and succeed in having his wish of keeping it all together for posterity be achieved? The US had a chance at it, and so did the French, but in the end it was Portugal that won the honor. The Foundation is to be complimented on preserving the nature surrounding the museum as well as the cultural wealth within. The cafe lunch was delightful sitting out on the patio watching ducks, birds and small children playing nearby on a beautiful sunny day in May. It is a little hard to find on foot tucked away off busy streets in a less travelled neighborhood but asking for help from locals at a streetside cafe worked wonders. We spent over four hours there including a visit to a temporary exhibit of gifts to the Czars from Turkey and Iran in the Moscow Kremlin. Have never seen anything like these objects anywhere else in our experience.

Great collection in a peaceful part of Lisbon. The collection is free to visit on Sundays and if you go in the afternoon there should be no proper crowds. When I visited it was great and the near-by Museum of Modern Art has a fantastic park with sculptures and water pools, great on a sunny day. The visit to Gulbenkian Museum was one of the highlights of Lisbon for me with a carefully selected objects on display and a great architectural space.
Very beautiful paintings and rare objects. the statue of Auguste Rodin , "The Blessings "and painting The Mirror of Venus ( Sir edward Burne-Jones)

Looking for healthy salads after culture!!. Well worth visiting the Museum of Modern art at the Centro Culteral de Belem. The salads are amazing for lunch as is the dish of the day. Great vuews from the restaurant.

Enjoyable art - even if you don't like the modern stuff. A very intriguing place to visit with collects of modern and moretraditional art. The café looks good for lunch and the gardens are lovely. An enjoyable afternoon

One of the finest art collections anywhere. Amazing to think that one person made this collection.. Examples from Egypt and other prehistoric through the ages to 20th century. Nothing to dislike about this museum. Wonderful

What a collection!. Spend an entire afternoon ( or morning ) enjoying this 'best of the best' collection....a little bit of everything. Allow time for lunch in their wonderful cafeteria, sitting on the terrace, watching people stroll the garden. You will also enjoy strolling the gardens yourself...very serene and peaceful. There is a small cafe within the garden grounds if you'd like anything from a sandwich to gelato (very good!).

So many treasures. Goodness knows how much this collection of art and artefacts cost to put together. A jaw-dropping range of art and artefacts from around the world. We probably spent too long in the first few rooms and then ran out of energy later in the tour. Pleasant, reasonable value, cafe.

Eclectic mix. We went to see the Lalique collection (would have loved to have seen even more of this collection on display) but as it is the last room on the tour we just had to spend time looking at everything else. Wonderful. The only bug-bear is the same as in many museums/art galleries - not enough places to sit down and rest those weary feet!!

A museum to go for a whole day and more. The museum is located in the center of a wonderful park, families, young people, artists sit on the grass. Pigeons do not flee when one passes between them and there are many beautiful corners where to sit and enjoy.The Museum has a small but great collection, including many great Flemish masters and impressionists. On the ark there are two additional museums, the Modern Art and another that holds temporary exhibitions, both very interesting.

Amazingly varied collection in a brilliant little museum. Kudos to Gubenkian for having such impeccable taste in art and history! I've been to museums all over the world, but never have I experienced such an encapsulated journey through history from the ancient Mesopotamians all the way through to the modern Impressionists all in one museum, yet no piece of art or artifact feels cramped or out-of-place. Lovely gardens interlude with the rooms as you walk through time. The cafeteria is also lovely with an excellent selection of hot and cold foods, plus an outdoor patio on which to enjoy them. Only downside: slightly difficult to find while walking from the metro stop. I stopped to ask for directions several times!

Perfect for Art Lovers. If you're an art lover, this is the place for you in Lisbon. The foundation has a fabulous and varied art collection, but my favourite is the contemporary part. The gardens are also a must see.

wonderful personal collection of art etc. Open 7 days a week and free on Sundays (to pensioners anyway!) the Art,jewellery,and coins plus furniture and furnishings are antiques of the highest and rarest quality which reflect the cultural tastes of a very rich stateless man who was afforded Portuguese nationality.....his thanks were to leave his collection to that nation through the Gulbenkian foundation...

Amazing collection. This guy both had money and great taste and collected pieces from all over the world. I like the variety: ceramics, carpets, sculpture, jewellery, clothing, paintings, books, etc. A must see

Brilliant little museum!. A lovely personal collection of paintings, sculpture and ceramic housed in an ugly purpose built 60s structure in a pretty garden. Paintings in particular show the genius of the greatest French and Italian artists.

So Many 'WOW' Moments For Such a Small Museum. I gasped out loud 4 times in the Rene Lalique room alone. There are some rooms you will skip entirely because the epoch doesn't interest you, then you'll land on a room whose content blows you away. Just depends on your taste. It's really really close to a metro stop, so getting there is easy. If it's a nice day, don't miss the gardens. If modern art is your thing, the contemporary museum is at the other end of the property.
Loved the Gulbenkian. Beautifully arranged and displayed. I last visited in 1988 so now of course it is completely updated and so well done.
Interesting. An interesting and eclectic collection, wide-ranging. Worth a couple of hours for the visit. Free entrance on Sunday, closed on Monday.

Varied collection of art history. I liked the arrangement of the rooms with art from different regions/periods displayed separately. Photography without flash is allowed but the rooms are deliberately kept dim to protect the artworks. The Pre-Raphaelite paintings and the Lalique exhibits were my favourites.
The best art collection we have ever seen!. Allow plenty of time to visit, as it is a large museum, take a break and walk in the garden, as it is very pleasant. A great experience!
What a lovely way to spend an afternoon. We spent about 2 hours enjoying the exhibits and still there was more to see --- we just ran out of energy. Do take the time for a visit.
Very nice. The garden is peaceful, green, and you have terraces with the wifi. I love going there on week-ends! The museum is not very big but interesting, and free on Sundays.
Don't miss this museum!. The collection is unusual and stunning. We went here on our last day in Lisbon and it was worth every minute. There are gardens behind the museum which are also beautiful.

A must see!. This museum is wonderful. It's incredible that one individual could amass such a collection. The pieces are wonderful and the museum itself is very nice. The gardens behind the museum are also lovely. The modern art center is right around the corner and also well worth it.

Interesting collection. Enjoyed the museum and the collection was interesting.
Especially since collected by one individual over many years.

Best Museum in Lisbon!. The prior reviewer was upset because the Museum was closed on Easter. He should have gone to the Castle as we did--it was open. Of course I knew this because I did a a little bit of research before I left home. In fact, almost all of the museums were closed on Easter. Enough of that. The Gulbenkian was magnificent! I don't usually like museums but this one is special. It has something for everyone. And the gardens cover a city block. We went to all the highly rated places in Lisbon, Sintra, Cascais, and Belem (very disappointed with the Monastery), and the Gulbenkian was at the top of our list.

Great visit!. Loved the displays and the ability to take photos of the beautiful artifacts in the collection. Especially awed by the ancient Egyptian pieces but everything was beautifully displayed and identified. Nice to see a large number of staff overseeing the collection as well. Definitely recommended for visitors!
Easter. Don't try to go on Easter Sunday - incredibly, it's closed, although this fact isn't advertised in guidbooks!

Nice change of pace in Lisbon - nice mix of paintings. This was a nice change of pace for visiting Lisbon. The museum had a little bit of everything and really enjoyed the Guardi and impressionist paintings in the museum. From the old town of Lisbon, took the Metro to museum which is not too far from city center. On the way back ended up walking to Eduardo VII Park for city view before taking Metro back to hotel. Overall the museum is worth a visit, there is also a nice park behind the museum.

Perfect place for culture. This really worth while see if you are into Art. It has a modern Art center but also a museum concerning other periods (impressionism, art noveau, others). It has concerts for classic music and temporary exhibitions. And in the summer it has jazz concerts.Just save one day to see it, or at least one afternoon.If you are not into art, just enjoy the gardens, they are quite lovely and peaceful.

The best museum in Portugal. Go on a Sunday morning when it is free to enter. I honestly do not care for the contemporary part of the museum but Mr. Gulbenkian's original collection is priceless, of incredibly high quality. Usually their temporary exhibitions are very good as well.
Unique!. Unique pieces of oriental arts. This museum is definitelyt worth visiting, even if a bit away from the city center.

One of Europe´s best collections!. As an art lover this is truly one of the nicest art museums I have visited in Europe. It has a great permanent collection and is very elegant and well curated. I´d go back again and again. Its also worth mentioning that the foundation has a very active program with temporary exhibitions, conferences, talks, concerts and workshops. I´d go back again and again.

Gulbenkian. This museum was the highlight of my visit to Lisbon. The art displayed was exquisite covering centuries of art. I have been to many museums around the world and this one is in my top 5. I visited the museum Sunday morning when there is free admission. The museum was not crowded and there were times I was in a room by myself. The Islamic and Chinese art was especially awesome. This is a "must see" in Lisbon.

Fabulous concert hall. The back of the stage in the new auditorium is floor to ceiling glass, overlooking the trees around the pond in the Fundacao gardens. It is unlike any other concert hall I know. Great acoustics and comfortable, well-spaced chairs. And the spectacle of gulls soaring, ducks landing, and people strolling through the gardens behind the orchestra and choruses on stage. Rare opportunity to hear the full Bach St. Matthew Passion Oratorio with double choirs. Literally fabulous!
Great museum. Nice and cosy, with an excellent collection from all over the world, but the best part are the wonderful gardens just in the center of the city.
Oasis in the city. The Gulbenkian has some great art and objets d'arte. Particularly like the Pre-Raphaelite paintings and oriental art
Bright space. Great mix of pieces. All laid out in a bright space to allow you to enjoy in your own time.Well worth the trek up the hill.Nice cafe for an afternoon tea.

Nice change from churches and castles. Really enjoyed doing something different while in Lisbon. It's a small museum but well designed and interesting because of it's variety of articles. The Lalique room was worth the time by itself. Took a cab from city center.

Gorgeous Lalique and Islamic Art. This is an interesting, albeit somewhat out of the way, small museum that contains a chronologically arranged survey of art and art forms from 2500 B.C. onward. The fact that it is so inclusive is both its strength and weakness since it's an approach that can be superficial but also educational. The museum does have specialties in its spectacular collection of Lalique jewelry and glass, a large collection of Islamic ceramics and rugs, and a single gallery devoted to Guardi's dreamy paintings of Venice. The museum building is modern, spacious and well lit with interior views of an outdoor fountain and garden; the exhibits are nicely labeled; and there is a very pleasant cafe with outdoor seating surrounded by a garden.

A wonderful art/history museum in a beautiful place. The diversity of the pieces they had was outstanding. It scanned ancient Greece, Ancient Rome, medieval times, Asia, Africa, Europe and all fit together like a glove....

Amazing collection. The fact that one man was able to amass this enormous collection is amazing, but not as amazing as the superb quality and diversity of it all. To imagine those huge tapestries with cherubs hanging in his dining room! I enjoyed the clocks best of all, especially as they seemed to all be in perfect working condition. The one with the globe is truly outstanding. I highly recommend a visit to this museum.

Amazing collection. Possibly my favourite museum in Lisbon. A diverse collection from ancient Egypt to Impressionists...always the best of everything.... a Must-see. I will always visit this museum when I am in Lisbon. Love it.

worth the trek!. It took us some time to find our way to the museum but well worth it. Excellent displays most of which were explained in English as well. Wonderful 19th and 20th century art - Monet, Matisse, Gainsborough, Rembrandt and many more. Do visit!

The right kind. Very good collection of art from around the world Manageable size and no of exhibitsThe exhibition of Russian Czarist collection was fascinatingThe display notes could be better lit for ease of reading Good facilities and easy to reach from San Sebastiao MetroWell worth a visit

Not to be missed. This is a wonderful museum in every way - stunning building from the 1960s especially built to house Calouste Gulbenkian's amazing collections. Set out very spaciously to set off these world class treasures. We particularly loved the mughal carpets and beautiful textiles. The Lalique jewellery was extraordinary and fabulous. We loved our visit, truly something to delight everyone.
Gulbenkian Museum. What a surprise, a wonderful collection of Asian, Mid eastern treasures and spectacular paintings. A very special treat especially on a rainy day!

Lisbon's best museum?. Well, it was the only one I visited, so I'm really not best placed to make that judgement, but the Gulbenkian ranks highly in any comparison with other major European museums that I've visited.Easily found from the Metro, there is a separate Modern Art building, but I only had time for the main museum, a well laid out single floor trip through human cultural history - right from the Egyptian and Greco-Roman period up until Rubens and Rembrandt and quite recent modern pieces too.Sometimes, you can be overwhelmed by the size of a museum's collection and obliged to spend more time than you can really spare to absorb it all - but the Gulbenkian seems to judge it "just right" - a Goldilocks amount of art and culture, laid out in a simple path that was easy to navigate.I opted to stop for a bite to eat in the museum cafe, which was priced at a reasonable level and including an outside seating area in the museum's park - that was pretty good too.Recommended, especially if it's raining! And it's free on Sunday as well!

not expensive but you can see it in an hour. The best thing in this museum were the medieval books. It's very easy to walk round, there are some nice exhibits, a lot of carpets, big rooms. Nice cafe, decent coffee at a good price.

Sorry but a bit boring . I felt this museum was a little boring ..nothing exciting apart from the Islamic art which was beautiful. We went on a Sunday and it was free but you still have to queue up for a ticket . The staff were very friendly and it was clean and in order ..the outside was beautiful with lovely gardens ..
Historical. Vaste collection, nice setting. Interesting pieces from accent Egypt to 19th century Europe art. Very close to the hotel.
Interesting museum. Wonderful Lalique jewellery in the gallery plus interesting art and objects. Good cafe too with outside deck.

Don't miss this one. If the weather is not so good head for the Gulbenkian to see art that will knock your socks off. When Gulbenkian chose a painting it was not just a great artist's work, but one of the best done. so there are a Gainsborough, Turner, Singer Sargent the equal of anything found in the UK, an amazing Renoir, Manet and Rembrandt and don't miss the Ghirlandaio or the Ming vases and the Egyptian cat's sarcophagus. Breathtaking in a lovely park setting with large galleries that never get full - even on Sundays when entrance is free

A very interesting exhibition.... Very modern layout and located in a park setting. We could walk around in comfort and the facility was bright, large in space and climate controlled. We would recommend this museum as part of your visit to the capital city of Portugal.

What's not to like. This is a real must-see experience even if all aspects of the exhibits don't fire your imagination.I was totally overawed by the diversity of this collection and whilst my interest lies in his Art Collection the rest of the range was absolutely amazing.My wife and I are also keen on Gardens and were really impressed by this as well which was a real bonus.Our BIG mistake was that we left this too late and only left a morning for this trip.Not long enough - BEWARE!!!This must rate as one of the Top 5 places to visit.It also represents incredible value for money.It caters for people who have disabilities which is enlightened and necessary.

Beautiful. Over the past years I regularly visit the Gulbenkian mainly for the fantastic Concerts and other musicals from its anual programme! The main concert hall has recently been renovated and it is simply a most fantastic place to be! For some of its concerts they open the back of the stage, showing the lovely greens of the gardens ! It is always a pleasure to attend a venue at the Gulbenkian!The temporary exhibitions are also a must !

First class museum. This place is a first class museum that originated in a private collection of a oil business magnate that retired to Portugal after WWII. They have a great old art collection from islamic masterpieces to early XXthc jewellery made by Rene Lalique some i think also belonged to Sara Bernard. And don't miss the modern art collection too its impressive.
A real jem. Worth the trek from our hotel to the top of the hill and down again on the other side. Great value exhibition with a really good coffee shop. Quality and value rolled into one.
wonderful collection. This is the most wonderful collection of beautiful artefacts and paintings. Highly recommended, wish I could have spent more time there.

Must visit!. An outstanding collection of art and craft including french furniture and chinese porcelain spanning the centuries, the best that money can buy! Free entry Sunday.Close to El Cortes Ingles department store.
Fantastic private collection!. This is a great museum with a lot of artifacts of wide variety and great quality. A time well spent and a must visit, if you have time for one museum.
A lovely museum.. I am not a museum snob, so I thought this small museum was just right. We were traveling with three generations and we all enjoyed it.
Permanent Museum. Good collection of which he collected/bought/etc especially very rare Turkish Iznik tiles, vases and plates.

Poorly curated. Like a lot of personal collection it is a bit of a hodge podge. Information is almost non existent and the audio guide is a waste of money. Worth visiting if you are interested in Middle Eastern artefacts but in terms of paintings there is a good turner, an interesting Ghirlandaio and van der whey den fragment. Don't even think abou wasting money on the modern art section!

Small but perfectly formed. Beautiful museum in lovely grounds..highly recommended. Slightly off the beaten track but worth getting a taxi out to it or combine with a visit to El Cortes Ingles! Special exhibitions get v busy.
visited modern art musuem and gardens. very good. The gardens are a great place to chill and seem well used by the locals. We were lucky enough to be there on a lovely day.

Top Quality Artifacts. I was very impressed by the collection here, located in a modern building in a park off in a residential area. The collection spans centuries and everything is of the highest quality, not just a Rembrandt but an important one, along with other great masters. The tile collection is very impressive and the pottery and vases, as you wind down you come across a vast array of Lalique. I enjoyed my morning. Sunday's are free!
one of the best in europe about middle west. nothing disliked because everything is nice and beautiful and also the gardens are worth a visit A place to see and relaxe
Impressive. This place took a bit to find but was worth it, lots to see all on one level also the coffee shop was welcome after the visit.

Czar and the East exhibit. Visited the grounds (stunning oasis in the heart of Lisbon) and then the temporary exhibition Czar and the East. Very well displayed and some amazing items gathered by the Czars from mainly Turkey, Iran and the surrounding areas. The only improvement would be to have a seating area to allow lingering time to view these priceless treasures. At 4€ a person it is a real deal.

Well worth a visit. It was lovely to visit a traditional museum aimed at adults. Not a single interactive unit in sight! The exhibits are well displayed and extremely interesting. The Art Gallery is a must to visit. The original paintings on display are worth the visit alone. If you like museums then this one is really worth a visit, to fully enjoy allow a couple of hours as it is quite big.
Too small collection. If you have already visited the big museums in the world, this museum isn't worth it. I imagine if you go there for temporary exhibitions, then it's good.
Concert. We were surprised to see so many children at the Sunday morning classical concert - and they were well behaved!

Great Museum, Good Exhibits.. This is a great museum / gallery insofar as the building is marvellous and functional. Every exhibit is superbly lit and there appears to be space everywhere. Because I am a philistine, I thought that quite a few of the exhibits were displayed because they appealed to Mr Gulbenkian, rather than being there for any cultural reason. He had great taste in art, but some of the more "mundane" antiquities were made to look even more ordinary by comparison . If you want to see carpets go to The Hermitage or one of the Islamic city museums ! Still, I've been here twice. Sunday (when it is free) is a popular day for local families wanting a bit of culture and a decent meal. There is also free music downstairs sometimes. During the week it felt a bit dead even if you had unlimited time and space.

Outstanding. Everything about this museum is simply marvellous, from the design of the building to the quality of exhibits to the way they are displayed. The coffee in the coffee shop was good too! Having travelled the world, this is probably my favourite museum/art gallery - wonderful intimate feel to it. An absolute delight and a MUST on a visit to Lisbon.

Delightful museum! Highly recommended!. Such a wonderful collection of amazing artworks, displayed beautifully. Uncrowded, even on Sunday when admission is free. We especially like the varied art, some from major artists, but others that simply and beautifully depicted life in a many different cultures, over a span of 5,000 years. Highly recommended!

Larger than it looks. Very diverse collection! We went on a Sunday when it was free and it wasn't too crowded at first. Go when it first opens at 10 am so you might miss as much of the crowd as possible. If you want to, you can check your coat for free just past the ticket counter. Also, the garden is quite nice and relaxing.
Amazing collection. Very diverse and exquisite exhibition - Sunday's you go free!! The way through the museum is intuitive and covers all periods.

Astonishing Lalique Collection. Breath-taking room of art nouveau jewellry and other items. Worth the trip to Lisbon alone. Spacious uncrowded gallery - beautiful Islamic tiles and a few old masters treats. Don't forget the Burne-Jones.
Great visit. This was a wonderfully eclectic collection of items collected by someone because he liked them! Definitely worth a visit when in Lisbon

the lifetime treasure collection of an oilman. especially on a rainy day this is a great place to visit. look up mr. gulbenkian or better yet read about him in Daniel yergin's 'the prize' to get an idea of the remarkable character.

Its free on Sunday. If you don't want to read and study every piece it is a nice size museum to get around in a couple of hours. Very good cafeteria downstairs for lunch and the gardens are worth wandering around. We visited the Estufa Fria gardens on our walk back to Rossio Square in the same afternoon.

Fantastic collection emphasising quality over quantity. A definite must for any visitor to Lisbon!. The collection is not huge in the way of a Met or British Museum type experience, which seems to bother some reviewers on here. Instead this is the personal collection of Calousto Gubenkian, where each piece is of the highest quality. It covers superb examples of islamic and european objet d'art, paintings, carpets, sculpture, furniture... all housed in a well designed building set in relaxing gardens. They even let you photograph everything once you don't use a flash. A simply exquisite collection.
breakfast. I liked the simple good breakfast , eggs and ham with pastries , good coffee, before visiting the museum

Amazing gardens, wonderful exhibitions, fantastic music!. I've been going to Gulbenkian since I was a little boy. The gardens are amazing and the various exhibitions are always of high quality and interest. One of the "must see" of Lisbon for a nice stroll during a sunny day, or a visit to the museum. Also, the concert hall has just been refurbished, if you get the chance to watch a concert, do so! Jazz festival during summer in the open air is also a must.
Gulbenkian museum. Excellent food and value for museum cafe. Outdoor, as well as indoor, with pleasant a outlook onto garden.

Essential. Two beautiful museums with a wide range of art. The contemporary one had a wonderful exhibition of works by Amadeo de Souza-Cardoso, whom I hadn't heard of before - a find. Visit to this museum is indispensable when in Lisbon.
If you like Modern art.... ...make sure to visit the place. And of course the garden outside is amazing. Very nice place to chill.

Small but fantastic. This a small museum all on one level with fantastic collection of china, furniture, paintings,silver and a whole room dedicated to Lalique glass and jewellery.About 2/3 hours to see everything, toilets and small reasonable cafe downstairs with lift access, free coat and bag cloakroom.
