Fantastic Museum. A bit of a trip on Metro but well worth it. Excellent paintings Dega, Turner, Monet, Manet etc. Good Rene Laleque jewellery. Cafe good too. Euro 5 cost.

must do in lisbon. a great collection. I went for the European paintings but enjoyed just about everything else.
Delightful and inexpensive cafe too. Guide book at 18 euros a great souvenir
Islamic art. This is dominated by a wonderful collection of Islamic art but the european collection is somewhat disappoing also when you find rembrandt represented

worth a visit. most people have said the same about this museum,a huge collection of china and french furniture but not as many paintings as i thought although some masters and you can take photo's with no flash.
Very nice restaurant with good food at a small price.
Worth a visit and the best of a limited amount of museum's on offer.

civilization at its best. Lovely building, quiet interior with superb selection of art from many periods. Free on Sundays. Around the building is a public garden with pools and streams full of duck and geese families.
Super Museum. You could spend a whole day here.The collection is amazing & the restaurant is super so stay for lunch.
Excellent and most unexpected. See it, do it. This is a lovely museum/gallery with lovely exhibits. Make an effort to see it - it helps make Lisbon worthwhile.

A must for Art lovers. A great find just 3 blocks up the Eduardo Park from Pombal Square; this gift to Portugal and all is a beatifully designed, well laid out array of art pieces well worth the trip (park like setting is also great)

Wonderful museum, hidden off the main street. Hopped on the metro to El Corte Ingles and then walked to the museum - best to ask if you get lost like we did!
An amazing collection, each room bigger and better the last.
Just make sure you set aside enough time to do it justice!

Great Museum and Gardens. The Gulbenkian museum is situated near the park and it has a great collection of modern art. It is free on sunday morning so dont miss it. The gardens around it are amazing and great to sit around in the grass in a nice sunny day.

A hidden gem, best museum I've visited. This is a wonderful museum, off the beaten path in a somewhat suburban neighborhood of Lisbon away from the main tourist attractions. The museum is comprised of the life-long collection of an Armenian oil billionaire who left it to Portugal as a thank you for asylum there during and after World War II. Only the best pieces are exhibited, so it's easy to go through - and you can go right up the world-famous paintings to look closely and even take photographs (without flash) - Rembrandts, Manets, Monets, etc. It's an under-visited museum so it was not crowded. I've been in over 40 countries and this is by far my favorite museum.

A Wonderful Museum in Lisbon. I opted to visit the Gulbenkian recently on a very stormy, rainy day in Lisbon. It was a great way to spend a couple of hours inside but that being said, it would be a great place to visit at ANY time. The entrance fee was inexpensive (4 Euro - or more if you want to see the special exhibit and/or the Modern Art musuem). The Gulbenkian is an easy walk from two different Metro stops. At a leisurely pace, you can plan to spend 2+ hours here. The art collection is lovely and there is an optional audio guide that you can purchase if you wish. Don't miss the Lalique Room - the collection is breathtaking. I also had a light lunch at the museum's cafeteria; the food was good and very reasonably priced.
A collection not to be missed. This was a museum with one of the most amazing collections we have seen. Particularly the Turkish carpets and tiles were exceptional. Must go when you are in Lisbon.
Thank you Mr. Gulbenkian!. Love the way this museum is ageing.Loved the Lalique jewellery collection (but hoe would't?)Loved the Azuleijo exhibition.
Esoteric collection. A great contribution to Lisbon. Interesting if selective collection. The signs say no photography but everyone was!

Superior Museum with abundant staff. The permanent collection of this Museum are beautifully displayed with useful signs in both English and Portuguese. The temporary exhibition on the history of ceramic tiles was outstanding. Wonderfully curated the visitor is taken through the world history of ceramic tiles. Outstanding.
Incredible private collection. Loved it. Wonderful old and new fabulous exhibits. A gem in Lisbon! Lovely lunch recommended in their cafe!

Free on Sundays TOO!. There is a great collection here, with works from Manet, Monet, Dégas, and Renoir just to mention a few. I really enjoyed the coin collections in the ancient Roman and Greece rooms. The entire art collection is one of the best of the Iberian Peninsula, if not the European Union. Include in there that I went on a Sunday, when it was FREE was was even AMAZING.
Great. The museum is small but great, definitely worth a visit, especially they have a very valuable collection of Chinese china.
Don't miss it. Fabulous! Beautifully displayed art. Tiles, pictures, china, the list is extensive. Make sure you leave yourself enough time. A must in Lisbon.

amazing collection of European and Islamic art. When we first visited the Gulbenkian almost thirty years ago, we thought then that it was one of the world's finest museums. When we revisited recently our opinion was confirmed. What a rich group of amazing (and interesting) art and decorative arts. It is quite as interesting to consider that this was one man's collection (and to think about his "eye) as to view the masterpieces of the collection--which span Rembrandt, Impressionists, 16C and earlier oriental carpets, beautiful Islamic art pieces, French furniture, and more.

The garden is amazing. Right in the middle of the city this Museum has a beautiful garden. I have never been to the museum itself but I spend a lot of time in the garden for a walk or reading books at the outdoor anfiteather.

One of the best museums in the world. This is a remarkable place. I have never seen so many objects of breath-taking beauty in the same place. Yet the museum is spacious and calm - a place to spend time contemplating exquisite objects and art works of many kinds. Ideally I'd like to go again and spend a whole day with no pressure of time. It is a place which delights the eye at every turn. You come away with spirit refreshed and a new admiration of the genius of human creativity.

My favorite art museum in Lisboa. A collection rich in depth as well as quality. Quantity does not define this museum's holdings, but it offers many treasures installed in historical vignettes. It is easy to meander through each gallery progressing chronologically through the history of art. Highlights include a striking Manet and a fabulous collection of Islamic tiles and carpets. While the museum is very impressive, the cafeteria is a bit mediocre.
priceless. Here everyone will find something for themselves. Lovers of ceramics, ancient art, carpets, paintings and furniture. See live Rembrandt's painting "Old Man" - priceless.
Fantastic exhibition of azulejos. Fantastic temporary exhibition of azulejos from all over the world. Very interesting indeed. Sunday is free all day!
amazing. spectacular architecturebeautiful gardenexceptional eventsfantastic choir and concertsgreat collection of literatureI recommend to visit the place

Wow - artistic masterpieces. Great museum of art throughout the ages. The building was less than inspiring, but having seen Monet's, Manet's, JMWTurner's, Gainsborough's etc it is a must seen when visiting Lisbon.
Beautiful gardens. Amazing gardens to walk around or just to chill. There is also a restaurant and a museum!To repeat!

Small but charming.. Good walk up the hill from the city centre and by some nice greenery. Museum itself is small but cute, collection is eclectic and touches on different periods and areas. Rene Lalique's room is a gem worth seeing. There are different areas in the Museum and we have't seen all of it, being mainly interested in Lalique's art.The meal we had in the cafeteria was one of the best meals in Lisbon!

Two Museums + Garden. Note that in addition to the museum, there is a "modern art centre" (with separate or combo entry ticket) in another building. This one had a very nice collection of modern and contemporary art, but I am not sure which parts were temporary exhibition and which ones permanent collection. The landscaping and "garden furniture" would be worth of visit alone.

Art and Wonderful Gardens--Seventh Heaven!. I always wanted to visit 'The Gulbenkian' and somehow never managed it when I was in Lisbon. This time I was determined to do so and as the weather was cold and wet I decided it was now o never. It was a delight. It is of manageable size and has some stunning pieces like the Egyptian cat sarcophagus and a Ghirlandaio portrait which alone are worth the price of the entrance ticket. At present there is a fascinating exhibition not included in the entry ticket called 'The Route of the Tile' until 26 Jan which if you are in Lisbon should not miss. The gardens of the Gulbenkian complex are exquisite and the Modern Art Centre has some interesting pieces. All in all a marvellous afternoon.
Nice museum. Had fun at this place. I am not a huge museum goer but enjoyed this one a lot. There were not many people when we went so we could really take our time and enjoy each art piece.
Fantastic place, extremely lousy food. This is a fantastic building with a beautiful antique collection and amazing surroundings. The gardens deserve a walk.
One of the 10 best small museums. Impressive collection;Impressive surroundings;Impressive building;Impressive foundation;Impressive gardens.

More interesting than I'd anticipated, and free on Sundays. I'm not one for museums usually, and certainly not one for galleries. But this had enough interesting and rare pieces of art and artefacts from around the world (mostly the Arab/Muslim world and China) that Gulbenkian collected during his rather eccentric time on the Earth. I was a particular fan of the Turkish and Persian stuff, but it was all rather nice. Plus it was free on Sunday. Another bonus. It's considered an integral part of the Lisbon tourist experience, and I can see why.

Superb Collection. Visit the temporary exhibitions, but also the entire collection (impressionist, contemporary, classical) and sometimes free entry. I must say thank you to the gentleman for being a great lover and collector and having everything available in Portugal. The entire foundation, museum, and gardens are really nice. The exhibited works of high quality. Testimony of taste and exceptional wealth of one man who has everything and left Portugal with a diverse museum from Egypt to Lalique through the Middle East, the Impressionists, furniture and objects French art of the eighteenth century, paintings of all schools, etc. A must see if you go to Lisbon.
Must see collection from a great collector. I can tell stories about my visit. But just go there to see a wonderful colleaction of ancient art from the Ottoman empire days and later.
Wonderful paintings. This must rate as one of the best collections I have ever seen. I purchased the book of paintings so I am still re living the experience. The cafe was excellent too.

One man's passion shines through. The travel books advised that this was a must-see in Lisbon. And they were right. The Gulbenkian features an eclectic collection of art from ancient times up through the 20th Century. The museum is beautifully laid out so that each period of art gets to tell its own story. The day we were there it was almost empty, so we got lots of time to reflect on what was on display. Highly recommended!
Beautiful art. collection. Modern building in a garden with water, lillies dun and shadow. Private collection from ancient Egypt to modern times, everything first class. Beautiful impressionists.
Great museaum. Fantastic collection of art and historical pieces - a must see!Several pictures by impressionists, and interesting collections of wall tiles, egyptian pieces and rugs and carpets

One of the don't miss things to do. This private collection is wonderful gift to the people of Portugal. Some amazing Egyptian artefacts, an in depth collection of very ornate French furniture, some outstanding European old masters that you have only read about and may more areas where the best and most beautiful objects have been collected.The highlight for me was the wonderful collection of Lalique jewellery and glassware in Gallery 16.The foundation has an educational arm and Orchestra. there is an Art Library and a wonderful book shop and a range of tasteful gift objects. The admittance price is very cheap and you can save even more with the joint gallery passes
Great museum in the heart of Lisbon. Wonderful artifacts from 2000BC through 18th century. Roman coins, Chinese tapestries, porcelain, paintings, furniture...a great afternoon.

Definitely worth a visit. Bear in mind that this is the private collection of one man so don't expect to find a huge museum or collection. The works on display are very varied - sculptures, paintings, ceramics, tapestry, furniture, jewelry, etc. -, cover all the period from antiquity to modern age and include valuable works from distinguished locations or periods (for example, Persian rugs and Ming Dynasty porcelain) and/or by famous artists (Rubens, Rembrandt, Manet, Monet, Degas, Renoir, Rodin). The exhibition is very well organised and visitors follow a circuit that takes them from Ancient to Contemporary Art, ending with a magnificent exhibition of works by René Lalique. All this for 4€. Definitely not to miss!

It has all been said. Simply the best of everything...the quality of the Greek, Roman and Egyptian artifacts makes them seem as they were just crafted. Remarkable Asian and Middle Eastern pieces as well....well worth a visit.

Art and culture. This is far more than a good art gallery. The special exhibition while we were there explored the history and development of the famous azulejos, the lovely tiles on display all over Portugal. The gallery also offers wonderful concerts on Sundays (when it is free!) and it is even worth a walk through the grounds if you are not interested in art.

Fascinating Private Collection. What was not to like about in this museum. Artefacts from all over the world.The collections of Chinese vases,iranian carpets,paintings,sculptures and fabulous Lalique pieces. I could go on and on.you have to see the collection to believe that one man could have collected such fabulous stuff in his lifetime
Eclectic collection. Always exciting. The collection is excellent. Sometimes they have sunday concerts in the entrance lobby. They're excellent
What treasures. Modern museum with stunning collections especially the LaLique room. Free on Sundays. Good coffee bar.

MUST be in the bucket list. One of the most wonderful museums I have ever seen.
Absolute perfection of exhibits, the best of the best.
Thank you to the collector, Monsieur Gulbenkian, not to collect the "modern" painters.
He did not even collect Picassos :-)
I love this purity of aesthetics.

A must when you visit Lisbon. A great and interesting collection, from different centuries, regions and art forms, beautifully presented in a pleasant building. Also the surrounding park is worth a visit.

Allways a great experience.. I have visited this Museum many times alone and with may pupils and it is allways very interesting. I sugest a morning there, then a walk in the gardens and maybe lunch. If you are so luky to atend to a concert I guess it will be very good.

Good collection, fascinating biography. This museum showcases the collection of "Mr. 5%", an oil tycoon of Armenian descent born in the twilight of the Ottoman empire. He prospered through a genocide (Turks killing Armenians) and two world wars, and amassed the art displayed here. There is something for everyone, from a superb collection of Turkish velvets to a respectable Rubens and Rembrandt, to ostentatiously vulgar silverware. The gardens and the modern buildings in which the museum and foundation are housed are well worth an afternoon.

More interesting than I expected. I visited on the advice of others on this site and I'm glad I did. The museum is small compared to some, but there is a lot to see. Everything there was from the personal collection of one man; I found that to be truly amazing! (I bought a book in the giftshop with the whole backstory). There is a wide variety of articles to look at, from paintings by Monet and Manet, to incredible silver pieces, and the Lalique collection is beautiful. If you go on Sunday admission is free. It's also easy to get to using the metro (subway) system.

A Quality Art Museum in Lisbon. Today,I visited the Foundation Gulbenkian Art Museum located very close to the San Sebastian Metro Station.This art museum has outstanding paintings by very famous masters such as,Rogier Vander Weyden,Frans Hals,Rembrandt("Old Man"),Peter Paul Rubens,Hubert Robert,Francesco Guardi("Feast of Ascension in Piazza San Marco,Venice"),Jean Corot,Eduard Manet,Pierre Renoir,and Claude Monet("Breaking Up of Ice").Personal favorites were:Rembrandt's"Old Man",Bourne-Jones's"Mirror of Venus",Stanislaus Lepine's"L'Estacade",Jean Francois Millet's"Winter",and Claude Monet's"Breaking Up of Ice".This collection is not huge,but of superb quality.I also appreciated their splendid collection of creations by Rene Lalique and fine sculpture by Jean Houdon,Caroeaux,and Alfred Janniot.I also liked their Coromandel Screen from late 17th Century China.There is a fine cafeteria on the oremises and you can sit in the open air and enjoy the gardens.

Beautiful site both content and architecture. Worth the visit. Space and interior organisation, architecture, feeling that you can enjoy freely, no crowd. Even cafeteria is pleasant and not too expensive. Very high quality of what is on display, furniture paintings and sculptures.
Beautiful Lalique jewellery. My favourite of all of Calouste Gulbenkian's collection is Rene Lalique's jewellery. Just the Dragonfly woman is worth the trip to see it in person.
A Jewel of a Museum. A fascinating museum full of a delightful variety of art, furniture, and artifacts. Very interesting collection and a real surprise.

as expected. we were staying at Hotel Italia nearby and got the recommendation from the receptionist. the museum is located inside the garden with classical and modern exhibits. uou can do the whole museum in 90 minutes and go for a coffe outside

Great Collection In A Very Nice Setting. Calouste Gulbenkian was a wealthy oilman ( think the JP Getty Of Portugal) and this museum housing his private collection is very modern and well organized. The collection includes some European masters as well as furnishings and other objects. In addition there is a large Asian collection as well. It is near the large park and relatively easy to find. We walked from Central Lisbon but opted for a taxi back.A nice cafe with indoor/outdoor seating is on site.
Good Collection. Is a must to go place. Just in the other side of Spain Square with the underground near. You will see there one of the best museums in Portugal.

Beautiful inside and out. Fabulous setting and building perfectly setting off the amazing range of artefacts and artwork within. Paintings ranging from Rembrandt to Manet's Boy Blowing Bubbles and a wonderful exhibition of decorative tiles through the ages. Not to be missed.

Lovely space. This is a great museum in a lovely mid century building within a park in Lisbon. Really well laid out and interesting exhibits that are well displayed. A cool and tranquil escape from the noonday sun.

free on sundays. the museum is free on sundays but you still need to ask for a ticket. modern building in a modern park, but contents from past centuries. don't expect to find anything Portuguese in there though!

One of the finest museums in the world. It's so easy to find your way around the Gulbenkian as you get to sample fine representations of ancient Egypt, Chinese pottery, persian and Turkish rugs, Impressionist paintings and ending with the most spectacular Lalique jewelry I've ever seen.You can do the whole museum in 90 minutes too.

Well worth a visit. Something for most tastes whether it be classical, traditional or modern art. Close to Metro station but not very well signposted. We went round many sides of a major road junction before we found the correct road

Free on Sunday. Very good collection, beautifully displayed in an interesting building, set in a park.Entry is free on Sundays, when there are often also high quality chamber concerts. Very good café with outdoor terrace and good shop.

Great museum. This museum is actually divided into two buildings that are separated by a beautiful garden. The Modern Art is in one building and the more historic collections are in another. You have to go around the site on the external walk to move between the two buildings - there did not appear to be a connection via the garden. You can purchase a ticket for one or all of the exhibits. It took about 3 hours to go through - but the time would vary depending upon your interests. The Lalique was amazing.

great visit this museum is a must see.. we went on a Sunday, was free admissions to all exhibtions,staff were terrific all seemed to understand English. we walked through the magnificent sensory gardens to the modern art museum a " must see" for all ages. wonderful permanent exhibitions especially in ceramics,porcelains,and textiles in main museum and great food in the beautiful cafeteria good value too.were there for four hours .will return on next visit to Lisbon

GO- JUDGE FOR YOURSELF. This is a very nice museum with items displayed in a roomy manner. However to me it's just another museum . I guess I just don't appreciate history and art as much as I should. Go-give it a try and judge for yourself.
Go to Lisbon just for the Gulbenkian!. This is a treasure trove of art, artifacts and other collectibles from all over the world. Spend a day here, the gardens are also incredible.

Good but Wasn't Wowed. Don't get me wrong—this is a very nice museum, and I very much enjoyed one of the temporary exhibits there. But I read so many reviews that said it was one of Europe's best museums, that I was a little disappointed. This is not on a par with Europe's best museums like the Prado or the D'Orsay or even the two small Picasso museums in Paris and Barcelona. I much more enjoyed Lisbon's smaller, more intimate Tile and Fado Museums. If I only had a few days in Lisbon, I would skip this. If you have five days or more, knock yourself out! P.S. They have a pretty good cafe with a nice patio.
superb collection. the best and only the best. amazing collection of art treasures of amazing quality spanning 4,500 years in time. the japanese inzo boxes alone are worth visit

2 hours well spent. Smaller than I expected (it only took me 2 hours to go around and I am normally slower than most as I do take my time – if you tend to whizz around these sorts of places you might do it in an hour) but really good. Not the kind of stuff you’d expect one man to collect, more the stuff a national museum would. Loads of top artists are included such as Rembrandt, Rubens, Monet, Manet & Turner. The Lalique collection is small but beautiful. Very fine furniture and ancient artifacts from different regions.

Easy to spend lots of time in. The Lalique Room is worth the entrance money on it's own, loved the Syrian glass, Persian rugs , French sculpture and the Pre -Raphaelite ,Impressionist and Post Impressionist art. Selection of merchandise in shop disappointing. Rather nice café, but very busy over lunchtimes. Audio guide Ok, but some commentaries aren't any more informative than the notices by the display cases.

An Oasis in Central Lisbon. The Museum itself is wonderful - and the temporary exhibits such as the current one on "The Splendor of Cities - the Route of the Tile can be magical. The museum is without charge on Sunday and very reasonable otherwise. Don't miss the cafeteria - a serene terrace overlooking the park-like grounds - and the gift shop!

Inspiring.... Interesting collection, focused on the cultures, which are not so known and popular for us Europeans, like from Turkey, Persia, Middle East region. The display units are very good exhibited and the collection does`t make any fatigue for the visitors. Highly recommended to spent the interesting two hours.

Eclectic. What a great museum and what a treat to walk around viewing the exhibits without competing with crowds of people.The afternoon we were there the place was practically empty and there were more museum staff than visitors.A truly magnificent collection;if you're interested in paintings,sculpture,ceramics,tapestry tou will not be disappointed.
An incredible collection. We were rushed due to our poor planning. However, in one hour visit we were impressed by their incredible collection. Definitely worth a visit.

High quality museum. This was one of the first sites we visited in Portugal. We managed to see most of the museum in about 2 hours. We liked the variety of the collections..sculptures, gardens, beautiful furniture, artwork, even a temporary exhibit on Muslim art and a special exhibit with more modern ceramic pieces. There is a nice cafe with outdoor patio seating if you need to take a break.

Remarkable Collection. A lifetime collection of art and antiquity by an oil baron. The collection was brought to safety from Paris to Lisbon at the onset of WWII, and put on public display in 1969. It is candidly acknowledged that the collection represents Gulbenkian's personal tastes. It's arranged geographically and chronologically, but I'm not sure how else it could be done. It just seems a bit rigid. The works are simply overwhelming, worthy of any large public museum. The staff seemed distracted and diffident; if their behavior is typical of the security standards, this is a major heist waiting to happen. Senior tix are 2 euro each-best bargain in town. A must-see in Lisbon.
art. the hotel is within walking distance from the ibis and was so comprehensive in its collection.top notch.

So much to see!. Gorgeous grounds and a museum filled with a wealth of beautiful art crossing centuries. Make sure you walk through the gardens and take in the neighborhood, so different from most of Lisbon.
Amazing. Fantastic collection of art works, amazing to think they belonged to one man. Beautifully laid out. Go on a Sunday it's free!

A treasure chest. I loved this museum. It's literally offering the cream of the crop in terms of museum collections. The René Lalique collection is exquisite. A great size to visit but not tire yourself out. V nice cafe too.

Cool museum. This was actually a pretty cool museum to visit (and I'm not an overly huge fan of being in lots of museums). It was interesting, had some very cool old tiles, Arab art, Asian art - just a good mix of interesting stuff. We visited it on Sunday so it was free - as many of the museums are free on Sundays. It is worth going, and very easy short walk from the nearest metro station.

Nice but not what we expected.. We arrived on a Sunday morning in mid October and the admission was free. The park surrounding the museum was wonderful. Green and secluded with lots of benches to sit on and a small pond full of ducks and sunbathing turtles. The collection was nice but nothing amazing. The items were spread thin, as if there wasn't enough to really fill the space. It is something to do if you have time to kill or the weather is bad but we would not recommend it.

Wow, just wow.. This is my second visit as I'm a Rene Lalique nut. The museum is just the most wonderful collection of ceramics, decorative objects and religious devotional objects..... Oh and of course the most exquisite Lalique jewellery. It was as good as I remembered. No, in fact it was better. It is well worth a visit for those who love looking at beautiful things.

nice art museum. This place is very well presented and is worth the visit. Do not expect to view local art. The pieces exposed are of very good quality and simply presented to enhance their spirit. Nice visit

don't bother.... I found it quit uninteresting actually - random collection of items from around the world. seen similar stuff at a hundred museums before... only the two Rembrandts caught my attention

Well displayed, small collection of art works and decorative objects. Superbly assembled and displayed collection, doesn't take all day to look around. This had been one of our must-sees and did not disappoint at all. Very pleasant grounds to stroll around too.

The most beautiful and quiet garden in Lisbon. I love Gulbenkian! There is no other great place to go if you want to read, pray, lay down and relax. There are all kinds of animals around, university students chilling out and the environment is just great. It is a very safe park. Also the museum is outstanding and worthy of your time. The library is great if you want to have a quiet place where to work on something. There is free wi-fi.
Beautiful setting. The collection is impressive, but the setting is magnificent!! Take some time to walk around the buildings.

Quite simply - do not miss it. A modern museum, beautifully laid out with exquisite things.It's free (but busy) on Sundays and is a way from the centre of Lisbon, but taxis are plentiful or if you don't mind a walk the metro station is about 7 minutes away.

Don't miss this very special museum. This museum has it all and you don't have to spend all day to see everything. Incredible items - furniture, paintings, sculpture, beautiful gardens - everything. Inexpensive and they offer senior discounts.
Excellent museum. Wonderful small museum in a scenic setting. Definitely a must in Lisbon. Cameras are allowed but no flash.

Gulbenkian museum. On a very wet morning in Lisbon but staying within a half an hour walk we thought we ought to see this museum. I have to say it was stunning. For a start it was a Sunday and we got in for free, there was a convenient bag and coat drop and then the museum itself was wonderful. Full of amazing antiques all beautifully displayed with plenty of space for everyone to have time to stand and have a long look without feeling hassled in any way.You would need to spend at least 2 hours there and then there was an excellent restaurant in which to rest ,your by then, weary legs!
Great gardens, ice cream, jazz amd art museum. Great gardens full of peacefull, jazz in August, great ice creams during hot afternoons and the modern art museum

A super museum, and free on Sunday too!. This gem was just around the corner from our hotel, and a lovely place to spend a couple of hours on a Sunday. There was a great mix of exhibits, all beautifully displayed and lit. There didn't seem to be a problem about taking photos, which is unusual but very refreshingly relaxed. The gardens were lovely too.
a small welcoming museum. The Lalique exhibition was world standard and the overall collection is amazing. Lisbon owes Calouste Gulbenkian a big debt of gratitiude
Nice museum. This was a very nice museum, they had a lot of art and I really liked the wood floors it made the museum look fancy.

One of the great treasure houses of Europe. I have visited Lisbon many times and always promised myself a visit to the Gulbenkian. Food and fado have generally taken priority on short trips. But this time I devoted a whole afternoon to the museum. This has to be one of the greats of the world, housing the collection (or a mere fifth of it) amassed by the Armenian billionaire Calouste Gulbenkian and willed to Portugal (and the world) on his death. The notable thing is the perfect condition of the exhibits, from Greek vases to Persian rugs and old master paintings. Give yourself three hours to see and enjoy it all and then proceed to the coffee shop. Ticket to the museum costs, in September 2013, only 4 euros or 2 euros for seniors. The best 2 euros I have ever spent !!!!

Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian. The Foundation is housed in a fabulous building: 60's architecture at it's most outstanding, and surrounded by an excellent garden. The permanent exhibition is always of interest. The cultural programme is always exceptional. A number one destination for visitors and locals alike.

more of the same. Although my title seems disappointing, it is just to state from the start, that the collections in the Gulbenkian museum are large by itself. I mean to say that viewing a few vases, dito carpets, silver bowls, ore whatever, will do to get the impression on the subject. This is not so in paintings, coins and sculptures; they are very different. I found the Gulbenkian museum really worth visiting, but especially for the very special objects, like the extremely beautiful sculpture of Diana by Houdon, and the various paintings by several artists. The museum has collections of surprising subjects, and is thus rather varied, but many objects are, to my opinion, not too interesting. Nice to see, but I found it hard to see the real beauty in eg. the chinese lions. The collection is very large, and in my opinion, some items could be set aside as they are more of the same. Not another dish, I recall having thougt. But just bare in mind, that this collection is worth seeing, and for 4 euro's you have a couple of hours of real artistic experience, and if you are over 65 years old, you get a 50% reduction, so come on you vital old art-lovers ! ps I'm not a real museum fanatic... but I wanted to be surprised, and I was.
Beautiful art collection. Amazing private collection from Calouste Gulbenkian. Included in this collection were paintings, porcelain, silver,glass,jewelry, furniture, all presented beautifully.

A fantastic collection! Really worth spending some hours on!. A fantastic variety of 6000 pcs of antigue and modern art. Old ceramics, porcelain, furniture, carpets and beautyfull paintings by Rembrandt, Monet, Renoir and many others great painters.The variety and beauty is the attraction.Entrances free some times - I think Sundays.

The great and rich private collection - now for public. The private collection of Armenian businessman Calouste Gulbenkian is very different - it includes Greco-Roman art, Egyptian art, "Art of the Book", Eastern Islamic Art, etc. Maybe this is one of the most impressive museums of Lisbon.

Superb. One of the best museums we have ever visited. World class in terms of quality of items on show and the way in which they were displayed. Porcelain, silverware, marbles, Japanese lacquer work, Turkish rugs, tapestries, European paintings, illuminated missals, furniture, Lalique glass and jewellery. One man, Calouste Gulbenkian, spent his life collecting nothing but the best, and it shows! The contents must be the envy of almost every other national museum. Worth the trek from Belem by bus and metro.

A MASTERPIECE FOR CULTURE. When someone arrives to Lisbon, where they go? The usual "tourist attractions", of course: Jeronimos, Torre de Belem, Castelo de São Jorge, Alfama, Bairro Alto, Parque das Nações and Oceanário, 28 Tramway, etc.Why not go, shal I call it, "upstairs"?Up from Marquês de Pombal roundabout to "New Avenues".Get Saldanha, down Avenida 5 de Outubro (paralel to Avenida da República), turn left to Praça de Espanha, and you find yourself just in front of Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian, the REAL Department of Culture in Portugal. Not speaking the daily events (exhibits, concerts, lectures), you can walk on the magnificent gardens drawn by portuguese best landscape arthitect , Ribeiro Telles, anda find two of the best world museums of art which shows pieces from Ancient Egypt to modern artists. The Gulbenkian Museum shows paintings and sculptures from 3.000 B.C. to XX century artists.The Museum of Modern Art shows the work of contemporary artists, mainly portuguese.You'll be fascinated and amazed.So, when arriving in Lisbon, don´t miss this tip.

Good collection; nice museum. Liked the collection; nice selection of Eastern objects; very well displayed in a nice building. Adequate labels and information. Very nice cafeteria to enjoy a break during the visit.

Great private collection given to the public. An Arab oil man's private collection: the best of everything from BCE to Lalique. Impressionists, Rodin sculptures, Oriental carpets, ancient coins, Chinese ceramics, furniture.

A simply stunning collection!. A museum evolved from a fabulous private art collection. Eclectic, focused collecting by a very rich man, who knew what he liked. If there is nothing here that pleases you, then you must be brain dead. The highlights for me were the Gaudis, Turners, the Peacock silk wall hanging and the exquisite Lalique jewelry. This museum houses the best private art collection I have ever seen.

A Connoisseur's Collection - Simply Superb!. A visit to the Gulbenkian Museum was at the top of my list when I recently visited Lisbon, so when friends were off to see St. George's Castle and its spectacular view, I spent time here. I wasn't sorry. The collection offers insights into the eye of the connoisseur. Each object is the best possible of its type, with quality and condition outstanding. This museum is a feast for the senses and one that you shouldn't miss.The collection ranges from Ancient Egyptian to Medieval and Renaissance painting to Chinese ceramics and eighteenth century French furnishings and decorative arts. There are outstanding eighteenth and nineteenth century European paintings and a fine selection of Art Nouveau jewelry and glass by Rene Lalique. The Islamic art and textiles are outstanding.Not only is the collection fantastic, but the building and gardens shine and set the tone for the artworks. There is plenty of space and the museum doesn't seem crowded even though many people are there. Don't miss this jewel-box of a museum.
Great taste of art. Great taste of art, especially the islamic part. It's really great to visit a private collection of art once in a while, like this place or Albertina in Vienna.
Best of the best. This is a fairly small collection - but of wide ranging eras and cultures and superb quality. Beautifully curated.
Gulbenkian. Not the most exciting museum and it was further from our hotel than we thought so the walk was a bit long.

September 2013 visit. I had long ago heard of this museum and so a visit to Lisbon had to include a visit. I was not disappointed. The ticket price was extremely reasonable, progress through the museum was simple. The only exhibit that was almost overlooked by my companion until I pointed it out was the Lalique room, This could benefit from better signage. Overall, however, this is an outstanding attraction with a well-stocked bookshop and an excellent and reasonably-priced self-service restaurant. But a word of warning, we were wise to take lunch relatively early. As we were leaving the queue was extremely long. The gardens are delightful and well worth a visit, though signs pointing visitors to them could have been more prominently displayed.
Amazing gift to Portugal. It is so eclectic. The collection includes items from Egypt; Rembrandt, Monet, Gainsborough paintings; Asian glass ware, Turkish carpets, sculpture, and on and on
Excellent art collection. Art to suit all tastes. Well organised route through the exhibits. Cost 4 euros.Gardens can be of interest to bird enthusiasts.

A must visit museum. The Gulbenkian collection is high quality, and not huge. The highlights for me are the collection of Egyptian material, izhnik pottery, french furniture, and Lalique. The building is quite modern and works well to showcase the collection.
The modern art museum a short walk away is quite lovely with a broad collection of modern works.

Interesting and Enjoyable. The collection is varied and very interesting. The museum is well designed and you comfortably stroll through wide and well explained ( in several languages) exhibits. We went on a Sunday and there was no cost. I don't know if that is true every hSunday or we were just lucky.

Grest place to visit, when in Lisbon. In the city center, this is a great place to spend time and enjoy yhe art works, statues and the beautiful gardens. When looking for Culture, this is a place to visit!

Like the Getty, but much more personal. Wonderfully displayed personal items of someone who could afford the best of what was available. In some ways like the Burrell collection. The surrounding garden is lovely. One of the highlights of our visit.

well worth 2 euros. From outside it looks quite small, however you will surprised by the scale of display. Stage one is pottery, all excellent, but a special mention to the Turkish designs. I think these Turkish designs are where William Morris got his inspiration from. Forget the period furniture unless you are a fan of Louis XV1 onwards, I would give it a miss. The modern painting galleries are well worth seeing. Turner Degas Monet and Pre-Raphaelites includes a very large Burn-Jone Final area we liked was the Lalique collection of glass and jewelry. Brilliant.
A truly memorable experience. The museum is cool and spacious and there is a treasure trove of art to be experienced. If I could only visit one location in Lisbon, this would be my choice!

Outstanding Personal collection. I was not interested in spending my first afternoon in Lisbon indoors at a museum, but I completely enjoyed the experience. The entrance fee was modest, especially for senior citizens. Lisbon is very fortunate to have this collection.
An amazing and diverse collection. The museum has a very interesting collection (all donated by one person after ww II) that covers centuries and diverse geographies.

World class!. A brilliant collection - especially the Iranian and Ottoman art. Who says Islamic art cannot be wonderful? Both geometric and figurative Islamic work.European section is pretty good too - we liked a whole room of Guardi's scenes of Venice, and the Lalique early 20th century glass! Superb.
Nice Collection. It is a nice Museum where you can get an overview not only of European, but also of Asian art and culture.

The one museum to see in Lisbon. This museum is housed in a modern gallery next to the Gulbenkian Foundation. It has a spectacular collection of asian and greco roman art that will documented. The middle eastern collection is fantastic and also a fine European collection. The cafeteria is wonderful for the tired museum goer or for anyone else.
A must see in Lisbon. Certainly not the world's largest museum, but really very good and worthwhile. Impressive collections of Near Eastern and Oriental art. Interesting furniture collection.

Must see. The garden, the museum, the restaurant, the shows. All deserve a visit (or more).
An amazing Art Nouveau collection on the permanent exibition.

World class exhibition space. This collection is an excellent mixture of museum and art gallery, with enough on show to suit lovers of both. I only had an hour or so there before it closed, but it was easily worth the 2 Euro entry fee! [Over-65. Full price is only 4] The museum stands in a leafy park, and the inside space is large and stylish and makes the best of the exhibits. I personally loved the European art section, with Monets, Manets, Millets, Gainsboroughs and lots more, but the oriental tapestries silks and porcelain are amazing as well. If you like furniture or clocks there'll be enough to keep you interested, and there's a stunning Lalique collection as well. Just a short stroll from Sao Sebastiao Blue Line Metro station [and El Corte Ingles]. Not to be missed.
A personal collection in a custom built setting. This was a world class collection of art in a very modern building set in an interesting park. Well worth the visit.

Freely beautiful gardens, museum and collection ~ on a Sunday!. As the title says . . . .Well worth the visit, with varied items to suit most tastes if you have an enquiring mind.The buffet lunch was at a good price also, showing how much the Museum respects its visitors. Well done and many thanks.

one of the best of lisbon. during my long stay in lisbon i had enough time to visit some of the most recommended museums in the city and i can tell you this in one of the best i've seen.the hotel is easy to locate, it's in a very beautiful park which i also advise you to see.the collections presented here are from a very vast period of time - ancient to our days, and from different cultures. if you plan to stay in this part of the city for at least a couple of hours i also advise you to visit the dr. anastacio goncalves museum-house. although you may not find anything about it in your guide, check it on tripadvisor.

Stunning museum. Beautiful things displayed in a wonderful space. Apart from the obvious artwork and the lalique glass, I was blown away by the collection of velvet (I am determined to find some vintage velvet curtains/fabric for my house now!) and ceramic tiles. Beggars belief to think that this is just the top-end of an individuals collection but I am very grateful that I got to enjoy it. Unfortunately I missed out on the temporary exhibitions by a few days but the combo entry ticket with the Modern Art Centre next door was still well worth it.

Lalique; a glass act. This is an outstanding museum and art gallery, a fabulous collection sympathetically displayed. Stroll through the gardens first to wind down from the noise and pace of the city. The visit will be worth it for the Lalique collection alone - craftsmanship and style beyond ordinary imagination. It is free on Sundays too.

A bit of this, a bit of that..... Note that the cute duck working the pond in front takes a lunch break at your table at the snack bar outdoor area! Bring some "quackers"! Dont miss the LALIQUE on the way out. Check out the modern art building next door and the great garden.
Outstanding. Wonderful museum in a great park setting. The collection is absolutely outstanding with only top quality paintings and decorative arts.

Worth a visit, get the audio. This museum has a little of everything. Paintings of portraits and landscapes, sculptures, furniture, jewels, pottery, carpets, tiles, hair clips and pins are arranged beautifully in several different rooms that are laid out so you can walk from one to the next.I did the audio tour and thought it was worthwhile. For 4 Euros you hear a little info about chosen pieces (about 20% or less have audio information).The cafeteria is not pricey with a good lunch. The gardens are also worth a walk through.I did this in 1/2 a day but you could easily make a day out of it. The surrounding area is a nice part of the city to walk around and shop also!
A must. Great building housing a fantastic collection with the Lalique being the prime attraction.the paintings are a history of art in themselves.The coffee shop is reasonable and worth a visit.

impressive. You will be surprised to see many great works of art here: Renoir, Monet, Manet among others. You'll also see some Egyptian artefacts, a wonderful collection of tiles, Persian and Chinese art. There's also an impressive collection of Rococo furniture. The entrance fee is very reasonable.

Incredible tiles and carpets. I am a carpet and tile junkie. I was so overcome by the beauty of the Persian, Turkish, Syrian and Indian tiles and carpets it bought a tear to my eyes. A lot of earlier tiles 15-16 th century, which are obviously hard to come by and very rare. I've not seen a collection like this before. Beautifully laid out. Did not get audio guide,but would have been a good idea as very little description of each item other than the title and date. Rest of the museum was good too, Egyptian, Chinese, paintings. Got around in 1 hour, as I was on a schedule. Go! Even if you have less time. Not to be missed. Better than the National Tile Museum in my view, but I like the more intricate tiles, and less of the pictorial style. Taxis are also very easy to get, not like back from the Tile Museum.

For contemporary art lovers. It is a very good museum. You will be surprised by their own collection and also you can visit seasonal exhibitions. They have a good library where you can buy good books.

Stunning. What an astounding collection of art, jewellery, archeological finds, manuscripts, orgnaments, furniture etc etc. this was one of the best things about Lisbon for me. The surrounding garden is very lovely to wander in too.

A must!. Jewel of a museum. Beautiful modern building in a park-like campus-like setting with wifi. Only four euros and likely two if you are 66. Specific highlights for me were the art nouveau mirror, Parisian silver service wear, Lalique jewels to wear, Turkish pottery, Japanese boxes.
good value. Great collection of persian art. Well worth seeing. Not a huge place so very manageable for a two hour visit.

Excellent Eclectic Lisbon Art Museum. Excellent eclectic art museum in Lisbon; collection ranges from Greco--Roman to French Impressionists. Closest U.S. counterpart might be Barnes Collection, but this collection is more comprehensive, including furniture and other objects in addition to paintings. Well worth a couple of hours visit. In "new" part of Lisbon; not close to main tourist areas.

Classic & Modern heritage. Great environment , fantastic collection from Europe and Middle east but less than expected in Modern section.
Museum's external area is also very attractive and look like a big Park, a Must See in Lisbon for art lovers and families.
Wonderful museum. A museum built from the personal collection of Calouste Gulbenkian, with splendid architecture and lovely gardens around it.

After all the reading on TripAdvisor, still a surprise!. I had an half day left in Lisbon and did not really want to spend it here, I spent some time looking for photos on Google images about the exhibitions and I wasn't impressed.. but eventually I went and.. wow.. it was really good! The exhibition mixes artifacts and paintings of all ages and cultures. What makes it exceptional is the selection. The ancient artifacts are preserved in outstanding ways. There's a large number of ancient Greek and Roman coins that seemed to come out of my wallet, like new. I was also really struck by ancient jewellery in almost perfect shape. Chinese pots are also breathtaking. The second part of the exhibition is about medieval and modern art, again a beautiful collection. I was really impressed by the Breton Women at a Pardon painting, it looks like a photo.Overall, I gave myself a back pat for deciding to come here. Don't miss it, it's a cornerstone in Lisbon. Only minor issue, slightly expensive. Not too much less than 10 euros if I remember correctly.

Worth Your Time. Children under 12 are free. Students under 25 and visitors over 65 get 50% off. We spent the morning in Lisbon with a local guide to go to Belem, the stagecoach museum, and to view sights of Lisbon. We had a free afternoon before leaving Lisbon and I asked for her recommendation on how to spend the afternoon. She did not hesitate to recommend the Gulbenkian museum. This museum had an extensive collection of Egyptian, Greco-Roman, Mesopotamian, Eastern Islamic, Armenian and Far Eastern Art. There's also European Art with many pieces of sculpture, painting and decorative arts. There's a separate section with pieces by René Lalique. It was well worth my afternoon.

World class collection. This is a stunning collection, reminded me of the Frick or Burrell collection (Glasgow) in a purpose built building set in a peaceful shady garden/park. My favourites were the 5th century BC Greek vase (it took the English until at least the 18th century to create anything as exquisite!) and the selection of beautiful velvets would certainly recommend any textile/ fashion designers to go and visit for inspiration. There's also some beautiful paintings - a Rembrandt, Rubens,Turner, Gainsborough, Manet,Monet, Degas et al. Rodin sculptures..... It takes 2-3 hours to view. Had lunch in the basement cafe €6.60 for a main case and soft drink. There is also gift shop which sells tasteful reasonably priced products all related to items in the collection. Across the road from a Metro station "Praca de Espanha" All the exhibits are labelled in Portuguese and English and there are guides available in other languages. Admission was €4.00 The gardens surrounding the museum are worth a stroll around and offer plenty of shade.

Well laid out.. Good variety of art works, pottery and carpets. I am not be an art guru hence the average rating. Good freshly cooked food in the restaurant. Please be aware they do not allow backpacks in and if you wish to leave at reception they take no liability. If like myself you carry quite a bit of photographic equipment it meant having to go back on a different day with no backpack.
Worth a visit.. A nice Museum, not crowded, surrounded by a nice, quiet park.A tipical personal, eclectic collection. It has a fantastic Turner.

Fabulous collection of Lalique. This museum contains a wonderful collection of paintings, rugs, pottery, furniture, sculpture, ancient Greek coins, illuminated books and many other items, but my favorite was the collection of pieces by Rene Lalique. Not only were there examples of his glass, but also jewelry, decorative items such as combs and belt buckles and some of his preliminary drawings. The museum was not crowded on the day we visited (July 2013) so it was easy to see the exhibits.

I like the garden and the museum. I go there whenever I can because it is such a nice place to go, rest, read, have a pic nic, see exhibitions...It is in the midle of the city but it doesnt feel like.The garden is good for people who like trees.

One of the best museums in the world. This is truly a special place and should be seen not only for its extraordinary collection (one man : forty years : seven thousand objects : a sure instinct for quality and beauty : an exceptionally discerning taste) but also for the beautiful architecture and the seamless interweaving of buildings and garden. Dedicate at least two to three hours to see the collection and then wander around in the garden. There are several cafés with indoor and terrace seating. Another significant advantage was that even in mid-August this museum was half empty... a real respite from the more crowded tourist areas in Lisbon.
Place to visit, Sundays free. Beautiful collection of art. Exhibition of photographs Present Tense is not to be missed. Close to Gulbenkian Museum,if possible make it in one trip.

Must visit museum. This is one of the best museums I have ever benn to. Absolutely stunning private collection in one place. Paintings of Manet, Monet, Rubens, Turner; beautiful carpets, pottery, silver. Ans amazing collection of Lalique jewelry and glass. The museum is surrounded by beautiful gardens where you can walk after your visit. It is closed on Mondays,just like any other museum in Lisbon, and Sundays entrance is free. Cafeteria offers good food. You need at least 3 hours for your vistit.
One of the best city oasis. Incredible garden in the center of Lisbon. Perfect for a quiet walk and to have some quality time far from the city traffic.

Must see!. This is one of the best museums I have ever been to. The exhibits are very well laid out. The collection is outstanding. There is something to appeal to everyone. While looking at the collection you can look out the windows and see the lovely gardens. I was surprised that it was not more crowded. We ate in the cafeteria which was pleasant.

One of the finest collections in Europe. The Gulbenkian houses one of the finest collections of European and Asian art in Europe. The Islamic art is particularly extensive. And the gardens that surround the museum as such a wonderfully peaceful oasis from the busy city that surrounds. If you get a chance, take in an outdoor concert. And the other museum of modern art is really worth a visit.

Loved it, Free on Sunday, Art lovers will not be disappointed. The Lalique jewelry is like nothing I have ever seen and the sheer depth of impressionists, oriental pottery and art, tapestries, coins, romantic sculpture, Art Deco furniture, French Imperial furniture and clocks, it is so worth a visit, even if you pay, it will be worth the price of admission, it was one of the real highlights of a 2 week trip to Portugal.

A collection of items. This is one of the richest museums in the world. There is really something for everyone. My biggest gripe was how to get to the entrance. The signposting through the gardens is hopeless. If we hadn't walked all round Lisbon for two days it would have been quite pleasant but not when our feet already hurt. Inside I likes the beautiful illuminated manuscripts and the paintings. But my daughter was quite bored with most of it. Free on sundays

One of the most beautiful private collection. All kinds of styles, periods, objects.The private collection of Gulbenkian (foundation) is very impressive, as it contains objects, paintings, rugs, pieces of furnitures of great artists.The museum building has nothing special, but the collection is worth the visit.
Worth a look. Free on sunday. Lots of interesting stuff. Some beautiful and some plain weird. The Chinese pottery is stunning.

Fantastic small museum. Magnificent small museum, extremely well organized, in a short visit you can have a fantastic overview of the history of art. Ggreat oriental collection and at the top of everything there are few first class paintings: Rembrandt, Degas, Monet. Not crowded and quiet, for this reason I loved small museums.

a stunning personal collection. Set in a beautiful park, the Gulbenkian Museum is testimony to great wealth allied with great good taste. It is a personal collection, not an attempt at a comprehensive collection, and therefore uneven at times (e.g., one extraordinary Rembrandt, one mediocre Rembrandt). The Middle Eastern rooms are utterly amazing and contain a dazzling array of 16th-century carpets and 16th-century Iznik pottery. The Guardi collection is wonderful, and the Lalique collection at the end is an eye-opener.Just go!

A must for culture vultures. This is a must for art lovers in Lisbon. It is an art musuem housed in an architect designed gallery in an interesting landscape, with beautiful spaces to house the collection of Calouste Gulbenkian, Born in Cappadocia, he eventually lived in Paris where his collections were developed. It is worth reading about how the collections came to be in Lisbon. Fascinating story of war, trust and diplomacy. The collection includes an array of paintings by Rubens, Van Dyck, Frans Hals, Rembrandt, Guardi, Gainsborough, Fragonard, Corot, Renoir, Manet, Degas and Monet. A highlight is the marble original of Houdon's famous Diana, Collections of Egyptian, Greco-Roman, Mesopotanian, Islamic and Armenian Art are exhibited beautifully. Decorative arts with a stunning collection of Lalique jewellery and objets are also on display. It is free on Sunday mornings so worth waiting for this opportunity. The cafe is very good with a range of hot and cold foods- just beware of the hungry ducks on the terrace! And the shop has lovely cards and select gifts. A must do in Lisbon.
Beautiful. We chose to visit the classic portion of the exhibit. Took us a little over two hours a nd everyone enjoyed it. Even the teenagers, surprisingly. Low cost entrance and worth the trip.

one of the best art collection. This foundation/museum is definitely of of the best places i've visited , all the pieces exposed are perfect , the architecture is smooth and beautifully integrated in the gardens , even the food at the cafeteria is good.a place to visit more than once.

lalique! wow. comparing to most of the European museums its not a great deal BUT if you like Lalique jewels its a must. Gulbenkian used to be a close friend of him and has probably one of the best collections of lalique pieces. the gardens are also very nice. there is a modern art museum that has the best collection of Portuguese modern paintings
A remarkable art collection.. A complete and extensive find art collection in different areas and eras, such as painting, tapestry, jewelry, ceramic, inside a beautiful garden park in Lisbon center.

A must-see. One of the greatest art collections not only in Portugal but worldwide. Concise, yet very representative. Most objects d'art are top notch. Spacious rooms, lovely grounds, and a very good cafe as a bonus.

An unexpected treasure. The quality of the collection is remarkable. He had excellent advise in collecting. I teach art history and have never seen a coin collection in such mint condition. This should be the first stop when going to Lisbon
Culture in Lisbon. Remarkable cultural place to visit in Lisbon, with museum and exhibitions maintaned by the reputable Gulbekian Foundation.

Quality exhibits. This museum isn't as big as some of the museums in other capital cities, but I think the balance between quantity and quality of exhibits is just right. All the exhibits have interest, not like some museums where there is too much to take in. There is great variety in a small space, not rows and rows of similar exhibits. Admission is eu4 (students eu2), and you can see a lot for your money.The museum is not central or particularly close to other attractions or metro, also not paricularly well signposted. We found it with a sat nav, but a taxi ride wouldn't be expensive from central Lisbon.

Worth visiting. Not so well known this well funded museum has a great permanent collection of art and often has special exhibitions from around the world. Located close to Plaza de Espanha it is only a 10 minute taxi ride from the center of Lisbon

Stunning Museum. The Gulbenkian Museum features fabulous objects and paintings, beautifully mounted, in a lovely building surrounded by gardens and pools. Although relatively small, the Gulbenkian is a real gem.
A private museum, ex-libris of Lisbon. Really beautiful, enchanting gardens, well organised. I always go there both for the permanent and for the temporary exhibits.
Gulbenkian. So well laid out and so interesting with a wide variety of displays, like all the Gulbenkian museums.

The right size!. It's a wonderful museum! It has a bit of everything! If you're not fan of giant museums, probally you'll like this one. It's much smaller than Louvre and Prado, however it has a great variety of pieces of art and history.

Nice museum. We visited on a Sunday when it was free -- a great value and it was still not crowded at all. It is an interesting mix of paintings, furniture, vases, and sculpture from different cultures and time periods.

Interesting. Amazing garden, And very impressive photos of Africa. The Museun was nice. maybe some parts were closed. What was impressive is a show of photos from nowaday Africa. Shocking, worth the effort. A true social document!!! and the garden around the garden was amazing.

Not just the collection. I had read that this museum is worth a visit - and it was. Unusual collection of rare and very fine pieces of art - everything from Persian "flying" carpets from 17th century to european Art Deco jewelry (20th century) - and paintings by Rembrandt and Manet...The building itself is a modern concrete building that somehow fits very well in the jungle-like park and gives a very nice background for all kinds of art. We really enjoyed also the contemporary exhibition of very new African photos by several young photographers. You need time for this museum ! And sit some time in the park or the cafe...
Loved it. Terrific collection of Lalique jewellery - best I have ever seen. gallery not too busy. Hard to find and not well signposted. Good bookshop.

Very diverse exhibition. Greek coins to french impressionists. Entertaining variety of art and handcrafts. We liked the park and the building. Free on Sundays and not too crowded. Unfortunately there is no portugese context....

Museums. This is a fine museum. It has different buildings dedicated to different periods. You need a whole morning to see it. It is situated on the new part of town near the shopping centre El Corte Ingles.
What a Collection!. The collection is not only fascinating and extensive, each item is beautifully displayed. Free on Sunday, we discovered.
superb collection and cafe. always worth a visit when in Lisbon. Excellent combination of quality and quantity - went to cafe for first time. Really good find

Not sure why people love this place. Let's just say if I had the resources of Mr. Gulbenkian, I would have chosen very different art. There are many little jewels like this in cities all over the world--a wealthy private collector's vision. This felt a little like he hired someone to amass for him a little of everything. Lots of stuff, but nothing great and incohesive. It was a pleasant escape from the heat, but not an outstanding collection.

A wide range of exhibits. You would be unlikely to visit for the building, which is nevertheless set in a pleasant park. There are, however, some fascinating items amongst a wide range of exhibits.I like the idea of a personal collection - and I loved the Thyssen-Bornemisza in Madrid, for example, but there weren't enough surprises / highlights here for me. I left feeling slightly disappointed. Maybe it was a lack of colour, or sensuality, or something - it is hard to pinpoint. Why would I expect to have the same taste as an oil magnate anyway, I wonder?

Interesting place for a couple hours. Enjoyed looking at all of the old furniture, get the subway to sao sebastian and its a short walk from there....and buy figs from the lady outside the station...best ive ever had!

One of the best. Once you are inside you won't want to leave the place.It offers for free: exhibition, a beautiful park.You can also book shows, it receives the best singers/players in the world (classical, jazz, etc.)
Great place !!. Really loved this place, the garden is a must !! and the collection really beautiful, very impressive old art pieces, a place to go if you go to Lisboa

Modern complex, nestled in a leafy green park. Calouste Gulbenkian was an interesting man who apparently, over the course of over 50 years, only purchased the best. His Art Deco section alone had me enthralled. But I also enjoyed the many portrait and landscape paintings in his collection. We enjoyed strolling the shady gardens outside as well. In a pond at the entrance, ducklings and turtles paddle contentedly about. The complex, so well integrated into the natural surroundings, reminded me a bit of a Frank Lloyd Wright design.

Remember Sundays are free of charge. We were fortunate to hear about Museum Sundays and spent half a day at the Gulbenkian and still did not see it all. An incredible private collection of world art. A must see!

Trip Around the World. This museum takes you around the world with all the fabulous art from all over. Absolutely stunning collection. Had a nice inexpensive lunch in the basement cafeteria and be certain to browse the tiny museum shop.

Great place but difficult to find your way.. Very interesting and lovely place with great art and nice outdoor spaces. Definitely worth a visit. However, if you find a good guide book with a map, bring it. There are no useful maps available at the place. We do not usually have trouble finding our way around, but this was an unusual challenge with different buildings, outdoor spaces, a lake, etc. They require you to take a preset route through the permanent art exhibit, which seemed unnecessarily rigid to me. I was much more interested in the more recent art and did not know if I had time to see everything. Yet I HAD to start in the ancient art area and go from there. I hope they make accommodation for the handicapped who might have trouble getting to the parts they are most interested in, if they are required to take the preset route.

A wonderful space. A fabulously well designed museum & exhibition space surrounded by tranquil gardens. Particularly enjoyed the exhibition of African photography in the Africa Presente programme, Bamako photography Encounters. Staff here are helpful & well informed as you would expect.

Absolutely a Must in Lisbon!. The Gulbenkian has an outstanding collection of art and antiquities. You don't have to be a museum lover to enjoy and appreciate the Gulbenkian. Absolutely worth including in any trip to Lisbon.

Fantastic collection at a giveaway price. 2 Euros each (pensioners' rate) to get in! Amazing value for this eclectic collection of objets d'art from around the world. Rembrandt, Monet, Manet, Gainsborough, Turner to name but a few, and the Lalique gallery alone is worth a visit. Nice restaurant/cafe which is also popular as a lunch venue for local office-workers, as prices are very reasonable and what is on offer is good. Allow most of a morning or afternoon if you want to really take it all in. Yes, its a relatively small museum, but there's a lot to see in each gallery. We will definitely re-visit.
Museum. A very good collection, worth seeing. Metro close by. Good restaurant at the museum. Gardens nearby.
Interesting Collection. A variety of art, but also some special ( extra costs) exhibitions. Enjoyed the shop and the Café as well. Not well signposted within the building.
just ok. I wasn't wow'd by any museum in Lisbon sadly. Luckily they are all free by 2pm on Sunday, so I didn't spend money on them.

Nice exhibitions. The Galapagos exhibition was very interesting, and the other two were quite good as well. I thought the museum could have done a bit more with its set up, but quite good works on display, and it was free and air conditioned.

Incredible Museum. We visited in May 2013. The artifacts are stunning and there were no crowds at all. You should definitely visit it is a great collection of art, pottery, textiles, coins, furniture and even jewelry.
for art lovers. This is just an old-fashioned museum with lots of art (and persian rugs). So do go there, even on a sunny day (since it is cool inside).
Over the top. Very cool collection of European antiques and a great place to spend a couple hours viewing a wonderful collection of art

A Gem. This was our first trip to Lisbon and we had been told to visit the Gulbenkian while there. We ended up going on a very hot Sunday - thinking it would be cool inside (it was) and that we could take advantage it being free admission on Sundays. There is a main building with parts of the permanent collection and then 2 other parts with changing exhibits. All of this is in a beautiful peaceful park like setting and easy to get to using the metro. If you do only one museum on a trip to Lisbon I would certainly recommend this one.
Amazing. Worth a visit to see an incredibly ornate collection of art. Watch for the clocks, and note they are still keeping time!
Great Museum. Some fantastic gallery displays - well worth a visit when in Lisbon and most days it is reasonably quiet

A most accessible museum with a lovely garden. The museum is small enough to be seen in a couple of hours and it is set up to take you from ancient art through modern art. It's a little course in Art History with wonderful examples from each epoch. The cafeteria has very good, unfussy food. The museum is set within and next to a huge garden with charming paths winding through trees and gardens.

Truly a gem. Wonderful small collection of art: islamic, classic European painting, furniture, and an outstanding Lalique collection. It is not to be missed. It is worth the taxi ride and the museum cafe is also quite good.

World class. A fantastic collection of painting and art from many cultures and epochs. The setting is wonderful, a roomy well designed building and clear bilingual explanations make the visit a pure enjoyment for art lovers. Don't miss it if you are one.

unbelievable collection. The extravagant collection of period pieces that were incredible. I liked the location and there is an excellent restaurant across the street from the main entrance that just opened in July. Italian.
Thoughtful and Wonderful Museum. An odd building that houses a stellar collection. Free on Sundays. Worth the visit. Good temporary exhibits, too.

Breathtaking antiquities.. We went through the museum on recommendation from our travel guide and were not disappointed. This place is stunning! There are artifacts here from 2500 BC up to the 17 to 1800's. most are extremely well preserved and nicely presented, truly unique items from their time. If you are in Lisbon and have some time to spare, this place is a must-see. Give yourself plenty of time so you are not rushed. The museum is larger inside than it looks from the outside.
fun museum - enjoyed it. We had a brief visit at this museum and would love to go back and spend more time some day. Well worth the visit.
Contemporary art in an elegant building. If you have time after visiting the other key sites of Lisbon visit this beautiful stylish cool and spacious gallery for a change fromhistorical viewing.
Good deal for a museum. Great selection for a museum restaurant, and good value. Has a nice outdoor seating area. Come for the art, stay for the food.
Excellent museum and gardens. Wonderful exhibits from Ancient Egypt to the present, including a room of Lalique which is edgy rather than the pretty glasswear.

Not for everyone. Unless you have an interest in art history, this museum is not for you. Children in particular will be bored. The admission is 4 euros, free on Sunday. You'll be exhausted after walking though it, so don't plan to see the Modern Art Center on the same day.

Well worth a visit in any case. The Gulbenkian Foundation houses a good if ot great collection very well presented and spanning six centuries. The park is also a delight. Hask74( that's me) recommends breakfasting on the terrace of the museum cafeteria. As for paying more to see the contempoary art in the adjacent museum, well if you're pressed for time I would skip it, but expositions change often and it is a nice space. The highlights for me were the series of Guardi pictures of Venice, the fine Corot, the Largillière portrait....

Very special art and historical collection.... I´ve seen a very good art and historical collection in this place. They have very old books. They have very old carpets. they have arts. The place itself is very beautiful and they have a very nice garden. The place worths a visit.

Present Tense photo exhibition worth a visit. Saw work of southern African photographers exhibited here. Well worth the visit and exhibition runs until September. Main exhibition also enlightening and educational.

Heavy on ceramics and textiles. In reading the earlier descriptions of this museum I was expecting a larger, more diverse collection. I guess the museum houses the collection of a single man who donated them after his death. As a result they understandably skew to what he liked, which was definitely ceramics and textiles. I personally am not a huge fan of either so was a bit disappointed but it certainly wasn't the fault of the museum. There were also some great paintings and a few early pieces that I very much enjoyed.The cafeteria was very nice, with both indoor and outdoor tables, and both a meat and vegetarian based "daily menu," along with a good selection of a la carte options. I had their meat daily special which was very good and reasonably priced.The external grounds are absolutely gorgeous and a real pleasure to explore. I suspect they'd be a great spot for a picnic.

Nice place to spend a couple hours. We stayed at the Corinthia Hotel and it took us about 15 mins to walk there, not too far. The museum had quite a lot of pieces including some interesting ancient bible. I personally love the display of the traditional Portuguese tiles, but I find that the National Tiles Museum would be more interesting. There are also some European art collections, but it's not very attractive to me. More surprisingly they have Chinese vase and ceramic pieces which are also beautiful and interesting. There are some pieces that are very ancient which is worth looking. It's nice to spend about 1 and a half-2 hours time there. Although the disappointing thing is that the shop of the museum does not feature a lot of stuff, bought some folders but lack of choice, when there are so many beautiful pieces, the inspiration of different products should be limitless, it's disappointing to see there's not at many things as I would expect to buy. On the other hand, there is a pond outside the museum, there are many baby duckies there and they are absolutely adorable!

Definitely eclectic, but mind expanding food for the brain. Enjoyed a good 2hrs wondering through the regular museum, the temporary exhibits and the modern art building. The historical collections were a feast for the eyes, especially the Rembrandt. The Modern Art stimulates the synapses, although may not be everyone's cup of tea. For me, the most eye-opening exhibits were the photographs taken by numerous artists of the impoverished, pollution ravaged, environmental disaster regions in the world. The photos literally punches one in the face to wake up and take action. I certainly will step up my work with the NGOs for peace and alleviating hunger in the world.I hope you will be similarly affected and contribute in your own way.My thanks to the Gulbenkian Museum for their initiative.

Great. This is a museum one of the best place to visit. it wasn't far from our hotel. I love the sock they have lots of different cultural. the building is bit hidden means located off to the road but worth to visit.
A delightful museum. Combined ancient items, decorative arts and fine art into one manageably sized museum, beautifully displayed.

5 star Gulbenkian. It is appropriate to call this review five star because of the five different aspects of the collection at the Gulbenkian. This private collection belonging to Calouste Gulbenkian was originally housed in his private home in Paris. He was drawn five specific areas of collecting 1.Oriental and Classical Antiquary. 2.Eastern Islamic Art. 3.Armenian Art. 4.Far Eastern Art. 5.European Art, including a spectacular collection of works by Rene Lalique .The museum was built specifically to house the entire collection and although it is already 60 years old , the building complex has a timeless understated elegance about it. Internally, the relatively low ceilings cause the viewer to have a more intimate relationship with each of the objects. On the day I visitedthere were not many people in the museum and the one disappointment I had was that no English auto guides were available as they were sold out!Every object in each of the fields of the collection are superb quality. My own favourites were the the Lalique collection, the Alabaster low-relief from Assyria and the Mirror of Venus by Sir Edward Burne-Jones.Good quality food in the self service restaurant/ bar.
Excelent!. Everything is beautifull and with a lot of quality. From the building to the gardens, the exebituions, the staff...Must go there!
a worldtop museum. superb presentation of very eclecticworks of art:one of the topmuseums of the world,not in quantity but in quality

Heaven in the heart of Lisbon.
