Rui Jervis de Athouguia, Pedro Cid and Alberto Pessoa were the Architects of this beautiful building, inspired in the Brutalist movement of Architecture.(1959-69)The Gardens were also made by the Portuguese famous landscape Architect Gonçalo Ribeiro Telles e António Viana Barreto and won the Valmor Prize in 1975.The Museum is known internationally by the quality of its exhibitions and its own refined art collection.In the summer, you can enjoy the garden and the artificial ponds , lay down on the grass, read a book, flirt, take a nap or relax in this beautiful setting and in the hot summer nights, enjoy the Jazz summer festival - it's free, or take a look at the latest trends in Sculpture or Painting at the Contemporary Art Museum.What's not to like?

Best museum in town!. Gulbenkian is a gerat place for almost everything. The permanent collection is amazing and on top of that you always have access to temporary exhibition, the best in town. Also, the gardens are something not to miss!
A must see for art lovers. World Class collection in an interesting modern building. Good cafeteria. This is something not to miss

Very interesting collection and lovely grounds. Private collections are always quirky, and this one is no exception, but we liked the quirks! There is something for everyone, starting from pre-historic artefacts to Rembrandt and Turner. The grounds are lovely and peaceful, with families of ducks wandering around the park. The cafe was fine for lunch.

Worth the stop. We visited this private collection and it is vast and diverse. Anything from world class paintings to lovely jewelry. The setting is pretty with gardens surrounding it. This was my husbands favorite museum in Lisboal
marvelous Collection. So much to see, what a marvelous collection in a nice relaxing atmosphere, Good Café in the basement too next to the library
Decent food, for quick meal. The place is quite pleasant and the food is very good for the price. It's great for a quick meal. The buffet offers a lot of variety.

An incomparable collection!. You can see immediately that Gulbenkian collected only the best. Every piece is the best example of its genre, whether that genre be Iznik tile or 18th century sculpture or whatever your favorite genre from the world of art and textiles might be.And it's not as if he focused on a few areas of art - he really covered everything. Just a stunning collection. And such a wonderful setting for this collection - not just the peaceful museum building, but the grounds of the entire Gulbenkian Foundation surrounding the museum.The one drawback is the location of the museum is a bit remote. Not knowing the neighborhood, when we exited the closest Metro stop, we turned in the wrong direction. The result: it took us an hour to get there from downtown Lisbon, when it should have only taken a half hour. Oh well - my bad. But this does deserve to be at the center of Lisbon cultural institutions, rather than on the periphery.
Best in Town. The gardens are lovely and the building architecture from the fifties is worth a visit.Lisbon is an fortunate city to have such museum!
Small museum with big setup. Visited museum on Sunday but it was not busy. Enjoyed every second of it. Reward yourself with unforgettible expirience!

Small museum, but worth visiting!. This is a great museum of carefully curated items. There are separate rooms with a dozen or so art pieces from each era (Ancient Egyptian through Impressionism). My husband and I went on Sunday (free admission) and because the museum is so spacious and well planned, it felt like we were on our own private tour! Trip Advisor recommends 3 hours for a visit, but this muesum is fairly small and you could easily see and appreciate all of the art pieces in 60-90 minutes. This is definitely not your typical, overwhelming art museum that you would find in Paris or London...but well worth your time through it!

Mindblowing collection a must to see. One of the best collection of archeology and art Ive seen in Europe. All was top quality and perfecty displayed. The museum is in a very nice building with a wonderful garden.

One of the best small museums we've ever visited. If you visit Lisbon this museum should be at the top of your list of things to do. It is simply wonderful and full of beautiful objects from Greek up to more modern times. Hard to believe one man could obtain so many gorgeous objects in his lifetime. It is nice to visit a museum where one isn't overwhelmed with too much stuff from any one time period. You can get great photos without using a flash. And there is a wonderful cafeteria, too. As with most attractions in Lisbon, people 65 and older can usually get in for half price (show proof of age with a copy of your passport)!

Fantastic collection of world art and antiquities. We visited the Gulbenkian on a Sunday when entrance is free, however the place was still not over-crowded. The collections of Middle Eastern porcelains, rugs and fabrics alone would justify a visit, but then there is also an amazing array of Chinese and European art. We only had a couple of hours before our flight home but would have loved to stay all day. We'll have to make another trip to Lisbon just to see this place in more detail!

Fascinating, world class gallery/museum. Fascinating to see and enjoy a huge private collection of objects of extraordinary quality: rugs, porcelain,antiquities, gold objects and an amazing collection of Lalique's work, especially jewelry, which is rarely to be seen in such profusion. This is a museum collected over a fairly short time so there is no 'padding' as often happens with museums that just seem to put everything out. He seems to have missed out a bit on the impressionists, but everything else is superb. The museum has something of the personal atmosphere of the Wallace or the Frick museums but not the charm of their buildings because the Gulbenkian is housed in a rather austere purpose-built building.Moreover all the support systems work. The cafe is of the standard one appreciates after a morning admiring artefacts, the gift shop has imaginative 'stuff' and there is an enticing programme of free concerts.
Beautiful art museum. Beautiful Art museum. I liked paintings by Edward Burne-Jones, There is also a nice restaurant inside the museum with good coffee.

Worth the trip if you want a gentle afternoon of art and culture. Great compact collection of art from all cultures and throughout history in a very mellow space. Not many other visitors about when I went on a Friday afternoon, so I had the privilege of looking at pieces by renowned artists like Rembrandt and Lalique totally on my own without the distraction of having to make way for other people. It's not too well signposted from the metro station, so just ask someone the way if you need to.

A must visit in Lisbon. This museum is a true treasure trove of the most wonderful precious pieces collected by Calouste Gulbenkian. From the outside the building is very 1960's, but inside the ambience and presentation is superb, though only in Portuguese and English, some more detail about some of the pieces would be welcome.The pieces to view come from all over the world and include porcelain, tiles, coins, tapestries and carpets, paintings and furniture.....all quite breathtaking.The museum was not very busy, and this probably reflects the lack of signage to direct visitors to it, but it has been a long held ambition to visit....and it is well worth the visit.

Versatile and interesting collection.. The Gulbenkian Museum in Lisbon gives a good view of the broad interest in art by the Armenian millionaire. I visited it for the second time within less than two years, and found new and interesting aspects compared to the first visit. Don´t miss it!The museum of modern art next to it, run by the Gulbenkian foundation, has to wait for the next trip to Lisbon.
Lots of gems. Relatively small but very good art gallery, with lots of gems in it in a lovely little garden. Well worth the visit.

A Must See. If you are going to Lisbon and have an interest in art, failing to see the Gulbenkian is a crime. It is easy to get to by metro (although when you go up into the Praca de Espanha it can be disorienting - just walk across the traffic circle away from the station and into what looks like a park area, probably means going to the right if you are facing the traffic).
Beautiful Art. I liked it all. Perfect size and excellent quality. Many gorgeous Turkish artifacts, fabulous paintings and furniture.
Fabulous museum. One of my favorite collections in Europe! Interesting variety of exhibits but all first quality and well curated. Impressive!
An incredible collection. It's just incredible to imagine that one person collected all this art from ancient times to The Impressionists and more recent works. It's well worth a visit.

Something for everyone. We walked up to the museum from the coast, not too far with a coffee stop on the way! The museum is free on Sundays and was not at all busy. The exhibits are set out with loads of space so you don't feel overwhelmed at all. I enjoyed the art, my husband loved the tapestries, our boys were fascinated by the oriental collections. Well worth the walk.

Small but great. This is a wonderfal little museum. This is not the Met or the Louve. But it has the same wide variety of exhibits and you're beable to view the whole museum in one visit. It's located in a businee district and it has parking, enjoy.
An afternoon at the museum. Very well worth our time. Amazing collection of art, furniture, clocks, clothing and tapestries . The story of this private owner also fascinating.
Worth visiting. Very nice collection and some of the exhibits are really impressive. It's worth visiting whenever someone travels to Lisbon

Superb choice of art. This collector definitely knew what he was buying: from Persian rugs to antique mantelpiece-clocks to master paintings, everything is of high caliber. Definitely the best museum in Lisbon for amateurs of classical fine arts. Too bad it's so much out of the way for people willing to do everything on foot.

Very high quality private Art Collection in Lisbon. Take the time to visit this mid-sized museum displaying the Private Art Collection of Calouste Gulbenkian. It's a broad-range of Art (Ancient to early 20th century; Eastern and Western). Much more manageable than a huge Museum like the (wonderful) Metropolitan in NYC.

Extensive collection of rare glass and porcelain of middle eastern and Persian origin.. Small, intimate quality collections. The rare glasses, porcelain and rugs collections are very extensive. Comparable items are seldom seen in other museum this reviewer has visited over the years.

Sensational exhibits of Greco-Roman, Ottoman & Persian artefacts. Just get there and spend under an hour in a wonderful environment seeing object from so long ago in the most perfect setting and just gaze in awe. Fantastic
A museum of quality. A wealth of artistic expression spanning the centuries, beautifully displayed in spacious surroundings. The collection of Lalique glass is the icing on the cake.

Calouste Gulbenkian - a man of taste?. This museum contains an astonishing and eclectic collection of artwork, and is a must for any art lover visiting Lisbon. We know that oilman Gulbenkian was immensely wealthy - but did he personally choose the artefacts, or did he employ others to 'have taste' on his behalf? Whatever - we can be grateful for the opportunity to see a mini New York Met, British Museum or Louvre - with many ancient Egyptian pieces (including some statues in which we can devine the characters of some leaders); a wonderful Greek urn; silks and tapestries from Syria, India and elsewhere; some beautiful illuminated manuscripts; and paintings from the middle ages up to the impressionist period.The question of taste arises since Gulbenkian not only bought so many beautiful pieces, but also shelled out for some hideous Chinese pottery - the dragons are especially awful, and contrast with the subtlety of the japanese pieces nearby - and a large collection of grotesque French (Louis XIV?) furniture - nice marquetry spoiled by OTT gold fittings - "just because you can do something doesn't mean you ought to do it".For me, the highlights were two paintings - one a portrait of an old man by Rembrandt, and the other a glorious late Turner (there's also an earlier one, more 'traditional' and much more muted in its colour palette). But who knows - maybe some of you will rave over the Chinese dragons, and diss these paintings.Whatever - go see.

Go early and work backwards. The museum collection is arranged chronologically. Go early and head for the last room, then work backwards toward the entry. You will avoid crowds that way. Do not forget to walk to the modern wing, about 5 minutes away in the same park.

The Rembrandts are wonderful.. Although I have to admit that I only wanted to see the Rembrandts, the entire museum was very enjoyable. The Islamic art collection, including textiles and ceramics, gave a good historic lesson in where Portuguese tiles and ceramics originate. There are Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiquities, which were very interesting, as were books, and miniatures. Not a very large museum, but definitely worth a visit.

surprising and great. Design of museum beautifully integrated with the contents and the contents are a fascinating wide ranging collection of a powerfully infulential business man with the financial means to acquire an eclectic and strong collection of all forms of art - tapestries, coins, glassware, ceramics, paintings from ancient Egypt, Turkey, Persia to masters of European painting. A must visit.
An absolute must. Even more than the paintings, already a remarkable collection indeed, antique objects and artifacts deserve altogether two hours of your time.

Go for the late 1960s architecture. This museum has its charms - the 'oriental' galleries are gorgeous, and the building itself a wonderful example of what you could do with concrete in the late 1960s. However, the collection as a whole is best approached with fairly low expectations. As a private collection it is impressive, but in no sense does it come near what one would expect from a major European gallery (as some guidebooks would have you believe). Fans of 18c French decorative arts might be more rewarded.
Best Museum. A very personal collection of exquisitely beautiful items. Carefully presented in a spacious modern museum. Do not miss it if you visit Lisbon

Lovely, Spacious Art Museum. This is a private collection of a wealthy collector that treated his acquisitions like children. There is a wide variety of sculptures, rugs, pictures, coins and more from antiquity to the 20th century. The building itself has a lot of natural light and benches to sit and enjoy the beauty of the natural setting outside, as well as the art inside. We went on International Museum Day and got free admission, but paid 4 euros each for the audio guide, which was worth it. Good info without getting into too much detail.
free on Sunday. If you have some time in Lisbon on a Sunday the museum is free and near a wonderful lookout point. I wouldn't make a special trip to go to the museum.

Exceptional private collection, in a very nice setting. I've been to many museums, large and small, but must say for a private collection this is one of the best. He collected some truly amazing pieces, from a wide range of regions and periods. If you have an appreciation for art and craftsmanship you really should not miss this exhibition. Some of the pieces are so stunning they are hard to believe. The gardens are also very pleasant and relaxing, and the food in the cafeteria is good enough for a satisfying lunch. If you're a senior the full ticket price for all the exhibits is 4 Euros, an amazing bargain. Overall very well worth the time and effort to see. Highest recommendation.

Worth a look but not amazing.. I went here because it was so highly rated on here. I found the Egyptian and Roman sections interesting and the 18th/19th century English and French artists quite impressive. There are large sections on middle and far eastern ceramics that while interesting to a point got a bit tedious for me. It is located in a lovely grounds, great place to sit and relax in the shade.

Breathtaking collection. So glad we visited the Gulbenkian with such an eclectic collection on display and just enough to fill a couple of hours, leaving you stunned by the sheer craftsmanship and artistry of humankind throughout the ages. It is also a beautifully dimensioned space for display, surrounded outside by pleasingly landscaped gardens and a really good coffee shop with which to end your tour. Reasonably priced and highly recommended.

Must see!!. The whole complex including museum and the botanical garden is awesome, it is so various, and when you think that one man managed to collect all that art and to preserve it in a way how every piece needs to be treated is just amazing!

Masterpieces galore in a splendid setting!. From Rembrandt to J.M.W. Turner, Giotto to Manet, this splendid museum has it covered with one masterpiece after another. It is not to be missed. The Gulbenkian is situated inside a splendid (free) park, where we made a fast picnic before venturing indoors. Every piece, from a bust of Moliere to a magnificent Jean-Francois Ebe mechanical table, dated 1762 and carved of the finest oak, poplar, lime wood and other exotics, has its own proper place with ample space to view and digest. The collection of works is beautifully curated, and so is the decor. Floors are mahogany-rich, inviting the viewer to linger for hours. Especially striking is the Lalique group as well a tapestry trio from Mantua, Italy, dated 1540, called, "Children Playing." Not only do the children dance, but so do the silver and gold threads woven into the hangings. My one quibble is that the audio player is too superficial for a museum of this quality. Many pieces aren't covered at all, and those that are do not offer sufficient depth or breadth. But this is a minor complaint in what was a paradise of an afternoon.

Not to be missed. Outstanding museum consisting of the the collection of Calouste Gulbenkin. The holdings span ancient art, Oriental art, the great masters all housed in a modern, bright and airy space. Reading about the life of Gulbenkin before your visit will enhance the experience.

Variety and quality. An amazing collection with something for everyone, pleasant gardens, good cafeteria. Turkish textiles and ceramics, Lalique jewellery, many important paintings to name just a few of the rooms. Well worth going out of your way.

Loved this place. This is so far my most favourite museum in the whole world, full of wonderful, excellent samples of worldwide and ancient art.I would revisit again and again.Free on Sundays and has an excellent cafeteria.Set in an attractive park.

Lovely place. This is purpose built,with only about 15% of Calouste collections. The best ones of course. We were told. The man had a eye for these things. I've been once with a friend. However this time we took the museum guide. Which enriched our experience with history and questions answered. You can learn more about the man himself with the guide, as well as about the items displayed. There are combinations of furniture, painting, tapestry, china, ornaments, jewellery and so much more, just in the main museum. There are temporary exhibitions and galleries too. However to appreciate all the contents I believe you need a couple of trips. Maybe taking in the the galleries seperate.The coffee shop/restaurant had good lunches and cakes. With stairs and a lift going down. Reasonable prices, with beautiful outside setting set in the gardens. These gardens are well worth a wonder too if you have the time. The gift shop is ok. The staff are pleasant. I would defiantly return for a third visit.
Free on Sunday. Earlymorning is best before the crowds arrive,loved the ceramics.gardens are relaxing!metro San sebastian

A Terrific, Well-Organized Museum. The museum (what used to be a private collection spanning Egyptian times to 20th Century is not overwhelming. The exhibits are well spaced in each room. There islots to enjoy, including the Lalique collection.

A matter of taste. The Gulbenkian is an attractive, modern museum which focuses on ancient and Oriental art, along with European art up till about 1850; its collection of such objects is surely impressive. However, there is not much from 1850 onward, though the art nouveau jewelry was unique. Nevertheless, it is probably the best art museum in Lisbon, and is worth a visit.

Good average museum. We spent a nice 2 hours. The museum doesn't have anything like the Louvre or the British museum or other top ones but still very enjoyable. A lot of "niche" kind of arts and relics.

gulbenkian. the gulbenkian museum is set in lovely garden surroundings it gets busy i got there at 9 40 it opened at10 there was a queue you can take photos with out the flash.its a fantastic collection well worth a visit,

Museum and Music. A wonderful museum near Sao Sebastian subway stop. It makes a perfect visit since it´s not too big. There is a wonderful Turkish tile collection, as well as Rembrandt and other paintings. We were fortunate to get tickets to an evening symphonic performance of Mendelssohn's "A Midsummer Night´s Dream". There is a wonderful music auditorium within the buildings.

Interesting. The Gulbenkian shows all highlights or art. It is small but with a great surrounding: the view on the park in the background gives an extra dimension to the art which is displayed. The Museum is not expensive and well worth visiting.
World class. Don't miss it, fantastic collection of the best of the best in Western and Middle Eastern art, but not huge. Well presented.

Gulbenkian a pleasant surprise. The exhibits and artworks are an eclectic mix as you would expect but the quality was a surprise. My wife particularly loved the Lalique Art Nouveau jewellery and bowls.

Must see. Seriously.. This is one the great galleries of the world and you'd be mad to miss it. The collection is beautifully presented in an understated,elegant building. You go through in the order the gallery stipulates, which is not only chrononological but logical and quietly educative.The surrounding gardens - almost a zen-like design - are a must see as well. They are designed to calm and regenerate and they were beautiful to walk through before and after seeing the collection. Take the time; you'll appreciate it.

One of the most important Foundations in Europe - arts, charity, education and science. Although is not quite popular amongst tourists, probably the guided books have no reference to this place, indeed if you love culture, art, painting, music, this is the place to go, with many expositions and concerts, located in central Lisbon, near Spanish Embassy.A legacy from the Armenian oil magnate Calouste Gulbenkian, the foundation is one of the most important in Europe. Check their official website for more information and temp exhibitions.Don't miss a visit if you have couple of days in Lisbon.

Lisbon's piece de resistance. If, in the Hereafter wherever I may be, I am permitted a day’s return to Planet Earth to visit one natural and one cultural wonder, at this late point in my life the choice would be the Iguassu Falls and the Gulbenkian. The reason for the latter choice includes its moderate size, allowing the whole collection to be seen in 3 hours. The range of art displayed is universal in origin and comprehensive in subject. The Asian collection, headed by Turkey and Persia, is the most abundantly impressive ---- including carpets, pottery, calligraphy, and paintings ---- and the pinnacle of quality. China, Japan, and former Asian-Russian Republics are also well represented. The European collection begins with the most exquisite miniature wood and ivory carvings, glowingly colourful illuminated manuscripts, silver and gold reliquaries, moving on to paintings from the Italian, Dutch, Flemish and English schools of which every one is a masterpiece, especially works by Hals, Rembrandt, Rubens and Van Dycke, that must be included among the 3 greatest canvasses of each of these giants. The French paintings are the most numerous, and the most spotty with regards to quality. Some fine Impressionist canvasses from the likes of Degas, Manet and Monet are on display, but there are whole walls of Daubigny, Corot, and Theodore Rousseau that ----while charming and well crafted ---- cannot match the caliber of the Non-French exhibits. But France does emerge triumphant with a stunning array of sculptures ( most of them marbles, rather than bronzes that however good are found in dozens of museums as copies) from Carpeaux, Houdon, and of course the great Rodin ----- easily the best of his work that I have seen outside of the eponymous museums in Paris and Philadelphia. The collection of furniture, clocks, and tapestries around which the paintings circle, is 90% French and utterly overwhelming in the artistry and majesty of each item. And to crown it all, at the very end, a large room displaying the greatest jewelry and ornaments I have seen ------- a collection of 80 items by Lalique that blew me away so utterly that I risked a late divorce by purchasing a book illustrating all 80 items, thereby breaking the most adamant prohibition with which my wife (who was not so impressed) has ever bound me.I crept back the next day to spend my last 90 minutes before catching my plane out of Lisbon with these newly acquired friends. For the rest of my days, I will not forget them. Nearby is a Museum of Contemporary Art, also under the aegis of the Gulbenkian Foundation that I cannot recommend. The Permanent Collection is trivial, and most of the space is taken up with Temporary Exhibitions confirming that Adolph Hitler may have been right in his assessment of Contemporary Art, for which he was able to find a Final Solution.

Very impressive collection in an elegant building. Surrounded by a nice park you'll find in this elegant building an impressive collection gathered by an outstanding art collector. Early Grecian and Roman art, ancient tapestries, glazed tiles, glass and silverware, a small but beautiful collection of paintings as well as antique furniture.Worth a visit!

Disappointing. It was Sunday, perhaps the busiest day.There weren't enough staff in the eaterie, which is cramped anyway, and the queueing took too long. By the time I'd paid and found somewhere to sit, the hot food was no longer hot. A small grumble, because the museum itself is delightful
Cool museum. A combination of interesting architecture and good exhibits. Set in a park, so make sure you allow time to sit outside and enjoy the surroundings.

Superlatives abound. This museum may not have the biggest collection on display but everything is the most exquisite example of its kind. I have never seen so much so much beauty in one place - from the Lalique jewellery to the early Grecian art.
great find. What a nice discovery. Close to our hotel & a place my parents had been to in1987. Beautiful garden with ponds, ducks & sculptures.
Charming. Interesting permanent exhibition, revealling exquisit taste. Temporary exhibitions are also usually worth it!
Enjoyable. Great pieces of art, very green atmosphere surrounding the museum. Recommended to those who are interested in art.
Astounding collection of art. Loved the statues of Diana and Apollo. And the tiles, the different relics from different cultures, the ability to take photos, nice cafeteria, and audio guide.
A vey pleasent visit. The museum is not so big like other collections' museums, so it was a very good museum to go with the kids. We particularlly liked the egyptioan and the oriental collections.
Wide collection. Go on Sunday - it is free then. If you have been to other major museums in other cities you can skip this one. I had lunch in the cafeteria which was actually quite good.

Not that great. If you have been to museums in Italy and France this is no big deal. The admission fee is Euro 4 per person and if you have the Lisboa card it's not free but you get a discount of only 20%.
However, the gardens of the museum are beautiful and roaming around them is absolutely free.

What is possible to collect. Good collection of painting (Monet, Manet, few others). Furniture - a lot of wood and gold - can be skipped. Interesting collection of coins, some nice carpets. Visit the second building with contemporary art (temporary exhibitions).

What a collection!. The collection of Calouste Sarkis Gulbenkian is arranged really well and reflects his likes and personal taste. The museum is light and airy, and is set in Parque Santa Gertrudes so has good views. The Lalique collection is breath taking. And the museum is free on Sundays!

Unexpectedly wonderful!. We discovered this by accident wandering into the park area near to the shopping center. The museum and gallery are much bigger than we thought but more especially we were interested in the concert hall. Beautiful wood walls and plush seating. Acoustics phenomenal. New places have the benefit of technology to make sure its good I suppose, rather than retrofitting as you find in older auditoriums. The foyer is also a pleasant place with modern sculpture, huge collage on the walls, indoor plantings, and lovely bar and patio, to spend time in during intermissions. Catch a concert or event if you can. We were lucky enough to hear concert pianist Leif Andsnes on tour from Norway. The guy at the desk found us last minute excellent seats! It seems every event is sold out fast. Check ahead if you get the chance.

Must see. Amazing collection by what must have been an amazing gentleman. The museum has just the right amount of exhibits, bathrooms very clean, and very helpful employees. Go on Sunday and it is free!
Like National Gallery. A terrific monument to one man's collection of art, furnishings etc. Like nat Gal and waddesdon combined.
a grand collection. The collection of artifacts is certainly large but its not what we came to Lisbon to see. It was less about Lisbon then about the history of a collector.

Small but perfectly formed. This is quite a trek out walking from the centre, but well worth it. The items on display are wonderful, from the Egyptian (all small) exhibits to the wonderful Lalique display, in very pleasant grounds.We didn't visit the modern art gallery, though it is supposed to be good, but there are some choice older paintings on display.
5Star Museum. Well laid out and enough exhibits to keep you interested for hours.great location too in a huge park.nice outside terrace to the cafe too.

Accessible in size and fabulous collection. This collection is marvelous and well displayed. The lighting is good, there is adequate space between exhibits and the artifacts and paintings are top notch. The only thing that I found difficult was the map of the particular exhibit in the cases--I wasn't really sure what was what when I looked at it. Some things seem to have been moved a bit but it is a minor complaint.
Must see. Considering the size, better than louvre, or Prado. Perhaps not the breadth, but can be taken in Less than a day. Rembrandt to Turner to Monet, Asian art etc
One of the world's best. Simply a brilliant, "small" collection (in contrast with large art museums). Great variety. Wonderful scale, and fascinating to explore the collection of one individual.

The gardens surrounding the Museum are brilliant. The building is lovely, the collection is varied. The highlight of the museum for me was the gardens surrounding the different buildings, and the architecture of the buildings themselves (they are excellent examples of modern 20th century buildings).The spaces inside really make the collection shine. The collection itself is very varied including Egyptian and Greco-Roman artefacts, to Chinese and Japanese pieces, as well as 18th and 19th century European furniture and paintings. The paintings include those from Monet, Manet, Degas and Turner. There is a small section dedicated to Lalique, which although is not quite my thing, would interest some people. Generally a really lovely private collection. Try the cafeteria in the main museum as well. There is a lovely terrace outside.P.s the entry for one museum is only EUR4 which is a bargain! Easily accessible by metro.

A remarkable collection. This lovely museum has a staggering collection of ancient and modern works. It is in a beautiful park, also worth visiting. It's hard to believe this is the collection of one family. The Egyptian collection is small but excellent, and there are some superb impressionist paintings. We didn't have time to see the modern museum on the site, but what we saw was "awesome" to use an irritating American expression.
April in Portugal. Very interesting Museum - well laid out and the audio self guidance is excellent. Don't miss the Lalique jewelry collection at the end.

Stunning. A fabulous and fascinating collection in a modern spacious light-filled building, perfectly set in gorgeous gardens. A real surprise for us and certainly unmissable. One of the best things in Lisbon - and that's really high praise.
a bit of everything. this is a manageable hotel with a very interesting selections of treasures. The museum itself is also beautiful.

An amazing collection that is worth the trip. The old world masters were a surprise to discover hidden away at the end of the museum. Go on Sunday when it is free before 13:00, and the cafe in the garden is a nice place to rest before going to the modern wing.
Worth the visit. Wide range of art up to present, including major pictures by Turner and French artists, in woodland surroundings.

Range of interesting exhibits and a lovely cafe. Really enjoyed our visit. Modern spacious museum with a broad range of exhibits set out by age. Set in lovely gardens, with a nice cafe with good lunch menu. Would highly recommend in conjunction with shopping trip to nearby El Corte Ingles department store.

Few Gems. This museum carries a wide array of art from carpets to furniture and to master paintings. Although not immense some of the paintings in there are worth the detour. Some Monet, Manet, etc. Again not a large museum, but quality exhibits.
A must-see!. Amazing collection of art! Too bad I left it for the end of my trip, I would have enjoyed staying longer....

Timeless!. Even for people who get bored with ancient art, it is worth a visit - many pieces can tell something about the Portuguese art throughout the ages. The exhibitions are usually diverse in terms of subject and art forms.

Major private promoter of Arts, Science, Education and Charity in Portugal. The activities in the Gulbenkian agenda are at the highest standards and certainly have an international focus in each field, from music to science, from traditional to contemporary forms of fine art and performative arts. In my opinion, a must see (more than once!)

worth a visit. My advice for this museum is to read the biography of the man whose collection this is and how he came about it before wandering around the museum. was disappointed that Manets famous Boy blowing bubbles portrait wasnt hanging - and no reason why on the wall. that said - it was well worth the 4e entry fee. Easiest way to get to it is metro (parca di espania)

Very good. This was my 2nd visit, and like everyone else I found it very good and interesting; for the quality of exhibits it was a bargain! Cafe was good - even has a vegetarain choice. Charming garden.
360 exhibition. Excellent exhibition about the Discoveries, new medicines brought to Europe. New drugs known, new books written, specimens preserved.

exhibitions and conferences. I attended several international conferences and they were amazing, see their dates in www.fcg.pt the exhibitions are also good and the other cultural programes, the garden is nice to relax in summer and there are also outdoors festivals too. Besides this nothing more to see.

....and all the clocks are in working order!. On 9 April we visited the Gulbenkian.And it was more than worth it.Mr.G. spent his money well for all of us to enjoy.His collection took us through a life and love of art ,whether paintings, sculptures,applied art or...clocks, which all of them actually worked! Mr. Gulbenkian was indeed a man of many tastes .A taste for the Orient as well as Europe in many forms, shapes and materials.What more can I stay but: go and see for yourself when you are in Lisbon.

Manageable and interesting. It was a lovely collection and unlike many museums that can be too much, this was just right. The Lalique collection was breathtaking and all in all a very pleasant afternoon

Lunch and exposition. Lovely garden, great expositions and a nice buffet lunch. That is basically our opinion on the Gulbenkian museum. Have a nice walk in the garden, on a summer day take a blanket and a book with you so you can enjoy the envoirement. In the city centre, but within the garden you feel free as a bird. Have lunch in the cantine, nice buffet to choose from.

One of the best in Europe. Unlike so many museums that overwhelm you with sheer quantity regardless of quality, Calouste Gulbenkian had an eye for only the very best for his collection so what you see as you look round is of stunning quality and in some cases you have to look twice to confirm it's not a replica such is the perfection of the pieces. Although there are some 6,000 items, it doesn't become a chore to visit the entire museum, but it's worth taking your time to get the best out of your time here.

Fabulous museum. Very interesting museum with all kinds of ítems , surrounded by lush gardens. The pottery collection is lovely and with a great variety, there are also very beautiful books. The best...the Lalique room which has absolutely fantastic masterpieces.
Free on Sundays. Great interesting museum and gardens with good cafe with choice of hot and cold food .Try to visit on Sunday as it is free and was not too busy early on

Unforgetable place for culture and acknlowledge. Nohing to dislike...the Foundation is perfect. This visit is must and trip done to Lisbon deserves see again. The Gulbenkian Family left their marks with this museum.

Interesting collection. Well presented collection of art. Really good cafe to refresh tired feet and weary teenagers. The Lalique room was enchanting with some stunning items. The art was a mishmash of disparate styles, which I found interesting, although not all of our party did.
Lovely Museum to visit. We truly enjoyed is with the world pieces and many pieces form our country of Turkey . Highly suggested ... Easy access by metro ..

A perfect museum. One of themost pleasureable museum experiences I have evr had. The buildings are attractive, the collection is amazing, but intellectually and aesthetically accessible. A memorable experience. And, a really good cafe.

Sargent, Renoir, Monet, Rembrandt, etc. in one place. What a place to be in: 2 paintings of Rembrandt and 1 of Sargent/of Renoir/of Monet side by side. A cache of Lalique's masterpieces - those medusa pieces are a suprise. Exquisite pieces of Persian/European/Japanese wall/floor carpets/tapestry - worth of time spent appreciating that Japanese wall carpet, so subtle in color, yet its thread (flow) are captivating. Jaw dropping silverwares in size. One of a kind marble statues strategically placed. etc. etc. - don't miss this place when in Lisbon.
Superb quality collections. This is one man's vision and the range and quality are excellent. The Lalique jewelry and objects are ravishing!
A pleasant surprise. We particulary enjoyed the Asian collection at the museum but the broad variety of pieces made it very enjoyable for a couple of hours stroll.

Outstanding collection, nicely organized. So worth the trip (and the metro was easy), the Gulbenkian is a gem. Tiles, textiles, Asian art, Louis XIV stuff, impressionists, and a modern art collection in a nearby building -- delightfully curated and exhibited, all wheat no chaff.
Well worth the time!. Well - curated and a great value. Easy to get to via Metro and with the added bonus of a visit to the grand food hall of El Cortes Ingles near the Sao Sebatio stop.

world class. Really wonderful collection with some surprises, 2 Rembrants, Hals, a couple of great,Turners
Excellent displays of porcelain

Quality items displayed well. Really liked this museum. It is clear that the collector accepted nothing but the best, everything is perfect. It is all very well displayed also. The Egyptian items and paintings stood out for us, but the other items were interesting as well.

A Superb Collection. While a bit out of the way it is easily reached by bus or metro. The collection ranges from ancient egypt and greece to impressionist pictures and lalique. The quality is superb and well laid out.

a bit of everything. liked the collection and diversity of it.Furniture-paintings and persian carpets etcetc.Entre reasonable in price.
disliked the awful building

I went there 2 times within a few days because I liked it so much!. To my opinion this is the biggest treasure room of Portugal from so many different cultures and eras. You haven't seen Lisbon when you haven't seen the Gulbenkian.

Good for a rainy day. Excellent collection very much a must see. Only 15 minutes walk from the Zenit Hotel.
Have a bite whilst you visit, food is cheap and very good.

A fantastic colection with many rarities. It has a nice garden that takes you out of the city to a garden landscape.
The security guards suspicious of everyone...
The modern art museum is a must! You will find rarities here!
Museum and art gallery. This museum had a lot of interesting exhibits but from the write up in our guide book I was expecting more!

Excellent Collection & Well Presented. An excellent collection from Egyptian Art to Impressionist paintings. The entire collection is a fantastic tour of Art History. My only regret is that we had only one hour with which to visit. I would go back again.
Museum is free on Sunday, 4 Euros other days which is still good value.
Worth the trip for the Lalique. Small museum with some lovely paintings, the Lalique exhibition is fantastic. Go on a Sunday when it is free

Very interesting collection. Enjoyed this museum, set in a pretty garden. An interesting collection of furniture, artefacts and paintings. Enjoyable few hours. Also worth visiting the restaurant for light lunch, outside tables.

Not To Be Missed. The Gulbenkian Museum has a truly extraordinary collection of Asian art (much of it Turkish, although the Chinese collection is also very good), but around every corner one finds a surprise. The furniture collection is fine, and the paintings include a Reynolds, two Sargents, and a Cassatt, Be sure to check out the working clock from the 18th century - it chimes every fifteen minutes (the staff describe it as a ticking bomb, since its loud ticking can be heard some distance away).

Diversity and nice pieces. This museum is big, and has a lot of diverent pieces to show. Pieces from all over the world. And noy just some paintings of Rembrandt or monet: also carpets, statues, furniture, pots and glasses, and much more.....You need some time to see all of it, I combined the visit with the centro de arte Moderna (modern paintings) where you can also have e great lunch in the restaurant (all of Lisbon comes here to have lunch: we were the only tourists).
Gulbenkian Museum. Worth visiting!The art and history of the world in one place.For those who love art and history, visit the Gulbenkian Museum in Lisbon is mandatory.
Must See. Eclectic mix of art, furniture, clocks and jewelry that I strongly encourage the visitor to Lisbon to see.

The one that got away!. This is an amazing collection of art, pottery, antiquities, ceramics, silver, tiles and even carpets that was destined to be housed in London. Lisbon ended up getting the treasure trove instead, and it is their gain!I thoroughly enjoyed a whole day wandering around this impressive display. In particular I have never seen such a show of chinese ceramics and 18th century french furniture. What a great surprise this museum was.If you are in Lisbon, you must visit.

oh look another Jar and Vase set.. Its just too repetitive. The exhibits themselves are individually fantastic but they were too often of the same things. Couldn't help think that there's a much better way of presenting the best of Gulbenkians hoard.

Beautiful collection. This is an amazing museum. It is a collection of many different art pieces. There are ceramics, tapestries, carpets,, furniture, tile art, silverware and then some. You will find paintings by Rembrandt, Reuben, van der Wyden, Manet and many more world renowned painters.There is really a bit of everything, but the ceramics collection is particularly astounding. The pieces are beautifully displayed allowing a lot of room for each piece to be properly appreciated. Some of them are extremely old. The workmanship is out of this world. This man certainly had an eye for beautiful things and obviously the means to acquire them.The museum is surrounded by a lovely garden, very well kept.This place is a must see when in Lisbon.
absolutely wonderful. Make sure you go. Wonderful collection and space. Enjoyed lunch there and the grounds. Staff helpful. Easy to get to by metro.
Excellent museum with wide range of exhibits. Stunning building and grounds containing an eclectic collection. This was a private collection now available to the public. Well worth a visit.

best museum in portugal. If there is one museum you want to go in Portugal, it,s this one. It's amazing how many treasures cumulated this armenian businessman and then left it for the humanity to enjoy it.
interesting collection. Great paintings, carpets and furniture. This museum also have nice garden with caffe where to spend some time.

Extraordinary collection. This is a spacious and well laid out museum of several modern buildings spread across a leafy campus about a couple of kilometers north of the city centre and with good transport connections. The prime collection ranges from ancient Persian and Chinese ceramics and other artefacts, through a good representative selection of European art to 18/19th century French furnishings. In addition there is a permanent collection of modern Portuguese art together with temporary exhibitions, which was not entirely to my taste.

What a great museum!. This is one of the coolest art museums I've been to. It's even cooler when you realize that everything in there was collected by one man. There are tapestries, tiles, rugs, paintings, vases, furniture, sculptures, clothing, jewelry, and more, from many different countries and different time periods. Everything is beautifully restored. I loved the ancient Greek and Egyptian artifacts, the elaborate French furniture, and the Persian dishes. The gardens are wonderful too, even in the winter! You could spend many relaxing hours there. I think the gardens are open to the public even if you don't pay to get into the museum.

Worth visiting. I walked here and found the lack of signposting along the way rather irritating but it was worth persevering. The building is unattractive but the setting is good and the contents are an eclectic mix eg paintings, ceramics, Lalique, tapestries. There's a cafe on site.

Worth a visit, not so many clear highlights. The museum building itself represents somewhat ugly design of the 1970's concrete frenzy. But don't let that discourage you, it's what inside that counts. We visited the place on Sunday and to our pleasant surprise the entrance was free. Never found out why, though. The collection is partly awesome and partly a bit boring. It depends on your personal preferences of course, but for me the vast collection of carpets took too much space and time. Some amazing art nouveau pieces and ancient far east porcelain collection are sure worth a closer look. The museum has a very nice coffee shop downstairs that will restore your energy levels after the visit.

If you can only visit one museum make it the Gulbenkian. Absolutely wonderful collection of great quality artifacts and works of art from all the great artists and craftsmen through the ages.Well worth the 10 Euro entry fee it showed off the impeccable taste of Gulbenkian who did not collect any old thing for the sake of aquisition but who had a good eye and obviously appreciated things of great beauty.All set out in a wonderful spacious and well lit building, this museum is an absolute delight to visit and the highlight of my trip to Lisbon.There is a wonderful selection of Islamic art and tiles as well as beautiful Korans and Holy Scriptures that are so beautiful and look as if they had been painted recently in rich vivid colours,embellished with gold.There were fabulous collections of Roman coins and Oriental and Persian silk hangings and carpets.Browse around the bronze sculptures by Rodin and a wonderful selection of paintings by Monet and Manet as well as paintings from the school of Rembrant and other such artists.English artists were well represented too.There was a lovely collection of antique French furniture, all of the highest quality, but the jewel in the crown is the fabulous collection in the Lalique room.The beautiful craftsmanship and design of the jewellery by Lalique was simply breathtaking and I enjoyed every minute of my visit.If you can only visit one museum then do make sure it is the Gulbenkian as it is outstanding.

Wow!. A discovery for me.Great eclectic private collection of this not very well-known "tycoon" (oil), Calouste Gulbenkian (Armenian who finished his life in Lisboa).From ancient Egypt to Lallique accessories!Only museum unfortunately I had time to visit - worthwhile!

Well worth the visit. Well displayed and and wide variety of art to suit all tastes. An electic mix of one man's passion, but he had taste. Lalique display the end is well worth it. Nice cafe and grounds on lower floor. Lack of seating within the art displays means you will be on your feet during the visit.

Best things come in small packages. This was the ideal museum for us - the right size so that there was no need to rush but also no need to set aside a whole day for the experience. Top quality exhibits clearly labelled in English as well as Portuguese. A little out of the touristic centre of town but walkable and also easily accessible by metro. The collection of Lalique jewelry is stunning.

A gem in a peaceful haven. A well curated collection of beautful objects and art, just the right size to wander around without feeling overwhelmed. A well laid out in chronological order. All set in a lovely park.

Small but perfectly formed. I skipped the older collection of ceramics and headed for the paintings.They have some works by Monet and particularly Turner that deserved to be seen, but nothing extraordinary. It's in a small space so seems cramped at times.This might have been because I went on a Sunday, which is free admission day. It's a nice venue but doesn't rival other galleries for choice of work.

Absolutely Outstanding Collection and Grounds. Words can hardly describe how exquisite the collection is and how beautifully it is displayed. The grounds are absolutely lovely - and can be viewed from many windows inside - and the cafe has delicious and reasonably priced food. Plan to spend most of the day there and see the entire collection.

great art. An impressive collection, paintings, books, ceramics, furniture - all in one museum. The entrance is somewhat hidden and the building doesn´t look loke much from the outside, but a very pleasant surprize from the inside. Free on Sundays.
Educational time for a few hours visit. Rare and exceptionally well maintained. Prices very affordable. Plenty of information available. Books are cheap and of high quality.

wide range of art and antiques. So I went to this museum on a saturday morning. the gulbenkian collection apparently was gathered by a very wealthy guy who owned some oil in the middle east so it was a bit like going into his house and looking at some fabulous stuff he collected all over the world. im not particularly into antiques so i wandered around this bit quickly and went into the modern art building for lunch. lunch at the museum cafe is very affordable but usually you get a long queue if you go there after 1pm. I prefer this part of the museum because it's spacious and you don't get into people's way (or the other way round) when appreciating art. The main exhibition is on Júlio dos Reis Pereira's paintings and they are lovely. The temporary section now is on Afghanistan and it features an interesting short film in the theatre. Most of the books they sell in the museum shop are Portuguese though. Outside the museum it is a small park where you see young families running around with their kids or couples cuddling looking at the duck pond. Nice place to chill if you are not in a hurry. If you could, try to go there on a Sunday because it's free admission.

Marvellous. The Gulbenkian Museum is one of the finest that you can find in Lisbon. For a small fee, you are able to see a varied collection, from Ancient Egypt to Modern pictures. It should also be noted that the Museum is surrounded by beautiful gardens, which are lovely for a sunny afternoon - and the children will love them, because there are usually ducks to be found! Very romantic, as well!
Top Spot. Only the best quality items are on view here. probably the best Lalique Collection on view anywhere in the world!

fantastic site - 3 museums in one and only E8. The Gulbenkian is on both of the tour bus routes so really accesible. It is also really good value for money - E8 for the traditional art museum, modern art museum and also a really good temp exhibition on the age of discovery. All 3 museums would be worth E8 on their own and there is also a nice restaurant. One of the best museums I have ever visited.
Wonderful Collection. Amazingly eclectic collection, particularly beautiful 16-17th textiles, French Furniture and paintings. Do not miss it if you visit Lisbon.

Diverse Collection. This private collection comes close to measuring up to greats like the Barnes in Philadelphia. I like Gulbenkian because of the diversity of the art. Worth the subway ride and walk. Plus the subway station is under El Corte so you can get some shopping in at the same time!

Amazing exibitions. Go to see amazing exibitions, excelent museums , concerts, opera. The best Lisbon as to ofer. Go and see the colection of the foundation , the modern art museum or the temporary exibitiosn. And in a beautiful spring or autum afternoon relax in the gardens.

Excellent collection. This was our first stop on our recent stay in Lisbon. The Middle eastern collection is fantastic and I loved the room of Lalique jewelry. Highly recommended and only a short metro ride from the center of town.

excellent & very pleasant museum. a wonderful collection and very well displayed. some very interesting works that you don't see in other museums; the carpets were beautifully laid out. cafe crowded but pleasant outdoor spaces and good food.
lovely little museum. worth a visit extraordinary collection of oriental arts, the museum is not too large and is housed in a lovely contemporary building.

Amazing diverse personal collection. There's a little bit of almost everything here, enabling you to stroll through centuries around the world in one visit. Some unexpected treats and a great show of the sea next door in the foundation. Eclectic, unusual, intersting
An Oasis in Lisbon. Art ,nature , architecture , music ... a visit to Gulbenkian always feels like a real treat . A real oasis in Liabon

A must see sight in Lisbon. Fantastic collection of art, pottery, jewellery and pretty much everything else you can think of. Entry fee of 4 euros is a bargain, there is no pressure to rush round and there are English audio guides too. The Lalique room is a definite highlight, as are the paintings by the likes of Rembrandt and Monet. Loved the tiles too.

amazing is the least word to describe it. the biggest private collection you can see in museums. every thing is there ( paintings, furniture, carpets, sculptures, silver work, glass work.... ), the clocks are still working, having the right time of today. every thing is so rich, that you feel you are in a palace of a king. If you are to visit one museum in Lisbon, this is the one.

Fantastic collection and great cafe make for a great afternoon!. The Gulbenkian Collection and Foundation is a must see. Funded by early oil pioneer Calouste Gulbenkian, the museum is wonderful. The cafe features outdoor seating and great food as well as wine. The view is very nice. People chill out here during visits. The gift shop has great books and prints. I took several large posters home to the US on my first visit thirty years ago. I highly recommend you visit!

Fantastic!. One of the best museums I have ever visited, personal touch of the billionare owner visible in each one of the incredible, hand- picked pieces (from ancient greek coins, through real persian art to Lalique jewelllery) you'll find in this collection. Loved it!

Brilliant ,A MUST SEE .. I always passed by the street where the museum was in and I was there for 2 months , I decided to go and visit and to my amazment it was HUGE ,seriously it was amazing to discover and to go and sit along in the park there was pretty nice too , they always have different exhibitions and a variety of them .usually there's a day in the week that you enter for free so check that before you go !!!

An amazing museum with a rich and beautiful collection! Not tiring to go around since you can see it within two hours!. This is a great museum which exhibits the collection of Calouste Gulbenkian enhanced with additional items bought by the museum afterwards. Rich collection of oriental art as well as paintings! Paintings are remarkably beautiful (pieces from Rembrandt, Peter Paul Rubens, Gainsborough, Corot, Monet, Renoir etc).Although I am not a fan of Chinese art, I was FASCINATED by the pieces exhibited (beautiful vases and other objects). It is amazing the fact that museum exhibits a variety of ojects and is not focused only on one kind of art. There are from textiles to tiles, from domestic objects to statues, clothes, coins etc! Very important and unique collection by Rene Lalique (mainly jewellery) is also exhibited in a separate room. If you get an audio guide is very useful (at least the one in English language that I used provided short, to the point and not tiring long descriptions on the objects). After the visit you can rest and have coffee and sweets outside at the beautiful veranda of the museum cafeteria! The only thing I would maybe suggest is to enhance the objects for sale at the bookshop. There are mainly books and very few other little things. By selling more things would also bring more money to the foundation.I wouldn't hesitate to visit the museum for a second time! A must when in Lisbon in my opinion.
Great museum. Brilliant museum, loads to see, particularly liked the Lalique room. The Gardens are also beautiful.

Must see museum. There are many paintings of great artists : rembrandt, renoir, monet, mane, klee etc. really good collection !There are also artifacts from all of the world : egypt, greece, china, japan, turkey, armenia...
not to miss. This is the prize of Lisbon with 350 peices of the best art collection, spanning over several centuries. From Oriental, French, Eygptian art.The garden is also a must

Great collection. Very diverse collection. Don't miss the Rembrandt and the lacquer jewerly. The [english] audio guide was not very helpful, very short descriptions always leaving you wanting more information. Sometimes a second layer of information was available, but that was mostly 5 seconds longer containing one more random fact about an item.

Beautiful museum with some real treasures. This museum was a lot larger than we envisaged. It is split into sections devoted to different styles, eras, etc. Our favourite rooms were the first and last; the Egyptian art and the Lalique. These rooms alone make it a must see museum.

Nice size, good selection. This is a very nice sized museum with good pieces from a veriety of periods. We were impressed with the vision of the director and the choices. The Lalique room of jewelry and objects was fascinating.
Great space and interesting for almost everyone!. Even if you don't like museums this place will hold your interest. Much to see in a great space. Easy to get by Lisbon Metro.
rare East Asia items. As an East Asianist, this museum's nanban screens were on my must-see list, and I wasn't disappointed. It's a small facility, so you won't be overwhelmed.

Wonderful small museum. We visited this museum on a Sunday, and admission was free. The collection is beautifully presented, and the building is lovely and in a tranquil setting. This is a nicely sized museum - not overwhelming - two to three hours is plenty of time.

Jewel of an art museum. Our refuge on a rainy day, but worth the visit in any weather. The collection is not overwhelming, but rather a careful selection of global treasures in beautifully designed rooms set within a small park. Good cafeteria for a light meal.

Nice museum. It's a great museum, with a fantastic collection and the building itself is Art.
The modern art section is probably not the same level as the classic collection.
Great museum. Great and varied collection, just big (or small) enough! Loved the Lalique room! Stay away from the cafeteria.

Cool Collection from Armenian Gulbenkian. What a great art collection so interesting. I love that they have pictures of his house you can imagine how it looked in his home. The Turkish pottery and the Statues are really cool

Stunning. This is one of the best museums that we have seen, anywhere in the world. A stunning collection amassed by one wealthy individual - you could easily spend half a day here - an incredible value at 5 euros for admission. The items are beautifully laid out and presented and the audioguide is very helpful. The Lalique collection, although small, was a real stunner and a great way to end the visit. Get here by taking the metro on the blue line to Sao Sebastao stop - it's about a five minute walk to the museum unless you get lost in the maze of buildings which form part of the complex. There is another museum of modern art plus a conference hall before you get to the museum itself so it's easy to get lost but everyone was helpful with directions.
one of the great small museums of the world. Great coverage with choice selections covering 25 centuries. Pleasant atmosphere, easy to digest, good signage.

Amazing collection.. This is a well laid out museum and very easy to get to via metro. You take a walk through the centuries starting with Egypt, Roman and Greek, Muslim, Asian all the way to Lalique. I spent a good 3 or four hours enjoying the paintings and furniture displays. The museum documents how some of the pieces were showcased in Gulbenkian's home. Nice cafe where you can sit outside on ground floor.
A taste of the far east. Among with other interesting artifacts. You can find more information in a guidebook. Restaurant has Portuguese beer at low cost and a good selection of dishes.

5000 years in a delightful afternoon!. I thought Lisbon was always sunny (in my imagination!) so when it rained for the first few days of our visit, I found myself at the Gulbenkian Museum, recommended by Rick Steves as the best of Lisbon's 40 museums. I wasn't disappointed! Great value to see such a wonderful collection of priceless items! It was well laid out, spacious and inviting. The audio guide was good, but not necessary to enjoy the museum. Even without the rain, I'd highly recommend spending a couple hours there!

Although a rambling collection there are some fascinating things. As stated in other reviews best to go on a Sunday when it is free entrance. The collection itself is all in one or two big rooms, the only smaller room being for the jewellery at the end. The artefacts themselves range from old Greek coins, to a few things from an Egyptian tomb or two, a few large Persian rugs, Chinese vases, etc. There are a few examples of each but nothing on the scale of e.g. the British Museum in London. The link between the displays is rather tenuous. I expect this proves that the Portuguese plundering from other cultures was quite subdued compared to the other colonialists. The most interesting bits for me were the 18-19th century serving vessels made from silver and the jewellery at the end. There is English information which is better than museums in some other countries so at least you don't have to be a native to read some of the interesting facts .A plus was there is an art gallery near adjoining so you can do both. The restaurant downstairs is great though for salads and hot meals at a reasonable price. It was full around 2pm on a Sunday. All in all made a good Afternoon.
Gulbenkian is Great. This is the most interesting museum in Lisbon. I saw a wonderful temporary exhibit of great artworks related to the sea.

Not to be Missed. Easily reached my metro and the collections are wonderful. Amazing that one man could accumulate so much history in one home. Food at the cafeteria (that has an outdoor seating area) was better than many museums I have visited. Suggest at least two hours for a visit.
Museums, Gradens and Concert rooms. Near the place I leave. Its like a small paradise in center Lisbon. Very good museums. Very nice gardens. Great musical concert place.
Gulbenkiam Museum. Great artistic jewel located in wonderful park area. Easy to get to. Has many wonderful master pieces.

A Lisbon must see !. Wow, I visited the Gulbenkian museum today at the urging of a good friend, much to my delight. I'm not a museum type and I'd already been to a few in Portugal that confirmed my disinterest but this one is different. I was very impressed with this museum - both the collection and the grounds. Whether you're an avid museum goer or just like to take in the odd one here and there, go to the Gulbenkian. You won't regret it.
Exquisite collection. This is the single best collection of artefacts I've ever seen, with the exception of just the major museums like the Louvre, the V&A and British Museum.
Impresive collection. The private collection of Gulbenkian really had a broad varaity. Especially liked the Lalique room. Nice garden sorounding the museum and a small café.
Very good!. Not a big Museun, but the is a very good well keep "treasure" from one of the past Oil giant of the western world.

A must see! Don't miss it.. If you are ever Lisbon, you must make every effort to visit the the Gulbenkian Museum. It has a everything you can imagine and more from ceramics to silks, stone, glass, wood, paintings, furniture, it is all there in abundance. The sister museum of modern art is just a pleasant stroll through the garden away.

Unique museum reflecting the tastes of a discerning collector. The Gulbenkian is an unusual and rather exciting museum in that it reflects Calouste Gulbenkians tastes. Very impressive collection of Near East and Muslim artifacts as well as some European masterpieces .Don't miss it!

Unbelievable collection. Huge variety of collections. Paintings, statues, carpets, ceramics etc from all over the world collected from one business man! All seperate in different kind of rooms. A must see Museum!

Excellent collection of Eastern Decorative Arts .... which, for the most part outshine the western art that the Gulbenkian collection includes - particularly the very disappointing collection in the separate, but proximate, Museum of Modern Art. The accessibility, given that it is a modern building and the money that the Foundation Gulbenkian has at its disposal, is very poor for any wheelchair user or someone with restricted mobility. Staff were also disinterested/disengaged and the cafe facilities functional and uninspiring in terms of food and decor. But much of the early Middle and Far Eastern Art makes it very much worth the trip.
Good. Lovely pictures, porcelain, glass, furniture, textiles etc - just enough of each to for a lovely taste of culture
Great museum. Every thing is displayed well. Very interesting items from all over the world. The guide is helpful. Beautiful environment and views outside.

A well presented unique museum.. This museum of one man's collection of artifacts across a broad range of genres, is possibly one of the best we've seen in many years of travelling. In particular, the early Chinese ceramics, early Lalique, French impressionists paintings, numerous Gaudi paintings, early tapestry & velvet, Egyptian pharonic artifacts, left us quite aghast. It's free entry on Sunday's before 2pm, something we would have avoided if we would have known beforehand, too many viewers! although it got more comfortable as time went on. After we went through the museum, we had a lovely lunch in their cafe sitting outside in the lovely Lisbon autumn weather.

Loved the Gulbenkian - excellent collections; dreadful lunch!. Myself and my husband absolutely loved the Gulbenkian which catered to his taste for European portrait paintings (some huge names including Van Dijk, Rembrandt, Rubens) whilst also housing an amazing collection of Islamic and European ceramics which I love. The Louis XIV furniture was pretty awe inspiring too. We both enjoyed the whole roomful of enamelling of Rene Lalique and our philistine children just about coped as it is a small affair, so it is possible to get some level of immersion in an hour and a half! We'd probably have stayed for an hour longer if the children were not with us. I've mentioned what we saw as the highlights based on personal taste, but there are other collections too. The cafe was not so good. We were encouraged by my Rough Guide which suggested that it had good vegetarian options and also by the very long queue. The menu boasted a range of different cuisines but the food was not good. There were under-cooked roast potatoes and our three boys had various different pasta dishes, none of which were enjoyed, so the half hour of queuing was not worth it! We should have gone elsewhere to eat - there are several restaurants and cafes in the surrounding streets, or a quick metro ride takes you straight back into town.

Don't miss this excellent small museum. This was recommended by our tour guide and he was right . . . this is a fabulous and often overlooked small museum. It is the collection Caloutse Gulbenkian who spent 4 decades collecting according to his own tastes so it covers a wide range but only the best. Items span the classical, oriental European art and twentieth century. The pieces from Egypt all though small is size are wonderful (and frankly rivaling what we saw in the Cairo museum as far as quality!).If you go, be sure to notice that there are large black and white posters of Gulbenkian's Parisian home that show the pieces as he had them displayed. We were with a tour and many people failed to even look at the posters. A real mistake as they provide an extra depth and contest to his collection and should not be missed.

Gulbenkian Museum. Very interesting collection and the modern exciting, the park enchanting. Antique book exhibition with coulered pictures were beutiful. The Lalique room is amazing. This man must have been some extra, Mr five percent, he was born i Turkey and then lived i Paris and London. He gave all this collection to Lisbon and he has done a lot of other things for the people like schools, dentistcare for example.
great collection. a charming museum, some really fine pieces. the story of the Armenian who made this possible is as interesting as the museum itself.

Interesting eclectic art collection. We visited it courtesy trip advisor reviews and it was a revelation. What an impressive collection of art esp. paintings! Visit it on Sunday. When its free! Personally it jwas a great experience to see so many paintings by the 18-19th century masters whose names i had read about!

If you go to Lisbon, you must go to the Gulbenkian. In its 50th year, this institute is a cultural must. Classical music venue as well as art. A really good exhibition is now on until June 2013 called the Ages of the Sea, which is a really well curated exhibition of paintings linked to the sea, including Turner and Monet.

Outstanding eclectic collection and nice lunch. This is an amazing collection of one man, an oil magnate from Turkey who moved from Paris to Lisbon during WWII and then gave his collection to the city. He was a friend of Rene Lalique and has a unique assortment of Lalique items from the turn of the last century. He has a wonderful collection of items from the Middle East, rugs, ceramics, etc. as well as his Louis XIV furniture from his apartment in Paris. Also items from Egyot, Greece, China, and paintings from major European artists. Well worth a visit!
nice park. Gulbenkian has a nice park to spend a couple of hours on a piknik or just sunbathing, located in the metro stop "praca de espanha", has great accesses.

Amazing collection. This was a highlight of our trip. An amazing personal collection that is well presented. Admission was 50% off for seniors(2 Euros each), as it was at many of the places we visited in Portugal.
What an amazing collection, so diverse.. Loved the Parque das Nacoes with the beautiful Vasco da Gama Bridge, cable cars and brilliant shopping centre.

I feel shame. It was a wonderful experience overall. I felt shame that my country refused to give funds and premises to Mr. Gulbenkian, in his homeland for theis museum.The exhbit "Ages of the Sea" was wonderful. The permanent exhibit was impressive. I could not have fathomed a private individual could have posessed such treasures from ancient Egyptian gold sculptures to Ottoman Iznik artifacts ,Esfahan rugs and Rembrandt originals.The museum is very conveniently organized.Great pleasure to have been here.

Small museum, pretty good stuff. Apparently, Calouste Gulbenkian made his money in oil, bought a lot of art and decorative stuff, and built a museum in Lisbon to house it. He either had some very good advice or got very lucky, because he wound up with some significant art, especially French pieces from the first half of the 19th century and some nice Lalique glass. The Museu Calouste Gulbenkian is no Prado or Louvre, but it's well worth an afternoon. If you go on Sunday, it's free.

Art and culture ... in one place. This museum, library and bookstore, itself contains several permanent and temporary exhibitions, auditoriums for lectures and other cultural activities. Thanks to donations from patrons whose foundation is named, this museum stands out for its impressive collection of ancient art (Egyptian). No less important is the green space that surrounds it, a walled garden whose area is the highlight .... a leisure and culture ....

Not for light eaters, unexpected tastes. I can't complain about the service or the dishes. Staff were nice and friendly, I think it just isn't made for light eaters. When in the mood for a "light" dinner or lunch, many people opt for sushi but when you are referring to the menu on this restaurant this is simply not the case. One thing is for sure it was the most different "sushi" I ever had! Unexpected tastes!!

One of the Best. The Gulbenkian Museum in Lisbon is a masterpeice in every way. The museum itself is designed to showcase each invididual piece of art. It is not overwhelming in size, but pefect in beauty. TheLalique pieces of glass and jewelery are truely special.
A speculants art investment. Much wonderful art, but put there by a spurios history. Guess some, but not all, of the artists represented, prefer this presentations to oblivion or destruction.

Best Art Museum in the City. Peaceful park like setting around the museum. We were impressed with the old masters on display-especially the Rembrandts and other French impressionists. Great collection of items formerly owned by Gulbenkian at his Paris apartments. Very good cafeteria. I would go out of my way to eat there. They have their own orchestra and concert series.

GULBENKIAN. A breathtaking collection- each and every item a masterpiece, brilliantly displayed in a purpose-built and very beautiful building.Particular pleasures- Iranian silks, Van Dyck, Rembrandt and Rubens paintings, and superb Lalique glass and jewellery.Excellent shop, restaurant.

Fabulous museum. This is wonderfully compact and beautifully laid-out place. It has a bit of everything, showing international and Portuguese art & history. The museum is large enough to keep you entertained for a while, but small enough not to be overwhelmed. The area also has some nice local restaurants and parks to go on an after-lunch stroll.

A lovely visit. Beautiful and varied objects and styles. In every room, there are pictures of some of the objects as they were in the owner's home and I think it is a great idea to see these beautiful objects as they were in a home and not only in a museum. Great museum, not too big not too small.Good food in the cafeteria at extremely reasonable prices.
Nice museum with modest collection of broad range. A great way to look at a broad spectrum of art from a collection donated by a wealthy donor, this museum is a lovely one.

private collection now in museum. easy to get to-collection spanned bc through impressionist with tiles and rugs in between-a little of everything-most info signs also in english-nice cafe on premisedefinitely worth a look for art lovers

surprisingly good. Wonderful location in Belem, very good exhibitions with the art of Mr. 5% as Gulbenkian was called.. In walking distance of the monastery and the Torre de Belem, it is something that is definitely worth visiting, when visiting Lisbon
art. the northern renaissance art and architecture, as well as the grounds. Very reasonable prices as well.
boring. some interesting artifacts; most interesting that one man collected it all but otherwise not sure why everyone raves; only go on Sunday when its free

Great Museum and Great little Cafe on bottom floor.... It is free on Sunday afternoons..after 2PM. Wonderful museum with interesting history..Love to eat in the cafe on the bottom floor..great food at reasonable prices. Has wonderful park like grounds to explore too!
Spectacular collection!. An amazing collection of art and objects from antiquity to contemporary. An excellent value for the price of admission.

Exceptional collection. We thought we would spend an hour here but we arrived at 10am and left at 3pm. We did do lunch which was very good but the museum has an exceptional collection of various porcelain, furniture, art work including a couple of Rembrandt's and Lalique classwork. Worth a visit. Thin cost was 4 euros each.
Superb. Wonderful art of all forms & eras & on amazing grounds with wonderful vegetation, ponds & birds. The park is open to the public. We went twice in one trip.

Gulbenkian Museum Lisbon. Remarkable museum! We spent 2 full days in Lisbon and we not sure if we should spend our time at this museum but it was well worth thevisit. Exceptional collection of a wide range of art and objects from a private collection. Each piece was exquisite and extremely well displayed with notations in Portuguese and English.
