The collection is not overwhelming and manageable in a 2 hour visit. The building itself was well designed and a wonderful interaction with the landscape. This is a top notch international museum. This is a must if you are in Lisbon.

Lovely museum, not too big, something for everyone. We enjoyed our visit to this museum, as it was just the right size - you could see everything in about 2 hours, or skip your least favourite sections for a shorter visit. I particularly enjoyed the islamic pottery and the paintings, my friends loved the Chinese pottery. The small room of Lalique jewellery was fabulous. The art collection held an impressive number of works by famous artists, Turner, Sargeant, Burne-Jones, lots of early Manets and Corots, among others.The museum is spacious and cool and there are plenty of seats to rest on. The gardens are very nice too.Entry was 4 euros, and we rented audio guides for 4 euros but were disappointed in the commentary, which didn't tell us much extra about the exhibits.The cafeteria-style cafe was reasonable value.
Don't miss it !. Impressive museum for the building as well as the Gulbenkian collection.Beautiful garden which you can see through the huge windows as if it were just another work of art on display.

Do NOT miss this museum!. I was on a group tour to Spain and Portugal and opted out of a day trip to go to this museum. Am I glad I did! I am a museum junkie and have been to terrific places, but this is a little gem. It has a whole room devoted to Lalique, which was breathtaking. You'll find a beautiful Egyptian exhibit and wonderful ancient Greek coins. Then there's the Rembrandts, Rubens, Gainesboroughs . . . I could go on and on. I also had a very good lunch in the cafe.
Don't miss it. An amazing, eclectic collection of top-quality art from around the world. Not too large, and not a single thing in it that's not in some way remarkable. Definitely too good to miss.

Beautiful and uncrowded. We went the day we landed in Lisbon since it was within walking distance from our hotel. A great place to start a vacation. We were pleasantly surprised at the beautiful modern, well-lit, uncrowded museum. The collection spans the centuries. We ate lunch at the cafe and then took a taxi back to our hotel since it was all uphill.
Great museum.. Beautifully laid out exhibits. Places to sit throughout the museum. Gardens are worth a visit on their own.

A Lisboa Gem. Gulbenkian is a remarkable musuem with a blend of objects from various regions of the world covering a vast period. It has a whole spectrum of artifacts from the Orient on the one hand and various masterpeices form the nineteenth century European artists on the other. It's not as vast as the Metropolitan Musuem in New York and can be thoroughly covered in a couple of hours. The museum also has a garden that surrounds it, The garden also serves as the venue of outdoor concerts, exhibits etc. It's a delight to take a stroll in the garden.
Good museum. This was recommended by our guide and was great. It had a nice mix of items. It was a great place to look around leisurely for a few hours. The staff was friendly.

2 hours well spent. Nice collections of persian and chinese art, a few Rodin's - which I particularly enjoyed - and absolutely fabulous, must see Rene Lalique gallerry. I stared at every detail of every piece.. simply amazing.

wonderful art. We went on a Sunday when admission was free. The art was spectacular and having pictures of Gulbenkian's
mansion and the art when it was displayed there was very interesting. It also was not very crowded so we had time to really examine and admire the art. Certainly a worthwhile visit.
Wonderful private collection!. What a lovely museum with surrounding gardens! A visual feast but not so much as to be overpowering in a single visit. Very eclectic and appealing to diverse interests

A little gem. A fabulous eclectic mix of the finest things a very wealthy man could buy, a perfect way to spend a couple of hours, if you've only got half an hour go to drool over the Lalique jewellery.

If you are going to do just one indoor museum in Lisbon, consider this. Take your time to wander through the rooms with a wide range of art pieces from glass, tiles, rugs to paintings. Do make time to stroll through the gardens also.

More for the view than for the food. A very nice self service restaurant in a wonderful surrounding in the middle of the Calouste Gulbenkian park. Prices are a little bit excessive but it is a wonderful place to be.

beautiful location. Beautiful location for a museum. The gardens and cafe are worth a visit alone. It is located within a park. The entrance was a little tricky to find....we met some other tourists who were trying to find the entrance too!

Impressive. A gem of a museum with very fine collection of Asian and European art. I was most impressed by its Egyptian, Persian and other Middle Eastern pieces which were particulary fine and intricately crafted. It also has a dedicated Lalique room. Highly recommended.
Everyone needs to check out this GEM. An amazing collection of arts and antiquities from Calouste Gulbenkian. His incredible eye for the best is easily visible from his vast collection
Culture!. Nice paitings and frames, really beautiful garden! It doesn't take so long to visit it all... Go preferentially on a sunny day.

Respect. A museum that has a bit of everything. Some really valuable pieces, very impressive collection, especially when you think that this was all once a single person's possession. The building looks a bit threatening at first but, once inside, you really appreciate how good a ground it is for the works. An amazing garden!
diverse museum. Its intresting because it shows items from different cultures, well worth the visit. its not too big that you can visit in a couple of hours.

Magnificent museum. Exceedingly well laid out and easy to move through the various areas. The donor of the collection had a very eclectic taste but of high quality. The rest facilities were very good and the whole atmosphere was calm.
The collection is housed in a well laid out garden area and well worth a visit

A great size museum for kids. This collection is not huge, but it is very varied, so it's really accessible and enjoyable for children (or adults !) who are generally bored to tears in bigger museums.We particularly enjoyed the Chinese & Japanese statues, vases and prints as well as the French period furniture.The Gulbenkian is a short (10 min) bus ride away from the heart of the city centre, but very easy to access. It is rarely crowded and has a good cafe with very affordable prices and a nice terrace seating area.

Gulbenkian Museum is a must see. This museum is interesting, well-designed , and very user-friendly for English-speaking. We spent 2 hours visiting the inside of the museum and had lunch in the cafe with beautiful views of the gardens which you can visit if you have the time. A highlight.Enjoy.

Interesting and relaxing. I've been to this museum twice. The collections are really interesting and well presented. But the real great thing about it is the garden, so lovely, so beautifully designed, so well kept. And don't skip a drink or meal in the restaurant there; the view is relaxing.
Unique. Not to be missed if you visit Lisbon. A unique museum in as much the museum has been specifically built to house the exhibits. Really really nice.

Nature`s and art interaction. I saw lot of museums but this one has very specific interaction with nature.Yes, museum is not too big but feeling there was so unrealistic. Maybe the beginning is bit boring but paintings are so beautiful and give lot of pacification.If you have possibility just try to feel atmosphere of museum which beginning was private collection (it gives feeling of privacy).Shadows, water, fountains and ducks all together make network of calm joy and revitalization.

A gem. Lovely gardens surround stylish modern building in which are housed a wonderfully diverse range of interesting, historical art objects. Really worthwhile, especially on a Sunday morning when it is free. Remarkable.
Great little museum!. Nice museum that you can see in 2-3 hours - wiht a good selection of pictures, furnitures, porcelains. Free on Sundays!

The Best Fine Arts Museum in Portugal. The Calouste Gulbenkian Museum is Portugal's best fine arts museum. It has classical and Oriental art, European art, furniture, and a small section devoted to Rene Lalique.The museum allows one to take photos without flash, so I was able to take photos of all the pieces of art that I enjoy. I have a small notebook and write down the name of the art, the name of the artist, and the year it was created.I enjoyed the Chinese porcelain and the porcelain and tile from Iznik, Turkey. I spent two hours in the museum and enjoyed every moment there.

A fantastic collection. The place is a bit hard to find: apparently they believe that "everyone knows where they are." A better-organized pointer could have saved us an unnecessary half-mile trip round the rear fence.However, the weather was good, so we did not really suffer the extra walk too much. And what we found inside was a fair compensation. The collector - "Mr 5 per cent" as he was nicknamed - had both the money and the good taste for art. Well worth the symbolic 4-euro ticket price. Highly recommended. Photos permitted, just turn the flash off.

Superb museum. This is an amazing collection of furnishings, paintings and collected artefacts from several cultures - all put together by one man. What I particularly liked were the large B&W photographs of Calouste Gulbenkian's original Paris apartment showing the carpets, furniture, sculptures etc. as they had been used in is household - each photo being adjacent to tht actual items in the museum.It is almost too much to take in at one visit - I shall certainly revisit the next time I am in Lisbon. It is a worthy rival to the Burrell Collection in Glasgow. Well worth the entrance money.

great museum. The gardens are a real oasis in the city and there are lots of exhibits both inside and out. The entry price was a little on the expensive side and the art gallery was having a new display installed so not a lot to see but overall would recommend.

A fine museum. This is a beautifully-designed, attractive museum set in a spacious and leafy park. The European paintings and furniture are well-displayed and fine examples of their genres up to the end of the 20c. The Chinese collection is particularly beautiful, but the highlight is the Lalique collection.As a whole the museum provides a tranquil and aesthetically gratifying experience.
A must to see. World renown. Gulbenkian museums of modern art, antiquities and planetarium not to mention the foundation is the center for cultural events and is known all around Europe

Great museum, great grounds. I love to wander in and outside of this museum, which is set in a huge leafy park. The permanent collection is wonderful, with art and artifacts from all over the world. I would say it is worth a couple of visits to really absorb it all. And living in Lisbon, I love to go back for the temporary exhibits whenever they change. On nice days, the amphitheater is a great place to hang out, and on summer evenings they sometimes have concerts there.Really a great artistic center in Lisbon, and worth checking out if you are a tourist of a resident!

Great experience. This museum is certainly worth a visit. Free on Sundays (when we went). All kinds of artifacts from all over the world. Also a separate modern at building, if that's your thing! Great little cafeteria too!

Great museum, especially on Sunday when it is free!. Free on Sundays' Great collection of Middle Eastern tapestries, especially velvet. Museum has a nice garden worth walking through as your time permits.
Nice Museum. I spent a couple of hours here nice small collection to see and the cafe serves some good lunches at a good price.

Overated Museum. Worth visiting but on a Sunday when all Museums are free before 2pm, otherwise around 7.5Euros each. I had high expectations after reading the reviews and we were expected a larger collection of items and I wouldn't rush back. When compared to the British Museum, Istanbul Archaeology Museum or the Museum of Egyptian Antiquities the collection here was minute! The items on display we spread out over a large area. I enjoyed the Rene Lalique collection as it was very beautiful.

Very interesting and well laid out. Enjoyed our visit. Spectacularly varied set of objects. Amazing to think one man collected them in a single lifetime. Needs more than one day. The cafe is also worth visiting for good food at reasonable prices.
Great museum and park, good exhibitions. Two great jazz conserts in the evening, interesting exhibitions - I used most time in the modern art exhibition.
Really interesting visit. Everything from Ming vases to Turner painting and even a Mary Cassat and Renoir. Modern building and fairly easy to get around not too long. Pleasant afternoon visit.
A very nice museum. This is a place worth visiting, either for the museum itself - General art and modern art museums - and the gardens where they are located.

Great spot to relax. This gallery and the surrounding park is an excellent place to see and spend some time. The park and gardens were a great spot to wander, very peaceful and a nice break from the city.

Peaceful with nice Cafe. The museum is a great space and when we went, really great exhibition. The thing my boyfriend and I loved the most though was the cafe - kind of an old school cafeteria vibe with traditional lunches. We discovered there Avocado Mousse which neither of us had heard of before. Totally delicious. Outside the museum is a really peaceful park to walk through and have some quite moments.

Modest, but excellent. This is not a gigantic museum, but what it has is superb. You need not plan a large amount of time to see it, but it is worth the stop. Plus, there's an excellent cafe in the lower level with indoor and outdoor seating.
A different experience. interesting displays also new exhibits each time we visited. Well worth a visit to thi amazing place

A beautiful museum. Enjoyed the museum. The extreme wealth this man must have had to have collected all of these pieces. Very lucky for Portugal to be able to share it with the public. The staff are not very nice but you're not there to see them!

Compact but Superb. This is a fascinating collection of antiquities, paintings textiles, sculpture, jewellery etc. It's not a large enough collection to be overwhelming and you should be able to see it all and appreciate Gulbenkian's varied and refined taste.It is housed in a modern complex and set in a beautiful park. Admission charges are reasonable at 4 Euros. This is a MUST SEE collection! The "old masters", Impressionists and Lalique alone are worth it.

Beautiful Collection. This museum has a beautiful collection of art spanning 5000 years. This museum is so well laid out with breathtaking works of art in every room. Of special interest are the pictures of these art treasures as they were in Gulbenkian;'s apartment in Paris. The audio guide was of great assistance. The commentary is short and to the point on each piece or room featured. It is a wonderful way to spend an afternoon or morning.
unknown but place to be!. a great museum with a nice restaurant and terrace - marvellous collection: a must see! very close to the Sana Reno hotel

A pleasurable few hours. I visited the museum on a Saturday after strolling around the grounds with its water features, sunny glades and wildfowl residents and even so, it was far from crowded. Some fascinating exhibits, but for me the highlight were the Roman medals, made from solid gold and crafted with the utmost skill to reveal 3D details of heroes and Roman myth. If you like history, fine art and splendor, then be sure to pay a visit.

A rich museum deserving your visit. Calouste Gulbenkian decided to adopt Portugal as his second country where he has been so warmly treated. The best way he found to thank was to create one of the best museums in Lisbon - there you can find permanent collections, and temporary ones, inside a lightly building, but you'll also be surprised by several statues while strolling in the garden
Great Museum. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Although the collection spans 5000 years, it only displays a few select and exquisite works from each era. No museum overload here.

Excellent experience. we visited this wonderful museum for free - on Sunday mornings many of Lisbon's museums are free.It's wonderful being able to get so close to the exhibits - being so close to Pre Raphaelite paintings was incredible.The diversity of the exhibits is very good too.The layout and design is simple and modern but gives a clean look allowing the exhibits to speak for themselves.The cafe is excellent too - well worth a visit

A Wonderful Museum Experience. This museum is great to visit! It is the perfect size and was not crowded with pushy tourists. I really enjoyed the simple layout. Though it lacks major masterpieces, there is a lot of art worth seeing, and the highlight is Lalique collection.

Unmissable even for those who are not museum buffs. A beautifully designed museum situated in well landscaped grounds that shows off select displays from ancient Egypt and the Orient as well as some great works of post-16th century European art to good effect. Some of the gaudy French baroque furniture from the 17th and 18th centuries are missable but on the whole this was the best museum we visited in Lisbon and even on a Sunday when entrance was free it was not so crowded that you couldn't appreciate the art.

Amazing personal art collection, loved the tile displays. Visited this museum due to it's great reviews. It is a tiny bit tricky to find the entrance, but just follow the people. The collection is impressive and the way the pieces are displayed are amazing. The tile is inlaid in the wall which was really cool. The museum has photos of the artwork in the collector's home which made the collection come to life. Great museum, and not so much artwork that you get tired of reading all the plaques! Like most spots in Lisbon, it's closed on Monday!

A great museum set in a beautiful park. Don't forget to wonder around the park with its lakes, aquatic birds, picnic benches, etc: many people were picnicking when I went and it was such a lovely day that I sat and read there for a couple of hours after visiting the Museum (really an art gallery), where I was most impressed by the Islamic Art. The displays are spacious and hugely varied, and it is easy to follow your tastes.
Interesting range of contents. From ancient Greek urns to impressionist paintings, this is one of these heterogenous collections that is not too big but has a bit of everything for everyone.

great variety. the variety of the exhibition as its the bes of everything from Egyptian and Roman right through to art deco jewelwery, simply stunning. Good value food at the cafe in the gardens underneath, much nicer inside the building than its outside

A Connoisseur's delight. A wonderful collection of choice objects,paintings and an incredible collection of Lalique's jewellery, all in a beautiful building which merges into the garden that in turn merges into the building. For lovers of art , architecture and landscape architecture, this is a must.

No much publicity made in Lisbon and so Wealthy!. Take your time to go to this museum, there are splendid things to visit. The story of Calouste Gulbenkian and so many others are beautiful. And you will find more about Egypt and te other permanent part of the museum. Modern Art. Park is nice and quite, you can easily wander and go afterwards to the big mall at 250 miles from there.
Amazing Collection of Art. This museum was unbelievable! We had a little trouble finding it, but well worth the search. To see one man's collection was astounding! Be sure to read his story.....

Do it!. Fabulous! But plan to have time to wander out and take a breather in the gardens, lunch, and head back in. Also go to the Modern Art adjoining for a modern perspective. Be prepared to spend for entry and maybe audio. Consider - will you be back soon?Tip- from the train station, go downhill. For a world famous attraction, there is little signage.
a good impressions. of serveral peoples, culturs and artsdivers collections from ancient period, islamic art, medieval objectsnice settings, pleasant haven in the city

Well worth the visit. This museum is world class! The quality of the pieces as well as the presentation makes this well worth a visit. It has been said that this is the best art museum on Iberia, and I do believe this.

One of my favorite museums anywhere. I have a affinity for museums that reflect the collector’s personal taste, and this is one of the best. ( A similar personal favorite is the deMenil Museum in my hometown of Houston). Items in the Gulbenkian are perfectly displayed and lit with English & Portuguese explanations. The modern building also takes advantage of the park like setting with occasional windows looking out onto the grounds. The permanent displays are interspersed with placards showing how the items were originally displayed in Gulbenkian’s home in Paris before he exiled to Lisbon. The museum reflects Gulbenkian’s collecting tastes, rather than professional curators, such as rooms of French furniture & table silver that could have been at Versaillles and a room of paintings of Venice by Guiladi. You can quickly walk through the museum in a hour, or take your time to linger over the perfect treasures.

Wonderful. On the outside this does not look like and interesting place, but once inside and having paid our 8 Euros (4 Euros - half price for seniors) for the 3 galleries we were not disappointed. Recommended time for the antiquest gallery is approx 1 hour, we spent 2 and a half and had to rush back to the car park as our time had run out. We totally missed the art galleries which was a shame if it was of similar quality to what we had seen. Fascinating exhibits, all well labled in english as well as portugese.There is a small shop and a cafe but we did not eat here, too much like a works cafeteria.

A must see Museum. The Museum is part of the Foundation Calouste Gulbenkian, LisbonIs has two independent circles, one dedicated to Oriental and Classical Art, and the other concerning European Art ( Paintings and Sculptures). Many masters are represented, such as Manet, Degas, Monet, Rubens, Rembrandt, Fragonard, Robbia and many others...It not difficult to park, and it also very easy to go to due to the location of the park. There is a restaurant inside, but normally very crowded. In the vicinity, I recommend the restaurant " O Policia"

Fascinating collection in tranquil surrounds. A well-designed modern museum displaying old Asian, Egyptian, Greco-Roman art as well as objects from the Middle/ Far East, e.g. Persian tapestries, Chinese porcelain and Japanese paintings. There is also a large section devoted to European art, with an emphasis on French decorative arts. One room features Art Nouveau jewellery of René Lalique only. I also very much enjoyed the serene landscaped park in which the museum is located

Must see. One of the best museums I've ever been to. It was 4€ to get in, maybe 1.5 hours to see everything (it's not huge, but we were going thru quickly). The thing about it is since he was a private collector, he only bought the best of the best, nothing broken, nothing boring. We joked the rest of our vacation about whether or not other museum pieces would have passed muster with mr gulbenkian.It's located in the park, which itself is nice to walk around in.
If you only go to one museum!. Unbelievable to think this was a private collection! Diversified collection from several cultures.

Gulbenkian. One of the most interesting museums I have seen in Lisbon.Must see it if you like, Chineese art, French ,Dutch <italian painintings ,Lalique pieces,etc.It has also a cefeteria where you can eat at the smallest prices in Lisbon - closing at 5 pm

One of the best art museums I have seen. This is one of the best art museums I have been to. We enjoyed it because it had a variety of items (paintings, sculptures, vases, manuscripts) and covered from early Egyptian to Renaissance. We used the headphones, which gave about an 1-1/2 tour, which was perfect in length for us. I would highly recommend it.
Well worth a visit. It's not a very big museum, but its exhibits are first class and very well explained and organised. We were very impressed.

Amazing collection of art. We visited this museum and were very impressed by its collection. The sections we most liked were Persian ceramics and Chinese porcelain. Also the silver collection from French court and the jewel collection from Lalique are extraordinary. Never seen such a collection of finest exhibits of arts!

Superb museum.. The Gulbenkian does not have a large collection, but it is an excellent one. My favorite sections are the first ones, taking in Egyptian, Mesopotamian, Armenian art, etc. The Middle Eastern collections are followed by a Far Eastern collection, then European art. I would call the museum compact rather than small. The collections are first-rate. There are very nice gardens for strolling as well. Best of all, Sundays are free.

good collection - not a lot of detail. The collection was very extensive and eclectic and the gardens were beautiful. I wasn't as captivated by the modern art museum part, I would have passed on that probably...

Brilliant!. I hadn't read the reviews until now - but agree with all the positive comments from others. Am so pleased we took the time to walk there from Avenida- it's an absolutely brilliant museum - everything is beautifully displayed and especially enjoyable if you like textiles and art deco.

Gulbenkian Museum. It was free the day we went. It's next to a modern art gallery too. And in a nice garden-setting. We had the time, so it was worthwhile visiting (and given they were both free anyway). There are some interesting things in the museum, such as all the ancient coins. But if you're time-poor, don't worry about missing it. The Lisbon metro is pretty easy to use.

Hidden gem. An amazing collection of art, pottery, clothing, manuscripts, bibles, everything! And free entry on Sunday! Also a lovely cafe terrasse in wooded surroundings. All is modern concrete clothed in lush greenery.

Up Close and Personal. Very intimate collection of a gentleman of taste. Loved the less curated display but the obvious passionate that treads this collection together. Come up close and personal with some remarkable pieces - Rembrandt, Rubens, Houdon, Lalique and so unique Chinese and Japanese pieces !!

Excellent private collection. This not so well-known museum is a testimony to impeccable taste of Calouste Sarkis Gulbenkian. Believe me, it is a true jewel. Gulbenkian's motto was "Only the best", and almost every exhibit is a masterpiece.

Lovely museum - hidden by landscaping, so difficulty to find!. Our timing resulted in having lunch at the museum - a very nice little cafe with tasty luncheon choices. The museum is world class - think Monet, Renoir, Rembrandt, wonderful ceramics and carpets, and Lalique jewellery!

If you are an art lover, a visit to this remarkable collection of art will be worth the trip to Lisbon!. The collection includes beautiful Middle Eastern tapestries, carpets and ceramics, magnificent French and English furniture, Japanese and Chinese art, and a magnificent collection of Lalique jewelry. There is also a lovely cafeteria with outdoor seating.

An eclectic but fascinating collection. With easy access by Metro and close to the only department store in Lisbon, El Cortes Ingleses this is a must see. The artifacts ranging from beautiful potery from pre history, paintings by the great masters of the 18th and 19th century and furniture from the 19th and early 20th century, are beautifully layed out in an amazing building. The building alone deserves your visit. Also worth visiting is the self serve restaurant in the basement. The hot food is limited in choice but is fresh and delicious as are the salads. The option to eat outside on a expansive deck in beautiful surroundings just adds to the pleasure of the visit.

Amazing collection. I would say skip the modern wing, it wasnt at all special. But once you get to the gulbenkian proper youll have to see everything. They really have something for everyone. Amazing displays of ancient artifacts from many different cultures. Then the collection of European paintings is one of the best in the world. Plenty of great Dutch painters and some Italian and English as well. Also there are many Rodin sculptures sprinkled around the rooms if you get bored. Super sweet

Do que melhor temos em Portugal /one of the best things in Portugal. One of the best things we have in Portugal: cultural, spacious, pleasurable, attractive, architecture, gardens. It deserves several visits!

The marketing does not do it justice. We had medium expectations when we arrived at the Gulbenkian museum. The self service restaurant (which was great value) did not visually impress so our initial feeling remained. However, once we began enjoying the collections we were quite taken. This is a real must-see, especially the paintings (Rembrandts, Renoirs, Monets etc) which just hang there, with what appeared to be minimum security. The museum is also free admission on Sundays, which came as a pleasant surprise although the entrance fee is definitely worth it. Compared to queing for hours to get a small glimpse of the Mona Lisa or similar, this is a really accessible way to get close to some fantastic art pieces.
Interesting Museum. Good selection of different types of collected items including furniture paintings and middle east art. Well worth a visit and good value.

Not my favourite but.... I went visiting Gulbenkian Museum during one of the hottest days in Lisbon, cause during our first visit in January we had not enough time to dedicate to this place.The permanent exhibition offers a wide collection coming from the founder's home in Paris (he left France in 1942 during WWII cause Portugal was neutral).In my opinion, the best part of this collection is the one dedicated to the islamic art and the small but precious Lalique collection.Other parts, if you already went visiting Musée d'Orsay or other major museums around Europe and the world, is not really impressive. There's also a pleasant garden where to have lunch or just a coffée.In any case, worth a visit if you're staying in Lisbon more than 3 days.

Fabulous exhibits - Gulbenkian museum. Breathtaking Lalique exhibit, gorgeous art and furniture as well. Some of the pieces dated back over 4000 years ago - breathtaking and awe-inspiring. Hard to believe one man could acquire all of that in one lifetime
Brill. Well set out, easy to find and you can always walk - we did.
A wonderful collection. This museum has the most wonderful antiques from the East.
good cafeteria. Be sure to stop by for a good cafeteria meal while exploring this amazing museum.
Great place. Wonderful garden, a huge and great collection. We liked it very much.
Lalique, carpets, furniture paintings and more!. Although I enjoyed viewing the collection, I found the antique French furniture to be especially lovely.
Great garden. is a fantastic place to walk, an oasis of tranquility in the city center and always with very good exposure
Diverse. The exhibits are quite varied, invariably of high quality and displayed in an uncrowded fashion. I particularly enjoyed the paintings and Lalique sections.

Lovely surprise!. Having been to Lisbon several times and seen most of the other famous sights, we figured we'd go check it out. We went on a Sunday for free admission. The collection is amazing and extensive ( I did question how some of the articles were acquired!) from all over the world.The grounds are also lovely and well looked after. I don't know if it was becuase the weather was hot and sunny but many people were out reading/relaxing. There is also a nice cafe.
Perhaps the best private collection in the world. Difficult to say what was best: the amazing quality of each piece, the variety, the setting, the collector himself and his history.

Almost missed the best part. Our taxi driver dropped us off in front of the modern art building. After touring the exhibits, we did not understand what was so great about it. After walking around the beautiful grounds, we finally figured out that there was a totally separate building with a fabulous collection of paintings, tiles, furniture, and Lalique jewelry. Don't miss it.

Very good collection!. This is not the largest museum, but I was positively surprised with the collection. I don't think any of the artists I learned about at school were missing. They even had some awesome Turner paintings. I can surely recommend spending a few hours over there!
fab collection. Not a large museum but such an exquisite collection. A 5 - 10 minute walk from the metro in a small park this is a really interesting place to spend an afternoon

Awe inspiring amazing gorgeous collection of Lalique. Amazing interesting fabulous collection of Art Jewelery by Rene Lalique is awe inspiring. The collection of art and treasure from around the world is over the top and very extensive. This man had an amazing eye and lots of money to back up his wants. We thoroughly enjoyed our afternoon spent at this world class museum and would recommend it highly.

Sublime. A lovely, modern building set in beautiful gardens houses a fantastic art collection. The Gulbenkian was built specifically to house the private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian, so the architecture doesn't overwhelm the art. The collection itself is eclectic and spans cultures, centuries and styles. It's a superb collection that can be viewed easily in a few hours. The Lalique pieces are exceptional and not to be missed.Minimalist signage in Portuguese and English. Closed on Monday, free on Sunday. An easy 6E taxi ride from the city center.

SUPERBE !!!. A wonderful museum, a good modern building in a beautiful park, ABSOLUTELY to visit. From old Egyptian Art, to Mesopotamia, carpets from Persia, ceramic from Turkey, porcelain from China, old wooden furniture to paintings (Monet, Manet, Renoir but also many older ones) and sculpture (even three from Rodin!) you'll see culture from many centuries and only the finest examples !
Lovely varied collection. Well worth a visit and at EU 7.50 to get in, it won't break the budget. The museum is set in wonderful gardens (no charge) with waterfalls and birds and picnic areas.
went again the next day - a real gem. difficult to find - do take metro, buses leave long walk

chill zone. Loved the park around it, you easily forget you are in the middle of a really busy city and you just feel at ease and really relaxed there. Plus the museum itself is good too...and the bookstore is amazing.
Spectacular collection. Not huge but a fine collecton of many types of art materials.

Very interesting - go on a Sunday. Very interesting museum, with exhibits from different eras and countries. Definitely worth a visit, especially on one of those rare dreary, rainy days in Lisbon when I went. I got there at about 11:00 a.m. on Sunday, and the museum (like others on Sunday before 2:00 p.m.) was free admission. Definitely worth the visit. The cafeteria is rather tasty and was quite crowded when I visited. A nice way to spend a lazy day in Lisbon.
Something for everyone. We went for the Lallique glass but were fascinated but the variety that one person could accumulate. His life story only went part of the way to explain his vast interests.

Nothing but the best and beautiful. Calouste Gulbenkian contributed his vast collection of art to Portugal in gratitude for her safe passage during World War II. What a gift to Portugal and the world. The collection is housed in a well designed building amid spectacular gardens of exotic plants. The art is representative of items from around the world and throughout time. A great tour through art history, with nothing but the best on view.
Little gem.. Not on main beaten track but defo worth visit. What an amazing collection of treasures.
Interesting. A good couple of hours spent looking at the treasures collected by this very wealthy benefactor. Some beautiful art works. Sunday gives free entry.
Fantastic personal collection very well displayed. Not only are the items ancient, they are exquisitely beautiful. The collector had superb taste (as well as a very large fortune)

Fabulous collection. The collection of art pieces from the Middle East is out of this world: their quality exceeds what you see in NYC's Metropolitan Museum. There are also some lovely early Renaissance European paintings, and finally I would recommend his collection of 18th century French furniture (Louis XIV-XVI) - he has some beautiful pieces - plus a most unusual collection of early colonial furniture from India. His collection of French Impressionists is not large but of excellent quality. And of course you do not want to miss the Lalique collection, nor the statue of Diana which he bought and brought over from the Heritage Museum. The main museum building, specially built to house this collection, is quite handsome and sits in a lovely park. The adjacent modern art museum, while not as interesting (or as attractive a building) houses a very interesting collection of Portuguese Modernist paintings, along with Russian counterparts. If you are an art lover, just seeing this museum is enough reason to travel to Lisbon.

World class museum. Beautiful furniture and paintings.
Also fantastic tapestries and egyptian collection.
Great museum and beautiful garden. This was an amazing discovery. The venue, the exhibits, the services - all outstanding.

A COMPACT DISPLAY OF GREAT ART. Great art in pleasant compact surroundings.
Not over whelming.

One of the finest private museums in the eorld. Set in spectacular grounds this Museum is simply great. The collection is full of beautiful pieces from Greece, Islam and Persia, China and Europe. Obviously his taste was "conservative" (esp the paintings which do not include Immpressionists or Post-Impressionists) but there is a great Turner. The exhibitions are well-lit and titled in English. The cafe is very good, the bookshop has quality merchandise. Also there is a short walk to the Modern Art Museum through the gardens.
Small museum based on a private collection.. Reasonably priced museum with some interesting pieces. Worth a visit.

Unbelievable depth for a private collection. Easy access from the subway (don't go into the modern art museum by mistake like I did). Pieces are exquisite and representative of all eras from ancient Egypt and Rome thru the 1950's.

A purpose-built museum which is a must for art lovers. The Gulbenkian was built purposely to house the private collection of Calouste Gulbenkian, which means that the rooms flow well, with pieces housed in an environment that shows them off at their best. Signage (in Portuguese and English) is clear and there are audio guides available for people who want more contextual information, or information in other languages. We spent a couple of hours in the main museum, then had a nice walk through a pretty park to the nearby Centre for Modern Art, which has some famous and less famous pieces, as well as a fantastic (and hence very busy with locals) cafeteria - the large portions and good value prices mean it's worth the queue!

A real gem at the heart of the city. At Sundays the entrance is free. What I like the most is the Lalique collection. This museum has an enormeous Garden and lake, a Good Cafeteria for a tea and a nice museum shop. In the summer, they have jazz concerts at night. really nice
Free on Sundays!. A good collection well set out and displayed. Worth the €4 but it's free on Sundays - added bonus.

A real gem. Huge range of fine and decorative arts from many different cultures and periods, but with the personal connection to Calouste Gulbenkian indicated through, for example, photos of how he displayed it in his house in Paris beforethe Second World War. Wonderful spacious and light modernist building set in gardens to display it. Labelling minimalist so one had to appreciate the art purely for its aesthetic qualities unless one hired the audio guide or bought the guide book for more historical and contextual information

Amazing. An ugly building, very much of its time but a treasure house of wonderful things. I had no previous knowledge of this museum but name almost any type of treasure and it's here. A whole room of Lalique! Egyptian treasures. Gainsborough, Renoir, Turner. Chinese jade and porcelain, Rodin sculptures, illuminated manuscripts, all beautifully displayed in galleries designed to house them. Worth the trip to Lisbon just for this.

Great museum!. First off...this is not the Louvre, Prado or Hermitage. It is the private collection that one individual amassed throughout his lifetime. When you look at it from that point of view, it is truly amazing. The museum was only a 5 minute walk from our hotel and we went the morning we were leaving Lisbon. We did not know that the museum is free on Sunday mornings and yet there were not that many people there when we arrived. This allowed me to stand a foot from a Rembrandt and not have anyone else in the room. Everything was wonderful. Was it the largest collection of each type of art? No. Was each piece wonderful in its own way? Definitely yes. And the Lalique exhibit is worth the admission price alone.

Great art collection!. This beautiful modernist building surrounded by a big garden is one of the places you can't miss if you're visiting Lisbon. Inside the building you'll find a great art collection. There's Rembrandt's portrait of an Old Man and Alexander the Great, Renoir's portrait of Madame Claude Monet, Rubens' Portrait of Helene Fourment and other works by Monet, Ghirlandaio, and Van Dyck among others. More highlights include Houdon's Diana sculpture, François-Thomas Germain silver once used by Catherine the Great, and a unique collection of René Lalique jewelry. Next to the museum is the Modern Art Centre with a collection of Portuguese and international art, including works by Paula Rego, Antony Gormley, and David Hockney. Closed on mondays free on sundays.

Excellent museum to visit, especially on a Sunday when admission is free. We went to the Calouste Gulbenkianmuseum on a Sunday afternoon and enjoyed the collection greatly (even more so because admission is free on Sunday :-) It was amazing to see all the treasures amassed by one individual (albeit one who owned 5% of some oil companies and was very wealthy because of that -- says that they called him the "5% man"). The collection seems to include everything from ancient coins, statues, furniture, paintings galore, ceramics, ancient books, and so on. You can see the essentials in an afternoon. To get to the museum, take the Blue line metro from Restauradores (near Rossio) to Sao Sebastiao station, then walk straight ahead to the next big road and turn left for a short walk to the museum.

Great museum with fantastic collection. What an eye for perfection did Calouste Gulbenkian have and how fortunate for Portugal that he left it to the state. Wonderful setting in the parks area and the collection thoughtfully showcased. Collection from Egyptian art, European paintings, Eastern art and furniture and more and finished with a beautiful collection of Rene Lalique jewellery. A great way to spend a couple of hours.

Great Collection of interesting art stuff.. This man collected a lot of great and beautiful things. It is neat to see them all displayed for the public to see. I also enjoyed the grounds around the museum.
great collection. Mid size museam w dynamite eclectic collection. Also interesting building and nice grounds
Gulbenkian, the man with the magic eye. A collector par excellence. There was almost nothing he collected that could not be called "the best". If you love art this is a must see in Lisbon.

Eclectic collection in a museum sitting beautifully in its space.. Really good collection and if you have a real feeling for other peoples things being a mirror to their soul this is one for you too. Garden not to be missed this modern exhibition space is beautifully sited and access for those with limited mobility very good.

The nicest museum in Lisbon. Despite visiting the museum on Sunday morning when it was free, there were very few people there. Even if you don't care much about art, you should probably still visit this museum. It represents a very broad spectrum of oriental, as well as European art and doesn't overwhelm you with the size of its collection. Every single item, be it a vase, a coin, or a painting is a marvel to look at.

Great museum. A collection of art masterpieces (from Ancient Egypt to Renoir, from China to Canaletto) based on personal taste. Interesting furniture, have a look at photo tha show how those picture, tapestries and so on were collocated in mr Gulbenkian home in Paris. A must see in Lisbon. Avoid cafeteria on Sundays, crowded and expensive.

Fabulous. The guide books rate this attraction as a 'must do' place to visit, but don't say just how awesome a place it is. The displays are fantastic, especially the Persian fabrics and pottery. If you have time to only visit one museum, make it this one.

Amazing private collection. Extended and good organized museum, with some great permanent and Egiptian and Persian exibition.
It gives you an idea of what the middle east ent to our Western civilisation, they were 3 to 4 centuries ahead of us at that time.

It's Gulbenian and thus unique. We have been to the Gulbenkian on every visit to Lisbon. Usually go on Sunday when it is free,and surprisingly nor crowded,(May/June time)We enjoy the eclectic and oft eccentric collection of artefacts coins,pottery,floor covering. furniture and 'decorations'. What one must appreciate is this is one man's personal art collection which was bequeathed to Lisbon on his death.(Portugal had given him a home and nationality)Bearing this in mind it is a pleasant way to spend half a day ....soak up the pleasure the collection must have given him, and envy his taste and culture compared with that of more modern multi-millionaires.
Good value. Lovely museum, good value for money. An excellent choice for half a day if it's raining. Museum cafe also good with lovely views of gardens.
An extensive and fantastic collection of Art. A bit off the beaten track but well worth the visit if you are interested in Art. An amazing individual collection. Grateful for the chance to visit
Dull. Small museum with many derivative works by artists of only local interest. Takes some time to get there from central Lisbon when using public transportation.

No art lover should miss the Gulbenkian. The Gulbenkian Museum is an extraordinary collection of a very rich man with an eye for fine art. As such, the collection is eclectic and visitors will no doubt identify items they prefer. Nevertheless, it is one of the world's finest private art collections. The Persian items were of particular interest to me, plus some magnificent paintings. If you don't like fine art, don't bother visiting. If you do, it is absolutely unmissable. Easy to reach by Metro.The building was constructed in the 1960s and is starting to be historic in its own right. Architecturally, I think it's one of the finest buildings of its era (although not everyone will share this view!) The gardens are magnificent and well worth a visit.
World Class!!. Great collections in a great building. Wonderful collection of Lalique jewelry, vases and other items.
Great Museum. Museum was very well layout and was an excellent overview of various styles of art. Highly recommend.

The best. The best all round museum I have been to, its not the biggest museum but everything is quality. To walk past a Monet, Rembrandt, Degas & Constable and enter a room full of oriental art dating c 2000 years old is sublime.

museum is way bigger than I expected. had never heard of this museum until doing research on places to visit in Lisbon ,the ancient Egyptian artifacts caught my attention but there is so much more in this museum,paintings by great artists, furniture ,carpets glassware ,we didnt have time to get around it all but a great place to visit
Excellent. Wonderfull place and collection. It´s very special, runway from tourist places and enjoy a pleasure morning.

Not very impressed. Perhaps I was expecting too much and was a bit disappointed. Except for the originals of Rembrandt, Monet and others, other exhibits were not awe-inspiring. For a One-Man collection museums, do see Salar Jung Museum in Hyderabad , India

Fantastic for art lovers. The museum itself is a "box" built in the 60-70's, however the collection is great. Chinese ceramics, ancient Coins, impressionist paintings and furniture were to me the most impressive parts.

Interesting. This was interesting, and worth a visit, particularly if u are interested in Maritime and the journeys of the Portuguese explorers. We used the cafe attached to the museum and although the service left a lot to be desired the food wasn't bad.The service in the shop was poor. We waited to be served only to have the assistant ignore us and serve the person behind us.

sublime. This museum holds the sublime collection of an aesthetes passion. His selection of Portugese and Chinese pottery is the best. The Lalique jewellery is gorgeous too.The cafe at the museum is very good value for museum food and the gardens are very pleasant to walk in.
ok but blah. you are a lalique fan you ll love it but thats about it. yes, islamic collection is awesome but there are better things to see in lisbon.
Interesting museum. Intersting to see what a person can collect during a lifetime having the opportunity, interest and the money.
Worth a visit. Well worth a visit. Only 4 euros to see a wide and varied slection of paintings, ceramics, furniture and more. Easy to reach by the metro.

What a brilliant place!. This is a collection of objets d'art of the very finest standard in a stylish purpose-built museum in a beautiful park in the wonderful city of Lisbon. No-one who visits Lisbon should fail to go there.

Frustrating collection, indifferent staff. I found this museum annoying - no marked entrance, no coherence to or context provided for the collection. And the staff bordered on hostile (it was after lunch and I swear one guard I queried was drunk). There are much better museums and better collections elsewhere.

Wonderful Collection!. A friend and I visited the Gulbenkian Museum this past March and were amazed at the wonderfull collection of artifacts! We thoroughly enjoyed our time there and would definitely go back if we had the opportunity. It is a must-see for any visitor to Lisbon!

Traditional and multicultural. Gulbenkian is a place to visit for its museum, its music room and its gardens in the back. It is a place that reminds me a lot of my childhood since I spent several weekend afternoons there.
A gem. Manageable size museam with a beautiful collection, especially the Egyptian and Middle Eastern rooms. Our children, ages 9 and 11, also really enjoyed this museum.

Modest scale. but really top class collection. Easy access, close to the Metro at Praca de Espana. A fantastic collection, particularly of Islamic and Far Eastern artefacts. Very impressive 18th century french furnishings if you like that grand style, and beautiful Lalique jewelry. Also some really classy European paintings from 15th century onwards, check out the detail on the museum website (I was particularly taken with "The Mirror of Venus by Sir Edward Burne-Jones). There really is something for every art lover.
Excellent range of exhibits. The exhibits were laid out in sections of historical eras. A most comprehensive and visually stunning range of artifacts. A must see.
Eclectic to say the least. How could one man collect and want this range of "stuff"?Some great but a lot that was just there

Eclectic Collection. My partner couldn't wait to show me this museum. He had seen it at least twice before. I thought he was exaggerating it's merits until I visited myself. The collector had a good eye when it came to collecting items for his home. There are close to 6 000 items under one roof. What impressed us is that he managed to find some of the best examples of each type of artifact or art piece. The museum houses Egyptian, Greco-Roman, Eastern Islamic artifacts along with paintings and furnishings. We also liked how the collection was displayed. Great use of space and light. Unlike most museums this one can be enjoyed because everything (for the most part) is on one level. You don't have museum feet when you are done touring it! The entrance fee is more than reasonable. I can't wait to see it again. (P.S. I also liked that the museum included graphic images from the collector's former home - these allowed you to see how he had showcased the items in his home before donating them to the museum after his death).

Brilliant!. The Gulbenkian's gardens welcome you with their beauty and lovely details, then you see the Gulbenkian Museum, where you have a whole exposition of egipcian, neoclassical and so many other types of art! There are paintings, carpets and sculpures, and the entrance is cheap, for a student it's about 4,5 euros! Open from tuesday to sunday, and worth seeing!
Gulbenkian a disappointment. Very limited exhibits, but nice space, good restaurant for snacks. But hardly worth the effort. Amazed its described as a major cultural site in Portugal

A Collection of Everything - Art to Coins to Carpets. Best "random" collection of art in Portugal. This tycoon basically collected everything from impressionist art to amazing furniture to coins from thousands of years ago. It is very interesting and is worth an hour or 2 of your time. Definitely worth stopping by.
Nice.. We ran through the museum in about 2 hours trying to see what we could before it closed. Interesting place.
The Lalique room was well worth visiting. Just to see his work in the flesh rather then on some TV programme. Also sketches of some of his work that was on display.
Huge collection of furniture, painting, dinner sets and a lot more. Nice to see so much Arabic, Egyptian an European art of the 16th-19th century collected by one man.

Amazing. This is a fantastic little museum that you can easily do in one morning or afternoon. It's an eclectic assortment of art and pieces ranging from the Far East to the Middle East, with some Europeans pieces as well. I went on a Sunday, so it was free to get in. They also provide an audio guide for 4 Euros. It was money well spent!
Real gem. You will see a wonderful collection! Don't miss this museum. It is a must!

Disappointed in the museum. This museum is hard to find since we didn't see any signs pointing us in any directions. It is located in a large park across from Lisbon's large el Cortes Ingles department store. To take the metro, you would need to get off at Sao Sebastiao. There are two wings of the museum covering pre 1500 and post 1500. There was furniture from French kings which was interesting. The Impressionist paintings were a huge disappointment. There was a Gainsborough, a few Monets, Manet, John Sargent Singer and Renoir. If you have been to museums in Paris, Madrid, New York, Minneapolis and other large cities in the U.S. you will be very disappointed. I really enjoy going to museums but to me this one was not worth the effort. There is a very small bookstore downstairs as well as a cafe.
Nice collection. From Ancient Asian (objects, textiles) to Modern Art.I really liked the Lalique collection.
Surprised how nice it was!. We planned to spend a short time here and ended up spending 1/2 a day.VERY impressed with European art, textiles, furniture and jewelry.
Loved the museum. Beautiful Gardens and a very nice museum, although different from over European museums . Worth a visit!

What a Story!. An amazing and eclectic collection by one man! The value of the art alone could probably solve Portugal's national debt and then as well there are Egyptian treasures, beautiful furniture, Persian rugs and carpets etc etc. Rather like the Frick in New York I guess everything was bought because it had a 'happy' feel to it (and Mr G liked and wanted it!). The building is well laid out and the exhibits easy to see. Go there!

GREAT COLLECTION. This museum is one of the best ones in Lisbon. It was built in 1960 and its collection ranges from tapestries, Persian rugs, Chinese porcelain to Rembrandt and Rubens.For art lovers it is possible to spend the whole afternoon without being bored. It is not as big and grandiose as other museums in Europe but it is exquisite. I was fascinated by the rugs, vases, and illustrated bibles from Armenia and surroundings.To get there, take the red or blue line to Sao Sebastiao (both red and blue) or Praca de Espanha (only blue line). The entrance costs 4 euros per person and it is worth every dime.
The legacy of armenian oil magnate Calouste Gulbenkian. Great gardens, Modern art museum and the ancient art museum. A must see in Lisbon

Not a mind-blowing experience. European part of the collection was closed for renovation, and the rest of the collection was not exactly mind-blowing.. We went on a Sunday, so it was free and quite crowded. There was also a fusion concert held in the lobby (classic/jazz), which was very nice. Gardens are lovely for a walk on a sunny afternoon.
Marvelous collection. It is facinating to see so much and so many different cultures collected by one man.

a must. A wonderful 2 hours activity.Full of interesting things-masterpieces from different countries and periods.Don-t miss the gardens.Go for a walk through eduardo park and to corte ingles for shopping-closeby

Nothing stands out. I know the Gulbenkian is listed as a must-see Lisbon museum, but it's very small with a very limited collection. If you're expecting something along the lines of the major museums in Paris, Rome, Florence or Madrid you'll be disappointed

Will go back next time. Fabulous collection of art. Fell in love with a 3000 year old assyrian "relieff(?)" of alabaster. Admission on Sunday was free. Unfortunately we went to late in the day and had not enough time. Will go back next time with more time to spare.
You can't miss it!. Fabulous collection of art, very well preserved and updated. Beautiful gardens.

Beautiful, wish there was more. Its amazing Mr Gulbenkian collected all these beautiful objects. I wish I could have seen them as he arranged them in his home. There are photos in the museum of the objects as they were in his Paris house, but it's not the same! The architecture of the building and the way the collection was displayed was also lovely. I was disappointed when the exhibition ended...I wanted to see more!
Excellent venue for art and pleasure. Great location and wonderful art collections and exhibitions.
worth the trip. Museum captured a little of everything and alot of what it intended. great morning and a lovely cafe for a snack. try to sit outside
pure art and world history!. Absolute a must for art loveres! the best privat collection in the world

Fabulous museum with great artifacts and paintings.. This place was incredible. Rich in history from Europe and China. The private collection is astounding. Reubens, Rodin, Rembrandt, Sargeant, Monet. Unbelievable gardens. Great cheap cafe with very good food cafeteria style.
Something for everyone. Excellent collection. A little something for everyone. A must see in Lisbon.
quality quality quality. loved the collection and quality of eastern and asian ceramics. not as large as the largest museums but compact on one floor a wonderful couple hours.
A great collection.. A beautiful art collection, liked it much better than the Arte Antiga Museum.

A Gem. Wonderful, varied collection includes paintings, textiles, ceramics, rugs, Oriental art, Islamic art. Beautifully curated and hung. don't miss the gardens, which are an attraction in thmselves--outdoor architecture!

Collection of a billionaire with taste. Like the Burrell Collection in my home town of Glasgow, the Gulbenkian reflects the enthusiasms of its collector, especially Islamic ceramics and fabrics (breathtaking), French painting (subtly chosen - my favourite is the wonderful Manet of a bot blowing bubbles) and 18c furniture and the work of Lalique. The cafe offers delicious food for lunch, the building is set in a beautiful park and it is an easy walk from the S Sebastiao Metro.
not bad for private collection. especially i would like to mention rare works of Rene Lalique in this museum.
Small but excellent. It's a very good collection, it's excellent in any part of the world
A private collector with taste. I could identify myself with much of the taste Gulbenkian had. It was amazing to see what he manged to collect over the years.
Beautiful art. Special Lalique exhibition to be seen, beautiful 19th century paintings, superb french and dutch paintings

One of my favorite museums. A visit to the Gulbenkian Museum is always a treat! I've never been there when it was super crowded and I enjoy that you can take your time and enjoy the exhibits and artwork that is there. No other museum that I have been to allows you to get so close to the artwork and enjoy the work of the masters. The grounds around the museum are well kept and a great place to sit and relax and enjoy the quiet, even though you are in the city.
the best in Lisbon. Great museum for classical and Oriental art. See also English and French painting and some jewlery from Lalique. 2 or 3 hors well spent.
Inspiring. Fantastic collection - setting not A's good A's Louisiana Copenhagen

Variety and the best museum I know for Islamic Art. We loved the variety of carpets and Islamic Art and this was followed by examples of European Art through each century. The amount of material was just right and the variety and contrast between the History and the art was perfect.

First Class, exquisite collection of Eastern and Western Art. Do not miss the Lalique room!. The Gulbenkian is a must even if you are in Lisbon for just a couple of days. This is a superb collection of the highest quality items from Egyptian items to Roman coins and jewelry, Persian rugs and textiles, and jaw-dropping beautiful Turkish ceramics from Iznik. There are Flemish panels, Italian Old Masters, a magnificent Rembrandt, a great Rubens, some Impressionist paintings, a sculpture by Rodin... Mr. Gulbenkian certainly had exquisite taste, and his collection of Art Nouveau designer Rene Lalique's vases and jewelry is unique, and worth going to the Museum just to see this room, at the end of the gallery just before the exit door. There is a good Museum shop and a cafeteria in the basement. Entry is free on Sundays.

Definitely my favorite attraction in Lisbon!. The Gulbenkian Foundation is a must-visit in Lisbon, for their most beautiful collection of art and antiques, their temporary exhibitions or their bookstore where titles from their own publishing house are sold.The collection ranges from antiques and decoration, to paintings and sculptures: some masterpieces can be found here and there. The bookstore is a must for book lovers, specially because the Foundation publishing house is known for its high quality editions and its careful selection and translation of ancient books.Not to be missed at all.

lovely collection - though don't kid yourself re: origins. Though the collection was acquired via dubious means in many instances (i.e. Egyptian elements were obviously purchased from grave robbers - and should be returned to the museum of Cairo, in my opinion - , art bought from Russian museums during the country's tragic Great Purge of the 1930s) we enjoyed a nice visit on the first Sunday of the month, when all museum entrances in Europe are customarily free of charge.The grounds are beautiful and take note of the reasonably-priced cafeteria on the bottom floor: we each had a delicious main course with wine for under 10 Euros, and sat out on a sunny patio surrounded by gardens.
Good Museum. Very nice museum : a variety of paintings, sculptures and objects from a lot of different time periods and regions
nice museum. It is a nice and quite large museum. You could spend some hours here.
very professional. Plenty of space, well laid out and all descriptions in English also

Ugly museum, great collection. On the outside, the museum looks like something from old Soviet times, it is really ugly, but don't be fooled by the looks, it's what's inside that matters :-)First of all, it's a huge collection, and it's only part of the original collection - second of all, only one man has collected all the items - one man! You have to see it and then be amazed, because almost every item is a gem.It is also impressive that the collection does not only contain paintings or tapestries or gold watches, but all kinds of art objects: paintings, vases, sculptures, furniture - you name it.What I remember the best were the Chinese vases, because normally I am not too fond of Chinese art, but these vases were simply beautiful, I could not help admire them - I would really like to go see them once again next time.
Wonderful museum and garden. Wonderful museum and garden in the middle of Lisbon. Don't missid if you like modern painting

Absolutely amazing!. Not surprised this museum is attraction #1 on Trip advisor. The collection is absolutely stunning and you can easily spend 2 or 3 hours there (we stayed there for 2 and the only reason we left is because it was closing time). Don't miss it!

Make sure you visit the garden. The Gulbenkian collection of art is beautiful and interesting, ranging from ancient Egypt to French art nouveau, with lots of oriental pieces. Though it's not like other great european collections, it's really really worth the visit. And don't forget to walk around the building to see some lovely gardens.

Excellent museum. I went recently to his museum for the Still Life exhibition (now finished, hope you had a chance to see it, it was fabulous). I had been a few times before, years ago, but I found that I appreciated it more this time.Expect some queuing for the big name itinerant exhibitions, as I guess is to be expected in all museums.Unbelievably clean toilets for a public attraction and it was quite busy.The museum is not huge but the collection is very interesting. Entry is cheap. Definitely worth spending a few hours here.The botanical gardens outside are wonderful and a welcome haven of peace in a city that doesn't have enough green spaces.

Great museum. We first went to the museum and on our next visit to Lisbon visited the concert hall. Both were excellent and well worth visiting, the museum has a small but broad collection and the concert programme varied.
interesting and worth seeing. Lots of interesting objects. Also visit garden that is around museum. It pays to see

A must for museum lovers. Gulbenkian, me being an amateur painter was great, it has the perfect mix between ancient art and objects and todays art. While we aere there there was an exhibition on 'still lives'. We'll be back.
Just a Museum. It has a good garden, but in the reality is just one more museum with not much to add.
A must. All items beautiful and well chosen - have been twice!

something for everyone. when in the beautiful city of Lisbon, this museum is a must see, it has housed within it´s walls what is billed as one man´s lifetime collection. but it is hard to imagine a thousand men collecting so much.As i say at the head of this review this museum truly has something for anyone even remotley interested in the evolving history of man and for me the paintings by the great impressionists were worth the visit alone.

Great Museum with Great Restaurant. Wow! We walked to the Gulbenkian many times to enjoy their cafeteria style restaurant. The food was very good and very reasonably priced. You can eat inside or outside to enjoy the view of the gardens. I highly recommend this eatery. Check the hours before you go as it closes earlier than you would expect. It is located downstairs in the museum; as you enter the museum, go past the ticket counter and down the stairs.
An excellent museum!. Surrounded by a beautiful park this museum houses great permanent collections as well as very interesting temporary exhibits.

Free on Sundays. Although not terribly expensive at 4 euros, it's still nice to visit a museum like Museu Calouste Gulbenkian for free. (which it is every Sunday)Since the contents of the museum are all from a single, private collection, I feel like you really get a unique assortment of paintings, furniture and artifacts. This wasn't a hand-picked selection for a particular exhibit or theme, it was the collected works of a man so rich he probably could have up and simply bought Portugal back in the day.To me, the early rooms are a miss - Egyptian artifacts and Persian rugs - but the later rooms with the furniture are simply outstanding. Specifically the clocks - the design and variety of ancient timepieces was at times stunning. To visualize them in their original setting, doubly so. The collection also boasts a few Monets, a Renoir and Degas. All excellent.If you're peckish, the downstairs cafeteria is actually quite good, and the prices are very cheap. Two people can eat a full lunch for 10-15 euros.

Great place to spend an hour or more. It is free. It is a weird collection. It has masterpieces. It has a story. I loved the ancient Egyptian art work and was surprised to find two Rembrandts. There are carpets, statues, furniture, every type of art. And the good thing of a free museum is that you can go in, enjoy what you like, ignore the rest, and go out again without feeling guilty. When I was there I saw a humongous queue for a temporary exhibition. This museum is popular, also with the locals.
Absolutely fantastic. Loved it all. This collection is probably the best I have ever seen. What a treat and totally unexpected. By taxi from Av. Liberty about E4-5. Worthy of a visit.

A stunning museum well worth visiting. The Gulbenkian was one of the highlights of our visit to Lisbon. A well organized museum which is easy to visit and appreciate its art. The audio tour is quite helpful and informative. We were lucky during our visit as the temporary exhibition was also very interesting. Allow at least 2 hours to visit.
loved the variety. so much to see ...saw treasures from around the world ..i loved the variety of what was on display ...if you are in Lisbon do visit

Small private museum. This is a museum containg the private art collection of one individual. There was a very varied collection of artwork, relics, antiques from various eras and cultures. The collection was interesting, just the right amount to not be overwhelming. The grounds were nice to walk through.
The Best Museum from a Private Collection. A wide range of art but within each an expression of fabulous taste by its original owner. My favorite museum experience in Portugal - by far.
Modern Art Museum Cofee Shop. Nice place to go when visiting de Museum or walk in the garden
Wonderful Museum. This is a fairly small museum, but has a wonderful collection of a variety of art.

A great museum!. It was a great pleasure to spend the better part of a day at this very fine museum. The wide variety of art pieces is astounding considering it is from a private collection. The presentation of the works and the atmosphere at the museum is very fine. We had a delightful lunch on the outside patio and walking around the substantial beautifully laidout grounds which surround the museum was a great delight. Don't miss visiting this highlight in Lisbon.

very intresting situated in a very beactiful area. I liked the exhibited pieces, from many countries and cultures, that helped me to learn new things. I also liked the restaurant (very good food and service). I was surprised that there was not entrance ticket because it was Sunday (I am travelling a lot, this has never happened to me before).
Great but small museum. We enjoyed this museum, took about 1 hour to visit.
Gem of a museum. There was a wide variety of exhibits for all tastes from Portugal and across the continent spanning many centuries. We spent several hours perusing the museum.

Colourful collection. Gulbenkian was a rich art and crafts collector, and many items in the museum are fine indeed. Somehow I felt like being in a kitsch shop. Museum park, shop and café make it a good destination, anyway.

Who knew what an amazing place this would be???. In Lisbon going to only one museum??? Make it this one! Eat in the cafe, then tour the artwork. An extraordinary collection. If only Istanbul has some of these pieces.......
Great!. great museum! Nice collection. Worth the visit also to the gardens.
Great museum!. Great place to visit if you only have time for a few museums. Amazing private collection! We visited it on sunday, therefore it was free.
A place you cannot miss. Great location, surrounded by natural gardens, modern art museum and great food in the cafeteria. Be prepared for a good a surprise
A must see in Lisbon. A great art museum in Lisbon, also with beautiful gardens

museum visit. not too overwhelming, great range of exhibits. I especially like seeing the photos of where Gulbenkian placed certain items in his Paris apartment. Lovely garden and excellent cafeteria.

Unexpected compact and impressive collection. We visited on a free Sunday morning and found this collection quite incredible . The variety and quality of rare objects showed what an obsessive collector Gulbenkian was. He had the resources to collect museum quality pieces from so many countries including China . ( foo dogs) We spent 2 -3 hours visiting all of the rooms including the temporary exhibit of early 1900's artists. Their timeline of fashion world events and art was illuminating. One of the best museums in the world.
very portuguese. very cosy building with an amazing cafe !!!!full of art and ok temporary exhibitions go there and visit the cafe !!!!
High quality collection. I thought the collection was well balanced, art, furniture, sculpture, carpets, coins. Well worth a visit
worth the visit. this museum has great collections, try to go on sunday coz all museums in lisboa is free and avoid mondays, most musems are closed
Do not miss gulbenkian. Fundação Calouste Gulbenkian is like an oasis in the middle of the town. Very good museum. Wonderful gardens with sculptures. Such a lovely place.
not to miss. A great collection of art and a magnificent place to end the evening with a concert of music.

This was the best museum we viisted on our trip fascinating & full of great art & history.. WEll worth a visit
This was the best museum we viisted on our trip fascinating & full of great art & history.
Interesting and unique!. Interesting museum, nice collection, manageable size to visit in one day.
Great small museum with impressive high end collection. Beautifull high end collection of Art works, but European and Islamic art.

Nice Museum. Worth visiting but it won't take your breath away.. I had expected more, having heard about this museum before we left for Lisbon. It is quite small, but very clean and well laid out. There is no getting lost at the Gulbenkian--it is basically one large "U"--you start at one end and finish at the other. There is a very satisfactory cafeteria on the lower level, along with a tiny gift shop.What is really quite astounding is that this was all one person's collection. Be advised that the special exhibits are not included in the entrance fee.
Fascinating. A random collection of objects but very engaging nontheless.

A wonderful place to spend an afternoon. The modern art exhibition which is based on the carnage in Columbia it was shocking but in a good way. The museum itself is fantastic with everything from early Egyptian artifacts to pieces from the various Chinese Dynasties a splendid collection of Le Leche(Probably not spelt correctly) glass. The art exhibition is also a rare treat. This is a must when in Lisbon
My favorite museum in Lisbon. This is one of the best places in Lisbon. Great museum and great garden to relax, just in the city center.

Fabulous collection. The Calouste Galbrenkian Museum in Lisbon contains the entire extensive and eclectic collection willed to the city of Lisbon by a grateful expatriate Armenian. Although not the largest or most unusual, it´s my favorite museum in Lisbon. Galbrenkian amassed an amazing collection, from Roman sculpture to Regency furniture, including a massive amount of ceramics, both European and Asian. The museum is contained on one floor, and is well-organized easy to negotiate. An interesting touch is the occasional photo of an object as it was displayed in Galbrenkian´s house, although this seemed to be a temporary feature.
Definitely worth a look if you like art and history. Check it out for a good feel or art and object history.Good temporary exhibition on when I was there too.

Not too large. Sensible interpretation of what one individual collected. I just wish that I had had time to look at the 'in situ' exhibition, i.e. how the objets d'art had been displayed in Gulbenkian's Paris residence.

Surprisingly rich collection. Terrific find well outside the lower, touristed parts of town. Small but rich collection of paintings but the real highlights are probably the Middle Eastern and East Asian decorative arts.

Worth a half-day visit. The Gulbenkian collections of sculptures appear to be in perfect conditions, no broken nose or arms. Perhaps he is a perfectionist. Many pieces by famous artists such as Rembrandt and Impressionist artists. The current temporary exhibits on Four centuries of European Still-life Painting is well arranged and the paintings come from all over the world. Cezanne, van Gogh, Matisse, Courbet, Picasso, and many others are represented.

It's free on Sundays!!. We loved the variety in this museum created by Mr 5%!! I loved particularly the Persian rugs which were very old, yet similar to ones we love today, the pictures etc etc. A must!!

The old, the new and everything moving. You have a museum with fabulous antigues, you have a great museum off modern art. But you have also amazing concerts, surprising temporary exibitions, and a lot more.Since long time talking about Gulbenkian Foundation is talking about culture on the move.
Well presented collection. Not too big museum but with a collection that spans centuries and is well balanced.
Beautiful works of art.. If you are a museum lover, you must see the Gulbenkian. Great works of art and an interesting spot.

Great Concert Venue and Int. Exhibition. We went to a concert of Scarlatti (female conductor, resident orchestra) and 2 new works - in the audatorium -wonderful performance , great accoustics and reasonably priced tickets Still life exhibition we went to was also interesting (lots of key exponenets) and free (museum free day?). Shop needs better merchandising probably as do many.

Concise and perfect. Although the space could see some revamp, Gulbekian Museum is an excellent place to stop by.
