The collection is priceless with works of art from several periods of history and is at the same time not that big making it perfect to soak in. The museum contains remarkable sets of art from several periods of history, from far Egypt to Armenia, islamic, China and Others.In painting you can see paintings of artists such as Monet, Degas, Rubens, Monet, Van Dyke, Rembrandt or Turner.There is also a superb collection of jewelry by Lalique, certainly one of the best of the world of this artist.Around the museum there are nice gardens. The complex sets as well another museum dedicated to Modern Art.
Great Museum. We went because we were interested in seeing the Lalique jelwery collection.
Very interesting. Museum very eclectic. Good collection of Egyptian art, Middle Eastern and Chinese. Something of the French school. The gardens of the building are beautiful.

Nice. I am not really into museums but I decided to visit this one since it was within walking distance of my apartment and I did not regret it. It was quite interesting and I went on a Sunday which is free until 2:00pm so that was definitely an added bonus.

The best museum in Portugal and one of the best in the world. This museum should be in 'must to do' list of any one with an interest in art and culture who visits Lisbon. It has got one of the best displays and a very good composite collection that won't make a visitor bored.Free entry on Sundays
Interesting art collection. Great art well displayed , lovely gardens, outside amphitheatre with a diverse selection of music, also a modern art museum

One of the best and most important museum in Lisbon. You must go if you enjoy art, there is a permanent exhibition and a temporary one.The permanent exhibition galleries are distributed in chronological and geographical order to create two independent circuits: 1 - Oriental and Classical Art on display in the Egyptian, Greco-Roman, Mesopotamian, Eastern Islamic, Armenian and Far Eastern Art. 2- European Art : Art of the Book, Sculpture, Painting and the Decorative Arts particularly 18th century French art and the work of René Lalique. You can also visit the coffee shop/restaurant where you can read all morning and a beautiful garden and lake in the back.

Money CAN buy happiness!. I can see why the French fought to try to prevent pieces from leaving Paris! Wonderful, and astounding. What is particularly interesting are the photographs of pieces in his Paris apartment. You must go
What a collection. An awe inspiring collection. Best thing I likes was not so much the collection itself but the photos of his house in Paris where he lived with all these goodies
Worth a visit. Impressive art collection in an elegant building surrended by manicured gardens

Excellent varied collection. Visited here on my last day in Lisbon waiting for a late flight and whittled away hours in this museum. Each room is themed and generally starts with the oldest to newest collection. The Egyptian artefacts are spectacular and each room has something for everyone. A audio guide is a must to find out more (if your a history novice like me or want to find out more about the artefacts) although it feels a little odd leaving a drivers license behind while you go round the museum! The art collection features many excellent artists and famous ones like Monet, Picasso and Van Gogh. Cafeteria was well priced and had lots of variety if a bit busy! Facilities were clean and it is easy to reach on the metro system.

Great museum, especially for those with short attention spans. The museum is essentially a showcase for the person collection of Gulbenkian. I have a 1-2 hour attention span for museums (although I love them) and found this collection could easily be viewed in that time frame. The collection includes painting, sculpture, furniture and other great items. The very old and lovely clocks were all running, AND kept the right time! I thought this was a great museum. It's also easy to get to via the metro, although the instructions in Rick Steeves book (if that's your travel guide) are not really accurate.
Go on a Sunday - it's free. Excellent value on a Sunday - and not too crowded! One can only be amazed by the opulence of the Gulbenkian home in Paris where all these treasures once were

A Must See. The eclectic art collection, of course, is outstanding. We like the layout of the museum; it has a sort of route to follow, so we knew we wouldn't be missing anything. Wonderful art in a manageable museum!
Nice and not overwhelming museum. Most museums have too much to view, this one was nice with a good broad mix of exhibits.

Nice light museum. The museum had a nice selection of various art and historical value. Our teenagers get bored easily and my wife could stay in galleries all day this museum had enough to entertain them both. We had no problems taking pictures in the museum. There is a nice outdoor park beside the museum that was a nice resting place. I thought the morning we spent getting to the museum (needed to get directions since we were walking) then having a delicious lunch in the cafeteria was well worth the half day.

Nice museum - skippable on a short trip to Lisbon. 4.50 Euros with Lisboa card (10% discount off 5 Euro admission). Sao Sebastian Metro station. Took about 1 hour. Mandatory coat check (free). No photos.A very fine collection, not that large. Highlights were right at the end of the tour: last gallery room and Lalique collection. Also a large collection of Louis XIV furniture. Everything is very well-presented. However, it understandably pales in comparison to the Louvre, Prado or Met.This museum does not have much of a Portuguese flavour, and if that is what you seek and you don't have much time (< 3 days), skip this in favour of the old neighbourhoods (Alfama, Bairro Alto, Chiado, Baixa), Belem, and Sintra. A good rainy-day option, though.

Stunning Collection. This is one of my favorite museums anywhere. Small compared to many others, but that makes it less overwhelming and intimidating. It's possible to see just about everything in half a day without feeling as if you're missing anything. The displays are properly lit, and overall facility is very comfortable with plenty of places to sit and relax while viewing the most significant pieces. Don't miss it!
Breathtaking. Some of the exhibits took my breath away with their quality and beauty. Well displayed and uncrowded exhibits. The restaurant is good and reasonably priced.

Don't Miss. We were exhausted and didn't really want to visit this musuem, but I'm VERY glad we did. The collection (especially the Middle East and Persia) is amazing and the space itself is cool. Very modern. There is a large garden in the area that I'd reccomend taking some time to explore.
eclectic. fine examples of a mixture of all sorts Egyptian artifacts to impressionist paintings
A great museum. Wonderful collection beautifully presented. This was a real highlight of our trip and is not to be missed. Don't forget to ask for pensioner's rates if you're over 65!
Undiscovered Gem. Great permanent collection of art treasures, but also excellent changing exhibitions. Remember to visit both buildings in the gardens!
An amazing museum. A very good collection of Persian and Far Eastern art and artifacts

Fantastic!. What a gem of a museum!! The collections were varied and exquisit！ The Lalique collection was outstanding! I regret that we didn't allot enough time so we ended up rushing a bit at the end. I had wanted to purchase a book from their shop for the Lalique collection, if nothing else, but the shop closed 10 minutes before we exited.
incredible!!. there is nothing to dislike about this museum! You would love it
A real delight. Such and amazing collection and the concert hall was a bonus

Excellent & Well Presented Works of Art. We spent a delightful few hours here . The layout of the superb paintings and artefacts is excellent and informative and the Lalique room is truly stunning.Well worth a visit.
Cultural afternoon visit. Unique collection of antiques, art, tapestries etc. A pleasant 2-3 hrs out of the hot afternoon sun.

worth the visit and time. This museum does not have an extensive collection, but what they have is really excellent. The Moorish art (rugs, pottery, tiles, etc.) is outstanding. Everything comes from a private collection. Mr. Gulbenkian was Turkish, and he really knew the good stuff.

Wonderful!!. This museum has such good quality pieces that start years B.C. and go into current times. The most amazing thing to us was how perfect the pieces were-especially the porcelain and pottery items. We are used to seeing old pieces which are cracked or chipped due to age, but that was not the case here. Everything is well displayed and when we came to the end of the museum, we wished there was more to see. Grounds are also very nice. This is a "must see" and one of the highlights of our trip.
a peaceful wander through some great art. Set in nice garden, museum has some great art and artefacts. Not far from the tube. Only 4 Euros entrance fee. Definitely one to put on the list

If you find art gallaries relaxing - this is a perfect escape from downtown.. We came here for an afternoon after a recommendation from several locals who said this was their fave place in the city. The buildings are fabulous (inside it looks a bit Mad-Men-eque!) and the collections are brilliant. We did both the modern art and the classic stuff. Great value. Could have spent longer looking around. The Modern art collection was particularly good. So easy to get to. A short walk from the metro and a department store (le corte ingles?) which has a really nice supermarket. We did an afternoon here, before picking up some scrummy food to cook in a studio we rented. Simple and perfect. The grounds are also charming. Definitely come here if you like art. It's not to be missed.

Beautiful and Easily Done Museum. There were so many different things in this museum that there is definitely something for everyone. It is just a metro ride away and worth it. It is also easily seen in an hour or two. I am really glad that we visited.

Trip advisor report disappointed me. Went all they way searching with hope of seeiing great collection. After visiting china and Egyptian museums it is nothing. May be it is well maintained except for few things all of them looked not very old.

Great Museum - Shame About The Security!. I went into the normal museum part (not the modern art or temporary exhibits etc) and loved everything from the Egyptian mummy masks right up to the Persian mats!Nowhere near as big as the MoMA in NYC, but still a little gem worth checking out. I think I was in there for a couple of hours (at a slow pace). Do visit the onsite café, it's not badly priced and the portions are big.The only thing that annoyed me was the security. They were literally in every CORNER of the room. I can understand the need for security in a place like this, but it was just annoying to have them constantly follow you about and watch you like hawks. There's a small 'open plan' shop downstairs (probably a few square metres) and the guy was practically following me around there too! It annoyed me, so I left without buying anything (it was pricey anyway).I never saw this much security even in the MoMA. They're even scattered all over the gardens and in the entrances, watching you as you leave! As I say, I understand their need, but I don't like to be intimidated by them.

Outstanding collection. May be it was the most balanced museum for kids that i have ever visited - you have all art history, room after room. Exellent place to make your kids closer to the world culture. Wonderful park with pools and waterfalls.

Excellent museum - variety, presentation, information, scale... all good.. Fascinating collection with and interesting story behind it. Wide range of exhibits from Egypt, Greece, Rome up to much more recent times, art, furniture, glassware, ceramics... all sorts. All very well presented in an excellent museum space, not too big, not too small... pleasant cafe, great value for money, all in all one of the top discoveries of this trip. Highly recommended.

Two Museums and one Garden - Great Collection. I've visited the Gulbenkian Foundation more than once, and It's always great whenever I go there. First you have the Museum with Oriental and Classical Art, galleries of Egyptian Art, Greco-Roman, Mesopotamian, Eastern Islamic, Armenian, Far East and Renaissance. An amazing collection!After that you have the Modern Art Center, with more than 9000 artworks from XX and XXI center.You can also visit, for free, the garden of the Foundation. Beautiful, with a lake and very peaceful. Can't miss.

Worth a visit. The Gulbenkian is near the dept store El Corte Ingles
A lot of oriental and ancient artfacts.
Go Sunday when free
the museum is MUCH better than the art gallery. the museum part was fascinating and not too big. the art gallery was a little disappointing though the individual artist's exhibition wasnt bad.

" An outstanding collection". It has been a must do before I die, since 20 years. And that could because of that have been very disappoiting, but not the least, it was a fantastic collection. I had my 13 year old son with me and he was as impressed as I. Besides we also took tickets for 2 contemporain exhibitions that also told us something about what is going on in Potugiese culture right now, which where right down my ally. All in all fantastic. And as everywhere we went the staff was so nice. So here is also a salute for Potugiese people, you are so nice to visite.
Great. Fantastic place, great value for all the history it contains.

Beautiful art collection set in a pretty garden.. The Gulbenkian Museum is really very interesting for those who appreciate fine art. The building and interior are modern in design and the surrounding gardens are very attractive. Best to go on a Sunday morning when there is no charge for admission.

Superb. The Gulbenkian Museum is absolutely great. Though the museum is not very large, the collection is absolutely amazing. The relatively small scale of the museum is also one thing I like about it. In larger musea, like the British Museum or the Louvre, you feel a bit overwhelmed by all the art, and because of the large quantity over there, you're not able to appreciate the collection as much as you can in the Gulbenkian.There are works from the greatest painters in the world, as well as a very interesting historic collection ranging from ancient egypt to japan.Especially on hot summer days (but of course also in colder seasons), this museum offers a magnificent retreat from the heat.

Great Apperitive. Knowing most young people do not like the idea of visiting a Museum, I was confident we could beat the odds here. So it happened.Calouste Gulbenkian is an excelent top art museum, in small package. Renoir, Corot, Rubens, Monet, Manet, Degas... This in regart to paintings.Then comes other form of art as ancient books, fabrics, coins, jewels, far east, greece, rome, egypt, persia... Even the most "I don't care" teen will like something here. Not to mention those art lovers.Personnel is very kind and helpful as it is usual in Lisbon, and the surroundings are beautiful. We were on vacation so it was a tuesday and there was very few people, so we could enjoy each piece we wanted.Not remotely as big as the NYC Metropolitan or Louvre, It's a small jewel you will not regret to visit.

What a collection!!. This museum has everything that you think of when you think about what should a museum have. The collection is really great, the Gulbenkian man had a lot of money and it is luck that he was into art because now you can see all the beautiful and so diversified wonders of the art from all around the world. Pay attention for porculan and marvelous jewelry. The museum is worth every penny and hour spent.

Fantastic. A wide ranging collection of the best of everything, no rooms and rooms of the same stuff, just many small collections of quality. Even if you don't like traditional museums go to this one, you won't be disappointed.

Garden Garden. Gulbenkian has a great art collection and the temporary exposicions are usually very interstings. But my favorite thing of all is the garden. When exploring the garden you feel like you are no longer in the city. Is like a farytale with all litle spaces ans lakes ans steps. Is is not possible not to felt in love.

oh the art! oh the garden!. Amazing place!The gardens are beautiful and the art collection, the antique one, is absolutely mind blowing. It's one of the best places to visit in Lisbon if you love art whether if you like or don't like art. You should go there anyway because the place is very beautiful and as an amazing atmosphere. The cafeteria is a little expensive but for the place is worth it.Definitely, one of the best museums in the ciy!

"Only the best". "Only the best" was Mr Gulbenkian's main criteria. Its well seen in the fabulous eclectic collection on display. Not too mcuh to get you bored as some other museums around the world and all this in a nice modern building in a beautiful park.The foundation is the richest cultural foundation in Europe and it offers an extensive array of activities around the year.

Interesting Range of Exhibits. Free on Sundays. Spent over an hour in the musuem and on the grounds. There were a lot of interesting exhibits - paintings, sculptures, artifacts. The grounds were nice just to walk around.

modern facility with a modest sized collection of exquisite art. The museum is in the center of Lisbon and accessible by metro. There are two buildings. One modern w/ permanent and temporary exhibits that can be challenging to appreciate. The other building has classic very fine antiquities, vases, jewelry, from Old Kingdom Egypt, Mesopotamian, Armenian, India, some Japan and China vases, several fabulous Asian carpets (on the floor), and mostly French paintings (and furniture) up to Monet and Manet. Gainsborough's Little boy blue is there. A wall of Corots. The collection is spotty or focused but the quality is excellent. Cafeteria is OK but has a great glass wall to an outdoor patio. we spent a rewarding 3 hours there to see everything.

Wow!. This is the most stunning, eclectic collection of 'stuff' I've ever seen. The museum is small enough to do in a couple of hours and was the highlight of our trip to Lisbon. We got a bit lost finding it - being directed by helpful locals to the right place but past 2 other buildings which we assumed were what we were looking for.

best mus(t)e(e)um in town. If you like small but first class museums - you mustn't miss this one. Select pieces f rom Old Egyptian thru Christian medieval ivory pieces to a stupendous collection of ceramics from the Middle East ( anything similirar somewhere else?) , some French furniture ( not my taste) , a just as select collection of paintings incl. some vanDyck and Monets to be capped by a selction of Lalique beauties. Great attraction in Belem. A real treasure. A mixture of antiquities from Egypt, Greece, Persia, China and others. Paintings and other art are also featured. The on-premisis cafeteria was reasonably priced with good quality food.A special Cartier exibit was also an unexpected treat. A first rate facility.

Surprises at the Gulbenkian. Whoever has written up the standard description of the Gulbenkian Museum in most tourism guides, has omitted to mention two of the most stunning components of its collection. All guidebooks mention the basic collection: a non-European collection that features Egyptian, Middle Eastern and Asian pieces, which vary considerably in interest and quality, and a Western collection that is surprisingly good as it includes such artists as Turner, Manet, Monet, Degas, Frans Hals, and Gainsborough. However, to most visitors' surprise, because none of the guidebooks mention it -- this collection also contains two Preraphaelite paintings by the genius Burne-Jones: "The Mirror of Venus" (1875) and "The Bath of Venus". "The Mirror of Venus" is riveting, and drew more spell-bound viewers than almost any other painting the day I visited. The second show-topper that is only at times included in the museum's write-ups is the Lalique Gallery, which again, draws crowds. This is the finest collection of Lalique I have seen anywhere and the full-length mirror entwined by two serpents is a show-stopper.If you have been to the British Museum and the Louvre, I think you could comfortably miss visiting the Gulbenkian, unless you have a special fondness for Preraphaelite art (as I do), or such masters as Turner and Gainsborough, or Lalique, in which case you must not miss this museum. The museum building itself is first-rate, very modern with very nice clean lines and large windows overlooking a perfect green, park setting.Visit on a Sunday, when the museum, like most museums in Lisbon, plus any special exhibitions they might be showcasing, are free to all visitors.

Museu Calouste Gulbenkian and surrounding grounds--a gem. The Museu Calouste Gulbenkian is a gem--it's small, easily accessible, and surrounded by pretty, relaxing grounds. We started out in the park, then went to the museum.The park is very pretty and relaxing, great for taking a load off after a lot of walking. There's a small amphitheatre, a small pond with ducks, and some funny and interesting scuplture. The Corte Ingles department store is just down the street, which includes a full grocery store, so pick up some picnic supplies there and have a pleasant lunch in the park.The museum itself is just lovely--it runs the gamut from painting to tapestries to furniture to clocks, and it has contributions from many parts of the world, both ancient and modern. They're not uptight about letting visitors take photos, either (though of course it's polite not to use flash). It was smallish--better described as a large gallery than a museum, so very doable in a few hours.

It's Great - the Einstein exhibition is good: geometric mural by Almada?. This place is GREAT - the Einstein exhibition is extremely good.I'm intrigued by the geometric mural in the foyer - it is signed by Almada, but who is he/she?
Go there!. This is an incredible place, full of things of beauty. My favorites are the old European paintings - faces from the past looking right at you, coming to life.

All arts catered for .... The Gulbenkian Museum (Museu Calouste Gulbenkian) is about 5 metro stops north of Restauradores, in a large park. There are two separate museums about 5 minutes apart: the Gulbenkian collection and the Museum of Modern Art. Combined ticket is 5 euros. Teachers and students get in free. Some attendants ask for identification, others just give you a free ticket if you say 'teacher' or 'student'. The Gulbenkian Museum houses a diverse collection of objects ranging from scriptures and icons to oriental ceramics and western furniture and painting. An audio guide would have been useful. The restaurant is very good, with a nice open air terrace.
